People make mistakes, but they also make choices. Itâ€™s important to James, that difference. He does his best not to confuse the two.

Chapter 1

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

People make mistakes. Most of the time, James thinks, you should forgive them. If theyâ€™re sorry. If they mean it. He himself has made some questionable decisions in his life. Some missteps. Everyone is just trying their best.

People make mistakes.

But they also make choices. Itâ€™s important to him, that difference. He does his best not to confuse the two.

Â 

The night that Sirius shows up on Jamesâ€™s doorstep heâ€™s barely able to stand. He has his wand. Thatâ€™s all. Heâ€™s not even wearing shoes.

â€œDidnâ€™t have time,â€ he tells James, words slightly slurred. Sirius smiles when he says it, but the expression doesnâ€™t reach his eyesâ€”cracking at the corners of his mouth. Before that night, James had never fully understood what it meant to want someone dead. But he could have killed them. All of them. Anyone who had ever touched Sirius.

â€œBit predictable arenâ€™t they?â€ he finds himself saying as he slips a gentle arm around his friend and starts leading him inside.

â€œWhat, shoes you mean?â€

â€œWell yeah, everyone wears them donâ€™t they? Whereâ€™s the fucking spontaneity? I look down and I know exactly what Iâ€™m gonna get.â€

â€œShoes.â€

â€œExactly!â€

Siriusâ€™s smile is a bit more genuine this time, though James can feel him trembling under his hands.

â€œFucking fascists,â€ Sirius mutters, just as Jamesâ€™s mother comes down the stairs, wand lit, feet slippered.

â€œJames, whatâ€”oh,â€ she stops there, halfway down the steps, and for a moment something painful flickers across her face. But then itâ€™s gone. â€œSirius, love, itâ€™s good to see youâ€”James, the den please.â€

James nods, slowly walking himself and Sirius towards the sofa. Siriusâ€™s breath is laboured and every once and a while James feels him suppress a wince.

â€œSorry about just turning up,â€ he says, his voice strained as James lowers him onto the sofa.

â€œDonâ€™t be daft,â€ he sits beside him, hand still on his arm, unwilling to let him go.

â€œYouâ€™re always welcome, you know that,â€ Mrs. Potter comes into the room behind them, a cup of hot tea floating beside her. She levitates it gently onto the coffee table. â€œMilk, four sugars,â€ she says, making Sirius grin.

â€œYou remembered.â€

â€œHard to forget a bloody toothache in a mug,â€ that earns James a pointed stare from his mother but Sirius only laughs, head resting on the back of the sofa like he hasnâ€™t got the energy to hold it up.

â€œWhat can I say, I like â€˜em sweet,â€ he winks at James, who grins in return. Sirius would flirt with a lamppost if he was bored enough. Or scared. Sirius wraps charm around himself like armour.

Euphemia kneels in front of him, her hand reaching out to gently cup his cheek. Sirius is pale, even in the dark James can see that, can see the circles under his eyes and the blooming purple bruise on the side of his jaw. If her frown is anything to go by, James would guess his mother sees it too.

â€œIâ€™m going to cast a diagnostic spell love,â€ she says softly, thumb grazing his cheek. â€œIs that alright?â€ Thereâ€™s a pause, a slight tightening at the corners of Siriusâ€™s eyes, never one to relish letting people in. Eventually, he nods.

Euphemia takes a deep breath before pulling her hand away and beginning to cast silently. James can feel her magicâ€”warm and sweet, like cinnamon. Siriusâ€™s eyes flutter closed, arm going stiff under Jamesâ€™s hand so he gives it a squeeze. Iâ€™m here, he hopes it says. Iâ€™m here. Iâ€™m here. After a few seconds Sirius squeezes back.

Euphemiaâ€™s wand drops into her lap but she waits for Siriusâ€™s eyes to open before she speaks, teeth nervously biting into her lower lip.

â€œIâ€™m just going to mend your ribs and ankle, okay? There shouldnâ€™t be any lingering soreness, but if there is you let me know.â€

â€œWhat?â€ Jamesâ€™s stomach clenches. The rage, when it comes, is a wave so high he canâ€™t see over the top of it. He drowns in it. â€œYour ribs? They broke your fucking ribs?â€

â€œJames,â€ his mother chastises. But he canâ€™t. Itâ€™s too much. Itâ€™s too fucking much.

â€œIf it makes you feel better, I donâ€™t think theyâ€™re actually broken,â€ Sirius shifts his position and barely holds back a groan. â€œMore likeâ€¦slightly cracked. Isnâ€™t that right Effie?â€ He offers her a smile and she huffs out a breath in return.

â€œIâ€™m going to need you to hold still,â€ is all she says, he nods again. This time, when the spells are cast, Sirius's control slips, small grunts of pain forcing themselves out of his mouth as his bones knit themselves back together. James wants to scream.

â€œThere we go,â€ his mother says softly, pushing the fringe back off of Siriusâ€™s forehead. â€œAll done now.â€

Sirius nods, eyes closed again as he slowly sinks down onto the sofa. James moves so he can stretch out his legs.

â€œSorryâ€¦bit tiredâ€¦thanks though. Thought I was gonna have to go to Mungoâ€™s. Worried they wouldâ€¦comeâ€¦get me.â€

Even in the dark James can see his mother holding back tears. â€œNo,â€ she says weakly, â€œno oneâ€™s going to get you Sirius.â€

â€œMmm,â€ is all he replies, already half asleep.

The two Potters stand frozen for a moment, silent in their darkened home, brimming with feelings that ache.

â€œJames, will youâ€”â€œ

He cuts her off with a nod, going quickly to the cupboard in the hallway and getting the spare blankets and pillows.

â€œGo to sleep mum,â€ he says softly, as he comes back into the room. â€œIâ€™ll stay with him.â€ He drapes the blankets over Siriusâ€™s body, gently slipping a pillow under his head.

â€œYouâ€™re sure?â€ she asks.

James turns back to her, offering what he hopes is a reassuring smile. â€œYeah, â€˜course.â€ Itâ€™s not as though he's going to be able to sleep now anyway, and thereâ€™s no way in hell heâ€™s letting Sirius out of his sight.

She nods, eyes still on Sirius even as she pulls James close and kisses the top of his head.

â€œHey mum?â€ he catches her before she leaves the room, still whispering. â€œThanks,â€ he says lamely, causing his motherâ€™s brows to draw together. â€œThank you forâ€¦â€ he doesnâ€™t know how to put it into words, how to say how grateful he is to his parents for loving Sirius, for seeing how desperately he needs them to. Deserves for them to. James gestures vaguely at the sleeping boy on the sofa. â€œJust thanks.â€

â€œI love you,â€ she says after a brief pause, voice thin and far too sad for Jamesâ€™s liking.

â€œLove you too,â€ and then, almost in the same breath: â€œIâ€™m not going to let him go back there.â€ Because it needs to be said. Because he should have said it ages ago.

She nods slowly. â€œI know.â€

But he shakes his head. â€œNo, I mean, not just right now. Not just this summer. Iâ€™m never letting him go back there. To them.â€

â€œYes,â€ a sad sort of smile finds its way into the corner of her mouth. â€œI know.â€ And then her expression shifts, as though suddenly remembering something: â€œRegulus,â€ the name comes out as a breath.

James blinks, thrown by the sudden change in subject. â€œWhat about him?â€ he doesnâ€™t mean it to sound as cold as it does.

His mother runs a hand over her face, looking tired. â€œWe canâ€™t leave him thereâ€”Iâ€™ll talk to Albus, see if I canâ€”â€œ

â€œNo, mum,â€ James glances quickly down at Sirius to make sure heâ€™s still asleep. â€œRegulus isnâ€™t like Sirius. Heâ€™sâ€”I donâ€™t knowâ€”heâ€™s one of them.â€

â€œHeâ€™s a child James.â€

â€œPfft,â€ he knocks her words aside. â€œNot hardly, we're practically the same age.â€

She smiles a bit at that. â€œYes. Exactly.â€ James scowls.

â€œHe doesnâ€™t want to leave,â€ he presses on. â€œHe likes it there, likes all that pureblood garbage. Iâ€™m not having him in my houseâ€”not having him around Sirius.â€

She arches her brow. â€œOh, itâ€™s your house is it?â€

Jamesâ€™s cheeks flush but he doesnâ€™t backdown, arms crossing over his chest as he holds her gaze. â€œIâ€™m not having him near Sirius,â€ he repeats.

A few moments of tense silence pass before Euphemia rolls her eyes, letting out a long suffering sigh. â€œIâ€™m writing Albus in the morning.â€œ

â€œMumâ€”â€œ

Her hand snaps up to stop him, a clear warning sign. Mrs. Potter is not a woman you want to cross and Jamesâ€™s protest is effectively shoved back down his throat.

â€œI wonâ€™t leave a child in that household James, not if I can help it, so I donâ€™t really care what you think of him. Am I clear?â€

Grudgingly, James nods his head.

â€œExcellent. Goodnight then.â€

He doesnâ€™t reply, sulkily sliding down onto the floor, pressing his back into the sofa.

People make mistakes. But this? His friend showing up broken and shivering in the middle of the night? This is not a mistake. As far as James is concerned the Blacks have made a choice, Regulus included. And it is unforgivable.

Â 

Itâ€™s brilliant, having Sirius stay all summer. Not worrying about running out of time, not seeing that look in his eyes as the days count down. Sure, there are still moments when heâ€¦drifts. To places that James canâ€™t quite get to. But on the whole, itâ€™s better.

He speaks about what happened in bits and pieces, like he canâ€™t handle it all at once. First to Jamesâ€™s mum and dad and then, when they come, to Professor Dumbledore and Alastor Moody.

â€œThey told me to take the mark,â€ Sirius explains, always in the same dead voice. Just once more, they keep saying, just a few more details. â€œI told them to fuck off. You can imagine how well that went over.â€

James never pushes Sirius for more. He watches the adults around them take from Sirius without even realizing it, even his mum and dad, so focused on the bigger picture. The politics. The war. They never notice how their questions strip him bare. How little is holding Sirius togetherâ€”probably because he snarks his way through it, throwing out one-liners like itâ€™s his own personal one man show. Itâ€™s only James who notices how his hands shake. Or the muffliato charm he throws over his bedroom at night.

But mostlyâ€”mostly the summer is good. Bright and warmâ€”they play quidditch nearly everyday, twirling around one another in the yard, diving for snitches that arenâ€™t there just to see if the other will follow, tugging on broom ends and knocking bludgers about.

Dumbledore comes and goes and there is no more talk of Regulus. At least not that James hears. Heâ€™s glad. Thatâ€™s the last thing Sirius needs.

â€œYou will try to behave wonâ€™t you?â€ Euphemia asks, as they face her on platform 9 3/4, the train thrumming behind them.

â€œTry?â€ Sirius says lightly, grinning as Mrs. Potter places a kiss on the top of his head. â€œCertainly we can try.â€

â€œLove a good try, I do,â€ James agrees, as he receives his own kiss.

James scrunches his nose. â€œDonâ€™t know why, if anything you should pity me the amount of homework that woman gives out.â€œ

â€œJames,â€ his mother says pointedly.

â€œYes Jamie, that was terribly rude. Everyone knows she goes by feline.â€

â€œSirius!â€

James chortles. â€œCat on her bad days.â€

â€œKitty on her very bad days.â€

â€œSIRIUS.â€

â€œI mean it you two!â€ Euphemia calls after them, not sounding nearly as cross as she probably means to. â€œBehaveâ€”and be careful!â€

â€œKitty,â€ James is still muttering to himself as they push along the train in search of the others. It doesnâ€™t take them long to find them. It never does, even without the map. â€œThey were spur of the moment,â€ Sirius said, when James broached the topic. â€œJust right place right time, you know, if Iâ€™d thought about it for even a second Iâ€™d have told you.â€

Shockingly, this had not remotely satisfied Jamesâ€™s ego.

â€œIâ€™m worried about him,â€ Remus whispers, bringing James back to the present.

â€œI know.â€

Remusâ€™s cheeks go pink as he looks down, fiddling with his quill. â€œI feel like Iâ€™m flying a little blind here,â€ he says finally. â€œI know that something happened this summer. But I donâ€™tâ€”I mean he didnâ€™t just walk out of that house. And I know itâ€™s not really my businessâ€”â€œ

â€œSays who?â€

â€œListen, Moony,â€ he puts his arms down on the table, leaning closer to his friend, â€œweâ€™re a team, yeah?â€

â€œI swear to merlin if youâ€™re about to make a Quidditch reference.â€

â€œYou absolutely would.â€

Remusâ€™s eyes go wide. â€œNo, I wasnâ€™t trying toâ€”â€œ

But James waves a lazy hand, knocking his worries away. â€œI know Moons, I know. Iâ€™m just telling you so you understand that thereâ€™s not some secret club between the two of us.â€

Thereâ€™s an uncomfortable pause that James was not entirely prepared for.

â€œI mean,â€ Remus shrugs, â€œthere is a bit.â€

He knows theyâ€™re not supposed to, but those words sting, and James finds himself sitting back, running a frustrated hand through his hair.

â€œItâ€™s fine James,â€ Remus goes on, clearly trying to cover up how very not fine it is. â€œYouâ€™re allowed to have a best friend.â€

James scowls. â€œI have three best friends.â€

Remus arches a skeptical brow but James refuses to backdown. After a few minutes of staring one another down Remus breaks, shaking his head with a laugh. â€œJesus James, alright.â€

â€œI donâ€™t think thatâ€™s exactly what I said,â€ Remus huffs, but the little smile still in the corner of his mouth is enough to satisfy James.

â€œListen, Moons,â€ he starts again, tone more serious, â€œme and Sirius, weâ€™re similar, at least in the obvious waysâ€”the ways that everyone can spot. More than you and me or me and Pete, but that doesnâ€™t mean I love you any less, yeah?â€

Remus blinks at him, a look on his face that James canâ€™t quite read. â€œJames...â€ he says slowly, â€œare you...proposing?â€

â€œAbsolutely not.â€

â€œAh,â€ he clutches at his chest. â€œRemus, you wound me.â€

Remus rolls his eyes, picking up his quill again. â€œIâ€™m sure youâ€™ll live,â€ he hovers the point over his parchment but doesnâ€™t pressed down. And then: â€œthanks, for...saying all that,â€ his voice a little tight, â€œIâ€”itâ€™s appreciated.â€

James nods. â€œCourse.â€

â€œAnd Siriusâ€¦â€

James sighs. â€œSirius,â€ he scrubs at his face with his hands before dropping them back on the table. â€œI think we just have to, you know, keep an eye on him. Be there. When he needs us.â€

â€œReckon we can handle that.â€

â€œYeah, me too.â€

Thereâ€™s a beat of silence before they both turn reluctantly back to their homework. Well, James is reluctant, Remus seems perfectly happy. But then, the bastard has already finished his potions, and is very rudely refusing to let James copy.

â€œHey James?â€ Remus says after a few moments have passed.

His eyes flick up briefly but Remusâ€™s are still on the parchment in front of him.

â€œI love you too, just so you know.â€ The words are quiet and fast and all squished together and itâ€™s so very charming and so very Moony that Jamesâ€™s grin is almost too big for his face.

â€œIâ€™m thinking July.â€

â€œFor the wedding.â€

James cackles, ducking under the table as a quill is launched at his head.

Â 

The first time he sees Regulus after the train, James is sneaking down to the kitchenâ€™s under the invisibility cloak some time around midnight. Itâ€™s the third week of school and Siriusâ€™s stunt pulling has not in anyway diminished. James is worried itâ€™s starting to prematurely age Remus. The problem with Sirius is you have to let him spin out a bit, not too far, of course, but itâ€™s like his feelings are too big. Too big to speak or think, so he has to act.

James rounds a corner and nearly runs headlong into the person on the other side. Luckily, he catches himself in time, flattening out against the wall as a very purposeful looking Slytherin pushes past him. It takes a few moments for his brain to catch up, fitting the curly black hair and haughty expression into place. By the time he realizes who it is Regulus is already half-way up a flight of stairs, headed very much away from the Slytherin common room.

For a moment James is frozen. Unable to decide which is stronger: his hunger or his curiosity? Heâ€™s barely made a decision before heâ€™s taking the stairs two at a time, trying to close the gap between him and Regulus before he loses him.

The younger boy moves nothing like Siriusâ€”heâ€™s all rigid straight lines and perfect posture. It makes James want to trip him, the pretentious prick. If he hadnâ€™t been so preoccupied with the position of Regulusâ€™s shouldersâ€¦and armsâ€¦andâ€¦hips, he probably would have realized where they were headed a lot sooner. But itâ€™s not until Regulus is throwing open the doorâ€”with James close behindâ€”that he realizes theyâ€™ve climbed all the way up to the astronomy tower.

James leans against the outer wall, watching as Regulus walks towards the edge of the tower. In the summer, when it doesnâ€™t get quite so cold after the sun sets, this is where people come to snogâ€”and maybe a bit more if theyâ€™re feeling adventurous. But somehow James canâ€™t quite picture Regulus being the type for a quick hook-upâ€”he really is nothing like Sirius.

The other boy is leaning over the edge of the railing, eyes on the sky which is, admittedly, rather stunning at this time of night. All velvet black and sparkling stars. The moon is beginning to fill out, something James has learned to watch with wariness.

He keeps expecting someone to come through the door, surely this is some kind of rendezvous even if not of the sexy variety. But no. No one comes. The only thing that happens is Regulus pulls a telescope from his pocket, un-shrinking it with the wave of his wand and then peering at the sky. For a horrifying minute James wonders if heâ€™s just gone and got himself stuck up here watching Regulus do his astrology homework.

James pushes off the wall and steps closer, watching as Regulus spins a dozen different dials, adjusting the lenses. Whatever heâ€™s doing, itâ€™s practiced. Nothing about his fingers is unsure. Heâ€™s always thought of Regulus as being so much younger than them, even though thereâ€™s only a year between them. But heâ€™s grown over the summer, James noticed his height on the train but now he can see that his shoulders and chest have started to fill outâ€”his hair longer. Like Siriusâ€™s, except neater.

Eventually Regulusâ€™s hands stop moving. He stares through the telescope for a solid few minutes before sighing and straightening up, eyes still on the sky.

â€œSheâ€™s gotten worse you know,â€ the words heavy, â€œsince you left.â€

James jumps at the sound of his voice, surprised, and momentarily afraid that heâ€™s somehow let the invisibility cloak slip. But no, Regulus isnâ€™t looking at him, his eyes still staring straight ahead.

â€œDid you even think, for one second, about what would happen to me?â€ he laughs coldly, looking down for the first time and scuffing his shoe on the ground. â€œI donâ€™t know how to handle them anymore, I used to, but lately itâ€™sâ€¦fuck, lately I canâ€™t breathe.â€

His voice has gotten thick and James thinks thereâ€™s a chance he might actually be crying, but when Regulus looks up again his face is dry. He scrubs at it with his hands before letting out an exhausted sigh. His eyes get caught in the moonlight and the sight makes Jamesâ€™s breath catch in his chest. Thereâ€™s something overwhelming about them. He doesnâ€™t think heâ€™s ever seen Regulus look this full before. Normally heâ€™s a stiff cut-out of a person, parroting his parents, practically two dimensional. But not here, not tonight. Tonight he feels so big.

With another piercing looking through the telescope he waves his wand and the thing shrinks to the size of a keychain. James watches him slip it into his pocket, watches him go back into the castle, the distant noise of his footsteps audible even after the door closes.

He feels off kilter. The entire time heâ€™s known Regulus heâ€™s been a spoiled, spineless git, who treated Sirius like he was a disappointment. An embarrassment. But whatever just happenedâ€”and heâ€™s still not entirely clear on what just happenedâ€”it didnâ€™tâ€¦fit.

Heâ€™s still stewing over it fifteen minutes later when he walks through the portrait and into the Gryffindor common room, invisibility cloak in hand.

â€œOi!â€ he looks up and sees Sirius, Peter and Remus all waiting by the fire, everyone else clearly gone to bed. Sirius raises his brows and gestures emphatically at Jamesâ€™s visibly empty hands. â€œWhat the hell Prongs? Where are the snacks?â€

â€œSnacks?â€ but as soon as the word is out of his mouth it dawns on him why he left in the first place. â€œRightâ€”erâ€”sorry, Filch was about soâ€¦â€ he shrugs, before moving towards the staircase.

â€œFilch?â€ Sirius squawks indignantly behind him. â€œSince when has Filch ever stopped us from doing anything? You had the cloak for fuckâ€™s sake!â€

James doesnâ€™t bother replying, suddenly feeling incredibly tired as he jogs up to their dorm room. He doesnâ€™t put on pyjamas, just strips down to his pants and crawls under the covers, closing the bed curtains around him. He wants to sleep off whatever the hell this weird feeling is thatâ€™s sitting in the pit of his stomach. But despite his best efforts his mind keeps lingering on the memory of Regulusâ€™s faceâ€”those stupid fucking eyes. The last thing he hears before falling asleep is Regulusâ€™s voice in his head, whispering over and over again.

I canâ€™t breathe.

Chapter End Notes

I have been obsessed with this pairing since Jegulus week but I haven't found any longer fics with them (if you have them pls send me those recs!!) so I thought I'd give it shot!

Comments are always appreciated :)

Chapter 2

Chapter Summary

Remus is going through it in this one - I know, shocking, a new direction for this character, his life is usually so easy.

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

He never gets used to it. The full moon. It starts a week before - Remus goes to bed early, he gets headaches, backaches, loses his appetite - James hates it. Hates that thereâ€™s nothing he can do, and that everything he says just seems to make things worse. Remus canâ€™t stand being fussed over, or when they hover around him. James gets it. Sirius gets it lessâ€”which is ironic considering he can be such an antisocial prick when heâ€™s in a mood.

On the really bad moons, Remus canâ€™t get out of bed. On the better ones he drags himself through his classes. Those days are the most stressful if James is honest, because Remus is so sensitive. He winces at the light, the noise, at being touched, which sends Sirius into overprotective mode and means that James spends the whole day trying to keep the both of them in one piece.

â€œPadsâ€”Sirius! Come on mate, calm down,â€ James mutters, one arm wrapped around Siriusâ€™s middle as he drags him down the hall.

â€œIâ€™ll calm down when McAllen learns to WATCH WHERE THE FUCK HEâ€™S GOING!â€ Sirius shouts at the quickly retreating back of a Hufflepuff third year.

â€œMerlinâ€™s tits, you wanna try not making me go deaf at the tender age of fifteen?â€ James is still dragging Sirius along, Peter and Remus up ahead, having not stopped to witness the spectacle that was Black v. McAllen.

â€œPrick.â€

â€œAt least youâ€™re self-aware.â€

Sirius scowls at him. â€œI meant McAllen.â€

â€œI don't see why, he was just trying to walk down the hall.â€

â€œHe ran straight into Moony!â€

James rolls his eyes. â€œHe barely touched him, and itâ€™s not as though it was on purpose.â€

Sirius looks mutinous but when he speaks he isnâ€™t angry. Not exactly. â€œHe winced, Prongsâ€”heâ€”â€ but Siriusâ€™s voice drops off, unwilling or unable to finish that thought.

James finds his eyes trailing to the sandy blond head in front of them, â€œI know.â€

He doesnâ€™t bother pointing out that on days like today Remus winces if you breathe too hard near him. He really ought to stay in the dorm, but he never does. He has to be practically catatonic before heâ€™ll consider missing class.

â€œOh good,â€ the boy in question says dryly, as they catch up to him and Peter outside the common room, â€œheâ€™s stopped shouting.â€

The portrait swings open and the four of them tumble inside, Sirius looking sufficiently cowed.

â€œSorry Moony,â€ he mutters, hands in his pockets.

Remus looks over at him, a weak smile managing to pull at his mouth. â€œItâ€™s fineâ€”just, maybe try not to fight everyone who steps near me, yeah?â€

Sirius lets out a dismissive â€œpfftâ€ while simultaneously glaring at a group of second years who've dared to start walking in their direction. â€œIâ€™m serious you know,â€ Remus says, making a bee-line for his bed, more out of breath than he should be and with a sickly sweat covering his skin.

Siriusâ€™s eyes light up. â€œNo, Iâ€™m Siriâ€”â€œ

James has his wand in Siriusâ€™s face before he can finish his sentence. â€œI swear to Merlin, if you make that joke one more time I'm going to hex your eyebrows off.â€

Sirius chokes back a laugh, hands coming up in mock surrender. â€œDonâ€™t know why youâ€™re pointing that thing at me, Moonyâ€™s the one who started it,â€ he sends Remus a wink over Jamesâ€™s shoulder that earns him an unimpressed huff.

â€œI like him better than you,â€ James says simply, dropping his wand.

â€œPlease, you couldnâ€™t live without me.â€

James rolls his eyes, knocking his shoulder into Siriusâ€™s. â€œPrick.â€

â€œTwat,â€ Sirius knocks him right back.

It feels good, joking around after the day theyâ€™ve had. A break in the tension thatâ€™s been pulling at the four of them. Ready to snap. James exhales and feels his shoulders drop away from his neck.

â€œSorry Moony,â€ Sirius goes on jovially, â€œyou were saying something before Jamie so rudely interrupted us?â€

But Remus has seemingly stopped paying attention, sitting on his bed with his head in his hands, his whole body rigid.

â€œRemus?â€ there's new urgency in Sirius's voice as he steps forward, James also inching closer. Sometimes, on the day of the transformation, things can happen too soon. One bone breaking hours before the moon has risen. One organ beginning the shift when the rest of the body has yet to wake up. It's rare, but it happens, leading to frantic emergency Infirmary visits. The first time was the worst, but it never stops being scary.

â€œSorry,â€ slowly, Remus pulls his hands away from his face, and James thinks he hears Sirius let out a sigh of relief, â€œheadache.â€

James almost laughs at how inadequate that is, even just looking at Remus you can tell the word â€œheadacheâ€ doesnâ€™t cover it. Itâ€™s another few minutes before Remus actually manages to lift his eyes off the floor, looking directly at Sirius. â€œI donâ€™t need you to protect me.â€

Sirius blinks. â€œWhat?â€

â€œThatâ€™s what I was trying to sayâ€”before. That I mean it. Iâ€™m not someâ€¦invalid,â€ the last word comes out sharp. â€œI can handle myself.â€

A series of emotions flicker across Siriusâ€™s face so quickly that James canâ€™t catch any of them.

â€œI know that,â€ he says finally.

â€œDo you?â€ the words barely make it passed Remusâ€™s teeth.

Peter, who had been lying facedown on his bed, sits up at that, sending James a worried look across the room. This is not going anywhere good.

â€œYeah,â€ Sirius says, starting to sound irritated now. â€œOf course I do. But just because you can handle it, doesnâ€™t mean you should have to.â€

â€œSirius,â€ Remus sounds tired, passing a hand over his face. â€œIâ€”appreciate that. But I donâ€™t need a bloody bodyguard.â€

â€œHeâ€™s really not. You go more mental around the full moon than he does,â€ Peter says, before ducking to avoid the pillow Sirius chucks at his head.

James is grateful for the interruption, they're all strung too tightly for this conversation. And the last thing anyone needs is Remus and Sirius going at each other. It doesnâ€™t happen that often, but when it does itâ€™s fucking vicious.

â€œI need you to have some faith in me Sirius, alright?â€ Remusâ€™s voice has softened a little, the pair of them staring at one another so intensely James feels like maybe he should leave the room.

â€œSince when does Sirius need encouragement to be an idiot?â€

â€œOi!â€ Sirius shouts indignantly, causing Remus to roll his eyes.

â€œHey Moons?â€ James asks tentatively. â€œYou need anything? Food? Water? Pepperup?â€

Â 

Itâ€™s a rather uneventful evening, all things considered. They spend most of it in the common room, one of them sporadically going upstairs to check on Remus. They bring him a plate from dinner knowing he probably wonâ€™t be well enough to eat any of it.

â€œSince when is that a thing?â€

â€œSince when is what a thing?â€ he asks perplexed, Remus gestures with his chin and James follows his gaze to Sirius and Mary who seem to have decided that snogging one another in the middle of the common room is perfectly acceptable behaviour.

â€œHave they?â€ the tense tone of Remusâ€™s voice brings Jamesâ€™s attention back to him. He looks like heâ€™s in painâ€”lips pressed together, eyes tightâ€”but then, he is in pain, so thatâ€™s not really surprising. Still, James can't help but feel that something is wrong.

â€œYou okay Moony?â€

Remus blinks, eyes still across the room, it takes a few seconds before he seems able to tear them away, swallowing thickly before he speaks. â€œYeahâ€”yeah, just the full moon, you know?â€

â€œYeah,â€ Remus wraps the jumper heâ€™s wearing more tightly around himself. â€œBetter get going actually, sheâ€™ll give me hell if Iâ€™m late.â€

â€œIâ€™ll come with,â€ James says, getting to his feet.

â€œYou donâ€™t have toâ€”â€œ but James waves his words away, already walking towards the portrait, Remus trailing slightly behind.

They walk in silence, the hallways mostly empty, people either still in the great hall or tucked away in their dorms for the night. â€œI know you wonâ€™t.â€

Remus doesnâ€™t answer right away, doesnâ€™t answer for a long time actually, doesnâ€™t look at James either. When they slow in front of the infirmary doors James half expects him to just walk on through without another word.

â€œI hate this,â€ he whispers, he looks small in a way Remus almost never does. He isnâ€™t loud and out of control like James and Sirius, but heâ€™sâ€¦strong. â€œSometimes I just wish,â€ Remus goes on, closing his eyes as he breathes out, â€œthat I was someone else. Anyone else. Anything has to be better than this. Than me.â€

Jamesâ€™s insides twist, wrecked by the pain in Remusâ€™s voice. It takes him a while to get himself under control enough to speak. â€œI know this is going to make me sound like a selfish dick,â€ Remus laughs at that, eyes still closed. â€œBut personally, Iâ€™m so fucking glad youâ€™re you.â€

Thereâ€™s a moment of stillness in which James is almost positive heâ€™s said the wrong thing, but then Remus opens his eyes, and theyâ€™re watery but heâ€™s smiling again, even if itâ€™s only a little.

â€œThanks.â€

â€œOf course.â€

Â 

Thereâ€™s too much time before they have to leave for the shack and James is too twitchy to go back to the dormitory. He needs to do something. To move. â€œYouâ€™re pathetic you are.â€

â€œAwe look, I think heâ€™s going to cry. Are you gonna cry wittle baby?â€

â€œMerlin, your poor mother, stuck with two pansies for sons.â€

â€œPlaces to be? You? That can't be right. Oh wait, let me guess, you got a hot date with the Giant Squid?â€ James casts a wordless incarcarous at Mulciber who is instantly thrown to the ground as ropes snake around his arms and legs. James canâ€™t help grinningâ€”heâ€™s been practicing that one.

â€œFucking Potterâ€”â€œ

â€œExpelliarmus,â€ James catches Averyâ€™s wand as it flips through the air. He barely has time to blink in Snapeâ€™s direction before he hears the beginning of a Levicorpus. He dives to the side just as the spell fires, missing him by an inch and cracking the stone wall behind him.

James laughs, straightening up with two wands in his hands, Mulciber grunting on the floor. â€œCareful there Snivellus, wouldnâ€™t want our little prefect getting in trouble now, would we?â€

â€œYes mâ€™am,â€ Sirius gives her a salute, but the grin on his face feels forced.

â€œHey Remus,â€ Peter manages to sound casual as he pulls up a chair. James does the same on his other side while Sirius sits at the foot of the bed.

â€œGot all your favourites,â€ Sirius lowers the plate onto Remusâ€™s lap but he barely looks at it.

â€œNot hungry,â€ he mumbles, putting onto the bedside table. The three of them exchange a quick glance.

Remus only shakes his headâ€”the gesture is sharp, pointed. He turns to James. â€œWhat happened?â€

â€œJames.â€

â€œYour hands,â€ Remus is practically whispering now, eyes the size of Jamesâ€™s plate. â€œYour hands were covered in blood. So I need you to tell me what happened. I need you to tell me the truth. And I need you to tell me now.â€ There is no arguing with that tone of voice.

James nods, exhaling tightly. â€œYeah, okay Moony,â€ he puts his own breakfast aside, running a hand through his hairâ€”nervous tick. â€œListen, itâ€™s like Pete said. Youâ€”you got a bit angry.â€

Remus visibly swallows. â€œAngry,â€ he repeats. â€œYou said I didnâ€™t hurt you?â€

â€œYou didnâ€™t,â€ he canâ€™t think of any way to make this better. To keep Remus from bleeding over this. â€œYouâ€”itâ€”â€œ his eyes flick nervously to Sirius and then back. Thatâ€™s enough for Remus though. He should have known better.

â€œTo be fair, he does have a disadvantage,â€ James chimes in.

â€œHard to be afraid of a bloke once you know how he folds his pants.â€

Sirius barks so loud that James half expects him to turn back into Padfoot. â€œQuite right,â€ he wheezes.

â€œI hurt you?â€ Remusâ€™s voice cuts through the room like a sharp knife. All brevity sucked out of the air. The look of horror hasnâ€™t left his face, his eyes pleading.

â€œIâ€”â€œ but the words donâ€™t quite make it out of Remusâ€™s mouth, he opens it and closes it several times before giving up.

James can see the small hitches in his shoulders, like his breath is getting caught in his throat. It reminds him of the way he gets before his skin splits open and the wolf slides out.

â€œHey,â€ Sirius moves so that heâ€™s right in front of him, hands on his shoulders. â€œRemusâ€”Remus? Look at me okay? â€œYou alright?â€ Sirius asks eventually, breaking them all out of whatever trance theyâ€™d fallen into, hands still on Remusâ€™s shoulders.

â€œHey,â€ Sirius holds up one of his hands to stop him. â€œYou donâ€™t have to apologize. Really, I mean it, cross my heart and hope James dies.â€

â€œOi!â€

â€œOkay?â€

â€œBit of a prat, but other than that, yeah, tip-top,â€ James grins in a way that he hopes betrays none of the anxiety still swirling in his chest.

Sirius reaches over to swot his head, but Peter is too fast, snickering as he ducks out of the way.

â€œCanâ€™t argue with that,â€ Sirius says.

â€œIt is a very accurate assessment,â€ James agrees.

â€œExcellent,â€ Sirius beams, trying too hard. James hopes that Remus is too tired to notice, but he doubts it. â€œNow we can get back to breakfast!â€

â€œIâ€™m really notâ€”â€œ but the plate of food has already been levitated from the bedside table back to Remusâ€™s lap. He rolls his eyes but doesnâ€™t bother fighting it, picking rather unenthusiastically at a piece of toast.

The pause in conversation allows James to realize how tired he himself is, nearly choking on his eggs as he tries to swallow and yawn at the same time. Judging by the light coming in through the windows they havenâ€™t got much time before transfiguration and James thinks again about skipping.

â€œDo you reckon it was maybe because of our little tiff in the dorm room?â€ Sirius says suddenly, causing everyone to start.

He isnâ€™t looking at them, eyes very determinedly on his breakfast, tone very determinedly casual. James groans internally. He really wants to do this now? Now? They only just managed to get Remus to let up on himself.

â€œDo Iâ€”what?â€ Remus stutters, dropping the piece of bacon that had been on its way to his mouth.

â€œIâ€”Iâ€™m not mad at you Sirius,â€ Remus says finally, carefully.

Something flickers across Remusâ€™s face for just a second before he shuts it down. Heâ€™s good at that, bottling things up. â€œYeah,â€ Remus says slowly. â€œYeah maybe.â€

But thenâ€¦

â€œYou reckon?â€

It makes sense, James thinks pityingly, as he watches his friend turn back to his breakfast, unsure of how he didnâ€™t see it before. Of course, Remus was angry.

He fancies Mary.

Chapter End Notes

Hey-o! Thank you guys so much for the commented recs on the last chapter, it was very much appreciated!

I wish I was the type of person who could be like "This fic will update on __ day" but I would be lying to you all because I keep no schedules. But hopefully frequently, I have plans!

A lot happens in this chapter so I'd love to know what you think!

Chapter 3

Chapter Summary

James is just trying his best - an accurate summary of this whole fic if I'm being honest.

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

James feels like he knows what muggles mean when they say the word â€œmagic.â€ They donâ€™t mean spells or wands or cauldronsâ€”well, okay, yes, sometimes they do. James knows that, because itâ€™s how he feels when heâ€™s flying.

Magic.

The sun is only just rising above the horizon, and even in his leather playing gloves Jamesâ€™s hands are still half-frozen to his broom. The warm dawn light reaches across the Great Lake towards him like fingers, the air crisp and sweet the way it only gets in the fall.

â€œMother fucâ€”â€œ

Thatâ€™s it.

â€œOkay, first off, who said anything about giving up on Lily? I have not given up. Secondly, woo-ing energy?" James wrinkles his nose. "Really McKinnon?â€

James looks at her flatly. â€œOh sorry, you had a point?â€

She opens her mouth to speak when another voice cuts her off:

James feels his heart flip. He always does when sheâ€™s close, has since he was eleven. Youâ€™d think heâ€™d get used to it at some point, or build up some kind of immunity. But itâ€™s always the sameâ€”always feels like the first timeâ€”like heâ€™s never going to remember how to breathe again.

â€œReady to go?â€ Lily stops beside Marleneâ€™s chair, barely looking at James.

Which is okay. Completely fine. James bites down on his tongue and forces himself to turn back to his coursework, holding in the numerous desperate and embarrassing things he wants to say.

Like, youâ€™re beautiful.

You make me feel too big for my skin.

â€œPotter?â€

â€œOh,â€ James says, which is a ridiculous response, so his brain quickly tries to remedy the situation by adding: â€œIâ€™m doing Ruins readings.â€

â€œErâ€”rightâ€”Marlene, should we gâ€”â€œ

â€œWhat aboutâ€”howâ€”you?â€ Fuck. Fuck. Fuck. â€œI meanâ€¦alright, Evans?â€

â€œIâ€™m fine,â€ she says wearily, before sending a pointed look at Marlene. â€œLets go?â€

And just as they cross the threshold, moving out of sight, he hears her say: â€œWhatâ€™s his problem anyway?â€

Â 

He hasnâ€™t been sleeping well since the full moon. He closes his eyes and heâ€™s back in the forest. He canâ€™t see, but he hears Sirius screaming. He fumbles around in the dark until his hands touch something warm and sticky that smells like iron. Then he wakes up.

Every time he feels like something in his chest is caving in, his hands and legs shaking as he resists the urge to rip back the curtains around Siriusâ€™s bed and make sure heâ€™s okay. Make sure Moony didnâ€™t turn him inside out. That he got there in time.

Itâ€™s stupid.

Heâ€™s too old for nightmares.

With a huff James turns onto his side, the steady breathing of his roommates letting him know theyâ€™re all asleep. He punches his pillow, lays back down, stares up at the canopy over his head. He counts centaurs like he used to do when he was little. He recites the ingredients to the Alihosty Draught they learned in potions this week. He imagines heâ€™s flying. None of it works.

Eventually he gives up, pulling his legs over the side of the bed and scrubbing at his face. He could go down to the common room and try and get some work done, or maybe sneak into the kitchens - do they ward off the quidditch pitch after curfew? James reaches carefully into the drawer of his bedside table and pulls out the map. Maybe once he figures out where Filch is patrolling heâ€™ll have a better idea of what to do.

Except Filchâ€™s name isnâ€™t the one that catches his eye.

The map unfolds in his lap and almost instantly he sees itâ€”all alone in the Astronomy Tower. Regulus Black. James blinks, double checking that he isnâ€™t making it up.

â€œNutter,â€ he mutters under his breath, but he doesnâ€™t take his eyes off the name. Heâ€™s probably up there yelling at the sky again, though why heâ€™s doing it at two-thirty in the morning James canâ€™t fathom.

A few more minutes pass before he sighs. â€œFuck it.â€

He shoves his feet into his trainers, not bothering with the invisibility cloak as he throws a grey jumper over his bare torso. He checks the map periodically as he moves through the halls but Filch is on the otherside of the castle and Mrs. Norris appears to be outside doing who-knows-what. He takes the stairs to the top of the Astronomy Tower two at a time, tapping the map closed when he reaches the door at the top.

For a second he wavers, wondering if this is really the best idea. But then, thatâ€™s never stopped him before. He shoves the map into the waistband of his trousers and gently opens the door.

â€œOkay I give up, what are you doing?â€

â€œCouldnâ€™t sleep.â€

â€œIâ€™m not on anyoneâ€™s side,â€ itâ€™s such an automatic response, James doesnâ€™t even think about it, but once he hears the words outloud he realizes that they arenâ€™t true. That they canâ€™t be, not anymore.

â€œIs there something else I should be up here with?â€

â€œA girlâ€™d make more sense.â€

â€œI did,â€ James says slowly. â€œYou donâ€™t owe me an answer, but I want you to know that Iâ€™m asking because Iâ€™m interested, not because I want something to hold over your head.â€

That seems to surprise Regulus, though he does his best not to show it. James waits, which really, he thinks is impressive. Heâ€™s usually quite impatient. Regulus lets out a breath like heâ€™s been holding it in for days.

â€œWeâ€™re all there,â€ he says finally, still not looking at James. He wants so badly to ask him to explain but he doesnâ€™t. He keeps waiting. Oh.

How does he respond to that? How does he even begin to hold all those feelings? He remembers third year, remembers Sirius showing up to school covered in bruises he didnâ€™t yet know how to erase. That causes Regulus to look back at him, grey eyes bright in the moonlight.

Regulus lets out a breath that might be a laugh. â€œNo, of course not.â€

They sit in silence, but it's not uncomfortable. Not the kind that makes your skin itch. And James almost misses it, when Regulus starts to pull away.

â€œYou ready?â€ James asks, resisting the sudden urge to pull Regulus back down beside him.

Regulus sends him a sly look. â€œAlways.â€ Heâ€™s at the door, one hand on the handle, but he pauses, standing there for long enough that James starts to wonder if heâ€™s having some kind of stroke.

â€œIâ€™m not my brother,â€ Regulus says eventually, eyes darting up to meet Jamesâ€™s.

â€œJust, if thatâ€™s whyâ€”if thatâ€™s whatâ€”â€œ he stops, face scrunching in frustration as he attempts to get his thoughts in order. â€œIf thatâ€™s why youâ€™re doing this, if you think you canâ€¦save me, the way you did him. You should know that you canâ€™t.â€

James feels his thoughts go in a million different directions at those words, unsure of what to address first.

â€œDo you need to be saved Reg?â€ he manages finally.

He isnâ€™t sure what heâ€™s expecting, but itâ€™s certainly not the sad smile that peeks out of the corner of Regulusâ€™s mouth. â€œGoodnight, Potter.â€

James watches the door close behind him.

Chapter 4

Chapter Summary

TW: Panic attack

This starts soft and fluffy and then gets less so...but, it's gonna be okay...well...I mean...as okay as James and Regulus can be...

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Heâ€™s not sure how it starts exactly. Itâ€™s an accident, heâ€™s almost certain, a coincidence, that he finds himself heading up to the astronomy tower almost every night after his friends have gone to sleep. Another coincidence, that Regulus is always there. Itâ€™s strange how quickly he starts to know Regulus. The different ways he smiles without using his mouth. Or how he tugs at his fingers when he gets nervous. James doesnâ€™t know what it means that he notices these things. He doesnâ€™t try to figure it out. Maybe he doesnâ€™t want to.

Â 

â€œYouâ€™re telling me youâ€™ve been at this school for four years,â€ James is lying on his back, arms thrown behind his head, â€œand youâ€™ve never stepped foot in the Forbidden Forest?â€

â€œExcuse me for taking the â€˜Forbiddenâ€™ part of the name seriously,â€ Regulus says, sitting with one knee pulled up, chin resting on top.

â€œI just happen to be in possession of something called common sense, you might want to try it.â€

â€œPfft,â€ James says dismissively, â€œsounds dead boring.â€

â€œYes, well, you would think so.â€

â€œIâ€™ll take you,â€ heâ€™s says finally.

â€œThe forest, obviously.â€

â€œSomehow, I doubt that.â€

â€œListen, if youâ€™re scaredâ€”â€œ

â€œIâ€™m not scared,â€ Regulus interrupts sharply, and James does his best not to laugh. â€œIâ€™m not scared,â€ he repeats. â€œIâ€™m smart. Thereâ€™s a difference.â€

â€œIf you say so,â€ James knocks his foot again, this time staying there, pressed to Regulusâ€™s ankle. â€œBut my point was, that if you did happen to be scared,â€ James holds up his hands the minute he sees Regulus open his mouth, â€œwhich you arenâ€™t, obviously. Thereâ€™s a beat of silence before Regulus drops his face into his knees, shoulders shaking with laughter.

Making regulus laugh is new. Good new. Really good new. It feels like scoring a goal in a quidditch match. Like scoring the winning goal.

Â 

â€œI canâ€™t believe you stole a snitch,â€ Regulus says, batting the ball in question away from his face.

â€œOf course, you are.â€

James tosses the snitch up and down a few times before he notices Regulus watching him. The younger boy quickly turning back to his telescope.

Â 

â€œThe Catapults are your favourite quidditch team?â€ Regulus repeats in shock. Theyâ€™re sitting on the ground, leaning against the castle, Jamesâ€™s most recent haul from Honeydukes piled between them.

â€œI donâ€™t know why youâ€™re so surprised,â€ James says, biting off the end of his jelly wand.

â€œThe Catapults?â€ is all Regulus has to say in return.

James rolls his eyes. â€œThey're badass. I mean, the award for riskiest play is named after one of their players, doesn't get much cooler than that.â€

â€œBecause he was eaten by a chimera,â€ Regulus says flatly. â€œNot because he did anything particularly impressive on the pitch.â€

â€œCorrection,â€ James waves around his half-eaten gummy to emphasize his point. â€œHe was eaten by a chimera AND he was impressive on the pitch. Canâ€™t ask for a better legacy than that.â€

Regulus stares blankly at him. â€œI canâ€™t tell if youâ€™re joking right now or if youâ€™re genuinely this ridiculous.â€

James grins. â€œPart of my charm, that.â€

Â 

â€œHeâ€™s trying to collect them all?â€ Regulus asks incredulously, passing his chocolate frog card to James.

â€œYeah.â€

â€œThatâ€™s absurd.â€

Regulus arches his brow in a manner that suggests he does not think that you actually do have to respect it, but he doesnâ€™t say anything. Instead he turns his head and stares out over the grounds, closing his eyes for a moment and breathing in.

â€œBad day?â€ James asks eventually, when the silence drags on too long.

Regulus sighs. â€œMaybe, I donâ€™t know.â€

James watches him, waiting for him to keep going. Heâ€™s learned in these moments that Regulus needs to feel like heâ€™s in control.

â€œAnd the healers canâ€™t do anything?â€

James feels a little light headed for a moment, fingers digging into the stone building underneath him. The pain helps, it keeps him grounded. We figured out how to turn ourselves into animagi for Remus, he thinks to himself, trying to get his stomach muscles to unclench. Weâ€™ll figure this out too if we have to.

â€œYes,â€ James answers without question. And then: â€œNot just him, though.â€

Regulusâ€™s expression flickers and then quickly goes out. He looks down at his lap, picking some lint off his pants in a poor attempt to appear indifferent. â€œAnyway,â€ he presses on, voice carefully held. Guarded. â€œItâ€™s hard, hearing from him, when I canâ€™tâ€¦do anything. To help.â€

James isnâ€™t sure what to say. He realizes, suddenly, that he doesnâ€™t know much about Mr. Black. Most of Siriusâ€™s stories centre around Walburgaâ€”her rules and her bigotry and her sharp magic. Magic that liked to slice into him any chance it got, sometimes lashing out unconsciously, his motherâ€™s anger bleeding out of her and leaving him broken. â€œHe works at the Ministry right?â€ James says finally, pulling out the one piece of information he thinks he can remember.

â€œHe did. But itâ€”heâ€™s gotten worse recently. He canâ€™t really use his magic anymore. Too bad, he used to be brilliant.â€

James recognizes that tone, knows that thatâ€™s how he sounds when he talks about his own dad. He tries not to feel angry at Regulus, really he does, but he canâ€™t get the images of Sirius alone on his doorstep out of his head. Or showing up to the Hogwarts Express every year held together by tape and glue.

â€œTheyâ€™re nice to you?â€ James finds himself asking.

Regulus doesnâ€™t seem surprised by the question. â€œI love them.â€

James bites back the automatic responses of how? and why? Because he knows they wonâ€™t get him anywhere. Knows theyâ€™ll just shut Regulus down.

â€œThatâ€™s not the same thing,â€ he says finally.

Regulus smiles dryly. â€œNo,â€ he concedes, â€œbut itâ€™s the thing that matters.â€

Â 

James has started sleeping better, which is ridiculous considering how much less time heâ€™s spending in bed. But it helps, for some reason, talking to Regulus. Thereâ€™s somethingâ€¦steadying, about the other boy. Now when he closes his eyes, the darkness is full of stars.

Â 

â€œOi, you lot! Hurry up, weâ€™re going be late,â€ James is walking backwards down the hill towards the pitch, desperately trying to corral the majority of the fifth year Gryffindors. Marlene and Dorcas are making bets on the match with a group of Hufflepuffs and Peter is having an adamant argument with Giffard Abbott about whose chocolate is better: Honeydukes or Cadbury, which for some reason has effected their ability to walk at a reasonable pace.

James sighs, running a hand over his face before looking at the lone figure beside him. â€œYouâ€™re my favourite Moony, have I ever told you that?â€

Remus snorts, watching the chaos unfolding behind them with mild amusement. â€œUh huh.â€

â€œWait,â€ James eyes the bag hanging off of Remusâ€™s shoulder. â€œDid youâ€”did you bring textbooks with you?!â€

Remus clutches at the bag like he's worried James is about to rip it away from him, sending his friend a sheepish look. â€œUhâ€¦might have, yeah.â€

James throws his hands up over his head. â€œForget it, I take it back, I hate all of you equally.â€

â€œOh please!â€ comes Siriusâ€™s voice as he starts making his way towards them, Mary now on his back. â€œYou love us.â€

â€œIâ€™d love you more if you could get your asses moving,â€ James says as they start walking again, throngs of other students in yellow and green moving with them.

Sirius rolls his eyes. â€œI donâ€™t know why youâ€™re so interested in this game, we all know Hufflepuffâ€™s got it in the bag.â€

â€œIs that a bet I hear Black?â€ Marlene calls from behind them.

Sirius laughs. â€œNot a chance McKinnon, Iâ€™ve learned my lesson. You cleaned me out last time.â€

James smiles. He loves this. He thought his heart was going to explode the first time he stepped onto the Hogwarts quidditch pitch. â€œMaybe youâ€™ve just never had very good ones.â€

In retrospect, he should have seen it coming. He didnâ€™t. But he should have.

The first thought he has, when Regulus pushes forward, pressing their mouths together, half-crawling into Jamesâ€™s lap, is that heâ€™s so warm. His mouth. His hands. For a boy who walks around like heâ€™s made of stone, Regulus touches like the sun.

He canâ€™t.

How could he not know?

He flinches when the door slams and now that heâ€™s on his own he realizes that he isnâ€™t breathing rightâ€”too fast and too short. Heâ€™s seen Moony like this before, like his bodyâ€™s forgotten how to breathe. James squeezes his eyes shut. Trying to get himself under control.

Breathe, he commands himself.

Breathe you idiot.

In and out.

In and out.

Fuck, something aches in his chest and he doesnâ€™t know what itâ€™s from but it hurts.

Breathe.

In and out.

In and out.

Itâ€™s okay. This is okay. This can be okay.

Itâ€™s just a kiss.

Except it isnâ€™t.

Itâ€™s Siriusâ€™s brother.

Breathe.

In and out.

In and out.

A boy who touches like the sun.

In and out.

In and

In and

In and

Inâ€”

Have faith in James though, he'll get there.

Chapter 5

See the end of the chapter for notes

He doesnâ€™t go back to the astronomy tower the next night. Or the night after that. Neither does Regulus, James checks. Thatâ€™s how he spends his free time now. Watching Regulusâ€™s name move around the map. It is absolutely and utterly pathetic. But that doesnâ€™t stop him.

â€œHey, earth to Prongs?â€ Sirius snaps his fingers impatiently in Jamesâ€™s direction.

James looks up from the fireplace to find his three friends staring at him.

A beat passes.

â€œSorryâ€”what?â€

Sirius huffs. â€œHalloween party planning, care to contribute?â€

â€œNot really,â€ he sinks lower in his chair, tilting his head back to look up at the ceiling. â€œCanâ€™t we just do what we did last year?â€

Remusâ€™s face appears above him.

â€œHey Moons,â€ he says wearily.

â€œOh yeah?â€

James nods, expression serious. â€œMhm, someoneâ€™s got to count all the cracks in the ceiling.â€

â€œIf youâ€™re going to kidnap me at least have the decency to tell me where weâ€™re going,â€ James notices that Sirius has retreated to the other side of the common room with Mary, Pete nowhere to be seen. Remus clearly dismissed them.

â€œIâ€™m not sure kidnappers are known for being particularly decent.â€

â€œSemantics,â€ James mutters, allowing himself to be dragged though the portrait hole and into the hall on the other side.

They walk in silence at first, James shoving his newly freed hands into his pockets and making a concerted effort not to look at anyone. â€œYou didnâ€™t bring the cloak,â€ James finds himself saying, eventually.

â€œI did not. Very astute of you to notice.â€

James huffs. â€œYou going to be okay when we get detention for walking around after curfew?â€

Remus taps the Prefect badge on his chest, sending James a sly look.

Chapter End Notes

Now if only Remus and Sirius could get it together, amiright?

As always thanks so much for your comments! Always interested to know what you guys think!

Chapter End Notes

Hello lovelies,

This chapter is one of those where when I wrote it I was like "Wow, amazing **chef's kiss**" and then every time I've read it since I've liked it less and less, so hopefully it still turned out okay!

Thank you for the comments they make my day!

Chapter 7

Chapter Notes

TW injury

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Regulus is complicated. It isnâ€™t that James is completely lost, he has been friends with Sirius since he was eleven. But itâ€™sâ€¦different. Regulus does come back, the night after Halloween, but he brings the telescope and holds himself apart from James. They talk, itâ€™s nice, but itâ€™sâ€¦stilted. Regulus never lets either of them get too close, doesnâ€™t laugh too loud, doesnâ€™t say anything important.

James wants to talk about itâ€”about Marlene, about Regulusâ€™s reaction, about how they can be more careful in the future. But heâ€™s met with silence. With an unreadable expression. With empty eyes.

They donâ€™t touch. Which is okay, except James doesnâ€™t know whatâ€™s allowed hereâ€”what Regulus wants. Where the boundaries are. Chapter End Notes

Hello lovelies!

I don't know about you guys but I'm a little obsessed with the Regulus / James interactions in this chapter (am I allowed to say that if I wrote them? Idk but it's true),

Your comments are so sweet, I hope you're all having a good day!

â€œI want you,â€ he says a breathlessly. â€œI want you Reg.â€

The other boyâ€™s eyes close briefly before he steps forward, slow, careful, and James lets him. Itâ€™s not like it was before, itâ€™s careful, breakable. And James thinks, this is what they mean, when they say love is falling.

Because he doesnâ€™t know where the floor is.

Because he knows itâ€™s going to hurt when they hit the ground.

Chapter End Notes

Hello lovelies!

This chapter was really hard to write for some reason so hopefully it turned out okay - I really struggled to get that ending right.

Honestly, I say it every time, but getting to read the comments on this story has been really nice so THANK YOU.

Chapter 9

Chapter Summary

Surprise it's Christmas (almost)!

Chapter Notes

I just wanted to real quick address something I know has been talked about in the fandom recently (and also is just important):

The characters in this story are minors, now, I still have some sexual content because a) teenagers do have sex and b) I want them to have conversations about consent and boundaries and (eventually) trauma because it's relevant (I think) to the characters BUT I try to do it in a way that isn't too explicit or graphic because, again, minors.

Hopefully I manage not to cross any boundaries but if any of you feel like I do, give me a shout, I'm always happy to make changes if something makes someone feel uncomfortable

Okay, I'm done now, thank you for coming to my TedTalk!

See the end of the chapter for more notes

James laughs, startling him. â€œYeah, yeah Iâ€™m good Moony,â€ he pulls himself up, scrubbing at his face. â€œThere any hot water left?â€

Remusâ€™s grimaces. â€œSome, Iâ€™d give it a minute. You know how Padfoot is, bloody boils himself.â€

James snorts, watching Remus fold up his pyjamas and fit them in his luggage.

â€œYou excited to go home?â€

Remus shrugs, pausing for a minute before straightening up. â€œIâ€™m excited thereâ€™s no full moon over the break.â€ He offers James a weak smile.

â€œYou know if there was Iâ€™d make you come to mine,â€ because itâ€™s true, theyâ€™ve done it before.

Remus nods, â€œYeah I know James.â€

â€œGood. Youâ€™ll come over anyway yeah? For New Years Eve? Petes coming too.â€

â€œI erâ€”â€œ his face looks tight and he starts fiddling with his luggage again. â€œI donâ€™t know, I might stay with my mum, she gets lonely.â€

Jamesâ€™s eyes narrow. â€œRemus?â€ he prods, because they both know that that isnâ€™t true. Remusâ€™s parents are alright, theyâ€™re no Walburga, but James knows Remus hates that house. The delicacy of it. The guilt that his parents have never been able to let go of. The realities they never seem to accept.

The other boy sighs. â€œI just thinkâ€¦I think Sirius might not want me there. Thatâ€™s all. Itâ€™s not a big deal.â€

James swings his legs off the bed, walking over to Remusâ€™s side. â€œHe wants you there,â€ James says with absolute certainty.

â€œJamesâ€”â€œ

â€œI know youâ€™re fighting,â€ he cuts the other boy off, â€œbut I also know Sirius. I know he wants you there. And I know I want you there. And Peter wants you there. And my mother really wants you there. Between you and I, youâ€™ve always been her favourite,â€ that gets a soft laugh out of Remus. â€œBut donâ€™t tell Padfoot I said that.â€

â€œCross my heart,â€ Remus makes the motion with his fingers and James smiles.

â€œSo really,â€ he goes on, â€œthe only thing that matters, is whether or not you want to be there?â€

Thereâ€™s a pause, Remus pulling his lower lip anxiously between his teeth, not really looking at James.

â€œI do,â€ he says eventually. â€œâ€˜Course I do.â€

â€œGood man,â€ James slaps him on the shoulder, â€œitâ€™s settled then.â€ He tosses the map and his wand onto his bed before moving towards the thoroughly debauched looking bathroom.

â€œJames?â€ Remus calls to him as he gets to the door, causing James to turn around. â€œThank you.â€

James nods, wishing he could say more but not at all sure how to say any of it without making things worse.

â€œYouâ€™re not alone Remus,â€ is what comes out of him in the end, his friendâ€™s eyes widening, â€œokay?â€

Remus nods. â€œOkay.â€

And James wonders if one day heâ€™ll actually be able to convince all the people he loves that itâ€™s true.

Chapter End Notes

Hello Lovelies!

Gosh, they're so cute! I should warn you, that things are maybe going to be much less cute in the next chapter so, brace yourselves.

Also, if you're interested, this is the painting they're talking about: https://www.nationalgalleries.org/art-and-artists/5009/achilles-lamenting-death-patroclus

As always, your comments are sunshine and rainbows, thanks so much!

Chapter 10

Chapter Summary

Welcome to the Noble and Most Ancient House of Black.

Chapter Notes

TW: Sexual assault (not graphically described)
TW: Child Abuse (Mostly magical, mostly psychological, a little physical)
TW: Trauma/PTSD/Anxiety/Panic Attack
TW: Threatened forced outing (Idk if this is a TW but, like, just incase)

OKAY as you can tell this is heavy, hopefully done in a way that is respectful of all these experiences

Last thing: the purpose of this is to understand Regulus, it's not to excuse him, or any of the bad things he may or may not do in this or any future chapters

Alright sorry I'm done, I promise to stop ranting at the top of these chapters

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Regulus was eleven the first time he fell in love with James Potter. It was really rather inconvenient, since he had already decided to hate him. Not for any of the obvious reasonsâ€”the tension between their families, the impending warâ€”but because, until Sirius went to Hogwarts, Regulus had been his best friend. They would make forts, and read stories, and go for adventures in the back garden. When Regulus had a nightmare Sirius was there. When their mother was angry Sirius was there. When their father got sick Sirius was there.

But the summer after his first year at Hogwarts all Sirius could talk about was James Potter. James Potter this and James Potter that and oh wasnâ€™t he so fantastic. Regulus quickly grew to despise him. A feeling his mother seemed to share. It wasnâ€™t that her and Sirius had ever gotten along particularly well, Sirius had never been very good at being quiet or sitting still or keeping his clothes clean. But they didnâ€™t start hating each other until Sirius went to Hogwarts. Until James Potter came along.

So when he boarded the train the following September, with his mother whispering viscously in his ear about all the things she would do to him if he was to find himself sorted into Gryffindor like his brother, Regulus already hated James Potter. More than he had ever hated anyone else in his little eleven year old life.

Sirius had dragged him into the compartment with his friends, and Lupin had been kind and Pettigrew a little jumpy and Potterâ€”Potter barely looked at him. A nod of the head, that was all, before him and Sirius were talking to one another a mile a minute, making jokes that Regulus didnâ€™t understand and telling stories he wasnâ€™t a part of. And the whole time James Potter didnâ€™t look at him once! Which was infuriating, because how was he supposed to communicate his intense dislike of the boy if he wouldnâ€™t even give him the time of day?

Of course, this all became less of an issue after the sorting. Slytherins and Gryffindors are natural enemies. They rarely interact except when forced and besides, Regulus was a first year, a little kid. It had never mattered to Sirius before that he was younger butâ€”now he had Potter. So Regulus didnâ€™t see his brother much. Or his brotherâ€™s friends. And mostly, he felt lost. He drifted through his classes, quiet and reserved, not wanting to draw too much attention to himself. Not wanting to be noticed. That was how he had always survived at Grimmauld Place. He assumed it would work at Hogwarts too.

He was wrong.

A few weeks into school Severus Snape found him kissing a boy. Orâ€”perhaps more accuratelyâ€”found a boy kissing Regulus. At eleven, Regulus didnâ€™t much fancy kissing anyone, he found the whole thing rather unbecoming if he was being honest. But Roger Flint was older, and bigger, and didnâ€™t seem to care one way or the other what Regulus wanted. He tried to explain this to Snape, after Flint ran off, but Snape was kind enough to inform Regulus that it didnâ€™t matter. People would think he was a freak either way. So it was in his best interest to do what Snape said, and that way no one would find out.

It had not occurred to eleven year old Regulus that Severus Snape, who barely had the strength in his lanky limbs to lift his own wand, was not going to out Roger Flint to the entire school. All he knew was that he didnâ€™t want Sirius to know.

Oh how little things change.

So he did as Snape asked: â€œMy homework Blackâ€ â€œMy Laundry Blackâ€ â€œPush that Hufflepuff down the stairs Black.â€ Regulus did all of it. Unlike Sirius, he had always been good at doing what he was told.

A few months later, he watched James Potter punch Severus Snape in the face outside of the great hall. And, well, it was hard not to fall in love with him after that.

Â 

Regulus takes these memories and puts them in a box. And then he buries it. He digs deep inside himself, for the darkest, lowest corner, and he puts it there. He puts all of James there. You do not walk into Grimmauld Place with your walls down.

Â 

â€œMistress Black is out for the afternoon but she tells Kreacher to inform his Young Master Regulus that she will be returning for supper at six oâ€™clock sharp.â€

Regulus nods, standing awkwardly in the middle of his bedroom, feeling like a ghost. A stranger.

â€œKreacher is making Master Regulusâ€™s favourite, roast pheasant.â€

Regulus looks down at the elf and forces himself to smile. â€œThank you Kreacher, I really appreciate it.â€

The elf preens. â€œOf course Master, Kreacher wants always to be a good help to the noble house of Black.â€

Regulus swallows. â€œYou are. Always.â€

He needs to get himself more under control, he knows that, heâ€™s letting it all get to him. The grey walls, the heavy smell of the air, the missing photos on the walls. He canâ€™t be full of cracks the first time he sees her.

â€œIsâ€”is my father up?â€ he asks finally.

Kreacher nods. â€œYes sir, he is very, very excited to be seeing Master Regulus Sir,â€ the elf does his best attempt at a smile, the sight oddly endearing despite all the teeth. â€œHe will be taking his tea now Sir, in his bed.â€

Regulus nods. â€œExcellent, thank Kreacher, thatâ€™s all for now.â€

Kreacher gives him a bow apparating out of the room before his head is raised.

Regulus closes his eyes, feeling the walls as much as he sees them. The weight of them, the pressure. Thereâ€™s never any air in this fucking house. He breathes in deep, trying to calm the anxious tremors running up and down his bones. He exhales. All of these feelings are useless and he needs to be done with them. Thereâ€™s no point in being afraid here. Better to wrap himself in a layer of apathy, of disinterest.

Nothing matters. If nothing matters than nothing hurts.

He opens his eyes, blinking the dim room back into focus and feeling the beginning of a familiar numbness spread through him. Good, he thinks, flexing his fingers, releasing some of the tension from his muscles.

There is no privacy in Grimmauld Place. The walls are covered in the shadowy silhouettes of the Blacks of yore. They whisper and scowl and scurry about. And all of them belong to his mother. Bend to her will. He feels their eyes on him now as he walks stiffly down to the floor below, their gazes making his skin itch.

Inhale. Exhale.

Nothing matters.

He pauses at his fatherâ€™s open door, his parents donâ€™t share a bedroom of course, they havenâ€™t since Regulus was young. Since before his father got sick. In his memories, his father is a towering figure, with big warm hands and a domineering presence. He never spoke much, even back then, always quiet. Regulus knows that he takes after his father, just as he knows that Sirius takes after their mother. Heâ€™s sure theyâ€™ve both ached over that truth.

Now his father is sitting in a chair by the window, flannel housecoat wrapped around him, dark hair shot through with white, the curls, once so like Regulusâ€™s, gone limp.

Inhale. Exhale.

Nothing matters.

â€œPapa?â€

The older manâ€™s head snaps to the doorway, on edge, suspicious, before he finds Regulusâ€™s face and then he smiles. For a moment, it almost doesnâ€™t look like heâ€™s dying.

â€œReggie!â€ he makes to stand but falters, his strength gone. Regulus has no doubt that Kreacher is the one who helped him into that chair in the first place. He crosses the room quickly so that his father wonâ€™t try again, bending down so that he can wrap his arms around him.

â€œLook at you,â€ his father gushes as keeps his hands on Regulusâ€™s shoulders even as he straightens up. â€œYouâ€™ve grown.â€

Regulus rolls his eyes. â€œItâ€™s been three months.â€

But his father only grins. â€œAh, not up but in, mon chou, your eyes are far wiser than they were this summer.â€

Regulus feels the twinge of something in his chest but quickly smothers it. It will not serve him to remember everything that has changed since the summer. Not here. Not now.

â€œViens,â€ his father gestures to the chair across from him, â€œasseyez-vous, asseyez-vous. Parle Ã  ton pÃ¨re pendant un moment, parle-moi de ta vie, je deviens fou coincÃ© dans cette piÃ¨ce.â€ His french is rapid, one word blending into the next. Regulus has always loved the way his father speaks French, the deep way his voice wraps around the vowels and hugs the end of each word. Slow and smooth, in a way English never can be.

His mother hates it, but itâ€™s only because sheâ€™s not very good at it. Expensive tutors are no substitute for the real thing, and Walburga cannot stand to be outdone in anything.

â€œOkay, okay,â€ Regulus takes a seat. â€œThereâ€™s really not that much to sayâ€”I study, I play quidditch, thatâ€™s it,â€ he shrugs.

Regulus feels himself blush. â€œIt wasnâ€™t that impressive.â€

â€œPlease, I hear the scouts are already talking about you. You never know, you might be the youngest player to sign with a major team in quidditch history huh? On ne sait jamais.â€

Donâ€™t we? Regulus almost says. Because they both know that even if he was approached by a teamâ€”next year, two years from nowâ€”Walburga would never allow it. He is needed for the cause. Everything else is dust.

â€œMaybe,â€ he answers instead, looking out the window, the sky is nearly as grey as the wallpaper. â€œThey really keep you coupâ€™d up in here all the time?â€

His father makes irritated grumble. â€œBloody healers. Wonâ€™t let me do anything.â€

â€œTheyâ€™re only trying to help.â€

â€œThatâ€™s certainly what they say.â€

Regulus rolls his eyes, turning back to his father who instantly holds his hands up in surrender. â€œMerde Reggie, donâ€™t look at me like that. Iâ€™m following orders, doing what they say, I swear mon petit.â€

â€œYou better be.â€

â€œI am, I am, why do you think Iâ€™m so miserable huh?â€ he shoots Regulus a playful grin that the younger boy does his best to return.

â€œOkay then.â€

â€œOkay then,â€ his father mockingly repeats.

â€œI donâ€™t sound like that.â€

â€œYou absolutely do mon chou.â€

Instead of responding Regulus reaches for one of the biscuits on the untouched plate in front of him, eyeing his fatherâ€™s thin frame as he takes his first bite.

â€œYouâ€™re not eating,â€ he says after he swallows. Itâ€™s not a question. His father is a shell of what he once was, shoulders slumped, skin hanging off his bones in unnatural ways.

â€œI eat,â€ his father says dismissively, but Regulus only scowls, shoving the rest of his cookie in his mouth.

â€œNot enough.â€

Orion laughs. â€œJeez, who is the parent here?â€

I donâ€™t know, Regulus thinks, you tell me. But for the second time he holds his tongue.

His father pauses then, eyes flicking nervously towards the door.

â€œSheâ€™s not here,â€ Regulus says, answering the question that wasnâ€™t asked.

Orion nods. â€œHave you spoken to your brother?â€

Regulusâ€™s heart drops. Sirius is a dangerous topic in this household and heâ€™s not sure heâ€™s up for the task of walking through that minefield right now.

â€œYes,â€ he says slowly, not sure what else he can say, not when his father is looking at him like that. â€œHeâ€™sâ€¦well.â€

His father smiles softly. â€œThatâ€™s good.â€

Regulus only nods, looking back out the window.

Â 

There was a wedge, between him and Sirius, the moment his brother could escape. The moment he didnâ€™t have to rely on Regulusâ€™s company alone anymore. But it wasnâ€™t until last summer that Regulus thinks his brother really lost faith in him. It wasnâ€™t the night he leftâ€”nothing so explosive and obvious.
