Â 

â€œIâ€™m just saying,â€ Peter hisses, as they slide into their seats in Potions. â€œIf youâ€™re going to startâ€¦doing stuffâ€¦in our room, you could at least use a bloody silencing charm.â€

â€œOh leave them alone Wormtail,â€ James says as he pulls out his textbook.

Peter looks mutinous. â€œEasy for you to say, you didnâ€™t have to listen to them.â€

â€œMerlin Peter,â€ Sirius rolls his eyes, looking far too pleased with himself. â€œWe were only snogging.â€

â€œStill gross.â€

Sirius pushes his chair back so that heâ€™s balancing on its hind two legs, arms behind his head. Just under his collar Remus can see the mark he left on him this morning and a ridiculous flush rushes through his whole body. Sirius catches him looking and winks.

â€œSorry Peter,â€ Remus says, when heâ€™s able to make himself speak. â€œWonâ€™t happen again.â€

â€œThe hell it wonâ€™t,â€ Sirius mutters under his breath, causing James to snort.

Remus is just about to tell them both off when he notices Professor Slughorn walking towards them.

â€œMr. Lupin?â€ he says as he stops at their table.

â€œErâ€”good morning Professor,â€ Remus isnâ€™t entirely sure whatâ€™s going on. â€œSorry, were we being too loud? We werenâ€™t aware class had started yet?â€

â€œNo, no,â€ the older man shakes his head. â€œProfessor McGonagall would like to speak with you in her office. She said to take your stuff and not to expect you back.â€

Remus blinks. â€œOh.â€

Slughorn smiles a little. â€œShe did not give me the impression that you were in trouble so thereâ€™s no need to look quite so frightened.â€

â€œRight,â€ Remus lets out the breath he wasnâ€™t aware heâ€™d been holding. â€œThank you Professor.â€

â€œNot a problem.â€

Slughorn heads back to the front of the class while Remus reaches for his bag.

â€œWhatâ€™s this about then?â€ Sirius asks, chair slamming back down onto all fours. â€œYou curse someone else Moony?â€ he asks with a grin.

â€œYouâ€™re turning into a right little bad boy arenâ€™t you?â€ James adds, causing both him and Sirius to snicker.

Remus rolls his eyes. â€œYou heard him, Iâ€™m not in trouble. Must be something to do with Prefect duty. Iâ€™ll see you guys at lunch yeah?â€

â€œSee Peter?â€ James nudges Peter with his elbow. â€œLunch, that meal we have together.â€

Peter rolls his eyes.

Holding in a laugh Remus turns to leave when Siriusâ€™s foot hooks around his ankle. â€œDonâ€™t get into anymore fights on the way to her office alright? Youâ€™ll break McGonagallâ€™s heart if she thinks weâ€™ve finally corrupted you.â€

â€œHilarious. Can I go now?â€

â€œYeah alright. See you later bad boy,â€ and then Sirius gives him a smile that makes tectonic plates shift in Remusâ€™s chest.

All he can do in response is shake his head, blushing furiously as he ducks out of the classroom.

Â 

Heâ€™s in such a good mood that he almost forgets that heâ€™s on his way to McGonagallâ€™s office. He knows they still have so much to talk about, him and Sirius, so much to get past. But they will. Because Sirius wants him. He wants him. Those words sing through Remus, just like the memory of waking up this morning with Siriusâ€™s weight on top of him.

â€œCome in,â€ McGonagallâ€™s voice calls out the second after he knocks. â€œClose the door behind you please.â€

Remus is surprised to find her standing in front of her desk instead of sitting behind it and it pulls him up short.

â€œProfessor?â€ he asks uncertainly. â€œProfessor Slughorn said you wanted to see me?â€

She nods. â€œYes,â€ thereâ€™s something in the look she gives him that isnâ€™t quite rightâ€”itâ€™s too soft, almost sad. â€œThough itâ€™s your father who wants to speak with you not I.â€

Remus blinks, now really lost. â€œMy father?â€ he repeats dumbly, looking around as though expecting him to jump out from behind some piece of furniture.

Professor McGonagall nods, gesturing to the fireplace just behind her. â€œHeâ€™ll be calling any minute now,â€ she walks forward, hand squeezing Remusâ€™s shoulder as she passes him. â€œIâ€™ll give you two some privacy.â€

â€œPrivacy?â€ Remus repeats again as McGonagall closes the door behind her. He looks back at the office, which feels so much more ominous now that heâ€™s in it alone.

Donâ€™t panic, he tells himself. It canâ€™t be that bad, not if heâ€™s only fire-calling. If it was a real emergency he would be here. Just donâ€™t panic. Not until you knowâ€”

â€œRemus?â€

His fatherâ€™s voice breaks him out of his thoughts.

â€œHereâ€”Iâ€™m here,â€ he moves quickly, dropping down in front of the fireplace and finding his fatherâ€™s flickering face staring back up at him. â€œWhat is it dad? Whatâ€™s happened?â€

His father looks stern, but then, he almost always does. â€œIs McGonagall there? Did she tell you anything?â€

Remus shakes his head. â€œNo, sheâ€™s gone. Just said you wanted to talk to me.â€ And his father never wants to talk to him, not even when theyâ€™re in the same house.

Lyall lets out a heavy sigh, hand coming up to rub his forehead. â€œItâ€™s your mother,â€ he says finally.

Remus feels something cold run down his spine. It drips around his heart, fills his lungs.

â€œWhat happened? Where is she?â€

His father sighs again, dropping his hand. â€œSheâ€™s dead Remus.â€

For a second, one second, he thinks his dad is joking. Not that itâ€™s a very funny joke, and really, this is a bit of an elaborate set up. But thatâ€™s the only way his brain can make sense of what his father is saying. Because his mother isnâ€™t dead. She just isnâ€™t. She canâ€™t be. Thereâ€™s no reason for her to be. His father, sure, his job is dangerous, he has enemies. But his mum? All she does is live in their cottage and bake and send Remus about fifty letters a week and itâ€™s annoying but mostly itâ€™s sweet, because he knows sheâ€™s just doing her best. And he loves her for it. He loves her. His mum. His mad overprotective mum. He loves her and really, sheâ€™s all he has, if you think about it. So she isnâ€™t dead.

She isnâ€™t.

She isnâ€™t.

â€œI donâ€™t understand,â€ he manages to say eventually, but his father is already moving on.

â€œThe funeral will be Thursday, McGonagall is going to organize a Portkey so that you can come, Iâ€™ll write to you with the time. She said you could come home until then but I told her no, Iâ€™m just going to be at work the whole time so I canâ€™t see the point.â€

â€œDad,â€ he chokes out, when what he really wants to say is stop. Stop now please. Youâ€™ve made your point, whatever sick point it was. I want to see her. I want to see my mum. I need to. I love her. And she isnâ€™t dead. So. I need to see her.

â€œWhat happened?â€ is what makes it out of his mouth.

The silence stretches on too long.

â€œThere was an accident,â€ his father says finally, almost grudgingly. Thereâ€™s no hint of emotion in his voice, hasnâ€™t been the whole time. He talks like this is a business meeting. Remus one of his colleagues.

â€œAn accident?â€

No.

She isnâ€™t.

She isnâ€™t.

She isnâ€™t.

â€œWhat do you mean there was an accident?â€

â€œShe took too much of her medication, bloody muggle stuff. I told her not to bother with it but she insisted,â€ his father goes on irritably.

Remus blinks, no more equipped to deal with that information than any of the information that had come before it.

She isnâ€™t.

The voice sounds pathetic and grasping.

She isnâ€™t.

â€œThat doesnâ€™t sound like an accident,â€ Remus says finally, which is clearly the wrong thing to say because his fatherâ€™s face instantly hardens.

â€œLeave it Remus.â€

â€œHow did she accidentally take too much of her medication dad?â€

â€œI told you to leave it.â€

â€œShe was so alone in that house,â€ and he knows, knows he should stop, but he canâ€™t. The words just keep coming. Words heâ€™s meant to say forever but could never bring himself to. Was never brave enough too.

â€œYou took her away from her family, her friends, you brought her into this world that doesnâ€™t want her and then you just left her. Just left her all fucking alone.â€

â€œENOUGH,â€ his father has never raised his voice before but Remus barely hears it.

â€œHow could you do that to her? How could you do that to us?â€

â€œI couldnâ€™t make any of it better,â€ Lyall says finally. â€œNot you. Not her. I couldnâ€™t fix either of you. What was I supposed to do?â€

Remus stares at him and ohâ€”oh no. He thinks he might actually start losing it now.

â€œFuck,â€ he curls over like heâ€™s just been punched in the gut. Pressure building behind his eyes. â€œOh fuck, oh fuck, sheâ€™s dead. Sheâ€™s dead. Fuck.â€

â€œRemus?â€ he hears his fatherâ€™s voice distantly. â€œWhatâ€™s the matter?â€

Which is a ridiculous question given the circumstances. And he suddenly realizes how much he doesnâ€™t want to do this here. In front of him. On the floor of McGonagallâ€™s office. So he tries to pull his denial back around himself, cracked and chipped as it is. Tries to push this all down, just until he can get back to his room. His bed.

â€œWhy did you marry her?â€ the question punches out of him as he raises his head to look at his father again. Because heâ€™s always wondered. Because suddenly he just needs to know. â€œWhy did you have me?â€

His father watches him for a minute, like maybe, for once, heâ€™s actually seeing Remus. â€œI thought it would be different.â€

Remus almost laughs. â€œWell,â€ he says shakily, feeling certain that any minute heâ€™ll break down into a million tiny pieces. â€œSorry we couldnâ€™t live up to your expectations.â€

â€œRemusâ€”â€œ and for the first time he almost sounds sorry.

â€œGood-bye dad.â€

The face flickers in front of him for a second longer before it disappears.

Remus tries to get up but doesnâ€™t make it very far, grabbing hold of McGonagallâ€™s desk for support.

His mum is dead.

His mum who tried so hard to take care of him. To be there. To make up for the one time that she wasnâ€™t. Who squeezed him so tight sometimes he thought he was going to burst. Heâ€™s never going to see her again. Heâ€™s never going to touch her. Never going to hear her sing or see her cooking in the kitchen.

Remus tries to breathe, but there are just so many fucking nevers, theyâ€™re crowding his chest, filling his lungs. How is he meant to let go of all of that at once? How does he cope with losing all of her at once?

Thereâ€™s a knock on the door and after a few seconds McGonagall steps in.

â€œSorry,â€ Remus stutters, reaching down and clumsily grabbing his bag. â€œSorry, Iâ€™m sure you want your office back.â€

â€œPlease, itâ€™s more than alright, take all the time you need. I just wanted to let you know that you will not be required to attend any of your classes for the rest of the week.â€

Remus nods stiffly.

â€œAnd that I have also had Mr. Potter, Black and Pettigrew excused from their classes as well, though just for today. I expect by now theyâ€™ll be waiting for you back at Gryffindor Tower.â€

Remus looks up, meeting her kind eyes, feeling his throat grow tight. â€œThank you,â€ he whispers.

â€œAnything you need Remus,â€ itâ€™s a shock, hearing his first name come out of her mouth. â€œYou let me know.â€

He nods, moving towards the door, desperate to get out, to get to the safety of his own room, but still he pauses before he leaves.

â€œReally,â€ he turns back to look at her. â€œThank you,â€ heâ€™s not sure heâ€™s ever meant anything quite so much.

She gives him a sad smile. â€œOf course.â€

And then Remus is pushing out the door and into the corridor outside.

Â 

He doesnâ€™t remember much of the walk back to the dorms. Mostly he keeps his head down and tries not to think. He knows that death happens, knows that people get left behind and that they find ways to move on with their lives. He just canâ€™t quite figure out how. Because she isnâ€™t just dead today. Sheâ€™s dead tomorrow too. And the day after that. And that. And that. She will be dead every day for the rest of his life. How are you supposed to deal with loss that big?

He nearly trips up the stairs to his room, taking them two at a time, glad that everyone is still in class. When he pushes through the door he finds his three best friends waiting. James leaning against his bedpost, Sirius pacing in front of the window, Petter sitting down, legs crossed. They freeze at the sight of him. The room more quiet than Remus has ever heard it. None of the lights are on, the space lit only with the dull morning sun.

Remus can feel himself cracking already. All those thoughts heâ€™d been pushing out rushing in. And he wonders if McGonagall told them whatâ€™s happened and feels a jolt of fear at the thought of having to tell them himself. Of having to say the words out loud because heâ€™s not sure he can.

But then Sirius is stepping forward, pulling Remus into his arms, and he goes willingly, burying his head in Siriusâ€™s chest. James is next, then Peter. The three of them holding him together as he slowly starts to shatter and break apart. They keep all the pieces of him, stop them from rolling away, from getting lost. Making sure his grief doesnâ€™t do anything that canâ€™t be undone.

In the haze of tears and choking sobs Remus discovers the answer to his own question. Because this, of course, is how people deal with loss. This is how they survive their grief.

Together.

Chapter End Notes

Hello beautiful people!

I'm not gonna lie, I'm a little nervous about this chapter, just cause I feel like it does a lot (maybe too much???) but hopefully you liked it!

Thank you so much for all the comments and song recs, love it all!!

Chapter 24

Chapter Notes

TW: Religion (this is not an important plot point at all but I know it's a touchy subject for some and it is referenced a couple times in this chapter so I'm throwing this out there)

ALSO, I realize no one cares but this chapter definitely has a soundtrack and it is: Oh Lightning by Valley Maker, it was on repeat the entire time I wrote this so if you want the vibes it's that.

ALSO ALSO there is Jegulus in this chapter, I know it feels like there won't be but there is I promise (I missed them too)

See the end of the chapter for more notes

PART I: REMUS

The day of his motherâ€™s funeral Remus walks into the dorm room to find his three best friends dressed in black suits. He stops in front of the door, staring at them, his own suit heavy on his skin. Theyâ€™re well into fall but the fabric somehow still manages to feel suffocating.

â€œWhere did you get those?â€ he asks eventually, having to clear his throat to get the words out.

â€œHave a little faith Moony,â€ James says. â€œWe know how to buy Muggle clothes.â€

â€œLily got them for us,â€ Peter says, earning him an elbow to the ribs.

Remus arches his brow. â€œShe got you three perfectly tailored suits?â€ he tries not to let his eyes linger on Sirius, on the way the clothes hug his chest and thighs.

â€œShe used magic for the tailoring,â€ James admits. â€œButâ€”uhâ€”we couldnâ€™t figure out theâ€”uhâ€”long cravat things,â€ he tugs on his collar.

Remus blinks, and then; â€œTies you mean?â€ realizing suddenly that not one of them is wearing a tie, making them look rather more like some sort of rock band than funeral guests. He almost smiles.

â€œLily didnâ€™t know how to tie them and we couldnâ€™t find a spell,â€ he shuffles his feet. â€œIs that okay? Or do we need toâ€”â€œ

â€œNo,â€ Remus croaks. â€œNo, itâ€™s fine. It suits you,â€ he blinks a few times, getting the moisture out of his eyes. â€œSo youâ€™re coming then?â€

James looks taken aback by the question but itâ€™s Sirius who speaks first.

â€œDo you want us there?â€

Remus meets his eyes for the first time. His beautiful eyes, on his beautiful face, wearing his beautiful suit. Itâ€™s too much really.

â€œYes,â€ he says softly.

â€œThen weâ€™ll be there.â€

He thinks about kissing him. Doesnâ€™t. But he doesnâ€™t look away either, desperate to suck the calm confidence out of Siriusâ€™s stare, to steal it for himself.

â€œWell,â€ James says eventually, â€œwe should get going, we have to be in Hogsmeade by half-past nine for the Portkey.â€

Remus shakes himself awake. â€œRight, yeah, umâ€”thank youâ€¦forâ€¦coming.â€

Jamesâ€™s face softens as he walks forward, hand squeezing Remusâ€™s shoulder. â€œYou donâ€™t need to thank us. This is what weâ€™re here for.â€

They make their way out of the room, James and Peter up front, Sirius and Remus behind, walking close enough that their shoulders brush.

When they get to the common room Remus is pulled up short for the second time that morning, Sirius landing on the stair just below him, looking up.

â€œWow, fantastic job with the suits,â€ Mary says impressed, eyes running the boys over.

Mary, Marlene and Lily are standing in the middle of the common room, each dressed in black and looking very much like theyâ€™ve been waiting for them.

Remus opens his mouth but nothing comes out except a shaky exhale. After a few more of those Sirius reaches up, squeezing his hand until Remus is able to tear his eyes away from his friends and down to hisâ€”wellâ€”down to Sirius.

â€œOkay?â€ Sirius asks.

Remus almost laughs. Almost cries. Finally he manages a nod.

â€œWell alright then,â€ Maryâ€™s voice cuts through the quiet room. â€œLets get this show on the road shall we?â€

â€œMcGonagall okay with this?â€ Remus finds himself asking as they make their way out of the common room and towards the front of the castle.

Marlene snorts. â€œLike Lily gave her a choice.â€

Remusâ€™s eyes find Lily a few paces ahead and he feels his throat grow tight. He isnâ€™t sure what he was expecting his friends to do, they hadnâ€™t talked about it, but he never could have asked them for this. Itâ€™s too much really.
As if reading his mind Sirius leans a little heavier against Remusâ€™s side, just to let him know that heâ€™s there. Theyâ€™re out to their friends but here in the halls itâ€™s easier to be a little moreâ€¦discrete.

Itâ€™s overcast today, the way it gets in the fall, making everything feel deep and saturated, the air cold. They walk down to the village in silence, Remus isnâ€™t sure if thatâ€™s his fault or not but either way he hasnâ€™t got the energy to rectify the situation. Honestly he kind of likes it, just listening to the sounds of their footsteps next his.

The Portkey is set up outside the post office, owls flying out overhead as they gather around the old satchel that McGonagall told them to look for.

â€œIs your father meeting us here or at the funeral home?â€ Lily asks gently.

Remus clears his throat. â€œHis letter said here,â€ Lily nods, though he doesnâ€™t miss the look she exchanges with Marlene. The Portkey is set to leave in fifteen minutes. Lyall is late. Not that thatâ€™s all that surprising. He usually is.

â€œIâ€™ve never been to a Muggle funeral before,â€ Peter says suddenly, voice sounding overly loud in the silence.

â€œWhat? Iâ€™m shocked,â€ Sirius drawls, earning him a shove from Peter.

â€œBoys,â€ James does his best impression of his mother, â€œdonâ€™t make me separate you.â€

Sirius smirks.

â€œI was just wondering if they were a lot different from wizard ones thatâ€™s allâ€”like, I donâ€™t know, what do you do with Muggles?â€ Peter turns to Remus who shakes his head.

â€œIâ€™ve never been to one either. Never been to any funeral.â€

â€œYou do know that muggles arenâ€™t another species, donâ€™t you Peter?â€ Mary asks, her tone a bit sharper than perhaps is warranted. Pete didnâ€™t mean anything by it, but then, he also doesnâ€™t have to walk down the halls listening to the Slytherins whisper â€œmudbloodâ€ under their breath.

Peterâ€™s cheeks flush pink. â€œNoâ€”I know, of course, I just meantâ€¦I always feel a little uncomfortable around them. I never know what to say orâ€”â€œ he cuts himself off, realizing that none of this is making the situation better.

â€œJust be polite Peter,â€ Lily says eventually, sending him a weak smile. â€œLet them talk to you about her. People like to tell stories at these things, it helps.â€

Peter nods, perhaps a bit too enthusiastically. â€œThanksâ€”yeah, er, I can do that.â€

Itâ€™s at that moment that a translucent hawk sweeps down on them, startling a yelp out of Marlene as it lands. It looks vaguely like a ghost and had Remus not seen it a dozen times before he might have been scared. Still, as it is, his stomach drops.

â€œHeld up at work,â€ his fatherâ€™s voice booms from its beak. â€œGo without me.â€

Remus blinks down at the bird, not quite able to accept what heâ€™s just heard. Waiting for the second half of the message. The â€œha, ha, just joking son, Iâ€™ll be there in ten.â€ Of course, that doesnâ€™t happen. And after a few seconds of silence the Patronus dissolves into nothing but white vapour.

Go without me.

His father does not know that Remusâ€™s friends have volunteered to come with him. As far as Lyall Lupin is aware, his son is completely alone.

Go without me.

Remusâ€™s chest suddenly feels uncomfortably tight.

â€œBastard,â€ Sirius hisses beside him.

â€œHeâ€™s scared of them,â€ Remus is impressed by how steady his voice sounds, eyes still trained on the spot where the hawk disappeared.

â€œScared of who?â€ Lily asks.

â€œHer family.â€

Sirius scoffs. â€œThan heâ€™s a coward and a bastard.â€

â€œSirius,â€ James admonishes.

â€œNo itâ€™s alright,â€ Remus finally forces himself to look up, meeting Siriusâ€™s gaze. â€œSomeone should hate him.â€ And it canâ€™t be me, he doesnâ€™t say. Because heâ€™s my dad. Because heâ€™s the only home I have left.

Sirius gives Remus a small smile, leaning into his side again as the satchel begins to light up in front of them. Remus takes a deep breath.

â€œLets get this over with yeah?â€

Thereâ€™s general nodding around the circle as they all step forward and place their hands on the bag, Sirius on one side of Remus and James on the other, like two pillars, holding him up.

If heâ€™s being honest, all forms of wizard transport make Remus feel a bit sick. Flooing. Flying. Portkeys. He hasnâ€™t apparated yet but heâ€™s sure heâ€™ll feel the same about that. When his feet slam into the pavement of the London suburb he feels the entire contents of his stomach enter his esophagus.

â€œSteady on,â€ Sirius whispers beside him, one hand on his hip, the other on his shoulder. Remus canâ€™t tell if his hands feel so good because this is new or because itâ€™s old. Sirius has never been stingy with his touches. With affection in general, at least not in superficial ways like this. Peter once suggested it was because he wasnâ€™t hugged enough as a kid and James shoved him off the bed.

â€œYou know where weâ€™re going?â€ James asks now, Remus blinking up at him through the haze of his memories.

â€œYeah,â€ Remus had been looking up the funeral home on the city map every hour since his father wrote to him with the time and place. In theory he shouldnâ€™t have needed to, in theory his father should have been here to guide him there himself, but then, maybe some subconscious part of Remus had always known that that was never going to happen.

â€œYeah,â€ Remus repeats, voice a little stronger this time. â€œI know where weâ€™re going.â€

Itâ€™s a surreal experience, walking through the Muggle suburb with his friends. They feel so loud even though they barely speak. Like every person they pass, every house, knows they donâ€™t belong.

Donâ€™t you belong?

Asks the voice in his head. He isnâ€™t James after all, isnâ€™t Sirius. Heâ€™s just as much Muggle as he is Wizard. Except it doesnâ€™t feel that way. He barely knows the Muggle part of himself.

His feet stutter as the funeral home comes into viewâ€”an unassuming building, made of redbrick and wood doors, a manicured garden in front, a parking lot full of cars he doesnâ€™t recognize wrapping around the back. His friends stop behind him.

â€œI canâ€™t do this,â€ the words are out of his mouth before he can stop himself.

â€œYou donâ€™t have to,â€ James says, at the same time that Sirius says; â€œYes, you can.â€

Remus lets out a dry laugh, because doesnâ€™t that just sum the two of them up? James always so willing to shield you, Sirius always so willing to put the sword in your hands. He finds himself turning to Peter, who stands with an uncertain look on his face, hands in his pockets.

â€œWhat do you think Pete?â€

Peterâ€™s eyes widen slightly at being asked, looking from James to Sirius and then back to Remus. â€œI think whatever you want to do is what your mum would want you to do.â€ Which is both sweet and unhelpful but thatâ€™s Peter for you.

Remus stares down the building in front of him, wishing he was somewhere else. Wishing he was someone else. Itâ€™s not a new dream.

â€œOkay,â€ he says eventually, forcing himself to relax, to breathe. â€œOkay. Lets go in.â€

Sirius squeezes his shoulder, Lily coming up beside him and taking his hand. He looks at both of them before letting out another shuddering exhale and stepping forward.

The inside of the building is beige. Beige carpet, beige wallpaper, beige furniture. It smells vaguely of rose potpourri and egg sandwiches and Remus almost immediately wants to turn around and head back out. He doesnâ€™t belong here. Heâ€™s not entirely sure where he does belong but itâ€™s definitely not here, not in this room where it feels like you canâ€™t touch anything, full of people he doesnâ€™t know.

â€œRemus?â€

He looks up and sees his aunt Mariam walking towards him, he hasnâ€™t seen her in years but when he was little she used to visit in the summer with her two kids and her husband. He never noticed before how much she looks like his mother. He squeezes Lilyâ€™s hand and she squeezes back.

â€œOh honey itâ€™s good to see you, I was beginning to worry youâ€™d gotten lost,â€ she pulls him into a hug thatâ€™s too tight, but he doesnâ€™t bother fighting it. Eventually she pulls back, hands still resting on his shoulders. Her eyes are sad, red rimmed, clearly sheâ€™s been crying. Remus doesnâ€™t know what he looks like. He hasnâ€™t cried since the day he found out.

After a few seconds she starts scanning the small crowd around him. â€œWhereâ€™s your father?â€ she doesnâ€™t quite manage to keep the bitterness out of her voice.

Remus clears his throat. â€œHeâ€”uhâ€”he got held up at work.â€ He hates his father for not giving him a better excuse.

Her gaze comes back to him. â€œHeld up at work?â€ she repeats. â€œThey couldnâ€™t let him go for his wifeâ€™s funeral?â€

Remus shrugs helplessly and he sees her expression soften again.

â€œWellâ€¦nothing to be done about it I suppose,â€ she pulls him forward, kissing the top of his head, all rather familiar for a woman he hasnâ€™t seen since he was nine. â€œCome on, the familyâ€™s waiting in the room just over here, the ceremony will start in a few minutes. Your friends can go take their seats,â€ she smiles weakly at them over Remusâ€™s shoulder, her eyes pausing on Lily. â€œUnless your girlfriend wants to come with you? Sarah might make a fuss, but she always does.â€

For a second Remus considers going along with it just so he wonâ€™t have to be alone. A second too long apparently, because he feels Sirius go stiff.

â€œUm,â€ Lily says awkwardly. â€œIâ€™m not his girlfriend.â€

â€œOh,â€ his aunt laughs. â€œSorry I just thoughtâ€¦â€ she looks down at Lilyâ€™s hand, the one Remus has been clinging to for dear life since they first walked in. â€œWell, anyway, you can all go in, Remus will join you at the reception afterwards.â€

â€œAre you sure I canâ€™t sit with them?â€ Remus says, the collar of his shirt suddenly feeling too tight.

â€œDonâ€™t be silly Remus, youâ€™re her son,â€ as though that means anything anymore. â€œBesides, you have to be up at the front with us to give your speech.â€

Ah.

Right.

That.

Part of him had been hoping theyâ€™d forget about the speech. The parchment in his pocket feeling like an anchor, dragging him below the tide.

â€œRight,â€ he manages finally.

Thereâ€™s a beat of silence.

â€œOkay well, weâ€™ll see you soon yeah?â€ James says, squeezing Remusâ€™s shoulder as he passes, Peter following closely behind, sparing Remus a sympathetic smile.

â€œYouâ€™ll be alright,â€ Lily whispers, giving him a quick kiss on the cheek.

â€œWhat she said,â€ Mary kisses him too before following after Lily, Marlene at her side.

Sirius drags behind, eyes flicking up to Remusâ€™s aunt whoâ€™s still hovering behind him, a friendly smile on her face. Eventually, after giving up hope that sheâ€™d get the hint and give them some space, he reaches out and circles Remusâ€™s wrist with his fingers.

â€œIâ€™m right here okay?â€ he whispers.

Remus nods. â€œYeah okay.â€

â€œYou can do this Remus,â€ he leans in so close their foreheads are almost touching and Remus closes his eyes briefly, breathing in the familiar scent of him.

â€œOkay,â€ Remus repeats.

â€œYour friends seem lovely,â€ his aunt says as he turns to face her.

He tries and fails to smile back. â€œThey are.â€

She guides him down a short hallway filled with generic paintings of landscapes and still life's. Everything about this place makes his skin itch. Itâ€™s tooâ€¦soft. Coddling. As though muted colours and perfume will take away the sting of losing his mother. Besides, Remus has never been good at soft. Heâ€™s all claws and teeth and scars.

â€œHere we are,â€ Mariam says as she opens a wood panelled door.

The room inside is no better than the rest of the building, worse maybe, if you take into consideration the dozen or so people dressed in black who all turn towards the door as they enter. He feels himself freeze, Mariamâ€™s hand coming down on his shoulder and giving it a squeeze.

â€œEveryone, this is Remus,â€ she says, as cheerily as she can manage.

Heâ€™s seen some of these faces beforeâ€”Mariamâ€™s children, his grandmother, his aunt Sarahâ€”but the rest of them are strangers.

Jesus, he thinks, looking around the room. Are these people supposed to be my family?

Mariam gives him a light shove into the room.

â€œNot long now until the ceremony, just make yourself comfortable okay honey?â€

He watches her walk over to a man he assumes is her husband, though he doesnâ€™t recognize him. â€œWhat the fuck happened to his face?â€ he hears someoneâ€”one of his cousins he thinksâ€”whisper as he walks past.

He tries not to let it bother him. He knows what he looks like after all. Knows itâ€™s shocking to people who havenâ€™t seen him before. Over the years heâ€™s gotten used to it, but his mum never did. She hated it when people would point them outâ€”hated answering questions, being reminded of where the marks came from. Maybe thatâ€™s why it stings so much right now.

â€œLyall not showing up then?â€

â€œUmâ€¦no, he got held up at work.â€

Remus does his best not to grimace. â€œYeah.â€

â€œHonestly, I wasnâ€™t expecting him to come,â€ she goes on eventually, pulling his gaze back to her. â€œAlways was a bloody coward. Never faced up to anything.â€

Remus wants to feel indignant, but, well, she isnâ€™t exactly wrong, is she?

â€œBut then, I wasnâ€™t expecting to see you either.â€

That takes him by surprise. â€œMe?â€ he asks. And then, stupidly; â€œSheâ€™s my mum.â€

â€œWas,â€ the word is sharp, meant to hurt. And it does.

â€œYouâ€™ve always been more his than herâ€™s,â€ Sarah goes on unfairly. Remus puts his mug back down on the table, certain that if he doesnâ€™t heâ€™ll end up smashing it on something.

â€œI would have gotten her away from him eventually. I would have made her see sense. â€œSo he knocked her up with you,â€ Sarah goes on bitterly. â€œThere was nothing any of us could do after that.â€

Without thinking Remus reaches out and grabs hold of the table next to him, holding himself steady. The air suddenly feels too thin, the walls too close, too many people, too many strangers who know too much about him.

Heâ€™s saved from having to come up with some sort of response by the sound of the door opening, everyone turning as the Pastor enters the room in his black robes. Sarah gives him one last cold look before pulling away.

Remus wonders, as he struggles to get his breathing under control, if that made her feel better.

â€œItâ€™s good to see you all, though unfortunate that it should be under such tragic circumstances,â€ the Pastorâ€”an older gentleman with thinning grey hair and a kind faceâ€”gathers everyone around him. â€œAh,â€ thankfully, he doesnâ€™t seem to feel the need to ask anymore questions. â€œNo problem. No problem at all. Now, are we ready?â€

â€œAlright then, if youâ€™ll all follow meâ€¦â€

â€œOh thank Merlinâ€”Remus,â€ he hears as he enters the lobby, looking up at the sound of his name to find Alice and Frank standing by the front door.

â€œBut youâ€™reâ€”but the Aurors, I thoughtâ€”I thought you didnâ€™t get days off?â€ he stammers.

Family emergency.

Family emergency.

â€œThank you,â€ he manages finally, voice choked as his eyes move from Alice to Frank, trying to make them understand how much this means, knowing that he canâ€™t possibly.

â€œRemus?â€

â€œGo on,â€ Alice gives his arm another good squeeze.

They slide into the front pew, Remus thankfully on the end so the only person he has to sit next to is Mariam. You took her for granted, whispers the nasty voice in his head. You thought she would always be there. Thought she belonged to you. Existed for you.

He clenches his teeth, trying to focus on the Pastor instead of his spiralling thoughts.

â€œâ€”was a warm, compassionate and vibrant woman who always went out of her way to help othersâ€”no matter what,â€ the old man is saying.

The problem is, Remus had taken his mother for granted. Sheâ€™d made him her whole life and it had never occurred to him that before he was born, before the accident with Greyback, all that time she spent worrying about him she had filled with something else. With someone else.

â€œO Divine Master,â€ the Pastor goes on, â€œGrant that I may not so much seek to be consoled as to console; To be understood as to understand; to be loved, as to love; For it is in giving that we receive; It is in pardoning that we are pardoned; And it is in dying that we are born to eternal life.â€

Was his mother religious? Heâ€™d never seen her pray, never been made to say grace at the tableâ€”not that his father would have allowed it. Far too Muggle. The lights dim as a white projector screen is pulled down at the front of the chapel and suddenly his motherâ€™s face appearsâ€”younger and happier than Remus had ever seen it. Some song he doesnâ€™t recognize plays in the background.

His mother has a bob with bangs, she has freckles on her cheeks that are squished up against her sisterâ€™s face, her front tooth is missing. He barely recognizes her.

â€œOh,â€ he hears Mariam coo beside him, looking over to find her face streaked with tears. He wonders what sheâ€™s thinking about, what memories she has of his mum. All the stories he hasnâ€™t heard. And suddenly he has a horrible sinking feeling that everyone knew his mother better than he did.

The pictures fade into one another, his mother slowly growing olderâ€”a teenager in floral dresses, her hair down to her waist. A university student at a Christmas party covered in tinsel. Walking across a stage in a cap and gown, holding a diploma proudly in front of her. Remus has no idea what she studied. He never asked.

In all these photos his mother is smiling, face free of the nervous cracks that heâ€™d grown so used to, the ones that never really went away no matter how genuinely happy she seemed. The woman in these photos is beaming. Sheâ€™s light.

The final photo is of his parents on their wedding day. His father is wearing wizard dress robes but theyâ€™re black and white so they could easily be explained away as some new suit styleâ€”or so Remus expects. His mother looks like a paintingâ€”hair braided, dress covered in lace, blooming out around her like sheâ€™s in the centre of a cloud. His father peers at the Muggle camera uncertainly, but his mother is still smiling. Remus wonders if that was the last time she would be that happy. That carefree.

The lights slowly come up again, an older woman hobbling onto the stage behind the Pastor and pulling on the screen several times before sheâ€™s able to send it zipping back up into the ceiling.

â€œWell that was certainly beautiful. What a lovely soul,â€ the old man says, looking out at the tear stained audience. â€œAnd now, we will be hearing a few words from her son, Remus John Lupin.â€

Oh.

Remusâ€™s heart drops into the pit of his stomach as he feels all the eyes in the room fall on him. Heâ€™s never wanted to be able to apparate so badly in his entire life.

On shaking legs he rises to his feet, stumbling up to the lectern where the Pastor gives him a fatherly pat on the back before shuffling off to the side, leaving Remus to face the room alone. His throat feels tight, the air suddenly too dry as he reaches into his pocket and smooths out the parchment heâ€™s been clutching all day.

â€œUmâ€”â€œ he starts, the faces in the seats in front of him going blurry, he clears his throat, rubbing at his eyes, but it doesnâ€™t help. His whole body suddenly feels like itâ€™s blurring, something left out in the rain, all his colours running together.

How is he meant to talk about his mum when he didnâ€™t even know her? When heâ€™d never tried to? Something starts scratching at the inside of his skin and he brings his hand up to the base of his throat to keep the sobs from being able to escape. He just needs another chanceâ€”to speak to her, to listen, to let her tell him all the stories he never asked about. Never made her feel important enough to share.

Heâ€™s been standing up here silent for too long, he tries to open his mouth again but quickly shuts it, afraid of what might come out. He should have told them this was a terrible ideaâ€”he doesnâ€™t give speeches, doesnâ€™t cut himself open in front of crowds of strangers. I mean, God, he can barely open up to the people he trusts.

He grips the lectern like itâ€™s the last life raft in the middle of the ocean, forcing himself to look at the page in front of him. To say something.

Then, in the distance, he sees someone get up. Three someoneâ€™s, actually. Silently, James, Sirius and Peter make their way down the aisle, like itâ€™s the most natural thing in the world. Not one of them looks uncertain, or like they arenâ€™t sure whether or not itâ€™s allowed, and Remus watches them. Desperate.

The minute theyâ€™re close enough Siriusâ€™s hand finds his lower back, Jamesâ€™s on his shoulder, Peterâ€™s circling his wrist, the three of them crowding around him. Remus feels himself sag into their touches. Into the warmth of their bodies. The comfort of it.

Home, he thinks.

This is home.

They donâ€™t speak. They donâ€™t need to.

â€œMy mum,â€ he hears himself say finally, words filling up the room, â€œliked to sing Billie Holiday when she baked.â€

Â 

The reception is in a small room connected to the chapel. The coffin is in there. His mum. His mumâ€™s coffin. Remus doesnâ€™t look at it. Instead he looks at the dozen or so tiny triangle sandwiches on black plastic trays.

Remus snorts.

â€œExcept they donâ€™t have peanut butter and jelly,â€ Peter says morosely, picking up a ham sandwich and glaring down at it.

â€œReally?â€ Jamesâ€™s eyes start scanning the table in front of him. â€œSeems like an oversight on their part.â€

â€œHonestly, itâ€™s the best one.â€

â€œAgreed.â€

â€œOi!â€

Remus smiles despite himself, not really paying attention to the food heâ€™s putting on his plate, he doesnâ€™t expect heâ€™ll be eating any of it, he just wants something to do with his hands.

â€œYou doing okay?â€ Sirius asks quietly, leaning against the wall next to him. People mill about around them, making small talk, the constant hum of â€œIâ€™m sorry for your lossâ€ filling the room. â€œHey?â€ Sirius nudges his foot.

â€œIs what supposed to help?â€

â€œBeing here. Doing this. Is it supposed to help? Because I donâ€™t feel any betterâ€”I donâ€™t feel like I have closure or whatever the fuck this is supposed to be. Itâ€™s justâ€”â€ he shakes his head, â€œItâ€™s like Iâ€™m being crushed by something. By the weight of this.â€

Sirius is silent for a moment. â€œI donâ€™t think anything helps,â€ he says eventually, causing Remus to look up. Sirius is watching him, eyes full, overflowing, but with what Remus canâ€™t tell. Something like affection butâ€¦more. â€œThis is a big hurt Moony.â€

Remus laughs at that. â€œA big hurt,â€ he repeats, scrubbing at his eyes with the hand that isnâ€™t currently holding a paper plate full of food he doesnâ€™t want to eat. â€œThat sounds about right.â€

â€œStuff like thisâ€¦â€ Sirius shrugs, hands slipping into his pockets. â€œIt doesnâ€™t get fixed. Doesnâ€™t getâ€¦put down, not for a long time. You just learn how to carry it.â€

Remus looks at him for a minute before shaking his head. â€œJesus, Sirius Black when did you get so wise?â€

â€œPfft, that old hack? He ainâ€™t got nothing on me.â€

And suddenly Remus feels the desperate need to be closer to him, to wrap himself in Siriusâ€™s smell and his warmth and his weight. â€œThanks for coming, for doing this, I know itâ€™sâ€¦not the most convenient thing.â€

Sirius gives him a weird look. â€œRemus,â€ he tilts his head a little closer. â€œIt wouldnâ€™t matter if her funeral was on the top of bloody Mount Everest, we would still be here.â€

Why? Remus almost asksâ€”has been dying to ask everyone all day. Why are you here? Itâ€™s how heâ€™d felt first year too, when James and Sirius started sitting with him at meals even when they didnâ€™t go down to the Great Hall together. You could be friends with anyone, heâ€™d thought, why on earth would you choose me?

He never did ask.

He doesnâ€™t ask now.

Sirius wouldnâ€™t understand.

Everyone has always wanted Sirius, even when they were kids. Sirius Black walks down the hallway and people look up, move closer. Some kind of primal instinct pulling them in. Lyallâ€™s voice echoes through Remusâ€™s head:

I thought it would be different.

Remus doesnâ€™t know what his father wants. But it certainly isnâ€™t him. Wasnâ€™t his mother. His eyes go back to the coffin.

â€œDo you want to see her?â€ Sirius asks softly, and Remus feels his heart drop.

â€œIt doesnâ€™t feel real,â€ he croaks, not looking at Sirius as his throat grows tight. â€œNone of this feels real. I think thereâ€™s a part of my brain that still thinks sheâ€™s back at home, you know?â€ He tries to swallow. â€œBut if I see herâ€”if I look at her faceâ€”â€œ

â€œItâ€™ll be real,â€ Sirius finishes.

Remus nods slowly. â€œIâ€™m not sure I want it to be, Iâ€™d rather pretend she ran away. Finally told my dad to fuck off and now sheâ€™s out there somewhere on some wild adventure.â€

He likes that idea. His mother on the highway in a red convertible, the top down, a silk handkerchief in her hair. Smiling the way she used toâ€”the way she had in all those photos.

â€œMaybe she is.â€

PART II: JAMES

Old habits die hard.

Itâ€™s not that heâ€™s looking for Lily. At least not consciously. But for an embarrassing number of years he was in the habit of knowing where she was at all times. The map did not help with that obsession. So, if heâ€™s being honest with himself, the reason he ends up outside, walking through the parking lot of the funeral home, is because part of his brain has trained itself to find her.

And he doesâ€”leaning against the brick wall by the dumpsters.

â€œHell sticks again, really?â€ he finds himself saying, bringing those green eyes in his direction, a cloud of smoke blowing out of the corner of her mouth.

â€œI swear I havenâ€™t had any since this summer,â€ she says, James taking up the wall space beside her.

â€œWhatever you say Evans.â€

She snorts, looking back out at the cars. Thereâ€™s a cool breeze that pushes against them, moving the clouds overhead, letting beams of sunlight filter through.

Lily looks down at her hand, turning the cigarette over between her fingers. â€œBeing in there,â€ she says finally, â€œjust reminded me of my dad is all.â€

James blinks. â€œOh,â€ because like an idiot heâ€™d gone and forgotten that Lilyâ€™s dad was dead. â€œAreâ€”was his funeral like this?â€ he nods at the building behind them.

Lily takes a drag from her cigarette, still not looking at James as she tilts her head back and blows the smoke up into the air. The smell burns Jamesâ€™s nose and the back of his throat but he refuses to cough.

â€œI donâ€™t know,â€ Lily says finally.

â€œYou donâ€™t know?â€ James repeats confused, pushing his glasses up so that he can rub at his eyes. â€œBecause it was so long ago you mean? Like you canâ€™t remember?â€

Lily smiles dryly. â€œNo.â€

Jamesâ€™s glasses fall back into place and he stares at her, red hair lose, hanging down her back, freckles paler than they were this the summer. He supposes thatâ€™s the Scottish countrysideâ€™s doing. Too bad, heâ€™s always liked her freckles.

She takes another deep pull of her cigarette before she continues. â€œI didnâ€™t go to my dadâ€™s funeral. Miscommunication orâ€”lack of communication I guess,â€ James has no idea what to say to that, but luckily Lily doesnâ€™t let him suffer for too long. â€œItâ€™s hard for Muggles to get in contact with wizards, and it was still all so new to us back then.â€

Her voice is calm, steady, but her eyesâ€”James feels himself ache for her.

â€œShit Lily,â€ he says softly. Sheâ€™s looking right at him now, stare burning, too hot to hold. There were years when he would have done anything for this, to have her attention for even a second. Years when he DID do anythingâ€”stunts and grande romantic gestures. The irony, he supposes, is that all he ever needed to do was this.

Eventually Lily looks away again, leaving James a little breathless, like someone whoâ€™s just stepped back from the edge of a cliff.

â€œIt is what it is,â€ she shrugs.

As Sirius Blackâ€™s best mate, James can spot a forced shrug a mile away.

â€œWere you close, you and your dad?â€

She bites down on her lip, flipping the ash off the end of her cigarette with the tip of her thumb. James doesnâ€™t think heâ€™ll ever get over how bloody cool she looks with those things. He definitely canâ€™t let Sirius see her.

â€œYeah, we were close,â€ she says finally, â€œas close as you can be with your parents anyway, butâ€¦â€ she trails off for a second, â€œmaybe that would have changed, the longer I spent at Hogwarts.â€

James feels his brow furrow. â€œWhat dâ€™you mean, he didnâ€™t like magic?â€

Lily laughs, â€œNo, no he loved magic actually. God, I donâ€™t know who was more excited when I got my letter, me or him. He was absolutely obsessed, used to make me tell him everything we learned, show him all my school supplies,â€ she smiles scuffing her shoes against the asphalt. â€œYou should have seen the way his face lit up the first time we went to Diagon Alley, I thought he was going to burst.â€

Now James laughs. â€œHe sounds brilliant.â€

â€œYeah,â€ she nods. â€œHe was. He saw theâ€”I donâ€™t knowâ€”the fun in life, you know?â€

â€œYeah.â€

But then something comes over her face, heâ€™d call it a shadow but that wouldnâ€™t be quite right. Itâ€™s something heavy, something that anchors down the corners of her smile.

â€œIt builds walls between you though, between you and the people you love,â€ she says eventually, looking down at the cigarette in her hand before flicking it off into the distance.

â€œWhat does?â€ James asks.

She looks up at him, green eyes bright. â€œGoing places they canâ€™t follow.â€

Lily Evans is a powerful witch, even when she isnâ€™t using her wand. The strength in those words vibrates through James like theyâ€™re hands on his shoulders, shaking him.

â€œIâ€™m sorry,â€ he finds himself saying, wishing he had more.

Lily only shakes her head, giving him a sad smile. â€œDonâ€™t be. We all make sacrifices for magic. I wouldnâ€™t change it. Wouldnâ€™t give it back. Not even for my family,â€ she wrinkles her nose. â€œDoes that make me sound horrible?â€

James shakes his head. â€œNo,â€ and then; â€œMakes you sound pretty fucking ruthless though.â€

That gets a proper laugh out Lily, loud and full, bouncing off the walls around them. â€œIâ€™ll take itâ€”ruthlessâ€”I like that.â€

James smiles back. â€œGood.â€

They stand in silence for a minute, both looking out at the parking lot in front of them and the street beyond that, cars speeding along the road like comets. James is always surprised by how big the Muggle world feels, how full of strangers. Thereâ€™s no anonymity amongst wizards, not really. Everyone is connected to everyone else and if youâ€™re not, well, thatâ€™s itâ€™s own identity.

â€œHowâ€™s Remus doing?â€ Lily asks eventually, startling James out of his thoughts.

â€œRemus?â€ he repeats. â€œMerlin, I donâ€™t know, hard to tell with him, he keeps everything pretty tightly bottled,â€ he takes a moment, running a hand through his hair. â€œHeâ€™s doing better than I would be, Iâ€™ll tell you that. If my mum wasâ€”â€œ he canâ€™t say it. Canâ€™t even think it, a shiver running through his whole body. â€œHonestly I donâ€™t how heâ€™s still standing.â€

â€œI think Remus expects the worst,â€ Lily says simply. â€œMakes it easier to handle when it happensâ€”not easy, butâ€¦â€

Chapter End Notes

Hi! Hello! Hey!

Chapter 25

Chapter Summary

Everything is stressful from here on out.

You are my happy.

He hadnâ€™t meant to say it. Heâ€™d been half-asleep. Unfair of James really, being all sentimental around him in that state.

He hadnâ€™t meant to say it. He had meant it though. In retrospect, that was the real problem. He needed to end this. He knew that. The Mark on his arm a ticking clock. Regulus does his best not to grimace, wand still in his hand. â€œRight, okay. That was really good Mary.â€

Her eyes squeeze shut, teeth shattering from the pain. â€œCan I get that potion now?â€

â€œYeah, of course,â€ he lifts his wand. â€œIâ€™m sorry.â€

â€œWhat?â€

â€œObliviate.â€

Her face goes blank. All the tension from the pain and fear dropping away. Regulus lifts his wand again.

â€œI really am sorryâ€”Legilimens.â€

The thing is, theyâ€™re going to ask her questions. Pomfrey. McGonagall. Dumbledore even. A student shows up to the infirmary unconscious and brutalized? This doesnâ€™t just go away, and a blank memory is almost as dangerous as a fully intact one. So he needs to replace it. For once in his life being his motherâ€™s son actually comes in handy. Heâ€™s seen Walburga mess with enough peopleâ€™s headsâ€”mess with his ownâ€”that heâ€™s picked up a few tricks.

He forces his way into her head. Sheâ€™s weak and doesnâ€™t seem to know Occlumency so it isnâ€™t hard, her memories fluttering around him, like heâ€™s standing in a room full of butterflies, snippets of voices and faces coming in and out of focus. Itâ€™s always best to build on something real, so he focuses on her most recent memories, pulling them before him. It takes a heroic amount of mental energy to control someone elseâ€™s thoughts and he knows he wonâ€™t be able to maintain this for long. He needs to act fast.

Everything is a bit distorted because of the Imperio, the moments in the dorm room few and far between. Most of the night just black. Regulus wonders if thatâ€™s because she was slowly pushing back against the curse. If the moments of blurry memory are her coming back to the surface.

Heâ€™s Obliviated the last hour or so, meaning she has no memory of coming fully back to herself, of fighting with Barty or Mulciber. But there is the memory of her getting cursed. Regulus grabs hold of it, watching as Barty walks towards her.

Hey Macdonald?

It sounds like Regulus is listening to them under water.

Get lost creep.

Aw, come on, donâ€™t be like that. Listen, I came to apologize.

Yeah, sure you did.

In the background Regulusâ€”and more importantly, Maryâ€”can see Snape, Mulciber, and Avery. He doesnâ€™t know where Evan is but thatâ€™s all for the better. Using every ounce of control he has Regulus pauses the memory like a video recording. He surveys the faces in the background, thinking. It would be so incredibly satisfying to frame Snape. But heâ€™s too clever, heâ€™d figure out what was happening, find a way out, hell, maybe even find a way to turn it around on Regulus. No. He needs someone stupid enough not to realize whatâ€™s happening until itâ€™s too late. Or even better, someone stupid enough to want to take credit for this.

Like wading through water he pushes through Maryâ€™s memory, grabbing hold of Mulciber and moving him into Bartyâ€™s spot, covering the first boy completely. Dispersing him like smoke. The image before Regulus flickers but he holds it tight, refusing to let go of the reins.

Hey Macdonald?

Mulciber walks towards her.

Get lost creep.

Aw, come on, donâ€™t be like that. Listen, I came to apologize.

Regulus watches the whole thing play out again. Watches Mulciber move further and further into Maryâ€™s space. Watches him pull out his wand, watches him Imperio her. Watches Maryâ€™s memory shake and blur and fade to black. The voice isnâ€™t quite right, still a bit too high for Mulciber, but thereâ€™s nothing he can do about that, he hasnâ€™t the time or the skill to fix it.

Taking a deep breath he pulls back, catching himself on his hands and knees as the corridor reforms around him. He blinks the spots out of his vision, breathing heavy as he turns to find Mary slumped against the wall, eyes closed again. He checks her pulse just to be certain sheâ€™s still okay, and then gets to his feet.

The world spins for a moment and he worries that heâ€™s going to pass out, but somehow he manages to keep hold of his consciousness. After a few more seconds he turns his wand on himself and casts a new Disillusionment charm, the old one having faded. Then he knocks on the infirmary door and starts walking.

Heâ€™s nearly at the end of the hall when he hears the door open.

â€œThis better be important ifâ€”oh, oh sweetheart, whatâ€™s happened to you?â€

Regulus doesnâ€™t stop. Doesnâ€™t turn around. Even as the horror in Pomfreyâ€™s voice trembles through him. The blood on his hands suddenly burning hot.

He wonders if heâ€™ll ever get the stains out.

Chapter End Notes

Â Hello beautiful people!

Yeesh, like I know there are some intense chapters in this fic but this one felt particularly intense, maybe that's just me though...

I feel like Mary's attack is one of those things that is sometimes treated casually but tbh the idea of going to school with wizard Nazi's sounds terrifying so I wanted to kind of show how magic makes the situation more dangerous but hopefully it wasn't too much

THANK YOU FOR READING AND COMMENTING ect. ect. Hope you're all having a great day/night/whatever time it is where you are!

Â 

**Hi, hello, it is Soph from the future. I was asked on my tumblr why I chose to involve Reg in Mary's attack and a few people thought it would be helpful if I posted the answer here so I'm going to do that below for those of you who are interested in reading it (it's kind of long so I apologize):

I think thereâ€™s this thing that happens in fanfics or fandom or honestly in the HP books (where Snape is concerned) of having characters who are Death Eaters who never do anything wrong except becoming a Death Eater (does that make sense?) Like theyâ€™re portrayed as joining the club but never participating in any of the group activities and therefore weâ€™re allowed to like them. And I think thatâ€™s a problem, because it sets up this narrative that you can be, y'know, a Nazi, or a white supremacist, or whatever real life group you wanna use in this metaphor, and still be a fundamentally moral person and I disagree with that.

If you are in anyway supporting and standing with this group you are morally compromised. And so I wanted to make clear that Regulus is not someone who does the right thing all the time (or who even knows what the right thing is) or who holds the right views or a healthy outlook on life. Because if those things are true than this story goes very differently. Then he never becomes a Death Eater, then he is essentially Sirius.

It was also a way of holding the audience accountable, like weâ€™re out here rooting for this kid (and I think there are lots of reasons to root for Regulus I really do) but this kid becomes a Death Eater and you donâ€™t get to act like that doesnâ€™t mean something. This fic was meant to flesh Regulus out, to give him depth, but part of that includes him being a character you cannot love unproblematically.

I really wanted to avoid skipping over the Death Eater thing which, again, I think happens a lot in this fandom. I love a morally grey character. I love an arc. I love that Regulus switches sides at the end. But that doesnâ€™t mean there isnâ€™t still ugly stuff and that ugly stuff is not going to be forgivable to some people and that ugly stuff should make you feel uncomfortable. Even if ultimately I would like people to root for Regulus, it should be difficult. Because being a Death Eater is not insignificant and it should never be considered so, and you cannot become one and not have that effect the decisions that you make and the way you treat people.

It would have been too easy to have Regulus handle that situation perfectly and be like â€œlook, he might be a Death Eater but heâ€™s a good Death Eaterâ€ like thereâ€™s no such thing. And when you start to act like there is you are romanticizing bigotry, which is something I think Jegulus gets accused of a lot and something that I wanted to confront head on and not shy away from.

Ok, I hope that makes sense. I also donâ€™t know that I actually managed to do any of the things I wanted to by approaching the story this way, but this is what I was trying for anyway!

Chapter 26

Chapter Notes

tw/cw: Sexual content (I wanna say that this is like YA level sexual content, I could be wrong but I feel like that's accurate)

See the end of the chapter for more notes

PART I: LILY

The friendship of Lily Evans and Mary Macdonald began under a bed. Lilyâ€™s bed, to be exact. See, sheâ€™d been having a bad day. It was first year and everything was justâ€¦a littleâ€¦much. She missed her mum and dad, back then she even missed Petunia, and Severus was there but he wasnâ€™t there-there. He was in Slytherin. After the sorting Lily had briefly considered begging the hat to put her in Slytherin too. Especially after being placed in the same house as Black and Potter. There hadnâ€™t been any posh kids at her old school but they were about as obnoxious and self-obsessed as she had expected. And Potter was so gaga for Gryffindor that she was certain it would be filled with people just like him.

In the end, however, Lily had not had the guts to ask anything of the sorting hat, so she had remained in Gryffindor. And mostly that had been okayâ€”posh bespectacled prats aside. Her roommates were nice, her classes were fun, and she did rather like not living in a dungeon. But she was alsoâ€¦lonely. And out of place. And uncomfortable. There were so many things that the kids around herâ€”even if they werenâ€™t Purebloodsâ€”seemed to know, and it felt impossible trying to keep up with it all. Severus did his best to help her along but she could tell that he was sometimes a little bit embarrassed by her. That was the worst feeling honestly.

One afternoon, at the end of September, for no reason in particular, it had all just felt too much. So sheâ€™d crawled under her bed, trying to make the world smaller. Easier to manage. About fifteen minutes into her pity party Mary had walked in. Lily watched her feet, listened to the David Bowie song she hummed under her breath. Her and Mary had barely exchanged more than a few sentences but she was secretly Lilyâ€™s favourite roommate, if only because she was the one who reminded Lily the most of home. The posters she hung on the walls were all of people Lily recognized and they didnâ€™t move or talk, plus, sometimes she would complain about things that Lily could relate toâ€”like missing ballpoint pens and three-ringed binders.

Sheâ€™s not sure, to this day, what compelled her to speak then. Surely the smart thing to do would have been to remain silent and hope that her new roommate wouldnâ€™t notice her having a complete and utter mental breakdown. But being quiet had never been Lilyâ€™s strong suit.

â€œDo you have records?â€ she wondered out loud.

â€œAh!â€ Mary shouted, her feet stumbling back into her bed. â€œJesus Christ, Lily? Is that you?â€

â€œItâ€™s just that Iâ€™ve never seen you play any but you hum them all the time,â€ she said in lieu of an answer.

â€œWhere the hell are you?â€ Mary demanded.

â€œAt home I have a bunch of records but my mum wouldnâ€™t let me bring them, she didnâ€™t know how safe it would be here and she was worried theyâ€™d get stolen, not that Wizards are dying for Muggle music but, of course, she didnâ€™t know that. Still doesnâ€™t know, I supposeâ€”â€œ

â€œLily,â€ Mary said harshly. â€œDid you get turned invisible or something?â€

â€œWhat? Oh,â€ Lily blinked. â€œNo, Iâ€™m not invisible.â€

â€œThen why the hell can I hear you prattling on but thereâ€™s not a single freckle in my line of vision?â€

Lily scowled up at the bottom of her bed. â€œI donâ€™t have that many freckles.â€

â€œUh-huh and the Giant Squid doesnâ€™t have that many legs.â€

â€œDid you justâ€”â€œ

â€œWhere are you?â€ she was beginning to sound genuinely exasperated, but to be honest, Lily quite liked being a disembodied voice. It was freeing

â€œIâ€™m under here,â€ she said eventually, and with great reluctance.

â€œUnderâ€”oh honestly,â€ some shuffling later Mary was kneeling on the floor and peering at Lily under the bed.

What the hell are you doing, is what Lily expected her to say. If it had been Petunia â€œfreakâ€ might even have been thrown in there somewhere. But the thing about Maryâ€”the beautiful, fantastic, brilliant thing about Maryâ€”was that she never did what you were expecting.

â€œI see,â€ is what she actually said, before sliding under the bed to lie right alongside Lily. â€œWhatâ€™s happened then? You and your boyfriend have a fight?â€

â€œBoyfriend?â€ Lily repeated confused, and then; â€œOhâ€”OHâ€”no. Sev isnâ€™tâ€”we arenâ€™tâ€”weâ€™re just friends.â€ Though her face blushed so furiously it burned.

Mary turned her head to look at Lily, brow arched. â€œReally? Then you two might want to stop making googly-eyes at one another all the time.â€

â€œWe donâ€™t do that!â€ Lily said almost desperately.

â€œYou do.â€

â€œDonâ€™t.â€

â€œDo.â€

â€œDonâ€™t.â€

â€œDo.â€

â€œDonâ€™t infinity.â€

Mary rolled her eyes. â€œWhatever. So if thatâ€™s not why youâ€™re under here, what is?â€

Lily chewed on her lip, looking back up at the bottom of her bed. â€œI just thinkâ€¦I donâ€™t knowâ€¦that someone made a mistake.â€

â€œProbably, but youâ€™ll have to be more specific.â€

At eleven Maryâ€™s dry sense of humour was largely lost on Lily. Mary would later credit her wit to her childhood obsession with Monty Python.

â€œI just donâ€™t think Iâ€™m supposed to be a witch.â€

Lily didnâ€™t have to turn her head to know that Mary was staring at her. â€œWhat do you mean â€œsupposed to beâ€ ? You ARE a witch?â€

Lily let out a frustrated noise. â€œBut Iâ€™m not really though, am I? Iâ€™m a Muggle.â€

â€œThat is literally not true.â€

â€œYes, but I know Muggle things and I like Muggle things and I donâ€™t know anything about Wizards really. Mary continued to stare at her for long enough that Lily started to squirm. She had rather been hoping that out of everyone Mary would understand.

â€œDid you know that the Gryffindor Quidditch team is almost always Half-Bloods and Purebloods?â€ the other girl said suddenly.

Lily blinked, adjusting to this change in topic. â€œIâ€”no, no I didnâ€™t.â€

Mary nodded. â€œAnd even when there are Muggle-borns theyâ€™re always seventh years, because it takes them that long to pick up the game,â€ her voice was determined. â€œNot me though, Iâ€™m gonna get it in three. Lily shook her head and Mary inched a little closer. â€œTo piss them the fuck off.â€

At that time swearing was still rather new to Lily so she actually gasped, and after several moments of shocked silence managed to stammer; â€œThem?â€

Mary waved her hands above her as much as the bed would allow. â€œThe powers that be, the system, the Man. The snooty Purebloods. Because I am every bit as much a Witch as they are,â€ her eyes locked onto Lilyâ€™s, â€œand so are you.â€

After that theyâ€™d gone to the Great Hall and only eaten dessert for dinner and eventually Marlene had joined them and Lily had felt better and by Christmas she didnâ€™t want to leave. Â 

The bruises take time to show up. When they do Lily waves them away with the flick of her wand. Theyâ€™re blue and yellow, on Maryâ€™s wrists, her neck, her jaw. They look like flower petals. Like fingerprints.

â€œPfft,â€ Mary scoffs, propping her pillow up behind her and then carefully leaning herself against it. Itâ€™s clear that sheâ€™s in pain. â€œIf Iâ€™m going to die young it better be because I overdosed at an orgy or something, not because some twats Imperiused me while I wasnâ€™t looking.â€

â€œThey what?â€ Marleneâ€™s eyes grow to about twice their normal size.

â€œMerlinâ€”what the hell,â€ Severus says from the ground.

â€œNO,â€ Severus says more fiercely.

Okay.

â€œYeah,â€ she croaks eventually, â€œme too.â€

PART II: REGULUS

Regulus is on edge, but no one comes for him. He isnâ€™t called into any offices, isnâ€™t interrogated by any teachers. Or Aurors for that matter. The day actually starts out rather normal. The only signs that something is wrong are the missing faces from the Gryffindor table during breakfast. No Marlene McKinnon, no Lily Evans, no James Potter or Sirius Black or Peter Pettigrew. No Mary Macdonald.

As the day goes on the rumours start to filter through the school. Theyâ€™re vague. Mary Macdonald is in the infirmary. Someoneâ€™s jealous girlfriend took revenge. No, actually, it was a Quidditch accident. Sheâ€™d been drinking and fallen off the astronomy tower. Sheâ€™d been outside after dark and gotten attacked by a werewolf. That one Regulus finds particularly funny because a) as if there could be a werewolf at Hogwarts that no one knew about and b) last night was not a full moon. Regardless, with every reiteration the story gets further and further from the truth and Regulus feels himself start to relax. Maybe this whole thing will blow over?

Then dinner happens.

Itâ€™s not that he doesnâ€™t enjoy watching Snape get his ass handed to him, he really does. The problem is that almost immediately after McGonagall drags Lily Evans away the tone of the rumours start to shift. Mary Macdonald is in the infirmary because of Severus Snape, people start to whisper. Which is not, by and large, a story that Regulus has a problem with, except that itâ€™s just close enough to the truth to bring back the pressure behind his ribs.

It is at that moment, with his anxiety on the rise again, that Remus Lupin decides to show up.

â€œEmpty charms classroom, third floor, fifteen minutes,â€ thatâ€™s all he says before walking away.

Regulus had been hoping theyâ€™d forget about the Veritaserum in the wake of Maryâ€™s attack. But apparently not. Itâ€™s not possible to disobey the Veritaserumâ€”well, at least not if its been made by any kind of competent potioneerâ€”but it is possible to control it to some extent. Because James always asks.

Always.

Weak.

Chapter End Notes

Hello beautiful people!

I really liked the idea of developing the James/Mary friendship so hopefully you guys liked it too!

Chapter 28

Chapter Summary

Dumbledore is not a great guy. Thanks for coming to my TED Talk.

Chapter Notes

TW: referenced / implied sexual assault

**French translation in the end notes!**

ALSO: I feel like I've said this before but Reg is not a reliable narrator. Just because he as a character doesn't really see the difference between the Death Eaters and the Order doesn't mean I'm arguing that there isn't a difference, like there is. There very much is. Very important difference. They are not equally in the wrong just because Dumbledore is a dick. This is not a Death Eater apologist fic. Just wanna make sure that's clear.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Over the years Regulus has, in passing, spoken to Mary Macdonald. Never for any great length of time or about anything important, but theyâ€™re only a year apart, in the same school, on opposing Quidditch teams. It happens. But neither of them has ever sought the other out, and he is more than certain they have never spoken alone.

Despite all that, when he walks out of Transfiguration and sees her leaning against the wall across from his classroom, he knows that sheâ€™s there for him. He considers, for one pathetic second, running away. He doesnâ€™t. But itâ€™s a near thing.

â€œHello,â€ he says, stopping in front of her, she holds his gaze unabashedly.

A moment passes before she cocks her head to the side, â€œover here,â€ and then starts walking.

Once again Regulus feels the strong urge to turn in the opposite direction and run for it. Once heâ€™s inside she flicks her wand, slamming the door shut behind them before she jumps up onto the teacherâ€™s desk at the front of the class. If sheâ€™s nervous she doesnâ€™t show it. â€œYes, alright, but you knew it was him that lead me to you?â€

â€œHe was asking me questions the other day. I think my brother has prejudiced him against me,â€ Regulus is careful to keep his voice as neutral as possible. â€œNo doubt they would both happily blame me for every shitty thing that happens at this school.â€

â€œMy tone?â€ he repeats skeptically.

â€œMmhm,â€ she places her hands on the edge of her desk and leans forward. â€œSo tell me Reggie Black, when did you and James Potter become friends and why the hell does he want me to tell Dumbledore that I didnâ€™t see you the night I was attacked?â€

â€œI thought you said he tried to be subtle?â€ Regulus says, instead of addressing any of the other numerous points she brought up.

Regulus groans internally. â€œI suppose thatâ€™s fair.â€

â€œSo?â€

â€œSo?â€ Regulus repeats back at her, a bit more childishly than he would like to admit.

â€œJames seems to think that I can help you, and maybe I can, but not until you start explaining this situation to me.â€

â€œWhat situation?â€ he asks, because he has no intention of revealing anymore to her than she already knows.

She considers him for a minute, legs swinging so that the backs of her heels are banging irritatingly into the desk sheâ€™s sitting on. Regulus doesnâ€™t see why she has to sit on the desk at all when thereâ€™s a classroom full of empty chairs surrounding them.

â€œLets start with James.â€

Oh goodie.

â€œWhat about him?â€

She rolls her eyes. â€œYou two. Youâ€™reâ€¦friends? Or what? Because the last time I checked you and your brother were not on good terms and James and Sirius are practically attached at the hip soâ€¦? What gives?â€

The only thing that stings more than knowing that James will never be his, is knowing that he will always be Siriusâ€™s. A fact heâ€™s reminded of in this school almost daily. Itâ€™s so like his brother to become some sort of minor celebrity. All anyone ever wants to talk about are the Marauders.

â€œPotter has a saviour complex, decided it was his Gryffindor duty to show me the error of my ways, bring me over to the side of light etcetera, etcetera,â€ he says flatly. â€œIâ€™ve told him to bugger off, but heâ€™s persistent.â€

He thinks thatâ€™s believable, maybe even a little too close to the truth. He does his best not to squirm under Maryâ€™s gaze.

â€œAnd why does Dumbledore think you attacked me?â€ she asks finally and Regulus has to stop himself from letting out a sigh of relief at the change in topic.

â€œSorry,â€ though he doesnâ€™t think he sounds very sincere. His voice never does the right things. â€œThat was crude of me.â€

â€œWhere were you?â€

â€œOut.â€

â€œWhere?â€

â€œAstronomy tower.â€

â€œNo one.â€

â€œNo one?â€

â€œNo one,â€ he repeats, a little more growl in his voice.

â€œJames really doesnâ€™t think you had anything to do with it,â€ Mary says eventually. It isnâ€™t phrased like a question so Regulus doesnâ€™t supply an answer. â€œWhat I canâ€™t figure out, is why, since youâ€™re clearly lying.â€

Regulus resents that â€œclearly.â€

â€œIs that all?â€ Regulus asks, after the silence goes on too long. Mary hasnâ€™t looked away from him once, her gaze inscrutable and far too clever for his liking.

â€œMacdonald, that is NOT what happened.â€

â€œSure Regulus, if you say so.â€

â€œFor Jamesâ€™s sake, you canâ€™t tell anyone,â€ he repeats, not feeling like going through this whole conversation again but hoping his tone is enough to get his point across.

Regulus lets out a heavy sigh, the annoying tug in his gut telling him that heâ€™s losing control. Too many people know. Thereâ€™s no way theyâ€™re going to be able to keep this secret much longer. Something like fear but a little worse grips his heart.

â€œYes,â€ he finally manages to say. â€œIs that all?â€ because he really wants to get out of here and maybe murder James Potter for putting him in this position in the first place. â€œIâ€™ll tell Dumbledore,â€ for a brief moment Regulus feels his heart stop and his fear must show on his face because she quickly continues. â€œThat I donâ€™t remember you being there that night,â€ she shrugs. â€œDonâ€™t know if itâ€™ll help you, theyâ€™re not listening to me much these days butâ€¦â€

Regulus canâ€™t help but notice the bitterness in her voice and he thinks of Dumbledore, bargaining away her justice, using her pain to buy himself a new spy.

â€œIâ€™m sorry,â€ he finds himself saying, not sure what heâ€™s really apologizing for.

â€œYou should know that I do though,â€ she says as he reaches for the handle, causing him to look back over his shoulder, forehead wrinkled.

â€œDo what?â€ he asks.

She gives him another one of those long looks, penetrating in all the worst ways. Then she slides off the desk, walking towards him at a leisurely pace. She stops when theyâ€™re right next to one another and for a moment Regulus sees something new in Maryâ€™s stare. Something violent. Like rage.

â€œRemember you,â€ she says sharply, pulling the door open and leaving Regulus struggling to breathe in her wake.

Chapter End Notes

**French: I'm sorry I did this to you. I'm sorry that I'm not strong enough to protect you. I think you might hate me for this someday. But I hope not. God, I really hope not.**

Hello beautiful people!

This chapter feels short and I thought about extending it but I just like ending with a Mary Macdonald mic drop too much so here we are.

Thanks for all the nice things you write! Hope you're having a great day!

PART I: REGULUS

Â 

Theyâ€™re in his fatherâ€™s garden in Scotland, the sun is out but it isnâ€™t too hot, the grass soft underneath them. Jamesâ€™s eyes are bright, the tops of his cheeks flushed. He laughs at something Regulus says before leaning forward and nuzzling at his neck. The affection makes Regulus squirm but he doesnâ€™t pull away, if anything he leans into it.

The air smells sweetâ€”they picked mint that morning and the scent still lingers on their fingers, their touches. Regulus takes Jamesâ€™s hand, holding it above himself, turning it over a few times before pressing a kiss to the inside of his palmâ€”to each of his knuckles. James grins stupidly at him.

Overhead birds twitter and bugs hum and the rest of the world feels very, very far away. They have no one to hide from and nothing to do. Regulus breathes in deep and then exhales, before pressing another kiss to Jamesâ€™s wrist, feeling his pulse beat against his lips.

â€œOkay.â€

â€œForever.â€

â€œOkay.â€

Regulus keeps making slow, aimless kisses along Jamesâ€™s forearm, enjoying the way it makes his cheeks grow rosier and his lips quirk up. James is a lot like a dogâ€”he loves to wag his tail.

â€œMore?â€

â€œOf the story. We were just getting to the good part.â€

â€œSure, but I also like Achilles kicking ass.â€

â€œUh-huh,â€ Regulus has to bite his lip to keep from laughing, he feels a little delirious right now. Maybe itâ€™s the sun. Maybe itâ€™s the way that James keeps looking at him.

James taps the toe of his foot against Regulusâ€™s heel. â€œGo on then.â€

Regulus sighs like itâ€™s some big inconvenience but the truth is, he loves telling stories. Always has. Theyâ€™re a kind of magic. They let you be anyone, anywhere, doing anything. Heâ€™s not sure he would have survived his childhood without stories.

â€œAs Dawn, in saffron robes, rose from the stream of Ocean, bringing light to gods and men,â€ Regulus starts, voice soft, drifting on the breeze. â€œThetis reached the ships bearing Hephaestusâ€™ gift. â€œLet you go.â€

His heart gives a pathetic leap. â€œOh?â€ he has to clear his throat because his voice has grown far too sappy. â€œEven if I was a dead body?â€

â€œEven then,â€ James says quietly.

Regulus lifts himself up, just enough to take Jamesâ€™s mouth. Desperately. Needfully. He never has any shame when it comes to James. He thinks.

â€œOh wow, look at the time, gotta go.â€

No,

Canâ€™t I just have it for a little longer?

PART III: MARY

â€œDonâ€™t go back there,â€ he says again, when itâ€™s clear Regulus isnâ€™t going to speak.

â€œI. Have. To.â€

â€œIâ€™m not asking anymore Regulus.â€

â€œAre you ordering me?â€ Regulus asks, voice sharp.

â€œThatâ€™s bullshit and you know it.â€

â€œIâ€™ve always been fine.â€

â€œI love you. You know that right?â€

â€œYeah,â€ Reg says into his chest. â€œYeah, me too. I love you too.â€

And that's all there is really.

PART II: SIRIUS

Â 

Sirius is sitting on the train, one knee bent, foot resting on the edge of the seat across from him. Theyâ€™re all going to the Potterâ€™s this year, well, except Peter technically, but his home is the closest to the cottage anyway so heâ€™ll be over loads. Sirius isnâ€™t sure what theyâ€™re going to do when they graduate but he pushes that thought aside. A problem for another day.

Needing a distraction he gives Jamesâ€™s shin a kick.

â€œPrick,â€ James says, pulling himself out of Siriusâ€™s reach without taking his eyes off the window. Heâ€™s been staring at the scenery all maudlin for like an hour. Sirius stretches out, kicking his shin again for good measure.

â€œOw!â€ James hisses. â€œFuck off.â€ But at least heâ€™s looking at Sirius nowâ€”well, glaring anyway.

â€œYou gonna tell me whatâ€™s wrong?â€

Itâ€™s work for Sirius not to roll his eyes. Instead he decides to shoot James a grin. â€œYes, that happens when you spend all night out with your boy toy.â€

James really does roll his eyes, itâ€™s all big and huffy and dramatic. He should win an award. â€œJust leave it would you?â€

He means it. Sirius can tell the differenceâ€”when James is pouting and when heâ€™s actually upset.

â€œDid something happen?â€ he asks, tone suddenly sincere.

â€œBecause he doesnâ€™t want anyone to know?â€

â€œIâ€™m an overachiever,â€ they share a grin before Sirius gets earnest again. â€œReally James, I mean it, are you okay? You can tell me, I wonâ€™t ask his name or like, birthday, or whatever you think is gonna give him away.â€

James gives him a sad look. â€œThank you, really, but I justâ€”I canâ€™t. I promised.â€ And thatâ€™s the end of it for James. Heâ€™s made a promise, and James Potter never breaks his promises.

â€œOkay,â€ Sirius says, even though it kills him.
