Weâ€™re here.

Those touches say,

Itâ€™s us and always us. No matter what you lose you will never be alone. We bleed together. And we cry together. And we survive.

Those touches say,

You donâ€™t have to be strong enough to carry this on your own. We will do it for you. With you.

This isnâ€™t their first time dealing with this kind of loss and that truth feels unbearable to James. Because it isnâ€™t fair. Life wasnâ€™t supposed to be like this.Wasnâ€™t supposed to be this endless tragedy. Voldemort and his followers have stolen the future they were supposed to have. And it makes James want to claw his eyes out.

â€œWhat the fuck?â€ Sirius demands.

James blinks, returning to the conversation. Sirius is glaring at Moody who glares right back.

â€œThatâ€™s bullshit.â€

â€œItâ€™s strategic,â€ Moody grumbles. â€œHaving people panicking is only going to lead to reckless behaviour and careless mistakes, which is exactly what Voldemort wants. We have to keep people calm.â€

â€œItâ€™sâ€”â€œ Sirius seems to struggle to find the right word. â€œItâ€™s disrespectful!â€ he decides on eventually. â€œThey deserve better than that.â€

â€œBetter than what?â€ James can feel it, everyone looking at him, uncomfortable with the fact that heâ€™s clearly been too zoned out to hear what was said. Another reminder that he isnâ€™t handling this well. And he isnâ€™t. He has enough self-awareness to know that.

â€œMoody wants to have the official cause of death be recorded as Dragon Pox,â€ Lily steps forward. When he meets her eyes she gives him a small smile, like she understands that itâ€™s hard for him to pay attention right now. He tries to return it.

â€œWe know who did it,â€ Moody snaps back. â€œWeâ€™ve been trying to get them for years now incase you havenâ€™t noticed.â€

â€œNo, no fuck the war. I want you opening a case for the Potters. I want you to treat this like you would any other murder. This wasnâ€™t a fight, didnâ€™t happen in battle, itâ€™s a crime and youâ€™re a fucking Auror so do something about it.â€œ

â€œYou donâ€™t think this is an act of war? Of battle?â€ Moody goes on. â€œSure it is, and Euphemia and Fleamont lost. They lost. â€œSet a date?â€ he asks.

Everyone looks at James expectantly. Like he should have an answer for this. Like he should have been thinking about this. And maybe he should have been. He gives it all another second to sink in before squeezing his fatherâ€™s hand and getting to his feet.

â€œWhatâ€™re you just going to keep your motherâ€™s dead body in your house or something?â€ Peter asks, earning him an elbow from Sirius.

â€œJames,â€ Lily starts but doesnâ€™t seem to know how to finish.

PART III REGULUS

â€œWould you wear dress robes or a Muggle suit dâ€™you think?â€

â€œExactly.â€

â€œIâ€”â€œ and then she immediately shuts her mouth, making a frustrated noise. â€œI donâ€™t feel likeâ€¦like I want toâ€¦you know.â€

PART V SIRIUS

Heâ€™s tired.

Heâ€™s so fucking tired.

The stairs up to the flat feel fucking mountainous and all he keeps thinking about is dragging Remus to bed and curling around him, feeding off his warmth and his smell and the feel of his skin against his mouth.

â€œRem?â€ he calls out when he shuts the door behind him. Remusâ€™s mug is sitting on the table in the living room, the couch a mess of blankets. â€œRemus?â€ he tosses his keys into the bowl by the door and tears his boots off, too lazy to unlace them all the way.

Heâ€™s planning to go to the hospital tomorrow with James to spend some time with Fleamont. Then maybe go out after, get James some fresh air, give him something to do other than stare at his parents' dying or dead faces. The thought bites and scratches and tears on the way down.

He really is fucking tired.

â€œRemus?â€ thereâ€™s no one in the bedroom, bed unmade, clothes on the floorâ€”Siriusâ€™s. He sighs as he heads back towards the kitchen. Remus must still be at Jamesâ€™s. Sirius thinks about just going to sleep but quickly dismisses the idea. If James needs people around than Sirius wants to be there. Wants to help.

He pours himself a glass of water and leans against the counter. Heâ€™ll take a quick shower and thenâ€”

His brain stutters to a stop at the sight of a piece of parchment on the kitchen table. It could be anything really, Sirius doesnâ€™t know why his first reaction is dread. Is suspicion. But the sight of it makes his stomach churn.

He places his glass in the sink and takes a cautious step forward. And then another one. And another one. Until heâ€™s standing over it, reading the words with a shaking breath. He must go over it at least three times before actually touching it. Actually picking it up and admitting itâ€™s real.

Iâ€™m sorry.

it says.

Iâ€™ll come back. I promise Iâ€™ll come back.

Thatâ€™s all there is. Not that there needs to be more for Sirius to understand that Remus has left again. Left to do something somewhere that he wonâ€™t tell any of them about.

Heâ€™ll be gone for the full moonâ€”if itâ€™s another week long disappearance Remus will be gone for the full moon. Fear overtakes Siriusâ€™s anger for a moment. Because whoâ€™s going to look out for him? Whoâ€™s going to make sure heâ€™s okay? Whoâ€™s going to bring him chocolate and tend to his wounds and make sure he doesnâ€™t hurt himself too badly?

Itâ€™s been years since they were separated on the full moon.

Not since they were kids really. If you ignore those months in fifth year, after Snape...and Sirius usually tries to.

But then.

Remus chose this.

And thereâ€™s the anger again.

He reads the letter one more time before incendio-ing it. Walking to the bedroom and slamming the door. He doesnâ€™t bother getting undressed, just crawls under the covers and wraps them around himself, pretending it doesnâ€™t make him want to die that everything smells like Remus.

Chapter End Notes

HAPPY HOLIDAYS!!!!!!!!!!!!! (Or if you're not celebrating anything right now Happy Sunday)

I feel like there were so many good friendship moments in this chapter and that makes me happy.

Also fun fact, if you're sitting there thinking "where the heck is Mary Macdonald?" you're in luck, she's in the next chapter a lot (at least currently) sooo that's something to look forward to!

Thank you all so much for the comments and kudos etc. even as this fic has gotten a little more popular everyone has still been really nice and kind which I'm pretty sure isn't how the internet is supposed to work, so thank you for, y'know, being your lovely selves!!

PART I JAMES

A month after his wife, Fleamont Potter dies.

James isnâ€™t there when it happens. Though he supposes at this point it doesnâ€™t really matter. Thatâ€™s what he tells himself anyway. They send him an owl, inform him that he needs to make arrangements for the body. In some ways, itâ€™s a relief. Theyâ€™ve already been talking about his dad like heâ€™s dead, at least now they donâ€™t have to feel guilty about it.

James has only just brought his father home when he receives a summons from Dumbledore.

â€œYou donâ€™t have to go,â€ Lily says, as she reads the letter over his shoulder. â€œWrite him backâ€”or hell, Iâ€™ll go. Tell him to fuck off.â€

James snorts. â€œAs much as I appreciate the offer, I think Iâ€™d rather have something to do.â€

She nods, giving him a soft smile and squeezing his arm. â€œPizza and butterbeer for dinner?â€

James groans. â€œMerlin, yes. Have I ever told you I love you?â€

â€œOnce or twice.â€

He kisses her then, one hand on the back of her neck, tilting her head up, her mouth warm and solid beneath his. â€œGood,â€ he murmurs against her, â€œbecause I do.â€

Theyâ€™ve unofficially moved into to his parents house, at least for the time being. James knows itâ€™s been hard for Lily. Knows it isnâ€™t ideal. But sheâ€™s still here, unshakable. A force of nature.

â€œGo on then,â€ she says when they pull apart, giving his bum a smack. â€œGo see what the old man wants.â€

James laughs. It helps, acting normal. Helps them both forget about the bodies upstairs.

Dumbledore has opened the Floo in his office so James is able to go directly to the castle instead of walking up from Hogsmeade. The old man is waiting for him, standing by the large window on the far wall, hands clasped behind his back. He smiles when he sees James, gesturing him into the chair in front of his desk.

â€œItâ€™s good to see you,â€ Dumbledore says, once theyâ€™re sitting across from one another. James doesnâ€™t have a response for that, but it doesnâ€™t appear that Dumbledore needs one. â€œHave you changed your mind on the matter of your parentsâ€™ funerals?â€

James grits his teeth. â€œTheyâ€™ll happen as soon as Remus is back.â€

â€œAh,â€ Dumbledore nods sagely, not bothering to add anymore.

James arches his brow, voice sharp. â€œAny idea when that might be?â€

Thereâ€™s a twinkle in Dumbledoreâ€™s blue eyes. â€œIâ€™m afraid I canâ€™t say.â€

James expected as much. It still pisses him off though.

â€œYou wanted to see me?â€ he asks when the silence begins to drag, his knee bouncing impatiently up and down.

Dumbledore nods. â€œI did. We have it on good authority that Voldemort is going to be bringing some of his supporters from Bulgaria across the boarder in a weeks time. Very skilled and dangerous supporters. I intend to stop him.â€

James stares blankly back at him. â€œOkay?â€ he says eventually. â€œAnd you want me toâ€¦help?â€

Dumbledore smiles. â€œOn the contrary, I want you to lead the mission.â€

That takes James by surprise, Moody usually insists that only trained Aurors are given leadership roles. â€œEr, why me?â€

â€œItâ€™s our belief that the group will be flying over.â€

It takes a minute for James to catch up. â€œOn brooms?â€

â€œPrecisely.â€

â€œThatâ€¦â€ he shakes his head, running a hand through his hair. â€œThatâ€™s bloody mental. Thatâ€™s a multi-hour flight.â€

â€œIndeed,â€ thereâ€™s that twinkle again, â€œbut seeing as the sky is the most difficult mode of transportation to monitor and control, I believe they think that it is the option that will give them the best chance of avoiding an ambush.â€

It still sounds absurd to James, but he supposes he and Voldemort arenâ€™t usually on the same wavelength so perhaps that makes sense.

â€œWhy me though?â€ he asks again, which actually has Dumbledore chuckling.

â€œAnd I was under the impression that you had a rather large ego. James, you are an exceptional flyer. The best in the Order, even better than the Aurors, though youâ€™ll not hear Moody say that aloud.â€

â€œFrankâ€”â€œ

â€œAh,â€ Dumbledore smiles. â€œYes well, Frank Longbottom was an excellent captain I think you and I can agree on that. But Iâ€™m afraid he canâ€™t hold a candle to your flying. A fact he would freely admit himself if you asked.â€

Deep down James knows thatâ€™s true, though heâ€™ll never be able to see Frank as being anything but aspirational. On and off the pitch.

â€œOkay,â€ he nods eventually. â€œOkay, Iâ€™ll do it. But I want Sirius with me.â€

Thereâ€™s the slight sharpening of Dumbledoreâ€™s expression. â€œSirius has his own assignments.â€

But James shakes his head. â€œNo Sirius, no me. Thatâ€™s nonnegotiable.â€

The two men hold one anotherâ€™s gazes for a long moment, neither flinching or looking away. Eventually though, Dumbledore does concede.

â€œVery well, youâ€™ll be allowed at least three other people, if not four. Do you have any otherâ€”â€œ

â€œFrank, Alice, Marlene,â€ James lists off before Dumbledore has even finished the question. â€œAnd Mary.â€

The old man arches his brow. â€œMary Macdonald?â€ he asks.

James nods.

â€œSheâ€™s not a member of the Order.â€

â€œI know,â€ James says without much concern. Thereâ€™s another pause before Dumbledore inclines his head in Jamesâ€™s direction.

â€œVery well, if you can get her to agree I donâ€™t see why she canâ€™t accompany you,â€ and then, a little wryly; â€œA Gryffindor team reunion.â€

James hadnâ€™t realized it, but he supposes it is what heâ€™s doing isnâ€™t it? He shrugs, â€œBest flyers Iâ€™ve ever met.â€

Dumbledore is smiling again. â€œIndeed.â€

James feels the finality of that answer, rising to his feet. â€œAre we done?â€

Dumbledore gestures to the fireplace. â€œWe are. Alastor and I will be in contact with you shortly to iron out the details.â€

James stares at the fireplace for a minute, feeling his chest tighten. Heâ€™s not quite ready to go back yet. To that house. To everything in it. All the grief he still has to face. Eventually he shakes his head, taking a step back.

â€œI think Iâ€™ll go for a walk actually,â€ he nods towards the office doors. â€œItâ€™s been a while since Iâ€™ve been to Hogsmeade.

Thereâ€™s the flicker of surprise on Dumbledoreâ€™s face but he quickly wipes it away. â€œWell then, by all means.â€

James doesnâ€™t bother with much more of a goodbye. It isnâ€™t that he doesnâ€™t like Dumbledore exactly. He doesnâ€™t agree with him always, but James knows that none of them would be here if it wasnâ€™t for him. Knows that Dumbledore is the backbone of the resistance and that as hard as all of them try itâ€™s nothing compared to him. James is, in many ways, grateful for Dumbledore. Itâ€™s just that he always leaves James uneasy and he can never quite pinpoint why.

Itâ€™s the end of the summer holidays, nearly September, but there are no children in the school yet. So James takes his time, walking leisurely through the familiar halls. Thereâ€™s a deep aching nostalgia that settles itself in the pit of his stomach. His memories like bruises. Theyâ€™d been happy here. Theyâ€™d been other things too of course, but he thinks above all, when it comes down to it, theyâ€™d been happy.

It happens by accident really. He means to be making his way towards the front doors. He doesnâ€™t know how he ends up on the seventh floor. Ends up in front of a wall that barely needs any prompting at all, as if it still remembers him after all this time, producing a familiar looking door out of thin air.

For a moment, just a moment, James considers walking away. But of course he doesnâ€™t. He never could. His breath hitches when he steps through, like stepping back in time. Everything is the sameâ€”the bed, the furniture, the painting on the ceiling. It even smells the same.

â€œFuck,â€ he says shakily. These memories are more than a bruise.

He forces himself to walk further inside, eyes and hands greedy to touch everything. Itâ€™s overwhelming. And he canâ€™t help but wonder if the last time anyone was in this room was the day Regulus showed him his Mark. He wonders if itâ€™s been sitting here all this time, waiting. If itâ€™s missed them.

He reaches the back wall, places his palms flat on the stone and drops his head. Trying to breathe. Trying to understand what the hell heâ€™s doing. He loves Lily. He loves her. So where do all these otherâ€¦feelings fit? This painful need. To have him. To hold him. To keep him safe.

He remembers Regulus, sleep mussed and sitting in the middle of the bed, smiling.

I might even be happy,

heâ€™d said.

If you can believe it.

Jamesâ€™s nails curl against the cold stone. He never did tell his dad about Regulus. It hadnâ€™t felt important before. He isnâ€™t sure why it feels important now. James tries to clear his head, tries to focus on the things he needs to do, tries to make lists. Get himself together enough to walk back out that door. But it doesnâ€™t work. His brain a mess of black curls and hesitant smiles and love. So much love.

â€œFuck,â€ he hisses again, pulling back and slamming his palms into the wall. Pain vibrates all along his forearms, the mirror next to him shaking before it crashes to the floor.

â€œShit,â€ James steps back as broken pieces scatter across his shoes, the golden frame laying face down. â€œShit,â€ he repeats, having absolutely no idea how youâ€™re supposed to fix things in an enchanted room. He bends down, carefully lifting up the nearly empty frame, a few more pieces sliding off and crashing onto the floor. He tries to run through all the domestic spells he knows, tries to figure out if any of them are any use in this situation, and thatâ€™s when his eyes find the now bare wall in front of him.

Thatâ€™s when he sees the carvings.

He places the broken mirror back on the floor and steps forward. There, carved into the wall, are initials:

G & S

James traces them with his finger before his hand trails down to the second set of letters, carved just beneath:

J & R

The second carving is slightly rougher, but still clear, and Jamesâ€™s finger follows the twists and curves as he tries to make sense of it. Tries to convince himself that itâ€™s just a coincidence. Because it couldnâ€™t have been Reg could it? When would he have done it? Why wouldnâ€™t he have said anything? Was itâ€¦was it after? Did he come back after all of it was over and carve them into the walls?

James flattens his palm over the letters, like heâ€™s trying to press them into his skin. Like heâ€™s trying to force a hole in space and time and go back to when they were written. He knows what they mean of course. Knows what this is.

Itâ€™s an I love you.

Reg never said it back that last time.

He carved them into stone but he couldnâ€™t say it.

Not when James was walking away.

The same way Sirius had walked away.

I love you.

James pulls his hand back from the wall and starts moving. He has to. Thereâ€™s nothing in this room but heartbreak, he doesnâ€™t know why he came here. This is the last fucking thing he needs. He just wants to go home to Lily and curl up on the couch and eat pizza and drink butterbeer and pretend that things are getting better. And pretend that he doesnâ€™t still feel as raw and lost as he did on the day he walked into that kitchen and found his mum slumped over the table.

He wants to be happy loving the things he has.

Because itâ€™s killing him to want the things he doesnâ€™t.

PART II REGULUS

The problem with Dreamless Sleep, is it only helps when youâ€™re not awake. These days Regulusâ€™s nightmares donâ€™t stay under his bed. Though he supposes, depending on who you ask, maybe they never did. Maybe they always had faces and voices and hands. In any case, Regulus is nothing if not a problem solver.

Heâ€™s started playing around with different potionsâ€”the endorphins of Amortentia, the high of Pain Potions, the peace of Calming Draughts. He hasnâ€™t gotten the mix right just yet, but he thinks heâ€™s close. Then maybe heâ€™ll be able to get them all to shut up. The ghosts in his head. In his chest. In the corners of his house. Two had been enough to keep him up at night. But four is driving him insane.

Heâ€™s been closing off Grimmauld Place, bit by bit. He suggested to the Dark Lord that meetings be held elsewhere, for the sake of maintaining the integrity of his potions, of course. Thereâ€™s a new paranoia that Dumbledore may have gotten himself his own â€˜sourceâ€™ and Regulus expressed his fear that someone might be tampering with his lab. It was a flimsy excuse but he received no push back, especially not once Lucius offered up Malfoy Manner. Always so happy to be of service. To make himself important.

Walburga was furious of course. As was Bellatrix. They yelled through the Floo. They sent howlers. They showed up and threw pots and vases and curses. But itâ€™s no matter. Walburga isnâ€™t coming back from Scotland and Bellatrixâ€™s claim on the house does not supersede Regulusâ€™s. So the unofficial Death Eater headquarters have moved and Regulus has started tightening up his wards. He canâ€™t keep out his family of course, as much as he might want to. But there are no more strangers walking around.

The house is much quieter now.

Most days thatâ€™s good.

Some days it feels like suffocating.

The potions heâ€™s currently brewing arenâ€™t complicated enough to hold Regulusâ€™s attentionâ€”to keep his mind from wandering. Heâ€™s taken some Calming Draught but it isnâ€™t powerful enough and his homemade concoction still isnâ€™t ready. After his third lap around the house he grabs his cloak and Apparates to the first place he can think of. Which turns out to be Diagon Alley.

Itâ€™s nearly September, which always makes him think of school, of coming here with Kreacher and picking out his books and gear. He expects thatâ€™s why he thought of it. And true to form the streets are filled with familiesâ€”with children whose eyes are nearly too big for their faces as they stare through shop windows, ogling sweets and racing brooms and potential new pets. It makes Regulus feel ancient.

Heâ€™s only eighteen.

He keeps the hood of his cloak up, doesnâ€™t draw attention to himself, mostly stays out of the shops. He spots one or two Aurors lurking about but they donâ€™t seem to notice him. He knows theyâ€™re only the tip of the iceberg, that Moody has this place locked down tight. This was a bad idea. Of all the places to go, he decided on the one place where heâ€™s most likely to cause a scene. It isnâ€™t that heâ€™s technically â€œwantedâ€ but technicalities are a funny thing these days, and he knows that if the Aurors catch sight of him theyâ€™ll do their best to find a way to drag him in for questioning.

He wonders if James would come, if he got arrested. If he would sit across some intimidating table and drill him with questions while dumping Veritaserum down his throat. Or if heâ€™d drag him away to safety. The war be damned.

Itâ€™s a pathetic thought.

But he has a lot of those.

Daydreams about James Potter. He thanks Merlin every day heâ€™s as good at Occlumency as he is.

The sun is out, peeking at them from behind the clouds that intermittently pass overhead. Regulus pauses near the end of the street where the crowds are thinner, tilting his head back ever so slightly and feeling the warm light brush his skin. He doesnâ€™t go out much these days. Canâ€™t even remember the last time he flew. The thought makes something in his stomach ache.

He sighs, dropping his head back down and getting ready to turn towards the Leaky Cauldron again, when something catches his eyeâ€”long black hair, a leather jacket, a scowling face. Itâ€™s been ages since he saw his brother.

Years.

Which shouldnâ€™t matter really. Not in the grand scheme of things. It certainly shouldnâ€™t change the direction Regulus is heading in. And yet, inexplicably, he feels himself moving forward, following after. He seems to be on a roll today, where poor decision making is concerned.

They turn off the main street, Regulus keeping a good distance between them and Sirius apparently not bothering to check behind himself. Typical. Itâ€™s not until he sees his brother heading for the side door of a shop that he realizes heâ€™s about to lose him. Which is good, this has been going on long enough, heâ€™s lucky Sirius is such an unobservant idiot that he hasnâ€™t found him out already. Now he can watch him disappear inside and head back home where he should have stayed all along.

â€œSirius?â€

Oh goddamnit.

Sirius turns around infuriatingly leisurely, like they arenâ€™t in the middle of a war where people are murdered and kidnapped on the daily. He doesnâ€™t look like someone who is being eaten alive by fear or anxiety. Sirius nods sharply, eyes intense. â€œWho did it Reg? Tell me who fucking did it.â€ Thereâ€™s an edge that wasnâ€™t there before but that feels familiar, an anger. And it hits Regulus that his brother has been behaving suspiciously politely.

â€œYou wanted information,â€ he says out loud, more to himself than to Sirius. He should have known that was the only thing that would keep Sirius from ripping his head off. Honestly, itâ€™s a miracle that neither of them has drawn their wand yet.

â€œJust tell me this one thing, just this once have a fucking spine.â€

â€œFuck you,â€ even if Sirius does have a point.

â€œForget me, think about James huh? You want me to believe you really gave a shit about him? Tell me who killed his parents.â€

â€œFuck. You.â€

Regulus is shaking and itâ€™s only partially from anger. Because he could tell Sirius the truth, could tell him it was Wilkeâ€™s who played the Potters. He could even tell him what department he works for at the Ministry. Except that maybe they would find him. And maybe they would talk to him before cutting him into pieces or flaying him open or doing whatever else it is they intend to do. And maybe he would let slip that it was Regulus who brewed the poison. Ice cold fear shoots through him and he takes a stumbling step backwards.

â€œDonâ€™t,â€ Sirius warns, now letting all facades fall away. â€œDonâ€™t you fucking dare try to run away. They were murdered, they were murdered by some cowards too afraid to face them. Thatâ€™s whose fucking side youâ€™re on. A bunch of weak backed Purebloods who canâ€™t even look the people theyâ€™re about to kill in the eye,â€ he gives Regulus a disgusted look. â€œBut then, I guess thatâ€™s why youâ€™ve always fit in with them so well huh?â€

Regulus turns on his heel while he still can, desperate to get away.

â€œStupify!â€ he hears Sirius shout behind him, but he swerves to the side, listening as the spell bounces off the cobblestone as he rounds the corner onto the busier street. Heâ€™s shoving people out of his way, hood falling back, causing far more of a scene than he ever wanted to. He knows Sirius wonâ€™t try to curse him again, not in the crowd, but that doesnâ€™t meanâ€”

â€œDEATH EATER!â€ he hears his brotherâ€™s voice carrying through the street, bouncing off the buildings, he winces, still pushing forward. â€œDeath Eater! Get himâ€”Sampson fucking get him!â€

Regulus is going to assume Sampson is one of the Aurors he saw earlier. Or maybe one of the Aurors he didnâ€™t see. Either way he doesnâ€™t look for him, doesnâ€™t check behind him to see where Sirius is. There are spells placed on high traffic areas like this, that prevent Wizards from being able to just Apparate wherever they chooseâ€”there would be too many collisionsâ€”other wise he would have done so already. But he can see one of the Apparation points just up ahead.

â€œStop him! Donâ€™t let him through, fuckingâ€”â€œ

Regulus gasps as he stumbles out of the crowd and into the designated Apparating zone, air flying from his lungs as he throws himself into the spell, ripping himself away from the street. His brotherâ€™s voice a fading noise in the background.

PART III SIRIUS

He doesnâ€™t tell James about Regulus. James already has enough to deal with and Sirius doesnâ€™t feel like opening up old wounds. Plus, in general, he likes to think as little as possible about what happened between his brother and his best mate.

Theyâ€™re meeting in the Hogâ€™s Head tonight. Dingy pub run by Dumbledoreâ€™s brother, who is technically in the Order but who never seems to be around. Either way, he agreed to close down early tonight so that James could bring them together for this bloody mission heâ€™s been given. Not that Sirius is complaining really, itâ€™s the most interesting thing heâ€™s had to do in weeks, and he needs a distraction. Remus has been gone more than twice as long as he was last time. Sirius has no idea if heâ€™s okay or when heâ€™s coming back and itâ€™s started to drive him a little barmy. Itâ€™s not helped by the fact that James refuses to burry his parents until Remus gets back. Just adds to the list of things heâ€™s pissed at Remus for.

â€œDo we know what kind of brooms theyâ€™ll be riding?â€ Frank asks about two hours into the meeting. As far as Sirius is concerned all the important details have already been hashed out and the rest is boring semantics.

If Remus was hereâ€”which he wouldnâ€™t be anyway because the bastard canâ€™t even flyâ€”but if he was here, right about now heâ€™d be fighting back a smile because heâ€™d know that Sirius was getting ready to jump out of his skin with impatience. And heâ€™d be enjoying every minute of it. Of course heâ€™d also make up some excuse to get them out early, and start laughing at Sirius the minute they left the room. â€œWhat did Dumbledore tell you, really?â€

Remus throws his arms up in the air in exasperation. â€œLet it go Sirius.â€

â€œNo, I want to know what he said that made you so convinced you canâ€™t tell me where youâ€™re going!â€ his voice cracks. â€œWhat the fuck did he say?â€

â€œNothing!â€ Remus finally shouts back, the word mutilated, like he barely allows it passed his mouth, teeth carving into it on the way out. â€œHe didnâ€™t have to say anything.â€

Didnâ€™t have to say anything.

Didnâ€™t have to.

Of course. Because who knows better than Remus Lupin what a betrayer Sirius Black can be.

Siriusâ€™s chair screeches as he pushes back from the table and heads out of the room.

â€œWhere are you going?â€ Remus calls after him, panic clear in his voice.

â€œBed,â€ is all Sirius says, before slamming the door to the bedroom closed behind him.

He curls up under the blankets, curtains drawn, lights off, and squeezes his eyes shut. He could keep fighting, he has it in him, heâ€™s a Black after all. But heâ€™s tired of saying terrible things. Tired of hearing them. Sometimes he feels the echoes of his mother in his voice and it makes him want to scrape out the inside of his skin. He just wants Remus to go away again. He likes himself better when he doesnâ€™t have anyone around to bite.

It might be minutes or hours but eventually the door opens and closes and Sirius feels the mattress dip. He doesnâ€™t look up, doesnâ€™t unfurl from his ball. Remus sighs, his hand coming tentatively to run through Siriusâ€™s hair. When Sirius doesnâ€™t pull away his movements become more sure of themselves, fingers dragging across his skull.

â€œI hate this,â€ Remus says finally.

Sirius only hums in response.

Thereâ€™s a pause before Remus speaks again. â€œI want you,â€ he almost whispers.

Sirius finally pulls himself properly out of the covers, looking up to find Remusâ€™s eyes already on him. The sight of him makes something trip in Siriusâ€™s chest. It always does. Remus Lupin is a work of art. He deserves to be carved out of marble and placed on the palace steps. Deserves to be studied and admired and remembered for generations to come. One day you will find him in a museum and people will travel from all around the world to see him and they will say;

This.

This is what it looks like.

To be made of magic.

Of daydreams.

Of love in all its colours.

This is Remus John Lupin.

â€œI want you,â€ Remus says again, voice sneaking beneath the blankets and kissing Siriusâ€™s skin. â€œI want you.â€

For a moment the past and the present blur, and Sirius can see two boys in their school dormitory. Together. Finally. After waiting for so long.

I want you.

â€œThen have me,â€ he croaks, stealing Remusâ€™s line.

He hears the other boyâ€™s breath catch and in the next second theyâ€™re crashing together, desperate in a way that has nothing to do with bodies or heat and everything to do with the wounds theyâ€™re both nursing. Both constantly tearing open.

Theyâ€™re clumsy as they push the blankets aside, Remus straddling Siriusâ€™s hips as Sirius runs his hands up Remusâ€™s sides, feeling like he might die from the sudden overwhelming sensation of having the only thing heâ€™s ever wanted.

Remus pulls off his own shirt, revealing a map of cuts and bruises and ribs that are too close to the surface. Sirius makes sure to keep his touches gentleâ€”reverent. They kiss with their teeth. Sirius lifts up and Remus pushes him back down, hands running along Siriusâ€™s arms until he has him pinned by the wrists.

â€œI want you,â€ Remus murmurs as he trails kisses along the underside of Siriusâ€™s jaw, along his neck, his shoulders. â€œI want you.â€

Sirius canâ€™t help bucking up, canâ€™t help whining in agreement. His life is empty when Remus is gone. His body is cold. His bed is too big. It is terrifying to know that someone can walk away and take so much of you with them. That without realizing it you have been cutting pieces of yourself away.

â€œWhat do you want?â€ Remus asks, breath hot against the skin of Siriusâ€™s stomach. He doesnâ€™t remember losing his shirt. Doesnâ€™t know how it happened or which one of them did it.

â€œYou know what I want.â€

Remus looks up at him for a moment, cheeks flushed, lips spit-slick and bitten raw. â€œYeah,â€ he says hoarsely. â€œYeah okay.â€

It isnâ€™t until later. When they are as close as it is possible to be. When Remus is filling him up and all Sirius can feel or smell or taste is him, that Sirius really embarrasses himself.

â€œDonâ€™t leave,â€ he pantsâ€”whinesâ€”not â€œharderâ€, or â€œfaster,â€ or â€œmore baby moreâ€, but; â€œPlease donâ€™t leave.â€ He thinks itâ€™s possible that there are tears escaping his eyes, rolling silently down the sides of his face. But he tries not to think about it.

Remus falters above him, concern washing over him. â€œSiriusâ€”â€œ

â€œNo donâ€™t,â€ Sirius huffs, out of breath as he digs his heel into Remusâ€™s lower back, urging him on. â€œDonâ€™t stop. Please donâ€™t stop.â€

Remus looks like heâ€™s trying to figure something out. Sirius isnâ€™t sure if he manages it but he moans in relief when Remus finally starts moving again. When he brings them back together, opening Siriusâ€™s lips and forcing his way inside.

Sirius is too hot, his skin too tight, everything dissolving into nothing but feeling.

Have me,

he thinks, as he comes apart in Remusâ€™s arms.

Have me.

Have me.

Have me.

Iâ€™m yours anyway.

Chapter End Notes

Hello beautiful people!

I honestly thought I wrote this chapter so fast, I was like "wow it's been like two days since the last update, look at me go" imagine my surprise when I realized that it has actually been a week since Christmas.

My grasp on time is so loose you guys. So loose.

ANYWAY! I hope this was worth the wait, still pretty overwhelmed by how nice everyone has been about this fic, I know it's not perfect so I appreciate how forgiving you are of the mistakes that slip through! Happy 2022 people, it can't get worse right? I mean...right?

tw vague reference to sexual assault

PART I JAMES

His parentâ€™s funerals are held two days after Remus gets back. People fill the Potterâ€™s home, they line up down the street. They bring flowers and food and alcohol. They bring pictures. Of his mother as a little girl. Of his father after selling his first potion. Of the pair of them dancing at their wedding and smiling at the camera.

Lily stands on one side of him and Sirius on the other. Remus is there. Peter. Mary, Marlene, Dorcas, Alice, Frank. They build walls around him. They stand guard. Never leaving his side. Itâ€™s an endless and brutal day. Maybe heâ€™s supposed to take comfort in it. In how many people loved his parents. How many lives they touched. Maybe heâ€™s supposed to think that theyâ€™re in a better place. That heâ€™ll see them again. But he doesnâ€™t. He spends the whole day feeling their absence like stones in his chest. He spends the night trying to figure out how heâ€™s ever going to fill the gigantic hole theyâ€™ve left behind.

Naively, James thinks that burying both his parents will be the worst part of his week.

It is not.

Â 

â€œWe should do our best to capture as many of them as we can,â€ Frank is saying as he pulls on his flying gloves. â€œInformation is what we need right now.â€ His voice is steady, he doesnâ€™t sound nervous, or like heâ€™s barking orders, merely advising.

â€œBut surely we donâ€™t need all of them for information,â€ Sirius is twirling his broom lazily in his right hand like a baton. Itâ€™s hard to see him through the night, what with his black leather jacket, jeans and boots. His hair is pulled back in a bun so at least his face is clear.

â€œNo,â€ Frank admits reluctantly, â€œwe donâ€™t need all of them.â€

Sirius grins, teeth catching in the moonlight. â€œWell then, lets go kill some motherfuckers.â€

Frankâ€™s mouth forms a thin line. â€œCareful Sirius,â€ he says, after pausing for a minute. â€œYouâ€™re starting to sound just like them.â€

â€œGood thing Iâ€™m on your side then, isnâ€™t it Frankie boy?â€ he winks, throwing a leg over his broom and pushing off the ground.

Frank watches him go before turning his unimpressed look on James who rolls his eyes. â€œHeâ€™s showboating,â€ James takes his own broom in hand. â€œItâ€™s just to hide how nervous he is.â€

Frank doesnâ€™t look convinced. â€œIs he going to be a liability out there?â€

That irks James. â€œHas he ever been a liability in the sky?â€

â€œDo you really want me to answer that?â€

â€œYes,â€ Jamesâ€™s stare meets Frankâ€™s and doesnâ€™t waver. â€œHe may not have always listened to what you said, but he never once made a choice that didnâ€™t end up getting us the goal.â€

He can see Frank clench his teeth, knows heâ€™s unhappy that he canâ€™t come up with an example to prove James wrong. They might have fucked around but neither James nor Sirius ever took winning lightly.

â€œThis isnâ€™t Quidditch,â€ Frank says finally.

â€œAnd Sirius isnâ€™t a liability,â€ James matches his tone.

â€œWhatâ€™re you boys talking about?â€ Alice calls out as her, Mary and Marlene start making their way over.

James holds Frankâ€™s gaze for another beat before tearing his eyes away. â€œNothing. Time to go. You guys ready?â€

â€œWhereâ€™s Sirius?â€ Mary asks as the other two nod.

James gestures upwards. â€œAlready flying,â€ he mounts his broom. â€œStay in formation yeah? Donâ€™t break, at least not until the fighting starts. We wanna have prisoners at the end of this not bodies,â€ he shoots Frank a look and the other boy dips his head in thanks. â€œTheyâ€™re no use to us if theyâ€™re all dead.â€

â€œAye, aye Captain!â€ Alice calls out.

Rolling his eyes, James kicks off into the sky. Almost immediately Sirius is at his side, maybe two arms width away and slightly behind. Theyâ€™re flying in something of a pyramid formation, James in the lead, with Sirius and Mary on the second line and Alice, Frank and Marlene making up the base. Itâ€™s dark and cloudy out, the air heavy with unspilt rain. And the wind is cold even though itâ€™s barely September.

Theyâ€™ve traveled south, waiting a few miles inland from the Channel. According to Moodyâ€™s sources overseas this is the route the Death Eaters are takingâ€”last spotted flying over Dieppe.

â€œStrange,â€ Frank had said when they got the news. â€œI thought they were trying to avoid an ambush, whyâ€™re they being so obvious about it?â€

That hadnâ€™t sat particularly well with James either but Moody and Dumbledore held firm that the mission should continue. So here they are. It is some comfort that according to the reports there are only four flyers. Outnumbering the Death Eaters is really the best outcome they can hope for.

James flexes his hands on his broom, eyes peeled as they search the skies. There is every chance that the two groups will pass one another and never know it, especially in this weather. In many ways this mission is a bit of a hail Mary pass. The hope that maybe, if the timing is right, if the stars align and luck is on their side, they can stop this before anymore Death Eaters get the chance to step down on English soil.

They move swiftly through the clouds, the night sky coming in and out of view. Itâ€™s disorienting, like being intermittently dropped into the thickest fog you can imagine. Sometimes heâ€™ll even lose sight of Sirius and Mary in his periphery. For a moment James wonders if itâ€™s a spell, if Voldemort has grown powerful enough to control the weather, but he quickly banishes that thought. Thatâ€™s exactly how they want you to thinkâ€”James has seen the pamphlets, heard the speechesâ€”the way Voldemortâ€™s followers talk about him like some greater being. Above them all. Untouchable. James doesnâ€™t buy it. He reckons if you pricked him heâ€™d still bleed red, just like the rest of them.

â€œJames, to the west,â€ Mary says sharply, voice somehow remaining quiet even while cutting through the wind.

He instantly follows her directions and, sure enough, there are four dark robed figures pulling out of the clouds and heading right for them, like the horsemen of the apocalypse.

â€œEveryone ready?â€ James asks, to general agreement. â€œGood. Lets make this as clean and fast as possible alright?â€ He slides his wand into one hand, steering with the other as they start moving towards their targets.

James isnâ€™t sure what to expect, isnâ€™t sure if the Death Eaters will try to run first or just stand their ground. But as the two groups move closer and closer together neither dithers. Jamesâ€™s nerves are going haywire but he doesnâ€™t fight them, instead he tries to grab hold of that feeling, tries to use it, just like heâ€™s always done in Quidditch. Adrenaline is your friend, even when it tastes like fear.

When they get close enough both groups stop, floating in the air facing one another, lit only by the moon when it manages to get in front of the clouds. James suddenly feels like heâ€™s taking part in some old-timey duel.

The man who appears to be leading the Death Eaters smiles, using all his teeth. â€œWeâ€™ve been waiting for you,â€ he says, which James thinks is not at all foreboding.

â€œYou should have said something, we would have come sooner, I do hate being rude,â€ James quips back, which only causes the other man to smile wider. Heâ€™s dressed in black, with long curling locks of brown hair spilling over his shoulders.

When he doesnâ€™t speak again James clears his throat, the realization of how unprepared he is for this dawning on him bit by bit. â€œListen, the way I see it, this goes one of two ways.â€

The other manâ€™s smile does not diminish. â€œOh?â€ he asks, tilting his head to the side, itâ€™s a sharp and unnatural motion. James does his best not to let it shake him.

â€œYou can make this easy on yourselves, come back with us to the Ministry, answer a few questions, and then turn around and go home.â€

One of the Death Eaters snickers at that, and James tightens his grip on his wand, gritting his teeth.

â€œOr?â€ the leader prods, voice dancing with amusement.

â€œOr,â€ James pushes on, â€œyou can try to fight us, in which case, some of you will die and the rest of you will still be brought in for questioning and then locked in a cell for the Dementors to snack on,â€ Azkaban is a bit of a hollow threat at this point seeing as the Death Eaters have more or less been running the place for years, but heâ€™s not sure if these men know that. Heâ€™s hoping they donâ€™t.

Their leader appraises him for a moment before he speaks. â€œYou think we will be so easy to defeat?â€ he asks, accent thick.

â€œYouâ€™re outnumbered,â€ James says simply.

â€œAh,â€ the man seems delighted by this. â€œMy apologies, but I fear you are mistaken.â€

Something heavy drops into the pit of Jamesâ€™s stomach and he resists the urge to start looking around for more flyers, that would only make him seem weak. So he keeps his eyes steadily on the man in front of him.

â€œDonâ€™t think I am,â€ he says smoothly. â€œNot unless they count differently in Bulgaria.â€

The man actually laughs, the noise echoing sinisterly into the night. â€œNo, no, I believe we count the same,â€ he points to the person next to him. â€œOne,â€ to himself, â€œtwoâ€, and to the empty space on his other side, â€œthree.â€

It is then that the air shimmers, the familiar sight of a charm being thrown off. A fifth flyer appears. And then behind him a sixth. A seventh. A tenth. A fifteenthâ€¦

â€œHoly shit,â€ he hears Marlene curse behind him.

Suddenly Frank is at his side, breaking formation. â€œHow many do you count?â€ he whispers quickly to James, whose eyes are still bouncing over all the materializing bodies, some of whom appear to be wearing full masks, others with their faces bare like the original four.

â€œI-I donâ€™t know,â€ James swallows to get the shakiness out of his voice. â€œThirty?â€

Frank nods. â€œAt least, we should have knownâ€”â€œ

â€œLike hell we should have,â€ thatâ€™s Alice, James doesnâ€™t look for her, doesnâ€™t tear his eyes away from the army in front of him. â€œAll the sources said it was a small group, I saw the reports my goddamn self.â€

â€œWell clearly they were wrong,â€ Frank replies flatly.

â€œListen,â€ the man with the long brown hair calls out to them, eyes dancing with amusement, â€œthe way I see it, this goes one of two ways,â€ that garners him a few laughs from his cohort.

â€œOh brilliant,â€ James says through clenched teeth, â€œheâ€™s a stand-up comedian.â€

â€œOur lord is not a cruel man,â€ the Bulgarian leader goes on.

â€œHe offers you all the chance to join him and his noble cause to return the Wizarding race to its proper place atop the Great Chain of Being, rulers over all, the natural kings of the earth.â€

â€œOh fuck me,â€ James can hear the eye roll in Maryâ€™s voice.

â€œJames?â€ Frank asks, he doesnâ€™t sound afraid or pleading, just curious.

Itâ€™s not as though he can say everything he wants to when the people ready to tear them to shreds are all staring at them, waiting, listening. But then, theyâ€™re Quidditch players. They can read each other better than anyone else. He meets each of their eyes and knows that they all understand. Eventually Frank gives him a little nod and James turns back to their captive audience.

â€œWell,â€ he says, squaring his shoulders, wand in his hand, mind already casting. â€œI think weâ€™re gonna kill some motherfuckers.â€

James fires off two spells before heâ€™s even finished talking, the others doing the same, breaking off in different directions. James drops into a feint, feeling the returning fire wizzing over his head as the cold night air bites his cheeks. Itâ€™s then that he fully appreciates why Dumbledore asked him to do this. Itâ€™s been so long since heâ€™s flown with people who arenâ€™t players, heâ€™d forgotten how awkward they are in the sky. â€œBailey Switch!â€

The Bailey Switch is a Quidditch move that Frank would be bloody embarrassed theyâ€™re pulling, but James nods anyway.

He makes a big swerve to the right, Sirius mirroring him to the left. Both of them increasing their speed as they circle around and head right for one another. If you were watching from above it might look as though they were making a sort of heart shape, their pursuers following behind.

The idea of the Bailey Switch, is that if two players on the same team are being trailed, they can orchestrate a collision. Flying towards one another at top speed and then ducking out of the way before the people behind them can react, causing them to run into one another.

In general, most players know to look out for this, itâ€™s a fairly obvious move, and as long as youâ€™re paying attention youâ€™re unlikely to miss that the person youâ€™re flying behind is heading straight for their teammate. But these guys are not Quidditch players.

Sirius and James run right towards each other, James almost pressing his chest to his broom handle heâ€™s going so fast, the men behind him speeding up as well. Even in the dark he can see the grin on Siriusâ€™s face as they get closer and closer. A game of chicken.

One.

James thinks, wind whipping the hair away from his face, the first few light drops of rain, splattering his glasses, hinting at the coming storm.

Two.

Theyâ€™re close now. Any sane person would have ducked out already.

Three.

James answers with his wand, the man in front of him barely dodging the spell, but laughing all the same, returning it with one of his own. â€œExpelliarmus!â€

Heâ€™s barely even thinking when he says it, just knows he needs to return his opponentâ€™s fire with something. â€œGot you,â€ he says grinning.

James will never know why it catches his attention. The loud indistinct noise behind him. There are lots of noises, have been this whole time. So what it is about this one that has James looking over his shoulder at the exact moment he shouldnâ€™t be, he doesnâ€™t know.

Thereâ€™s no thinking after that.

He canâ€™t reach.

Thereâ€™s too much distance and the ground is gaining on them.

Itâ€™s Sirius.

Sirius is tearing.

â€œCâ€™mon,â€ he hisses, sounding scared even to himself as he tries to pull up his own body weight as well as Siriusâ€™s. He needs to get upright again, needs to slow them down. He uses all his core strength but itâ€™s hardâ€”in fact it feels impossible. Which it canâ€™t be. James doesnâ€™t have the luxury of impossible right now. Pain shoots through his back and shoulders as he forces his body to do what it almost certainly wouldnâ€™t be able to without the copious amounts of adrenaline pumping through him.

â€œFuckâ€”Sirius?â€ heâ€™s breathing heavy, hands shaking as he runs over his friendâ€™s body. â€œFuck,â€ the word trembles. â€œFuck, fuck, fuck.â€ Sirius is lying on his back in the dirt, body at an awkward angle, head in Jamesâ€™s lap and he has no idea what to do. No idea how to fix this. And he just keeps thinking. Keeps thinking what ifâ€”what if they hit him withâ€”

A hand on his shoulder has James jerking around, heart in his throat, air only returning to his lungs when he sees itâ€™s Frank.

â€œI canâ€™t tell if heâ€™s breathing,â€ he blurts out before Frank even has a chance to speak. He sounds young. â€œI canâ€™t tell if heâ€™s breathing, I donâ€™t know what happened but he isnâ€™t moving, he isnâ€™tâ€”and Frank I canâ€™t tell if heâ€™s fucking breathing!â€

Frankâ€™s hand squeezes his shoulder. â€œOkay, alright, Iâ€™m gonna check okay?â€

â€œHeâ€™s breathing,â€ the other boys says, pulling away.

â€œYouâ€™re sure?â€

â€œI can hear his heart James.â€

â€œYouâ€™re sure?â€ because he needs him to be sure, he needs this to be true. He wonâ€™t be able to keep it together if it isnâ€™t. Everything he is will come crashing down if it isnâ€™t.

Itâ€™s you and me.

Thatâ€™s what Sirius had said that day on the kitchen floor.

Itâ€™s you and me.

Thatâ€™s what James had had when heâ€™d had nothing else.

â€œHere,â€ Frank takes one of Jamesâ€™s hands and positions his fingers on Siriusâ€™s neck. â€œFeel.â€

â€œHeâ€™s breathing,â€ he says with relief, eyes opening to find Frank giving him a weak smile.

â€œHeâ€™s breathing.â€

The spell comes out of nowhere.

â€œFRANK!â€

PART II MARY

Contrary to popular belief, Mary has not forsaken magic. In fact, she practices frequently. Legilimency and Occlumency have been of particular interest to her. Learning how to build walls around her mind. Learning how to break down the walls that others have built.

Another interest of herâ€™s, is Fiendfyre.

The flames pouring from her wand have grown wings, soaring over the heads of the Death Eaters around her and roasting them where they sit. It smells like Sunday dinner. Itâ€™s almost too easy honestly. Some of them seem to just be flinging themselves off their brooms. Earlier she caught sight of Frank trying to cushion their falls.

Mary has made no such efforts.

She pulls the fire back, itâ€™s a slow process, something this powerful takes patience and skill to control. But eventually sheâ€™s able to put it out, nothing around her but smoke.

â€œOh fuck off you prick,â€ Marleneâ€™s voice cuts through the night, pulling Maryâ€™s focus. She catches sight of her friend being dragged down to the ground by a man who appears to have latched onto the end of her broom.

Mary starts moving in that direction, incase Marlene needs back up. But as soon as theyâ€™re on the ground Marlene has an elbow in the guyâ€™s face and then she hits him with a Stunner. Mary canâ€™t help but smile.

At least, until a third figure appears.

He drops down right behind Marlene and sheâ€™s only just turned when the words; â€œStupefyâ€ cut through the night.

Stupefy isnâ€™t a particularly violent spell, except when used at close range. Marlene is thrown backwards, skidding across the dirt and landing on her front. She doesnâ€™t get up. The man is starting to mount his broom again when Mary presses the tip of her wand to the back of his neck.

â€œThat,â€ she hisses, â€œwas a mistake asshole.â€

He swirls around but Mary ducks, knowing the spell is coming. She immediately bounces back, casting her own. The man in front of her is wearing a mask and throws up a shaky shield that trembles against her. Mary fires off another curse, and another, not giving him a moment to breathe, the power of her spells forcing him to take a step backwards. His shield is barely holding, the air around him sparking and wobbling as it threatens to collapse under the onslaught of her attack. His mask, she notices, is also quivering.

Itâ€™s a spell, she realizes. The masks are charms. A stupid waste of energy and impractical. Sometimes the Muggle way really is superior. Mary makes sure to cast her next spell with particular force. She sees the shield shatter, like glass, broken pieces falling away, taking his mask with it.

The minute his face is clear in front of her, she starts to laugh. â€œOh this is too good. Tell me, does your daddy know where you are?â€

â€œOn your knees Mudblood,â€ Barty Crouch sneers, raising his wand.

But Mary canâ€™t stop laughing. â€œVoldemort is sneaking a bunch of people across the boarder and he sends you to help them? You? What are you supposed to be exactly? â€œI said ON YOUR KNEES!â€ his voice trembles, face flushed the way little kids get before they throw a temper tantrum. His confidence is shaken now that he hasnâ€™t got his mask. Now that she knows his secret.

â€œYes I heard you,â€ she finally manages to get herself under control, wiping tears of mirth from her eyes. â€œBut you see, the problem Crouch, is I get on my knees for no man,â€ she smiles then. â€œMen get on their knees for me.â€ She fires off a binding curse that Crouch only barely dodges and then theyâ€™re back at it again. This time though, he isnâ€™t trying to hide behind his shield anymore, giving as good as he gets.

â€œIâ€™m surprised youâ€™re even here Macdonald,â€ he grunts as one of her curses grazes his shoulder. â€œI heard you had gone full Muggle,â€ the last word is said with the ought most disgust.

â€œYou keeping tabs on me?â€ she asks, careful not to let her voice betray how much the thought unnerves her. â€œThis little obsession of yours is getting out of hand.â€

â€œIâ€™m not obsessed with you.â€

"I can't wait to see your father's face when he hears what you've been up to," she swerves around his Cruciatus Curse, enjoying the terror in his eyes at the mention of his father. â€œTell me, do you think Voldemort will break you out of Azkaban after your daddy stuffs you in there? "No one will believe you," he snaps, with all the confidence of a spoiled brat. Then, slowly, a smile stretches across his face. "Just like last time."

The killing curse leaves her wand before she even has time to think about it. Disappointment flooding her when it misses by an inch. Mary still has nightmares. Sometimes. She wonders if they'll stop after she severs his head from his neck.

"I see you managed to get rid of the lipstick," she says coldly. "A shame. It really was your colour." Crouch's whole face flushes red with embarrassment.

â€œFuck you!â€

â€œOh but darling you already did that,â€ there are wars in those words. Ancient and on going. â€œDidnâ€™t you?â€ She can taste venom in her mouth.

Crouch falters.

Mary does not.

â€œStupefy.â€

Theyâ€™re close enough, and Mary is angry enough, that when the spell hits him, square in the chest, it knocks him off his feet, like Marlene, sending him skidding into the distance. This is good. â€œMary!â€

â€œWhat?â€

â€œNo wait,â€ she looks back, still able to just make out the shape of Crouch in the darkness. â€œI have toâ€”â€œ

But then her stomach is suddenly in her mouth as Alice rips her from the earth, everything dissolving around her as sheâ€™s side-alonged out of the valley. Itâ€™s a wretched feeling, made worse by the fact that she wasnâ€™t expecting it.

Pain shoots up the fronts of her legs when they slam back onto solid ground, the world swimming around her as she tries to get her bearings.

â€œJesus Christ Alice,â€ she swears, gripping her head and staring up at the looming building in front of her. Itâ€™s large and dilapidated, with hauntingly blank windows and rusted red brick walls. A faded sign across the front reads; Purge and Dowse, Ltd. Itâ€™s an illusion that Mary recognizes.

Somewhere in the distance thereâ€™s thunder.

â€œThatâ€™s good,â€ Alice starts pulling them towards the front of the building. â€œBut they do.â€ She nods up ahead and thatâ€™s when Mary spots three figures slouched against the hospital wall. The boys.

â€œHeâ€™s breathing,â€ James replies almost automatically. Thereâ€™s something slightly panicked about Jamesâ€™s eyes, about the way he holds Sirius. â€œOi!â€ Alice grabs the arm of a man scurrying past. His eyes are wide behind a pair of wire framed glasses.

PART III JAMES

Itâ€™s warm in the house. The ceiling low and made of thick wooden beams, the stone walls covered in pictures and over stacked bookshelves, not an inch of space free. â€œThere are some spare rooms on the second floor, we can take them both there,â€ Molly looks over at James who is still clutching Sirius like heâ€™s expecting someone to come and steal him away.

â€œJames?â€ Alice prods, and when he meets her eyes; â€œlets go, okay?â€

He doesnâ€™t argue. Isnâ€™t in a position to. He canâ€™t help Sirius on his own, he wishes he could but he canâ€™t. So he follows Molly up the stairs, where she directs them into separate bedrooms.

PART IV REMUS

He canâ€™t remember if heâ€™s ever seen Sirius this still. He doesnâ€™t think so. Sirius Black is all action, all movement, all decisions that really ought to take more time. He hates sitting here, being useless. Hates that he wasnâ€™t there when Sirius needed him. That he never seems to be there anymore. He hates Sirius a little bit too.

Heâ€™s still holding his hand, keeps pressing his thumb over Siriusâ€™s pulse just to reassure himself. Heâ€™s become familiar with Siriusâ€™s pulse. He knows how to make it race and how to make it slow and how to hold it tenderly.

When everything first started falling apart tonight they didnâ€™t know what had happened to Sirius and the others. They didnâ€™t know if they were still alive or if theyâ€™d been taken hostage or if they were laying in a valley somewhere broken and bleeding out. Not knowing was the worst feeling.

Because he hates Sirius a little bit.

But he would bite off his own arm before he would live in this world without him.

Sirius groans and Remus feels his whole body react to the sound, instantly sitting up.

â€œSirius? Heyâ€”hey Sirius?â€

Remus waits for more but none comes, Siriusâ€™s eyes remaining firmly shut. After a few seconds Remus reaches out, placing a tentative hand in Siriusâ€™s hair but the other boy flinches and Remus instantly pulls away.

â€œIâ€™m not going anywhere,â€ which feels like all he says these days, feels like what heâ€™s trying to say even when he canâ€™t open his mouth. The promise he breaks over and over again.

Remus isnâ€™t sure how much times passes, how long they sit there, Sirius no longer still like he was, expressions flashing across his face that Remus tries and fails to understand. â€œYou didnâ€™t think we could do it.â€

Remus has no idea what to say to that, what to do with the complicated knot of feelings in his chest. But, predictably, Sirius doesnâ€™t give him the time to sort it out, because a few seconds later heâ€™s blinking his eyes open, letting out a shaky exhale before turning his head towards Remus.

â€œHey Moons,â€ he says again, this time looking straight at him. Those eyes will be the death of Remus one day, he just knows it.

â€œNot too much?â€ he asks gently, once heâ€™s found his voice again.

Sirius grins and he almost looks like his normal self. â€œWorth it.â€

PART V MARY

They sit in a living room filled with mismatched furniture and more pashmina rugs than Mary has ever seen in her entire life. Marlene is on one side of her and Lily on the other, Arthur Weasley taking the armchair across from them.

They all turn to Arthur who nods understandingly. â€œRight, got it, so,â€ he rubs his palms together. â€œWhere to begin?â€

Mary assumes this is a rhetorical question but the silence stretches on for a painfully long time. Eventually, when he continues to seem at a loss, Lily speaks. â€œThe Death Eaters have taken the Ministry.â€

Mary turns to stare at her. â€œExcuse me?â€

â€œTheyâ€™ve what?â€ Marlene demands at the same time.

â€œThey do have enough to hold it hostage though,â€ Lily adds.

â€œAnd the group from Bulgaria wasâ€¦what?â€ James asks. â€œA distraction?â€

â€œSo Dumbledore sent us to fight an army then?â€ Mary asks flatly.

â€œIt wasnâ€™t clear that thatâ€™s what they were before tonight, he was just as blindsided by that as the rest of us,â€ Arthur fidgets. â€œThe information we had really did make it seem like it was a mission to bring over specific high ranking members of his supporters from the continent, notâ€¦â€

â€œA whole bloody platoon?â€ Mary finishes for him.

Arthur gives her an apologetic look. â€œPrecisely.â€

â€œOkay, okay, but what the hell does that have to do with St Mungos?â€ Jamesâ€™s hair is an absolute disaster. You can almost always tell the state of Jamesâ€™s distress by the height of his hair.

â€œThey went after a few other government institutions,â€ Arthur explains. â€œThey werenâ€™t able to completely shut them down like the Ministry butâ€¦wellâ€¦you saw the state St Mungos was in.â€

â€œBastards,â€ Marlene hisses. â€œWhat kind of assholes attack a hospital?â€

â€œThe chair of St Mungos is Muggle-born so,â€ Arthur grimaces. â€œIt has been the target of a few small scale attacks before, this one was the biggest of course.â€

â€œWait, Iâ€™m sorry, so the Death Eaters are in control of the Ministry?â€ Mary demands.

â€œVoldemort and the Minister are currently barricaded in his officeâ€¦negotiating.â€

That instantly makes the hair on the back of Maryâ€™s neck stand up. â€œNegotiating?â€ she repeats slowly. â€œWhat exactly are they negotiating?â€

Arthur wipes a hand over his face, looking tired for the first time all night. Not that itâ€™s night anymore. Through the windowsâ€”which are all different sizes and shapes, because nothing in this house is consistentâ€”the first pink and gold strips of light can be seen on the horizon.

â€œThe Dark Lord has certain demands he wants met. Heâ€™s asking that all Muggle-borns and Half-bloods be removed from government offices. Including teachers at Hogwarts and Healers at St Mungos.â€

â€œWhat?â€ Marlene demands, outraged.

â€œThereâ€™s no way that the Minister is going to agree to that,â€ James says confidently.

â€œMoody is working on regaining control of the Ministry, teams of Aurors have been sent in, butâ€¦â€ Arthur trails off again.

â€œBut?â€ James prods.

â€œBut there were a lot more sympathizers in the Ministry than we previously believed.â€

Of course there were. Fucking politicians.

â€œWhat does that mean?â€ James asks, sounding agitated.

â€œIt meansâ€¦â€ Arthur struggles. â€œIt means that agreeing to Voldemortâ€™s terms is starting to look like the best way to end this without any bloodshed.â€

Thereâ€™s silence after those words, until Mary breaks it with a laugh.

â€œWithout any bloodshed,â€ she repeats derisively. â€œYou lot really think this is where this ends? That you fire a few people and Voldemort and his merry band of assholes will just leave us all alone?â€

â€œI donâ€™t believe anyone thinks that, no,â€ Arthur says softly.

â€œThis is not harmless,â€ sheâ€™s on a roll now. â€œIf the Ministry agrees to these terms, if they fire all the Muggle-borns and Half-bloods they are sending a message. That Voldemort is right. Mary is breathing heavy, her words leaving silence in their wake. Itâ€™s fine, she doesnâ€™t care, let them be uncomfortable. Let them feel it it. Eventually Marlene reaches out, hand wrapping around Maryâ€™s wrist and squeezing.

â€œSheâ€™s right,â€ Lily says, sounding a little bit less like sheâ€™s about to decapitate everyone than Mary. â€œIf we let them get away with this itâ€™ll be like admitting defeat.â€

Arthur looks back at them helplessly, palms upturned. â€œListen, I donâ€™t disagree with you, but unfortunately Iâ€™m not in charge of making decisions. All I know is that the feeling at the moment is that this is the best option.â€

Mary laughs coldly. â€œAnd whose feeling is that exactly? I mean how many Muggle-borns are consulted when Albus fucking Dumbledore is making these decisions huh? Or Alastor Moody? â€œMary,â€ Marlene says quietly from beside her, and Mary doesnâ€™t know if itâ€™s meant to caution her or support her but she doesnâ€™t try to figure it out.

â€œI mean the only people who arenâ€™t Purebloods here are me, Lily and Remus and would any of us even be here if we hadnâ€™t fucked one of you?â€

James actually chokes, Marleneâ€™s eyes going wide, Arthurâ€™s face flushing a deep red. Lily, on the other hand, laughs.

â€œIâ€™m so sick of this,â€ she goes on. â€œIâ€™m so sick of this whole â€œwe support you but only when itâ€™s convenientâ€ bullshit. There should be fucking bloodshed. At this point there should be fucking bloodshed.â€

She gets off the couch because she needs to move and because she has about a dozen more rants in her and she knows if she doesnâ€™t walk away now sheâ€™ll never be able to stop herself. For all his annoying cheer this is not Arthur Weasleyâ€™s fault. Maybe it isnâ€™t anybodies fault. Maybe itâ€™s everyones fault. Sheâ€™s just angry. Sheâ€™s just so goddamn angry.

She walks through the open doorway into the front room, standing at the window with her arms crossed and doing her best to keep it together. The sky is navy blue, the sun growing stronger and stronger in the distance. She cannot help but wonder what this day will be like for all the Muggle-borns and Half-bloods about to lose their jobs.
