She hears footsteps behind her, and then Lily is leaning against the wall next to her, Marlene wrapping her arms around her and resting her chin on Maryâ€™s shoulder.

â€œThat wasâ€¦pretty hot actually,â€ Marlene says, causing Mary to snort.

â€œCareful, Dorcas might get jealous.â€

â€œNah,â€ Marlene says easily, â€œsheâ€™d agree with me.â€

Lily nudges Maryâ€™s foot to get her attention, something heavy in her eyes. â€œThank you, for saying all that,â€ she nods back towards the living room. â€œSomeone needed to, itâ€™s not fair that it always has to be you.â€

â€œThough I donâ€™t know if that speech would have been quite as scandalous if Lily had said it,â€ Marlene adds. â€œNo offence Lily.â€

â€œOi, I can be scandalous okay?â€

â€œUh-huh.â€

â€œIâ€™ll believe it when I see it Evans,â€ that earns Mary an eye roll.

Theyâ€™re all quiet for a moment, watching the sun come up, Marlene still wrapped around Mary, Lily pressing their shoulders together.

â€œItâ€™s us first,â€ Lily says eventually, seemingly out of nowhere.

Mary looks over at her, brow arched.

â€œThe Order isâ€¦the Order,â€ Lily waves a dismissive hand, looking intently at Mary and then Marlene. â€œBut itâ€™s us first,â€ she gestures between them. â€œBefore all the rest of it, before everything else. You lot will always be what matters most. You know that right?â€ she looks specifically at Mary now.

They stare at each other for what feels like a long time, like a challenge. Lily doesnâ€™t flinch. Doesnâ€™t drop her gaze. Green eyes bright and fierce. Eventually, Mary nods. â€œYeah,â€ she says slowly, meaning it far more than she ever thought she would. â€œYeah, I know.â€

Chapter End Notes

Hey,

so,

here's the thing, I'm struggling with this fic at the moment.

I was trying to write both these characters as flawed and complex, they don't always do the right things because I don't think people always do the right things especially in extreme circumstances (especially when they're kids). That being said, I think I've made mistakes in telling this story and in the ways I've written some of these characters and I promise you I get that. Believe me. It was never my intention to write anything that was dismissive of sexual assault or any other form of abuse or trauma and I cannot express how sorry I am if that's what I did write or if I have in anyway contributed to any toxicity in this space.

Thanks for listening and for reading, appreciate all of you!

Chapter 48

Chapter Summary

I do know that Sirius got his motorcycle in 1977. I simply don't care. Time is a construct. I don't recognize its authority.

Chapter Notes

tw: Drug use (in the form of potions)

tw: I mean like the mildest reference to sexual content

See the end of the chapter for more notes

October 1979

PART I REGULUS

This.

This is good.

He should have been doing this from the beginning.

Should have been doing this years ago.

The potions make the world distant and soft. Everything in him just a little less sharp. A little less in focus. He wonders if this is how everyone else feels all the time? If this is how theyâ€™re able to walk through life unafraid. Like their memories arenâ€™t something heavy they have to drag with them.

Days and nights blend, heâ€™s able to function enough. Enough to do whatâ€™s expected of him. But he rarely goes to meetings anymore. Originally it was the thought of being in Luciusâ€™s house that made him stay away, now he just canâ€™t be bothered.

Grimmauld remains largely empty aside from him and Kreacher.

Evan visits from time to time, Barty less, Cerci when she can get away from her job and her mother who has grown profoundly unhappy with their relationship, as it becomes more and more apparent that it won't be ending in a marriage proposal. But most of the time itâ€™s him. Just him. Rooms left dark, left empty, the house starting to curl in on itself, like a plant that canâ€™t find the sun. Kreacher does his best to tend to it but itâ€™s no use, and Regulus is certainly not helping.

â€œMaster Regulus is not eating enough,â€ the house elf mutters one day as he watches Regulus poking reluctantly at his dinner. â€œIs it being Kreachers fault sir? Is he not making it right? Is there something wrong with Master Regulusâ€™s meals?â€

Regulus looks up at him and manages a weak smile. â€œYour cooking is excellent as always Kreacher, Iâ€™m just notâ€¦hungry.â€

Kreacher throws a dish towel in the air in frustration. â€œBut you is never being hungry anymore!â€

Which is true. The potions fill him up and make food so much less appealing, his taste dulled. Itâ€™s all just mush.

â€œIâ€™ll eat more, I promise,â€ Regulus says as he shovels a fork full of pasta into his mouth, but when Kreacher turns his back Regulus vanishes the rest of his plate.

Â 

â€œAre you sick?â€

He blinks, coming back to himself, sitting on his bed while Cerci stares at him with worried eyes. He isnâ€™t sure how much time has passed between this conversation and the one with Kreacher.

Is it the next day? Is it two days later? A week? Heâ€™s aware that some time has passed, obviously, itâ€™s just the specifics that his mind doesnâ€™t quite seem able to hold onto.

â€œRegulus?â€

â€œSorry,â€ he mutters, rubbing at his face. â€œSorry, Iâ€™m just tired.â€

Cerci doesnâ€™t look like she believes him. â€œI think you need a Healer, my family knows a good one, I can take you right now, I have the whole afternoon freeâ€”â€œ

â€œNo, I donâ€™t want that,â€ he knows he sounds cranky and he doesnâ€™t mean to be, but he canâ€™t help it. â€œIâ€™m fine. I told you Iâ€™m fine.â€

â€œI know what youâ€™ve told me,â€ itâ€™s the first time he thinks heâ€™s ever heard her sound irritated. â€œBut youâ€™re lying, and not even very well.â€

He sighs, flopping down onto his bed and staring up at the ceiling. A few seconds later the mattress dips and Cerci sits next to him, face hovering above his.

She bites on her lower lip. â€œIâ€™m worried about you.â€

â€œThatâ€™s a waste of energy.â€

She rolls her eyes. â€œRight, okay well, Iâ€™m going to do it anyway.â€

He shrugs, still staring at the ceiling. â€œYour prerogative I guess.â€

He hears her sigh, a tense silence falling over them. The house creaks and groans around them, begging for help. For a little attention. A little magic to soak up. This place has always been the stronghold of the Black family, heâ€™s sure itâ€™s never felt so lonely before. Heâ€™s a bad caretaker. A bad son. A bad brother.

â€œI miss Boo,â€ Cerci breaks the silence eventually, because of course she does. â€œYou never have him around anymore.â€

â€œItâ€™s just a spell,â€ Regulus replies flatly. â€œNot a pet.â€

The truth is, Regulus canâ€™t cast his Patronus when heâ€™s high. That wasâ€¦surprisingly hard at first. Heâ€™d grown used to the ghostly presence at his side, to the warmth it summoned up in him, a physical representation of something that had long ago disappeared from his life. But Boo never helped him sleep, never stopped him thinking, so in the end he kept swallowing the potions. He barely even notices the absence anymore.

â€œAlright, enough, get up,â€ Cerci hops off the bed, taking Regulusâ€™s wrist and tugging on it until he reluctantly sits up.

â€œWhy are we getting up?â€ he grumbles.

â€œYouâ€™re going to bathe, because quite frankly you look like you havenâ€™t had a bath in a week.â€

To be fair, he might not have.

â€œAnd Iâ€™m going to make lunch.â€

â€œKreacher will be upset if you make food, you know that,â€ he says, though he does force himself off the bed.

â€œWell, he can help then. Câ€™mon, lets go, Iâ€™m assuming you can run the bath yourself? Or have you forgotten how?â€

â€œYouâ€™re hilarious.â€

She smiles at him, maybe the first genuine smile heâ€™s seen since she arrived. â€œI know.â€

Regulus does bathe and Cerci does make lunch (with Kreacherâ€™s help) and a few hours later she leaves, still looking at him like sheâ€™s worried heâ€™s going to fall apart the minute sheâ€™s out the door.

He doesnâ€™t though.

He isnâ€™t.

Falling apart that is.

Falling implies some sort of speed and destination.

If anything, Regulus is rotting.

Â 

He sleeps at some point. Gets up at some point. Crushes ingredients and stirs cauldrons and bottles potions and whenever he starts thinking too hard about where those potions are going or what theyâ€™re being used for he drinks his own. Then floats around the halls. Haunting his own house.

He isnâ€™t particularly observant at the moment, which he supposes is how it happens that he walks up the stairs to his bedroom one day and finds the Dark Lord standing there, staring at something on his desk. For a moment Regulus is certain this is some sort of hallucination, rubbing his eyes and wondering if heâ€™s swallowed a bad batch of potions. But all thoughts of hallucinations disappear when the man in front of him turns around. The cold chill that runs through Regulus then is more vivid and real than anything heâ€™s felt in weeks.

â€œRegulus,â€ the man says, voice slightly high and boyish despite his age. His skin seems almost translucent, eyes deep and dark and too large for his gaunt face. â€œIt has been too long.â€

Regulus canâ€™t say that he agrees.

â€œMy lord,â€ he finally manages to force out. â€œIâ€”Iâ€™m sorry I wasnâ€™t expecting you,â€ he wracks his blurry brain for any memory of an owl or Fire Call, anything that would have warned him of Voldemortâ€™s visit, but his thoughts slosh around in his head, running into one another and providing him with no answers.

â€œNo, my apologies, I didnâ€™t have time to call ahead Iâ€™m afraid.â€ The manâ€™s gaze is sharp and Regulus wonders if he can tell that he isnâ€™t at his best.

â€œNo apology necessary,â€ Regulus says, forcing himself to speak slowly, to annunciate, running over every word in his head a dozen times before speaking, not trusting his judgement a single bit. For a moment the man in front of him simply watches, long bony fingers stroking the book on the desk next to him.

â€œI see a great deal of myself in you Regulus.â€

Which is about as shocking a statement as any. For a moment Regulus flounders, not sure how to respond. He can feel his fear scratching against the cage heâ€™s put it in, but itâ€™s distant and distorted by the potions running through his body.

â€œIâ€”that is far too kind, I canâ€™t imagine I deserve the comparison.â€ He means that and doesnâ€™t at the same time.

Voldemort smiles again, the expression not reaching his eyes. â€œI have great hopes for you, as does your mother, your mind is far above many of your peers and intelligence like that excites me.â€

Regulus is still standing in the doorway, not daring to step further into the room, to close the space between them. Heâ€™s overly aware of how alone he is. Of the bed beside them. Of all the other times he has found uninvited guests in his bedroom.

â€œBut I think we can both agree,â€ the Dark Lord goes on, â€œthat you could be doing more.â€

God, Regulus wishes he was sober.

â€œI want nothing more than to serve you, my lord,â€ he says tightly, he may not feel his fear as acutely as he normally would, but that hasnâ€™t stopped his legs and hands from shaking.

â€œThat is good to hear,â€ Voldemort says, as though Regulus could say anything else. â€œLucius was afraid that you would be resistant.â€

Regulus grits his teeth. â€œWas he?â€ he asks thinly.

â€œHe feared your withdrawal from social life was a sign of your wavering support for our cause. But I was never concerned. Social connections are of little importance. I care only for your skill and your loyalty.â€

Regulus swallows back the bile crawling up his throat. He doesnâ€™t know why Lucius has been trying to turn Voldemort against him, if heâ€™s still bitter over James or what, but itâ€™s concerning. Whatever Voldemort might say now to his face, Regulus knows that Lucius is one of the most powerful members of his inner circle.

â€œMy skill and loyalty are yourâ€™s my lord, of course.â€

The man before him nods. â€œTaking the Ministry was far easier than we thought it would be,â€ he goes on bluntly. â€œWe intend to try again and hold it this time. I want you to be involved. I want someone with intelligence and not simply ambition making decisions on the ground.â€

There is absolutely nothing Regulus wants less. His stomach gives a lurch, threatening to vomit up the few bites of food heâ€™s choked down today.

â€œI would be honoured,â€ he barely gets the words out.

â€œExcellent. Severus will contact you soon with further details.â€

As if this offer couldnâ€™t be made more unappealing.

â€œThis book,â€ Voldemort says suddenly, tapping the cover heâ€™s been stroking for the entirety of the conversation. â€œWhere did you get it?â€ his tone is casual but a chill immediately runs down Regulusâ€™s spine.

He squints, trying to work out which book it is without stepping forward. When he takes too long to answer the Dark Lord presses on.

â€œI read it once, at Hogwarts,â€ he looks down at the cover. â€œI wasnâ€™t aware there was another copy.â€

Regulusâ€™s chest grows tight, suddenly realizing what book it must be. â€œI found it in the library here,â€ he lies, not wanting to bring Cerciâ€™s name into it.

â€œHm,â€ Voldemort hums softly, seemingly deep in thought before he picks the book up, holding it tightly in his grip. â€œWould you mind terribly if I borrowed it?â€ he asks, the request so ridiculous that Regulus almost laughs. As though he has the power to deny the Dark Lord anything he wants.

â€œOf course not, please.â€

The older man smiles again. â€œThank you,â€ he pulls a pocket watch from his robesâ€”a small metal thing, ornately engraved, catching the weak sunlight dripping through Regulusâ€™s window. â€œI must be going unfortunately,â€ he says before snapping it shut. â€œBut itâ€™s been a pleasure to see you again Regulus. Do take care of yourself.â€

He isnâ€™t sure why those last words sound like a threat, but heâ€™s still trying to calm his heartbeat even after Voldemort has left the room.

It takes him a while but eventually heâ€™s moving again, scrambling towards his desk, ruffling through the mess of papers until he finds his notes. Heâ€™s taken them meticulously on every book heâ€™s read, trying to figure out what it is thatâ€™s been drawing on the Dark Lordâ€™s magical core. He might be going out of his mind but he isnâ€™t stupid. Voldemort didnâ€™t take that book to do some light reading, thereâ€™s something in it that he doesnâ€™t want Regulus to know. To have.

But what?

He drops onto the floor, spreading the pieces of parchment out in front of him and comparing the notes from every other book to the one the Dark Lord took. What was special about it? What did it have that none of the others did? What is Voldemort trying to hide? He runs through chapter names, through ingredient lists, through incantations. Matching them up line for line.

There is very little published about the Dark Arts, itâ€™s a bit of a taboo area of interest. Much of the knowledge of the lore has been lost due to a reluctance to print it. Something his mother frequently laments. But it also means that there is a great deal of repetition in all the works Regulus has been reading. So whatever the Dark Lord is hiding, it ought to stand out.

Heâ€™s going through his copy of the bookâ€™s appendix when his attention catches on a single word;

Horcrux.

Something heavy drops into the pit of stomach as he starts shuffling through his other notes, checking all the other books, praying he finds a match, praying he can cross it off the list of possibilities even though, the more he looks, the more certain he becomes that he wonâ€™t be able to.

In all the research heâ€™s done over the past few weeks the only book that spoke about Horcuxâ€™s in any length was the book that the Dark Lord just snatched from his room.

The walls start to spin and Regulus braces himself against the floor, closing his eyes even though that just makes his sense of vertigo worse. He blames it on the potions and his lack of food and not the reality that is slowly settling around him. The truth that he isnâ€™t sure he can deny. It fits, fits with everything heâ€™s noticed in Voldemort over the past few weeks.

Heâ€™s made a Horcrux. Made himself practically immortal. Anyone he goes up against will inevitably lose. And really it shouldnâ€™t matter, because they were always going to lose. Voldemort was always going to win. Regulus knew that. But he also thought that one day Voldemort would die.

And nowâ€¦

Â 

PART II LILY

Lily loves Aliceâ€™s flat. Red walls and velvet couches and vintage posters of pin-up girls who wink and blow kisses when you walk by. She has twinkly lights that, unlike the Muggle versions Lily grew up with, float along the ceiling uninhibited by cords and outlets. They look like fireflies. You can see pieces of Frank here and thereâ€”Quidditch magazines on the coffee table, alphabetized bookshelves filled with magic theory textbooks, a Chuddley Canons mug in the sink. But in reality, Alice fills the spaceâ€”all warm and bold and comforting. Lily doesnâ€™t think Frank minds.

Theyâ€™re sitting on the shag carpet in the bedroom, bags of sweets spread around them, the record player on in the background. Marlene tears viciously into a gummy wand. â€œYou think theyâ€™ll call an election?â€ she asks, the serious nature of the question fully diminished by the half-chewed gummy in her mouth.

Itâ€™s been a few weeks since Voldemort and his followers gained temporary control of the Ministry. It all ended very civilly. The next day there were even pictures in the Prophet of Voldemort and the Minister shaking hands. A compromise reachedâ€”all civic employees were now required to have pureblood status, any current employees failing to meet this criteria would be let go. A small price, the Prophet had said, for the avoidance of violence. The whole thing was being talked about like it was some kind of political negotiation and not a hostile takeover. It made Lily feel sick.

â€œWithin the year,â€ Mary says measuredly, watching her chocolate frog with vague interest as it hops around her palm. â€œHe was supposed to be a hard-liner. Not very hard-line is it, giving into Voldemortâ€™s demands?â€

â€œHeâ€™s been in for a while now anyway hasnâ€™t he?â€ Lily asks, she has a vague memory of the last Wizarding election. Sheâ€™d only been fifteen, not old enough to vote, it hadnâ€™t seemed that important at the time.

Marlene shrugs, swallowing the rest of her jelly before she speaks this time. â€œI mean, not really. Loads of Ministers have stayed on for ten years or longer.â€

Lily makes a face. She isnâ€™t sure thereâ€™s a single politician in the Ministry right now that she wants to be stuck with for the next ten years. Sheâ€™s about to say as much when Alice comes bouncing into the room with an arm full of bubblegum pink potions.

â€œI have them, I have them, I have themmmmm!!!â€ she sings, plopping down between Mary and Marlene and passing out the small glass vials.

Lily turns herâ€™s over in her hand, the vibrant liquid inside hurting her eyes. â€œSo how do these things work exactly?â€she asks, shaking her potion.

â€œWell, you swallow itâ€”â€

â€œUsually a good place to start with a potion,â€ Mary says dryly.

Alice rolls her eyes and continues. â€œYou swallow it, give it fifteen minutes, and then if your tongue turns green, itâ€™s positive.â€

â€œHuh,â€ Lily says, still inspecting the liquid. â€œSo if you have a green tongue then youâ€™re up the duff?â€

Alice laughs. â€œExactly.â€

Mary nods at the potion in Marleneâ€™s hands. â€œSomething you wanna tell us Mar?â€

The other girl rolls her eyes. â€œOh what, like youâ€™re expecting to be pregnant?â€

â€œGod no,â€ Mary makes a disgusted face. â€œBut itâ€™s certainly more of a possibility.â€

â€œWeâ€™re doing this in solidarity,â€ Lily interrupts before the pair of them can get going, theyâ€™re honestly as bad as James and Sirius with their little quippy tangents. â€œPlus, I wanna see these things in action.â€

Mary arches her brow. â€œYou and Potter looking to start a little brood of your own?â€

She snorts. â€œOne day maybe, right now Iâ€™d rather live vicariously through Alice.â€

â€œOoh,â€ Alice shimmies her shoulders. â€œI do love being aspirational.â€

â€œHow accurate are these anyway?â€ Mary asks, holding her potion at eye level.

â€œA hundred percent, as long as theyâ€™re brewed correctly. Though youâ€™re supposed to wait at least an hour or so after the deed is done in order to get an accurate reading, which is a bit of a drag.â€

Lily and Mary both stare blankly at her.

â€œAn hour afterâ€”â€œ Lily starts but isnâ€™t quite able to finish the question.

â€œYou mean to tell me,â€ Mary picks up where Lily leaves off. â€œThat an hour after I fuck some dude this potion,â€ she holds up the little pink mixture, â€œwill tell me if Iâ€™m pregnant?â€

Both Marlene and Alice seem at a loss for why their friends are so caught up on this particular point.

â€œYes?â€ Alice ventures finally.

â€œHoly shit.â€

â€œGod I love magic,â€ Mary laughs. â€œYou got any spares lying around Longbottom? I could use these in my life.â€

â€œDo Muggles not have a way to tell if youâ€™re pregnant?â€ Marlene asks, sounding highly concerned.

â€œI mean they do,â€ Lily explains. â€œBut not anything that can tell you right away.â€

â€œHow long do you have to wait?â€ Alice seems similarly concerned.

â€œI donâ€™t know,â€ Lily looks at Mary who shrugs, â€œweeks, at least?â€

â€œWEEKS?â€ Alice and Marlene demand in unison.

â€œAnd if you donâ€™t want to go the hospital for it itâ€™s a bloody pain to do at home,â€ Mary grumbles. â€œThe kits are like a potions lessons. A lot of mixing things with urine.â€

â€œWITH WHAT?â€

Lily bites back a smile, leaning into Mary ever so slightly. â€œI think we might be traumatizing them,â€ she mock whispers.

â€œWizards,â€ Mary sighs, â€œso delicate.â€

â€œIâ€™m sending you both home with a dozen of these,â€ Alice says indignantly. â€œThat sounds completely barbaric.â€

â€œI mean Iâ€™m not sure itâ€™s barbaric, though itâ€™s certainly inconvenient.â€

â€œAlso you are aware that weâ€™re Witches right? We can buy our own potions?â€ Lily adds.

â€œGive them out to your Muggle friends then! They shouldnâ€™t have to put up with this.â€

â€œThatâ€™s definitely illegal,â€ Marlene chimes in.

â€œThough I do appreciate the sentiment,â€ Mary nudges Aliceâ€™s knee with her own. â€œAnd Iâ€™ll take you up on those dozen potions.â€

â€œDone.â€

â€œSpeaking of potions,â€ Lily says, holding up the one in her hand. â€œMaybe we should take these, yeah? I wanna find out whether or not Iâ€™m going to be an auntie.â€

â€œYesssss,â€ Marlene drags out her â€œsâ€. â€œAll I want is to be a cool aunt.â€

Mary snorts. â€œYou really think youâ€™re going to be the cool aunt?â€

â€œOi!â€

â€œTo everyone being the cool aunt,â€ Lily uncorks her vial and lifts it into the centre of the circle.

â€œThis might be my favourite toast ever,â€ Alice lifts her own potion happily.

â€œTo spoiled brats,â€ Mary joins them.

â€œThe responsible thing to do is get rid of it,â€ she repeats. â€œWeâ€™reâ€”weâ€™re too young and weâ€™re not ready and we havenâ€™t even been together that long, not to mention weâ€™re in the middle of a bloody war,â€ she runs a hand through her hair, â€œThe responsible thing to do is get rid of it.â€

â€œRight,â€ James says, not knowing if heâ€™s supposed to be giving feedback at this point but feeling that he needs to at least let her know that heâ€™s listening.

â€œBut,â€ Lilyâ€™s voice cracks, and she looks away, looks up at the ceiling, blinking the moisture from her eyes. â€œBut I just keep thinkingâ€”keep thinking,â€ she laughs wetly, â€œwhat if theyâ€™re a Quidditch player.â€

â€œOh,â€ James says for the second time, the entire contents of his chest lurching.

Eventually Lily brings her gaze back down, eyes still wet. â€œYou know?â€

He nods, because he does. He does know. And suddenly James feels an overwhelming swell of emotion hit him. For Lily. For the life they have. For the life they could have.

â€œIâ€”â€œ he starts and then stops, having to clear his throat before he continues. â€œI want this.â€ Lilyâ€™s eyes grow wide. â€œIf you want this,â€ he goes on. â€œI want this.â€

For a minute she just stares at him, terrified, and then, slowly, she nods. â€œI want this,â€ she whispers, like maybe she thinks sheâ€™s not allowed to. And finally the tears spill down her cheeks and James pulls her in, wrapping her in his arms and feeling her burrow against his chest.

He kisses the top of her head before he laughs. â€œFuck.â€

â€œYeah,â€ Lily agrees, words slightly muffled. Itâ€™s a few seconds before she speaks again. â€œIâ€™m glad itâ€™sâ€¦Iâ€™m glad itâ€™s with you,â€ she says, making Jamesâ€™s heart flip. He squeezes her a little tighter.

â€œYeah,â€ he murmurs into her hair. â€œYeah Iâ€™m glad itâ€™s you too.â€

Â 

PART IV SIRIUS

Sirius is whistling when he gets home, carelessly throwing his jacket over the sofa and heading for the kitchen.

â€œHey, youâ€™re back,â€ he smiles at Remus who is sat at the table, some terribly thick and boring looking book in front of him.

â€œHi,â€ Remus says a little hesitantly, as Sirius brushes past him to the fridge, pulling out a beer and twisting off the cap.

â€œHow was Moody then?â€ he asks, leaning back against he counter and taking a drink.

â€œFine. Yâ€™know, as pleasant as ever.â€

Sirius grins. â€œRegular ray of sunshine he is.â€

He can feel Remus looking him over. â€œYouâ€™re in a good mood,â€ he says finally.

Siriusâ€™s grin only widens. â€œI am. Listen, donâ€™t freak out, but Iâ€™ve bought a motorbike.â€

Remus, much to Siriusâ€™s surprise, doesnâ€™t freak out. In fact, he barely reacts at all. Which is when Sirius notices the tension in Remusâ€™s shoulders, in his face. He feels his smile slip. â€œWhat is it?â€

Remus grimaces. â€œIâ€™mâ€”Iâ€™m leaving again. For a bit.â€

Siriusâ€™s whole body goes stiff. â€œAh,â€ he says, placing his beer down on the counter with more force than is strictly necessary. â€œWell, I must have done something right, to earn the privilege of being told in person this time.â€

Remus doesnâ€™t bother trying to hide his flinch.

Sirius does the math quickly in his head. â€œAnother full moon,â€ he says.

Remus nods, looking at the floor or the table, but certainly not at Sirius.

â€œWerewolves then,â€ the words tasting all wrong in his mouth. â€œThisâ€”this task Dumbledore has given you, this place you disappear to, it has to do with werewolves?â€

â€œSirius,â€ Remus says, in a tone that suggests that this is not going to be a fruitful direction for the conversation to go in.

â€œYeah, right, sorry, top secret and all that. Wouldnâ€™t want to let anything slip,â€ he picks up his beer again but finds he doesnâ€™t want it anymore, chucking it in the sink before dropping into one of the available kitchen chairs, arms crossed over his chest.

The silence seems to stretch on forever but Sirius isnâ€™t about to be the one to break it. Especially since heâ€™s not sure he can trust himself to say anything pleasant right now.

â€œAre youâ€”â€œ Remus eventually starts and then stops, face screwing itself up in frustration. â€œAre you going to beâ€¦hanging outâ€¦with Mary.â€

The question catches Sirius completely off guard, Remus still not looking at him. They havenâ€™t talked about what happened with Mary. About the kiss. Not that they ever talk about the things they should. Sirius feels a tidal wave of shame rise up in him.

â€œIâ€”â€œ he clears his throat. He knows what the real question is here. Knows it has nothing to do with hanging out with Mary. â€œNo. Iâ€™m notâ€”no.â€ He grits his teeth.

He needs to say more. He does. But apologies have always been difficult for him. Difficult when coming from a house where â€œsorryâ€ was nothing but another way for his mother to humiliate him. To force him to his knees. To make him beg. Heâ€™s never quite managed one without a bad taste being left in his mouth.

Eventually he reaches out, hand wrapping around Remusâ€™s wrist and tugging, until, rolling his eyes, Remus allows himself to be pulled out of his seat and into Siriusâ€™s lap. It isnâ€™t exactly the most comfortable position, but it allows Sirius to burry his face in the crook of Remusâ€™s neck. To bask in the heat of him. The weight. And like this. Like this itâ€™s almost bearable.

â€œIâ€™m sorry.â€

Sirius kisses his shoulder right after and he barely tastes the humiliation at all. Remus is silent for a while, but he has his arms wrapped around Sirius and he considers that a win.

â€œI need us to be in this together,â€ Remus finally says, voice soft. â€œItâ€™s too fucking painful being in it alone.â€

Sirius squeezes his eyes shut for a minute, glad that Remus canâ€™t see his face, canâ€™t see the things those words do to him. He bites the crook of Remusâ€™s neck and is rewarded with a huff.

â€œWe are,â€ Sirius says finally. â€œI promise we are.â€

He feels Remus nod, hair tickling his cheek.

â€œWhen do you have to leave?â€

â€œTomorrow morning.â€

Itâ€™s Siriusâ€™s turn to nod, and then, in the next second, heâ€™s getting to his feet and taking Remus with him.

â€œWhat the fuckâ€”Siriusâ€”Oh for Merlinâ€™sâ€”put me down you lunatic!â€

Sirius has managed to get Remus at least partially over his shoulder. Heâ€™s very limb-y and the task of carrying him isnâ€™t made any easier by his squirming.

â€œPut me down! Siriusâ€”youâ€™re ridiculous you know that?â€

Somehow Sirius manages to wrangle him into the bedroom, dropping him a little bit clumsily onto the bed, Remus laughing despite himself.

Sirius kisses him then, the way he used to dream about before kissing Remus Lupin was something he was allowed to do. Before it was something he allowed himself to want. He lays himself bare in that kiss, cuts himself open. It is all tenderness and longing. It is all love, love, love. Sirius never seems to be able to speak all the sweet nice words that lovers are supposed to. But he could write sonnets with his lips.

He wants Remus to know.

To understand.

That he never could have kissed Mary like this.

There are hands and teeth and nails. Spit and curses and heavy breathing. And Iâ€™m sorryâ€™s. And Iâ€™m scaredâ€™s. And donâ€™t leaveâ€™s. Those are the kisses that last the longest. That hit the hardest. That linger even after they are spent and sweaty and lying in one anotherâ€™s arms.

Â 

Sirius wakes up to a dark room and the dreamy feeling of fingers in his hair.

â€œHmm,â€ he hums happily, still caught between wakefulness and sleep. â€œI love when you do that.â€

He can hear the smile in Remusâ€™s voice. â€œYeah, I know.â€

Sirius blinks his eyes open, looking up to find Remus sitting on the edge of the bed, fully dressed.

â€œI have to go,â€ Remus says regretfully.

Sirius doesnâ€™t know what his face does, too sleepy to be guarded.

â€œI know,â€ Remus sighs, hand sliding down from Siriusâ€™s hair to cup his cheek, thumb running along Siriusâ€™s bottom lip. â€œI love you.â€

In response Sirius turns his head and kisses Remusâ€™s palm, eyes already drooping closed despite his best efforts. In the distance he hears Remusâ€™s quiet laugh.

Â 

The next time Sirius wakes up the flat is empty.

Chapter End Notes

Hello beautiful people!

Listen, a Jegulus reunion will happen. I promise you. I'm officially calling this fic a reverse slow-burn, like they get together fast, but they come back together slow.

I also just want to say that I am so overwhelmingly touched by the amount of support I received after the last chapter. It means so much, and some of those comments were just so thoughtful, and I promise I'm going to try and respond to them (I thought I would get through my messages on Tumblr first but it turns out that is taking longer than I thought). I also just want to make sure it's clear that criticism of this fic is totally valid so please don't feel like you have to defend it and especially don't, y'know, attack anyone who is offering up their opinion on it it's totally their right to do so and I 100% support that.

Okay, as always thank you all so much for hanging around and reading, and being your lovely selves, I read all the comments (even if I suck at replying) and appreciate them so yeah, hope you're having a great day!

Chapter 49

Chapter Summary

Welcome to Lupercal

Chapter Notes

tw Violence

tw Brief mention of suicide

tw Death (NOT main character, can't stress this enough, don't freak out, Regulus very much does not die in this chapter)

Oh yeah, and this definitely fucks with canon, I'm not sure specifically how, but definitely somewhere canon was fucked

See the end of the chapter for more notes

The sun is barely kissing the horizon as Remus jogs down the street, clutching his canvas duffle bag to his side. Itâ€™s cold this morning, his cheeks rosy, fingers going a little numb. The rusted blue Volkswagen Camper in front of him honks encouragingly as he hears the side door banging open.

â€œYouâ€™re late!â€ a voice shouts, echoing in the empty street, scaring the pigeons.

Remus huffs the last few feet to the car, grabbing the roof and swinging himself inside. â€œIâ€™m-not-late,â€ he manages between breaths, sliding into his seat. Someone else shuts the door. Remus flashes his watch at the driver with a grin. â€œSee, six AM, on the dot. Iâ€™m very literally on time.â€

The old man rolls his eyes, turning back to face the road. Heâ€™s balding on the top of his head, with a thick auburn beard covering his face. â€œCheeky,â€ he mutters, eyes finding Remus in the rearview mirror, unable to hide his amusement as he pulls away from the curb.

Remus settles, nodding at the other six passengers in the camper. Heâ€™s seen a few of them on his other visits but thereâ€™s at least two of them that are new facesâ€”new to him anyway. None of them talk, itâ€™s too early, Remus turning his head towards the window and watching the sky light up as the day slowly creeps in and they leave the city behind. Buildings and cars turn into fields and endless motorways, the early morning sun sparkling against the asphalt.

The first time heâ€™d come up, heâ€™d done it on his own. He had to take a train and then a bus, and then walk for about two miles. By the time he saw the sign his feet were killing him.

â€œLooks like youâ€™re planing to stay a while.â€

It takes Remus a moment to realize Arnoldâ€”the driverâ€”is talking to him. He blinks, still half-asleep, looking down at the bag in his lap. After a few seconds he shrugs.

â€œMight be, never know, wanted toâ€¦keep my options open I suppose,â€ he tries to give the old man a smile that doesnâ€™t betray any of the feelings swirling around inside of him.

â€œOptions huh?â€ Arnold asks, nodding. â€œWell, I know plenty of the folks up there will be happy to hear that.â€

â€œIâ€™m not promising anything though, so donâ€™t go gossiping,â€ Remus says, only half joking.

Arnold laughs, itâ€™s a deep noise, coming right from his belly. Like Santa Clause. â€œNo, you donâ€™t strike me as the type who makes many promises.â€

Remus chews on the inside of his lip to stop himself from grimacing, turning back towards the window. Little does Arnold know, Remus actually makes promises all the time, he just isnâ€™t particularly good at keeping them.

On his first visit things went wrong almost immediately. After the two mile walk he came to a painted wooden sign that read â€œLupercalâ€ at the top of a dirt road, bordered on either side by thick woods. Somewhere, at the end of this road, there was supposedly an old farm house that Remus was meant to find.

Moody had specifically told him not to make first contact on the full moon, he figured it would be safer, and Remus couldnâ€™t say that he disagreed. See, Lupercal is the largest group of werewolves all living in one place that the Ministry has ever been aware of. Moody refers to them as the â€œPackâ€ but Remus canâ€™t quite get over the discomfort that leaves him with. It makes it feel too much like theyâ€™re discussing animals.

â€œSandwich?â€

Remus turns to see the man next to him, whoâ€™d been asleep the last time Remus checked, offering him a Tupperware full of what appear to be ham and cheese sandwiches. Remus is going to refuse but he didnâ€™t have time to eat before he left and even just the mention of food has his stomach grumbling.

â€œThanks,â€ he gives in, reaching out and taking a quarter.

The man smiles. Heâ€™s one of the people Remus doesnâ€™t recognize. He looks like he might be close to thirty, with freckles speckling his face.

â€œNo problem. I always try to share, yâ€™know? Put that energy out into the universe, incase one day I need someone to return the favour.â€

This kind of attitude, Remus has learned, is actually quite common amongst werewolves. He supposes it comes from living such unpredictable livesâ€”being fired or evicted whenever their truth is discovered. Relying heavily on the charity of strangers and friends. Thereâ€™s no such thing as stability when youâ€™re a werewolf. Well, unless you have the good fortune of sitting in a train compartment with James Potter and Sirius Black one day.

â€œWeâ€™re about to pass the last Petrol station for a while you lot,â€ Arnold calls back to them. â€œIf anyone needs a wee speak now.â€

Thereâ€™s some laughter, but no requests are made.

â€œGoing once, going twiceâ€”â€œ they speed past the station in a blur of colour. â€œGone.â€

â€œI thought it was supposed to be â€œsoldâ€ not gone?â€ someone from the back heckles.

â€œDo I look like a fucking auctioneer McDavid?â€

â€œIs that a rhetorical question?â€

Thereâ€™s more quiet laughter, all of them turning back to their books or naps, or thoughts.

When Remus finally saw the farm house for the first time it was from a distance, down that dirt road, trees still blocking parts of it from view. It had been a sunny afternoon, not a cloud in sight, and while Remus had been nervous his guard had, admittedly, been down somewhat. And that's when he'd heard it.

Growling.

The hair on the back of his neck had stood up even while his brain screamed â€œno, no itâ€™s not possibleâ€. And yet, despite everything reason told him, when he turned his head the impossible had been right there.

Two glowing yellow eyes, staring out at him from between the trees.

The shock had paralyzed him, unable to move, to think, to grab his wand, as he stared into the face of a werewolf. A fully transformed werewolf. In the middle of the day. Weeks away from the full moon. Remus simply couldnâ€™t process a single part of that. And then, a second later, he felt claws and teeth sinking into his skin.

The wolf threw them into the trees on the other side of the road, branches and bushes whipping against Remusâ€™s back with such force they shredded his shirt. He had wondered, in a very detached way, if there was some sort of poetic irony in him dying at the hands of a werewolf.

He isnâ€™t sure how long it went on for, the wolf tearing him apart, Remus trying and failing to fight back. But eventually he heard a voice. Shouting somewhere in the distance. And then a howl. The wolf stopped, leaving Remus just floating there in the darkness, barely conscious. Eventually the weight on top of him disappeared, and the last thing he remembers before he slipped away completely, is the feel of a wet nose pressing against his cheek.

He was unconscious for three days after that.

â€œHere we are,â€ Arnold says as he turns down that same dirt road, past the sign and through the trees.

Remus generally rather likes this drive. Itâ€™s scenic. Calming. This bit though, right at the end, still makes his stomach drop. Phantom claws prickling his skin.

The main building at Lupercal is a large, ancient looking farm house. Wide, two stories tall, made of grey stone with rows of windows and a thatched roof. The lawn in front is luscious and green, some of the kids running around.

â€œAlright, get gone you lot, I have a busy schedule,â€ Arnold says as he parks the camper at the end of the drive.

â€œThanks Arnold,â€ Remus says as he slides out of the car.

â€œSee you soon Lupin, or maybe not so soon huh?â€ Remus sends him a look that has Arnold holding his hands up in surrender. â€œI know, I know, no promises,â€ he winks.

Remus adjusts the strap of his bag over his shoulder, the other travellers breaking off, some heading up towards the main house, others off towards the barn thatâ€™s also been converted into a living space. Remus has only just looked up when the front door flies open and a beaming face looks right at him.

â€œRemus!â€ the boy shouts, jogging down the front lawn towards him and pulling him into a hug without a second thought.

â€œOof,â€ it takes him a minute, but eventually Remus hugs him back. â€œHey Gabe.â€

The other boy pulls away but keeps his hands on Remusâ€™s shoulders. â€œYou came.â€

Moody hadnâ€™t exactly given him much of a choice on the matter. But the truth is, even if he had had a choice, Remus probably still would have come. He thinks of Sirius back in their flat, alone in their bed, and barely suppresses a wince.

â€œI told you I would,â€ he says finally.

Gabe grins. â€œYou did.â€

Gabe is the opposite of Remus in every way, at least physically. Heâ€™s shorter, muscular, with brown skin and a shaved head, tattoos snaking up his arms.

â€œWhere the hell are your clothes Gabe?â€ Remus asks, as the pair heads towards the house.

â€œIâ€™m pretty sure Iâ€™m dressed.â€

â€œYou donâ€™t have any sleeves.â€

â€œObservant of you.â€

â€œItâ€™s October.â€

â€œAnd he knows the date, gosh you are very impressive Remus Lupin. You really are.â€

Remus sighs. Heâ€™s not sure what he did to piss the universe off so much that it decided to fill his life with nothing but sarcastic bastards, but he is more than willing to perform some sort of ritual sacrifice to make it end.

â€œWell look who it is!â€ A girl with strawberry blonde hair comes around the corner, in ripped jeans and a Muggle band shirt. She hugs him too. Everyone here is very hug-y. Remus does his best to be accommodating.

â€œHey Ava,â€ he says, when she pulls away.

â€œI see this oneâ€™s already allover you,â€ she rubs the top of Gabeâ€™s head.

â€œOh fuck off,â€ Gabe pinches her side and she laughs, the three of them walking up the front steps and into the house.

The inside is warm, thereâ€™s no other way to describe it. Walls covered in finger paintings and photosâ€”Muggle photosâ€”all of the furniture well loved. The sound of singing drifts towards them from the kitchen.

â€œOi mum,â€ Gabe says as they walk towards the noise. â€œThe city slickers are here.â€

Remus rolls his eyes. Having grown up where he did heâ€™ll never be able to think of himself as a Londoner, but then, heâ€™s not about to tell Gabe that.

Mia is standing in the kitchen by the sink, a small girl in her arms. Well, Remus says small. She must be five or six, too old, he would have thought, to be held the way she is. Remus runs through all the kids he met last time but he canâ€™t place her.

â€œAh Remus, lovely to see you again,â€ Mia says with a smile, attention quickly hopping back to Gabe. â€œCan I get you to run to the barn and bring this to Harper? Sheâ€™s still not feeling well,â€ she gestures to the covered dishes on the counter.

â€œYeah, â€˜course,â€ Gabe squeezes Remusâ€™s arm as he goes by, grabbing, what Remus can only assume is food, and heading out the back door towards the barn.

â€œPut your bag down Remus, take a seat, take a seat, do you want tea?â€ Mia asks, blowing a strand of brown hair from her face, still bouncing the little girl on her hip.

â€œUh, sure Iâ€”â€œ

A shriek sounds from the front room, followed by loud whining; â€œWilliam thatâ€™s mineeee!â€

Mia rolls her eyes. â€œAva do you mindâ€”â€œ

â€œOn it chief,â€ she gives Mia a two fingered salute before sending Remus a look, like heâ€™s in on some sort of joke. Like sheâ€™s known him for years and not months.

â€œSit, sit,â€ Mia says again. â€œTea, yes?â€

â€œEr,â€ he laughs a little, dropping his bag on the ground and taking a seat at the rickety wooden table that looks like itâ€™s half covered in various art projects. â€œYeahâ€”yes, please. Tea would be great, thank you.â€

â€œLovely, do you mind holding Charlotte while I get it?â€ she asks while simultaneously transferring the little girl into Remusâ€™s somewhat hesitant arms. â€œSheâ€™s nervous about being on her own at the moment,â€ Mia says as she sets the kettle on the stove.

The little girl doesnâ€™t even bat an eye at being handed off to a stranger, instantly hiding her face in Remusâ€™s shoulder. Sheâ€™s heavy and warm and soft and heâ€™s almost positive he is not responsible enough to be holding her.

â€œHowâ€™ve you been then?â€ Mia asks, pulling a pair of mugs from the cupboard. One of them appears to be in the shape of a panda head.

â€œIâ€™ve been, yâ€™know, Iâ€™ve been fine.â€ There's only so much he can tell. It's not that he hasn't said anything about himself, I mean, they know his name. Know who his father is. But they donâ€™t know that he was sent here by Alastor Moody. That heâ€™s meant to report back; what theyâ€™re doing and thinking and saying. Who theyâ€™re talking to. If theyâ€™ve had any contact with Death Eaters. As far as anyone at Lupercal is aware, Remus heard a rumour about this place and decided to check it out for himself.

â€œYou donâ€™t sound fine,â€ Mia shoots him a knowing look over her shoulder. â€œYou sound miserable.â€

He canâ€™t help but laugh. Sheâ€™s not wrong. Not exactly. The little girl in his arms squirms.

â€œYouâ€™re too young to be miserable Remus,â€ she leans back against the counter, waiting for the water to finish boiling. â€œYou oughta be having fun.â€

He smiles grimly back at her. â€œBit hardâ€¦under the circumstances.â€

â€œHmm,â€ she says, unconvinced. â€œBut are you even trying?â€

Remus blinks, opening and then closing his mouth. All things considered, itâ€™s an entirely unfair question. Itâ€™s not as though he can just decide to stop the war. But, I mean, is he trying to be anything but miserable? No, not really. Heâ€™s mostly just, accepted itâ€¦seems like the easiest option.

Luckily heâ€™s saved from having to answer by the screaming of the kettle. â€œAh,â€ Mia says, turning to lift it off the heat, â€œhold that thought.â€

The girl in Remusâ€™s arms makes an unhappy noise, the first noise, in fact, that heâ€™s heard her make this whole time. Wriggling again, adjusting herself on his lap. He looks down at her and feels his whole body go cold.

In her adjusting her shirt has slipped slightly down her shoulder. And there, brazen against her skin, is a large, angry bite mark. Itâ€™s healed but not scarred yet. Meaning it canâ€™t be more than a few days old. Remus canâ€™t look away, he wants to, desperately, but he justâ€¦he thinks he might be shaking.

A little boy sleeping in his bedroom.

Claws scraping on hardwood floors.

Teeth and Teeth and Teeth.

â€œRemus? Remus?â€

He blinks, finally forcing himself to look up, finding Mia at the table, tea forgotten, the expression on her face telling him this isnâ€™t the first time sheâ€™s said his name. He opens his mouth to try to explain but finds that he canâ€™t.

She doesnâ€™t seem to need him to. â€œAva?â€ she calls out.

â€œYeah?â€ comes her voice from down the hall.

â€œCan you come take Charlotte for a minute please?â€ she never takes her eye off of Remus. He can hear the sound of Avaâ€™s footsteps on the old floorboards.

â€œOf course I can,â€ she says as she slips into the room. Remus sees the moment she registers something is wrong, eyes bouncing between him and Mia. Heâ€™s worried sheâ€™s going to ask for an explanation but instead she just puts on her little kid voice; â€œOkay darling, youâ€™re coming with me, lets go wrangle those big kids huh?â€ she takes her easily from Remusâ€™s arms, which barely even seem to be working at the moment.

He watches Mia nod to her, listens to the footsteps again, this time disappearing into the distance. And then Mia is sitting in front of him, her face level with Remusâ€™s.

â€œIâ€™m okay,â€ he chokes out.

A sad smile pulls at her mouth. â€œOh honey, you are the farthest thing from okay.â€

Remus isnâ€™t sure he thinks thatâ€™s fair but he lets it slide. â€œShe wasnâ€™t here the last time I was,â€ he finally manages, unsure if itâ€™s even what he means to say.

There are a few seconds of stillness before Mia nods. â€œNo, she wasnâ€™t.â€

Remusâ€™s chest feels tight. â€œGreyback?â€

â€œOr one of his supporters.â€

Remus doesnâ€™t think he hides his disgust. Or his fear. Heâ€™d been surprised by the number of kids here the last time he visited. Heâ€™d always thought that he was a bit of an anomaly, targeted because of his fatherâ€™s work. He hadnâ€™t realized that Greyback had made it his mission to turn as many children as he could get his hands on.

â€œHer parents?â€

Mia sighs, â€œSame old story, they donâ€™t know what to do with her, donâ€™t know how to handle it. Theyâ€™re afraid.â€

â€œTheyâ€™re afraid?â€ Remus demands. â€œHow do they think she feels?â€

She offers him a sad smile. â€œI expect they try very hard not to think about it.â€

Gabe was the first kid Mia ever took in. Remus found that out last time. After sheâ€™d been turned Mia lived out here on her own, something of a hermit. Until one day she got an owl from an old friend working at St Mungos. It said a little boy had been left, abandoned actually, at the hospitalâ€™s front door. A werewolf bite on his stomach.

â€œSo when you say sheâ€™s nervousâ€¦â€ Remus pushes, staring down the hall like he can still see Charlotte.

â€œShe was attacked playing alone in her back garden, she starts panicking if you put her down for too long, poor thing. Thinks something is coming to get her.â€

After Gabe, Mia told the friend to let her know anytime someone came in with a bite or symptoms. She wanted to help. To offer people like her a safe place, if they needed it. She had been just as surprised as Remus to discover so many of those people were children.

â€œWill they come back?â€ Remus asks finally, after a long pause. â€œHer parents?â€

â€œThey might, they do sometimes, once theyâ€™ve adjusted, wrapped their minds around it. Mourned the life they thought they would have.â€

Remus canâ€™t help but think of his own parents. Canâ€™t help but be grateful for them. For all of Lyall Lupinâ€™s faults, he hadnâ€™t left his son on the hospitalâ€™s doorstep, and Remus supposes that counts for something.

â€œSometimes they come back,â€ Mia goes on when Remus doesnâ€™t. â€œBut sometimesâ€¦â€

Gabe comes bounding through the back door, cheeks flushed from the run over to the barn, smile on his face as it almost always is. â€œOoh tea,â€ he says, reaching for one of the abandoned mugs on the counter. â€œBrilliant.â€

Â 

Remus has the same bedroom he did last time, in the loft of the barn. Itâ€™s small, with a single bed and plain wooden dresser. The roof is slanted so he has to duck down in some spots, and thereâ€™s a circular window on the outside wall. There are several rooms like this at Lupercal, for people like him, who come only around the full moon, so that they can have a safe place to transform, away from their towns and cities. Itâ€™s far better than being locked in a cell at the Ministry. Or at least thatâ€™s what Remus has been told, he himself has been spared that particular indignity.

Thatâ€™s where Arnold comes in. Driving the shuttle around to the areas surrounding Lupercal and picking up anyone who wants to come. Last time, Remusâ€™s first time meeting Arnold, heâ€™d asked him why he did it. It takes at least two or three days to pick up everyone, a rather monotonous task, and itâ€™s not as though heâ€™s getting paid. Remus wanted to know more about Arnold. About how heâ€™d met Mia, how heâ€™d ended up living here, how he was bitten in the first place. But he refrained. Heâ€™d never seen another werewolf in real life before, well, besides Greyback. Not until the day heâ€™d turned his head and found those glowing yellow eyes staring at him between the trees.

Suffice to say, on his first visit, he hadnâ€™t had the chance to ask many questions. Nor had he had his own bedroom. Heâ€™d woken up in Miaâ€™s bed. Disoriented and frightened and in nearly unbearable pain. He had never before been forced to endure injury without magic. Never had to let a wound heal on its own or a bone mend the slow way that Muggles do. Never had to feel any of it for longer than it took to unstopper a pain potion. But he had learned quickly that magic is not common at Lupercal.

Remus had been unconscious for three days after the attack. When he woke he was disoriented and weak and in pain. The other thing that had stuck with Remus, from the blur of those few days after heâ€™d woken up, was Jack. I didnâ€™t bite you.

I didnâ€™t bite you.

They checked.

I didnâ€™t bite you.

Remus was certain the refrain was for Jack more than it was for him. A reassurance that he hadnâ€™t done the unthinkable. The thing all of them are terrified of. The fear that haunts their existences.

Remus should have said something comforting to the kidâ€”like that it really wouldnâ€™t have mattered if he hadâ€”but the truth is, heâ€™d barely been able to process anything. If it had been up to him he wouldnâ€™t have. Two werewolf attacks was more than enough for one lifetime he felt. But as Moody had been very keen to point out. It wasnâ€™t up to him.

Â 

Itâ€™s late when Remus and Gabe get back to the main house. The children have all gone to bed, the candles have all been lit, someone has put the record player on. That full moon, transforming with werewolves for the first time, it was different. Sure it helped, when he had Prongs and Padfoot and Wormtail. But there was always an undercurrent of fear. He felt guilty about everything honestly. Tearing himself apart trying to figure out how to make it right. How to make it up to Sirius somehow. Only to find out that while heâ€™d been haunted by guilt Sirius had been snogging his ex-girlfriend.

Heâ€™d meant the guilt. But he knew that wasnâ€™t how Sirius took it. Not after the shape heâ€™d been in the last time heâ€™d come home. Not once heâ€™d made the connection to werewolves. Â 

He transforms under the night sky.

Transforms with the sharp crisp air of the woods in his lungs.

With Gabe at his side.

And he does.

And he does.

And he does.

Oh how happy.

To feel dirt beneath his paws.

And pack nuzzling his fur.

Oh how happy to play.

To sing.

To chase.

They howl into the night and their voices mix together, reaching up above and tangling with the stars.

Oh how happy.

How happy.

To be wolf.

Â 

The next day is slow. It always is. Most of them remain in their rooms. But dinner is had together, as always. And though Remus is tired and sore, with a few cuts here and there, he feels better than he has in ages.

â€œSomeone needs to separate you two,â€ Ava says as she falls into step with him and Gabe on their walk across the yard towards the main house. Sheâ€™s clutching a travel mug to her chest. She has bags under her eyes and a split lip but otherwise sheâ€™s unmarked.

Itâ€™s something heâ€™s noticed, about the wolves here, at least the young ones. The lack of scars. Gabe and Ava have barely any. When Remus asked Gabe about it heâ€™d looked sad. â€œIt isnâ€™t normal you know, for wolves to hurt themselves,â€ heâ€™d said. â€œItâ€™sâ€¦almost an anxiety response. Happens when weâ€™re alone. â€œListen,â€ Gabe says now, half laughing. â€œThis isnâ€™t our fault,â€ he gestures at her lip. â€œYouâ€™re the one who got in the middle of us.â€

â€œI hate him,â€ he hears Ava say behind them.

â€œYou keep telling yourself that,â€ Liam replies.

Dinner is nice. A bit less energetic than normal perhaps but thereâ€™s something soâ€¦warm about it. So comforting. No one fusses over him, no one sends him nervous looks. Thereâ€™s no need for him to feel self-conscious about the few scrapes on his face, no need to come up with excuses. People discuss the full moon like itâ€™sâ€¦normal. No big dealâ€”small talk. This thing heâ€™s spent his whole life hiding with his every breath is here laid bare. Itâ€™sâ€¦heâ€™s not sure he even has the words to describe it. What it means. â€œExcuse me.â€

Remusâ€™s looks up to see Jack leaving the table early, heading out the front door. Heâ€™s been quiet all day. Quiet since Remus got here honestly. Head down, eyes on the floor.

â€œIâ€™ll be back in a minute,â€ Remus says, to no one in particular, Gabe and Ava once again engaged in an argument so intensely he probably could have grown wings and they wouldnâ€™t have noticed.

He walks outside, worried he waited too long, that he wonâ€™t be able to find Jack. But thankfully, the kid is just sitting on the porch steps, staring out at the long driveway in front of him. Remus takes in a deep breath before stepping forward and sitting down next to him.

Jack instantly stiffens.

â€œWhen I was fifteen my friendâ€”â€œ his throat closes for a moment, hands shaking already. He holds onto his knees, neither him nor Jack looking at each other, but he knows the other boy is listening.

â€œWhen I was fifteen,â€ he starts again, â€œmyâ€¦friend, he told someone at school how to get to me on the full moon.â€

Jack hisses, like heâ€™s been burned. â€œFuck,â€ the word so soft Remus can barely hear him.

There is something strangely affirming about having him understand instantly, what that would mean. How much that would mean. Sirius will never know how vulnerable it is to transform. â€œThe hell I am!â€

â€œRemus,â€ Dumbledore says firmly, like a disappointed parent. â€œThis is important. It has never been about your personal feelings but about attempting to keep as many werewolves as possible from turning to Voldemort.â€

â€œBut Greyback has already chosen Voldemort,â€ Remus says desperately. He canâ€™t imagine being forced to spend time with him. To listen and look and smell him. He canâ€™t imagine having to see him fully transformed. The thought alone makes Remus start to feel panicky.

â€œThen convince his followers to do otherwise,â€ Moody snaps. â€œOr if you canâ€™t do that at least keep us informed on their plans. Their whereabouts.â€

Remus folds forward, dropping his head into his hands. He hates this. Hates this with every fibre of his being. Heâ€™s tired of it. The secrets and the disappearing and the double life. Itâ€™s too hard. Heâ€™s too exhausted.

â€œOkay, fine, whatever,â€ he sighs, sitting back. â€œCan I go now?â€

Moody looks like heâ€™s going to say something but Dumbledore cuts him off. â€œYes, of course. Weâ€™ll be in touch.â€

â€œGreat,â€ he gets out of his seat, heading for the door, but he stops before leaving. â€œThe law says no more than two werewolves together in one place correct?â€

Dumbledore nods, though Remus can see the question in his eyes. â€œThatâ€™s correct.â€

Remus holds his gaze with intent. â€œThere are two boys, Oliver and William, I want them to be kept together. I want you to do that for me.â€

â€œDo that for you?â€ Moody says indignantly. â€œWhat in the seven hells makes you think we haveâ€”â€œ

But Dumbledore holds up his hand, never taking his eyes off of Remus. â€œVery well,â€ he says after a brief pause. â€œThe boys will be kept together. You have my word.â€

â€œThank you,â€ Remus says curtly, not bothering with anything else before he pushes into the hallway outside.

Â 

Itâ€™s one in the morning by the time he gets back to the flat. Sirius is on the couch, reading, his shoulders tense when Remus shuts the door but he doesnâ€™t turn around. Doesnâ€™t look up. Remus doesnâ€™t blame him. He drops his bag on the floor, hesitantly walking forward. He feels so fucking hollow. Like heâ€™s barely processed anything thatâ€™s happen. Canâ€™t believe itâ€™s only been a day.

â€œThereâ€™s leftover takeaway in the fridge,â€ Sirius says when Remus just keeps standing there, unsure of what to say. Unsure of how to ask for what he needs. â€œItâ€™s from the curry place you donâ€™t like, but, well, I didnâ€™t know when you were coming back soâ€”â€œ

â€œSirius.â€

Siriusâ€™s eyes flick up immediately at the sound of his name. At the pathetic whimpering thing that Remusâ€™s voice has become. One look and heâ€™s dropping his book, getting to his feet.

â€œWhat is it?â€ Sirius asks as his hands come up to Remusâ€™s face, holding it carefully. â€œRemus what happened?â€

The tears start falling from his eyes and he knows they arenâ€™t going to stop. He shakes his head. â€œI canâ€™t, I canâ€™t fight right now, can we not fight right now? Because I justâ€”fuck I just needâ€”â€œ

Sirius pulls him close, hand going to the back of Remusâ€™s head, letting him burying his face in Siriusâ€™s neck. Breathing him in, feeling his warmth. He shakes as the tears keep coming.

â€œRem,â€ Sirius says softly.

â€œIâ€™m so tired,â€ he hiccups. â€œIâ€™m so tired of letting everyone down. I canâ€™t do this Sirius. I donâ€™t know how to do this anymore.â€

â€œSh, sh,â€ Sirius maneuvers them onto the couch, pulling Remus into him and wrapping them up in the blanket thrown over the back. â€œItâ€™s okay. Youâ€™re okay.â€

But he isnâ€™t.

He really isnâ€™t.

He buries himself further into Sirius. He shuts his eyes and he tries to pretend that everything is different. That he never got bit by a werewolf. That Sirius never told Snape how to find him. That neither of them ever lied. Or cheated. Or left. He pretends that this is their life, together like this, in their flat. Holding one another.

He isnâ€™t okay.

Really he isnâ€™t.

Â 

A few days later, for reasons heâ€™ll never quite understand, Remus feels compelled to look up the story Mia told him. Romulus and Remus. Founders of Rome.

It turns out she forgot a rather important detail in her retelling.

That Remus was betrayed. Murdered by his brother.

Fate works in mysterious ways, thatâ€™s what Mia had said.

Remus canâ€™t help but find that foreboding.

Chapter End Notes

Hey, hi, hello!

1) Chapter 50 is all James and Reg and Chapter 51 is Jegulus so I promise I am not leaving you guys hanging much longer!

2) Okay my reverse slow burn comment seems to have sparked a heck of a lot more debate than I was anticipating. The ending is still canon, just so we're clear, still canon, so I am gently suggesting we manage our expectations

3) I promise I will not take this long to update again, this was a lil extreme

THANK YOU ALL!!!

Chapter 50

Chapter Summary

HAPPY JEGULUS WEEK

Chapter Notes

Given recent events I just wanted to say that this story is currently taking place during a war and that might be particularly difficult for some people to read about at this point in time so please take care of yourselves!

tw: Drug use / addiction (via potions)
tw: Violence
tw: Panic attack
tw: Referenced sexual assault (there's also a moment where Lucius and Reg are alone together in this chapter and nothing happens but it definitely feels uneasy, if that makes sense? It takes place in the kitchen at Malfoy Manner just so you're prepared)
tw: Death (I don't think this counts as a major character death...but...it might...)

Just a heads up because some people do get angry about this, I've mentioned it before, but I am messing with the canon timeline, just because, in this story, it's more interesting if stuff happens while Regulus is still alive. Y'know? So yeah, that happens :)

See the end of the chapter for more notes

PART I JAMES

James, Peter and Sirius sit squashed together on a floral patterned sofa with lace pillowsâ€”one of which, is currently being cuddled by Peter. The living room theyâ€™re in is overcrowded, with people, yes, but also with stuff. And James really does mean stuff. Boxes and newspapers and old takeaway menus.

Oh.

And cats.

How could he forget the cats.

There are at least three that heâ€™s seen walking around, all of whom seem to be in love with Sirius for reasons he canâ€™t fathom. The rest are staring out at them from their portraits which are hung up throughout the house. On top of all that, the whole place smells a bit like boiled cabbage.

â€œThe following information has been kept from most of you for the past few months in the interest of your safety.â€
Dumbledoreâ€™s words instantly ignite a wave of murmuring across the room. None of the three boys on the sofa react, all well aware of what is coming. Though Peter does fidget ever so slightly, clutching his pillow a little closer to his chest.

â€œIt has come to light that there is someone amongst us who has been passing information to Lord Voldemort.â€

â€œWhat?â€ says a panicked voice at the back of the room, the murmurs escalating to more of a frantic buzz.

â€œI know this will be a shock to many of you. We were hoping to use this information to our advantage, to allow the individual in question to believe nothing was suspected, leading them to act more carelessly. However, as time has passed and no one has been found out, it has become more and more pertinent for all of you to be on your guard. To take seriously our requests that all knowledge of missions and tasks performed for the Order remain only between those actively involved in them.â€

James doesnâ€™t miss the guilty looks bouncing around the room. None of them have done a particularly good job of keeping information from each other. Except maybe Moony. James shoots a cautious look at Sirius but he seems to be focusing the entirety of his attention on the black cat purring next to him.

â€œAlastor will brief you on what behaviour to watch out for in the people around you. If you notice anything, I implore you to bring it to the attention of myself or the Head Auror.â€

Moody groans, rising out of his seat to address the Order members able to attend the meeting today. Remus isnâ€™t there, off doing god knows what. Sirius is positive heâ€™s trying to get the werewolves to join their side but James isnâ€™t entirely convinced. Alice and Frank are both back at the Ministryâ€”the security measures there have been increased astronomically. And Lily and Marlene are on a mission, though, of course, they werenâ€™t able to tell anyone where they were going or why.

Before she left James had suggested that Lily should perhaps stop taking Order missions now that sheâ€™s literally growing a baby. That suggestion did not go over well, though he still feels like he sort of has a point.

â€œâ€¦someone who is frequently unreachable,â€ Moody is babbling on, James barely paying attention. â€œWhose behaviour in the past few months has altered, whoâ€™s started disappearing without explanation, or anyone to corroborate where they were or what they were doing. Often times this sort of double life starts to take a toll physicallyâ€”if someone seems more ill than normal, weaker, less social. Like theyâ€™re trying to distance themselves. If they start expressing guilt for unknown reasons. These are all warning signs, things to look out for, and if you notice more than one of them in a single individual please come to see me in my office, do not,â€ Moody narrows his eyes, â€œI repeat, DO NOT send an owl, the post is unreliable and too easily intercepted.â€

â€œYes, thank you Alastor,â€ Dumbledore says, the faintest hint of amusement in the corner of his eyes.

The room around them has gone dead silent, perhaps the quietest James has ever heard an Order meeting before. Everyone, no doubt, running through a list of all their closest friends, trying to figure out if any of them match the description Moody has just given.

â€œAny questions?â€ Dumbledore asks after a short pause. No one raises their hand. â€œExcellent. Well, I imagine you are all eager to return to your homes, and Iâ€™m sure Arabella would love it if we would depart from herâ€™s. Thank you for all your hard work, Iâ€™ll see you all again soon.â€ He smiles. James doesnâ€™t know if anyone smiles back.

These meetings are strange nowadays. He finds himself waiting sometimes, for his parents to walk through the door. For his mother to pull them all into a hug and get lipstick on Jamesâ€™s cheek. For his father to watch on fondly, quieter and calmer but no less warm. He waits for that feeling of certainty that always filled him whenever they were around, the weight lifting from his shoulders. Because the adults were there. And surely they would take care of things.

The weight never lifts these days. But maybe thatâ€™s just what it feels like to grow up.

The room is slowly emptying. People going outside to Apparate since Mrs. Figg doesnâ€™t have a Floo connection. Some people still linger, small groups huddled along the walls, catching up since the last time they saw one another, taking stock of the damageâ€”whoâ€™s been injured, killed, taken. James, Peter and Sirius, however, say nothing. The three of them too tired to speak. Too tired to move. This winter is feeling long and it hasnâ€™t even started yet.

â€œDid itâ€”â€œ Peter starts and then stops, looking at the pillow in his lap and fiddling with the lace.

James waits for a moment, but when Peter doesnâ€™t continue on his own he decides to give him a push. â€œDid it what?â€

Peter chews on the inside of his cheek. â€œWellâ€¦itâ€™s just thatâ€”Iâ€™m not saying it is or anythingâ€”Iâ€™m just saying, it sounded a bit likeâ€¦â€

â€œJust spit it out Peter,â€ Sirius says, now petting two cats. Youâ€™d think him being a dog would make them automatically dislike him but apparently his charm works on animals as well as people.

â€œWhen Moody was describing everything to look out forâ€¦did it sound a bit like he was describing Remus to either of you?â€

Sirius freezes. He doesnâ€™t look up, doesnâ€™t speak, just goes deadly still.

James has somewhat of the opposite reaction. â€œTell me youâ€™re joking right now?â€ he asks, anger edging into his voice as he watches Peterâ€™s cheeks flush.

â€œI told you, Iâ€™m not saying he is Iâ€™m just sayingâ€¦well, the similarities were a bit hard to miss werenâ€™t they?â€ he now looks over at Sirius who still hasnâ€™t moved. James isnâ€™t even sure if heâ€™s breathing.

â€œPete can you give us a minute?â€ James says finally, voice held tight.

Peter looks at him. â€œGive youâ€¦â€ then back at Sirius. â€œOhâ€”oh right, yeah,â€ he awkwardly stands, taking a step forward before realizing heâ€™s still holding a pillow and placing it, somewhat delicately, back on the sofa.

Something is off. Sirius should be fumingâ€”James should be holding him back, barely restraining him. Why is he just sitting there? Why is heâ€”

â€œPeteâ€™s right you know,â€ Sirius croaks.

James has to run those words through his head a few times before heâ€™s finally able to accept that Sirius said them.

â€œWhat the fuck is wrong with you?â€

Thereâ€™s a beat.

â€œJamesâ€”â€œ

â€œNo really, what the fuck is wrong with you? How could you evenâ€”â€œ he has to stop because his anger is getting to be too much, making his words shake as they cut their way out of his mouth.

â€œRationally?â€ James cuts in. â€œSince when are you rational?â€

Somehow Sirius manages to make himself even smaller.

â€œItâ€™s Remus,â€ James says, not understanding why he needs to explain this. â€œItâ€™s Remus. Fuck reason, fuck every fucking similarityâ€”â€œ

â€œJamesâ€”â€œ

â€œItâ€™s. Remus.â€

â€œYouâ€™re kidding? Thatâ€™s like the most Remus thing to say it doesnâ€™tâ€”youâ€™re really fucking reaching with that one.â€
