â€œHe always feels guilty!â€ James shouts, loud enough that the remaining Order members have started looking their way. Frustrated, he gets off the couch, turning towards the window, hands running through his hair. Itâ€™s a while before heâ€™s able to face Sirius again.

â€œWhy are you acting like this? Why are you acting like you donâ€™t know who he is?â€

Sirius has gone back to staring at the floor, jaw tense. â€œMaybe I donâ€™t.â€

For a moment James actually thinks about hitting him. â€œDonâ€™t you dare say this shit to Moony, donâ€™t you dare fucking drag him down with this. Jesus Christ Sirius.â€

Sirius doesnâ€™t say anything, the same expression on his face he used to wear when McGonagall was dressing him downâ€”petulant, defiant, stubborn.

â€œYou need to figure your shit out,â€ James says finally. â€œIâ€™ve never met two people more incompetent at loving each other.â€

He doesnâ€™t mean it to sound the way it does. Itâ€™s supposed to be snarky not cruel. But he can physically see the words burn Sirius, his mouth flicking down before he gets to his feet.

â€œCheers mate.â€

Heâ€™s heading for the door before James even has the chance to blink.

â€œFuckâ€”Sirius!â€ James calls after him. But he doesnâ€™t turn around and James doesnâ€™t have the heart to follow. Doesnâ€™t know if it would do any good. â€œFuck,â€ he hisses again, kicking the sofa before collapsing back onto it. He brings his hands up, covering his face.

â€œI feel like that was my fault.â€

James peers through his fingers at a repentant looking Peter and sighs. â€œDonâ€™t beat yourself up about it, but yeah, it kinda was.â€

Peter sits down next to him and James drops his hands into his lap, both boys lapsing into silence for a while.

â€œDo you ever think about before?â€ Peter finally says.

James looks at him wearily. â€œBefore?â€

â€œBefore Hogwartsâ€¦before Sirius and Remus. When it was just us?â€

Not really, is the answer. For starters, Jamesâ€™s memories prior to the age of eleven are a little hazy, as he imagines most peopleâ€™s are. But alsoâ€¦everything before the Marauders feels flat somehow. James wasnâ€™t really himself before he had his boys.

â€œIt was nice,â€ Peter goes on when James doesnâ€™t answer. â€œRight?â€ His friend looks at him now, something a littleâ€”James doesnâ€™t even knowâ€”desperate? In his eyes. And James feels like heâ€™s missed something. Doesnâ€™t understand how they got from suspecting Remus to this.

â€œSure Pete. Yeah. It wasâ€¦nice.â€ He claps him on the back and watches something in Peterâ€™s eyes flicker. That was the wrong thing to say. Or the wrong way to say it. Peter can see right through him.

â€œPeteâ€”â€œ

â€œI should get going,â€ Peter says abruptly, pulling away from James and getting to his feet. He shoots him a self-deprecating smile. â€œSee you, yeah?â€

And before James can respond Peter is moving quickly out of the room. James watching him go.

Good job Potter, he thinks coldly. Thatâ€™s two people youâ€™ve let down and itâ€™s not even noon yet. Must be a personal best.

Â 

Itâ€™s only twenty minutes later that heâ€™s walking into his own house. The lights out. The rooms dark.

â€œLily?â€ he tries, even though he already knows she isnâ€™t home. Silence answers him back and he doesnâ€™t know why it makes him angry. He has half a mind to firecall Sirius. Half a mind to just show up at his flat and hash this all out. Partially because he hates fighting with him and partially because he doesnâ€™t know what to do with the insidious energy thrumming under his skin.

It makes him antsy. He canâ€™t sit. Canâ€™t read. He needs to move. He should go flying, that usually helps, but his hands are shaking too much, in this state heâ€™d crash into the side of the house.

He makes it up to the second floor, to his empty bedroom, sheets still messed up, and he starts pacing. Is this really how theyâ€™re supposed to live from now on? Never knowing where anyone is or what theyâ€™re doing or when theyâ€™re coming back? He always felt Remus was in the wrong for keeping secrets, even if it was on Dumbledoreâ€™s orders. It drives cracks into everything. Remus and Sirius never really fought at school, not after they got together properly. There were moments sure, but, for the most partâ€¦this fucking war. This fucking war is killing all of them. Itâ€™s driving them all out of their heads. Thereâ€™s no way that Sirius can really believe, I mean really believe that Remus would betray them. Right? Right?? Because if theyâ€™ve gone that farâ€”if theyâ€™ve lost each other that muchâ€¦how will they ever come back from it? What the hell is going to happen to them?

â€œFuck,â€ James snaps, knocking something off his dresser and feeling mildly satisfied when it slams into the wall. Not satisfied enough of course. He throws a real proper temper tantrum then, Sirius would be proudâ€”knocking things over, kicking and punching and cursing like a little kid who hasnâ€™t got his way. Like someone trapped in a life they have no control over, watching other people make decisions for them.

By the time heâ€™s done his skin is hot and sweaty, his chest heaving, the tremor in his hands gone. His room is also a fucking disaster. There are spells for this, but heâ€™d rather clean it up by hand. He took it all apart quickly but he puts it back together almost painfully slow. Delicate with his movements. Like an apology. Glasses and books returned to bedside tables, picture frames set upright again. When he heaves the dresser onto its feet some of the drawers slide out, contents spilling onto the floor.

Theyâ€™re clothes mostly. Socks and jumpers that he hasnâ€™t got the patience to re-fold so he just starts shoving them all back into roughly the same drawers and slamming them shut. Until his hand brushes against something hard. There, beneath one of his t-shirts, is a small wooden box. For a minute James just stares at it. Itâ€™s been a long time since heâ€™s looked at itâ€”shoved all the way at the back of his dresser. Heâ€™s not sure why he kept it, except that the idea of throwing it away makes him want to be sick.

Eventually he gives in, reaching for it as he collapses down onto the floor. He runs his fingers over it, brushing off the dust, before he flicks open the lid, revealing the little miniature ball inside, initials catching the light.

J&R

Sometimes, he canâ€™t even believe any of it really happened. It doesnâ€™t sound real. Doesnâ€™t sound like himâ€”getting with his best mates brother. A Slytherin. A Death Eater.

He stares the Quaffle down like itâ€™ll give him the answers. Like itâ€™ll tell him what happened and why all this time later it still feelsâ€¦like this. Heâ€™d told his mother he didnâ€™t want Regulus to become a bruise and heâ€™d gotten his wish. Regulus isnâ€™t a bruise. Heâ€™s a tsunami. And every time James lets himself think of him, lets himself remember, heâ€™s overwhelmed. He loses sight of the shore. Forgets it even exists at all. He isnâ€™t even here, hasnâ€™t been, in a very long time, and yet somehow, Regulus still has the ability to wrap himself around James. To be all he can hear and feel and think. All he can breathe and smell and taste.

Which is exactly why he needs to stay at the back of Jamesâ€™s dresser.

He snaps the box shut, eyes falling on what had been lying next to it. Black velvet, a jewellery case his mother had very politely not asked him about when she saw him buying it. This he really doesnâ€™t know why he kept. He sets the Quaffle down next to it, a matching set. Heâ€™d agonized about what to get Regulus, what could possibly match his gift. It couldnâ€™t just be something he bought, it had to be something he made. The problem was, Jamesâ€™s magic has always been big and loud and strong, well suited to duelling not meticulous charm work. Still, heâ€™d been determined.

He canâ€™t help wondering what Regulus would have thought, if heâ€™d had the time to give it to him. If everything hadnâ€™t gone to hell after Christmas. If things had been different. It shouldnâ€™t matter now. He wishes it didnâ€™t.

â€œJames?â€ the front door closes and James jolts, like heâ€™s been caught.

He throws the two boxes back in his dresser, slamming the drawer shut and trying to ignore the sinking feeling of guilt currently eating its way through his stomach.

â€œUp here!â€ James calls down to Lily as he heads for the bedroom door. Looking over his shoulder like heâ€™s expecting to see Regulus standing there. Like Lily could walk in on them. Catch him with the memory of the boy he used to love.

Still loves. When he lets himself. When he forgets about the shore.

Â 

PART II REGULUS

Personally, Regulus thinks Malfoy Manor is a little tacky. But maybe heâ€™s biased. Itâ€™s all marble floors and pillars, all thirty-foot ceilings and chandeliers, and gilded mirrors. Where Grimmauld is gothic and cluttered, Malfoy Manor is open and Grecian. There are peacocks in the front yard.

Like he said. Tacky.

They all sit in the drawing room at a long wooden table (Regulus is frankly surprised it isnâ€™t made out of marble too) listening to Snape and Lucius bicker. The Dark Lord isnâ€™t there of course, or things would likely be proceeding with more decorum. As it is, they are forced to watch two little men haggling over the scraps of power that have been left for them.

Regulus is sunk low in his chair, arms crossed over his chest, fighting the heaviness in his eyes. He expects all of this would be rather more annoying if he werenâ€™t blitzed out of his mind. The potions leave him sated. Content. Here or at Grimmauld place it doesnâ€™t matter. He feels the same.

Well, until Snape chucks an inkwell at his head. Luckily Evan swats it away because there is no chance Regulusâ€™s reflexes are fast enough to dodge anything right now.

â€œFuck off Severus,â€ Evan snaps, as the glass bottle clatters to the ground.

â€œYou know,â€ Regulus sits up straight, â€œif you needed something you could have just asked,â€ he notices a few uncomfortable looks being passed around the table and instantly understands his mistake. Snape had asked, Regulus was just too high to notice.

â€œHe speaks,â€ Snape sneers. â€œItâ€™s a fucking miracle.â€

â€œWell maybe if you and Lucius said anything worth listening to I wouldnâ€™t be falling asleep.â€ A few people chuckle.

â€œIâ€™m sorry,â€ Snape says, dark eyes narrowing, â€œare we boring you? I know you may not be aware of this little prince, but taking over a government is actually quite a bit of work.â€

Heâ€™s always hated that. Little Prince. Not just because itâ€™s patronizing, but because itâ€™s what they used to call Sirius. Except back then it sounded like they meant it.

â€œAnd how much of that work have you accomplished exactly?â€ Regulus snaps back. â€œBecause from where Iâ€™m sitting all youâ€™ve been discussing for the past hour is whose dick is bigger.â€

Thereâ€™s laughter again, Evan actually sounds like heâ€™s choking, â€œFuck Reg,â€ he mutters under his breath, the heat rising in Severusâ€™s face.

â€œI expect,â€ Snapeâ€™s tinny voice cuts through the noise, â€œif we were talking about dicks weâ€™d have more of your attention.â€

The mood in the room shifts instantly. Thereâ€™s no laughter. This is not a crowd that takes kindly to such accusations. Regulus wonders if Snape even fully understands that, having not grown up in this world, with these families and their mansions and their precious baby boys. If he ever understood what he was threatening Regulus with, even back in school.

â€œThe fuck did you just say?â€ Evan demands, but Regulus holds up his hand. He doesnâ€™t need anyone to fight his battles for him, especially not against Snape. Not anymore.

â€œTell me Severus, how is Lily Evans doing these days?â€ If his last remark filled Snapeâ€™s face with colour, this one drains it of it.

â€œAlright, okay, enough boys,â€ Lucius finally steps back in. â€œWeâ€™re all friends here yes?â€

Evan snorts but neither Regulus nor Snape contradict him, instead they settle for glaring viciously at one another across the table.

â€œExcellent,â€ Lucius goes on, clearly enjoying himself. â€œNow Regulus, we were wondering if you thought it was possible to make a version of a sleeping potion that was gaseous.â€

Regulus blinks, momentarily distracted from his staring contest with Snape. â€œGaseous?â€ he repeats. Heâ€™s never changed the state of a potion before and the challenge peeks his interest.

â€œYes, so that people will be able to feel the effects through inhalation rather than ingestion. Severus wasnâ€™t sure if it could be done.â€

And oh.

Oh isnâ€™t that just delightful.

He turns his gaze back on Snape who is practically vibrating with anger, a smirk curving the corner of Regulusâ€™s mouth. â€œSeverus wasnâ€™t sure?â€ he repeats, gloating.

I mean, he isnâ€™t sure either. Heâ€™s never done it. Never even thought about it. But nobody here knows that. Without taking his eyes off Snape he answers.

â€œYeah, I expect it can be done.â€

There is the faint murmur of skepticism along the table but Regulus doesnâ€™t pay it much mind, enjoying Snapeâ€™s scowling face far too much.

â€œWeâ€™ll need it to be ready within the next few days, so we have time to test it out before we make our move on the Ministry. Do you think you can manage that?â€

â€œYes,â€ another lie. Or, well, half-lie, at least. He has no idea how long itâ€™ll take.

â€œWell then, look at that,â€ Lucius claps a hand on Snapeâ€™s shoulder that only exaggerates the other boyâ€™s awkwardness. â€œI told you he would know what to do.â€

Snapeâ€™s eyes are mutinous, Regulus is surprised he isnâ€™t barring his teeth. â€œA shame he couldnâ€™t stay conscious long enough to tell us earlier. Save us all this back and forth.â€

â€œBeing a sore loser isnâ€™t very becoming Severus,â€ Regulus says dryly, not that any part of Snape is becoming. Next to him Evan snorts.

â€œNo one is perfect,â€ Lucius says, dismissing them both with the wave of his hand before looking down at the notes in front of him. â€œSo you two will have that done by Sunday, yes?â€

Regulus very nearly bangs his head on the table in front of him.

â€œThe two of us?â€ Snape hisses, lanky black hair falling in his face.

â€œWell you are our best potioneers and we need this done quickly. So yes. The two of you.â€

No really, Regulus thinks it would help, just slamming his forehead into something hard. Maybe if he gets a concussion theyâ€™ll take pity on him and wonâ€™t make him work with Snape.

Exhale.

â€œWeâ€™re just going to put you to sleep for a minute or two okayâ€”â€œ

â€œAdorable,â€ Snape says flatly in the background and Regulus feels his hands curl into fists.

â€œOkay,â€ he exhales. â€œOkay, so when I unstopper the potion you wonâ€™t have to drink it, youâ€™ll just have to breathe it in, you understand?â€

Another nod.

Regulus pulls out his own wand, casting the Bubble-head charm on himself and hearing Snape, behind him, doing the same. Kreacher waits, staring at him expectantly. Regulus hates this. Nothing happens.

Fuck.

But then, before his eyes, the potion begins to evaporate out of the vial, disappearing into the air.

â€œI is not feeling anyâ€”â€œ Kreacher starts, before his face goes slack. Regulus barely has enough time to drop the glass vial and step forward before Kreacher is falling to the floor. He catches him just in time, cushioning his head as he lowers him carefully to the ground.

Regulus finds himself grateful at least, that this is the potion they needed to test. Kreacher looks peaceful. It could have been so much worse. He feels Snape coming to stand behind him.

â€œExcellent,â€ he says, though he doesnâ€™t sound particularly enthused. He doesnâ€™t really sound like anything. â€œIâ€™ll write Lucius.â€

Â 

Itâ€™s two days later that Regulus finds himself back at Malfoy Manor. He expects Snape to be there, theyâ€™ve been tinkering with the potion for the last few days. Regulus assumes thatâ€™s why heâ€™s hereâ€”to discuss the potion. He doesnâ€™t quiteâ€¦recognize himself. Heâ€™s lost weight, which shouldnâ€™t be surprising but he just hadnâ€™t noticed, the bags under his eyes looking like bruisesâ€”blue and purple. Heâ€™s always liked his hair, especially when he was younger, because heâ€™d thought it looked like Siriusâ€™s. It wasnâ€™t until his second year at Hogwarts that he started straightening and styling it. Trying to stop people from making those comparisons he had once craved so desperately.

Iâ€™m nothing like your brother.

Thatâ€™s what Snape had said.

No, Regulus thinks, staring wistfully at his reflection. No, me either.

â€œSorry for the wait,â€ Lucius comes strutting down the hall, heeled boots making that distinctive clinking noise that Regulus has to force himself not to flinch at. â€œBusiness, you know how it is.â€

â€œYou going somewhere?â€ Regulus asks, eyeing Luciusâ€™s travel cloak.

â€œClements,â€ he mutters to himself, running over the address a dozen times. Heâ€™s almost positive heâ€™s never heard of the street before, meaning itâ€™s likely a Muggle populated area. He wracks his brain for who the hell they could be meeting in Muggle London but he comes up blank.

â€œFuck,â€ he hisses under his breath.

Itâ€™s dark out today, cold. The trees are losing their leaves, and everything seems to be some shade of grey or brown here. Regulus wraps his arms around himself and tries to remember the last time he actually stepped foot outside.

â€œWhat the hell are we doing here Lucius?â€

Thereâ€™s something distinctly shark like about the older manâ€™s mouth. â€œTold you, weâ€™re meeting our friendâ€™s.â€ He gestures to the dull brick house in front of them that blurs into the one next to it. Regulus can hear footsteps on the floors above them and voices coming from the room in front. The further in they get the more he starts to understand that this is not a house. Not a home where people live. Itâ€™s headquarters.

They come into a kitchen with what used to be pink wallpaper that has now faded to a murky white. Like the sitting room, there are papers and maps everywhere. Supplies piled in the sink and on top of the stove, takeaway containers stacked up high in the corner. All giving the impression that this is a space rarely actually used for cooking.

At the table in the middle of the room there is a group of people having a conversation, coffee cups clutched in their hands. At the centre of the conversation is a larger, gruff man that Regulus has seen before.

Fenrir Greyback.

Werewolves.

Regulus suddenly starts taking stock of the people heâ€™s seen, the noises. This house is full but the last time he checked Greyback had barely a dozen followers. A somewhat unappealing ally for the Dark Lord. Itâ€™s clear things have changed.

Lucius stops in front of the table and clears his throat. He looks fundamentally out of place with his fussy appearance and expensive robes. It isnâ€™t that anyone here is dressed in rags, but itâ€™s a lot more sweatshirts and ripped jeans than silk and velvet.

â€œAfter you,â€ Greyback say dryly as he gestures them into a small empty room. Because in front of him.

Bold as anything.

Is Remus Lupin.

â€œHavenâ€™t bitten him yet then.â€

Ah.

â€œRegulus!â€ Lucius shouts from the front hall. â€œLets go!â€

Fuck,

he thinks.

And his wand.

Fuck his wand.

Like a child.

Heâ€™s never really been in a fight like this. Never really been in very many fights at all, actually. Duels, sure. Wrestling matches with Sirius when they were little. Regulus wonders how it is that Evan learned his unforgivable curses. If his family took him into the back garden and made him torture rabbits too. Or if he didnâ€™t need that. If it came naturally to him. The way it never did to Reg.

Itâ€™s not because heâ€™s a good person. He has no illusions about that. He doesnâ€™t think he would mind so terribly if someone came along and killed the Auror he just left behind. Her death means very little to him. He just doesnâ€™t want to be the executioner.

Coward, he hears whispered again in the back of his head.

â€œHow much do you wanna bet I can take him?â€ Evan asks, eyes on the Head Auror, greedy and alight with the adrenaline of his last fight.

Heâ€™s tall, several inches taller than Regulus, and built like a house. No wonder he used his fists first. Regulus backs up, firing off another spell that is casually tossed aside. And another.

And another.

And another.

The man keeps advancing, and Regulus realizes that he has no intention of fighting back with his wand. Heâ€™s just going to keep blocking Regulusâ€™s spells until he can get his hands on him again. And at this rate that isnâ€™t going to take long. Regulus needs a new strategy.

He looks around desperately, still backing up, trying to keep the giant in front of him from closing the gap between them. His eyes snag on the windows above themâ€”the hundreds and hundreds of offices with views of the atrium.

He isnâ€™t as good with silent casting as heâ€™d like, but simple things he can manage. Like summoning charms. Perhaps, if he can get one of the panes of glass loose and bring it down on the advancing Auror with enough force, he might just get out of this.

â€œFunny,â€ he says, trying to distract the man. â€œHere I thought Aurors were supposed to be good at duelling.â€ He starts the incantation in his head, trying to concentrate, to visualize, to keep his wand as out of sight as possible.

â€œAnd here I thought Death Eaters were supposed to be scary,â€ the man doesnâ€™t smile when he delivers the line. Regulus tries his best not to be offended.

Accio window.

Accio window.

Accio window.

â€œTell me, how exactly did you manage to get past your OWLs? Did you just punch the Professor?â€ The man is still advancing and if he gets his hands on Regulus before he manages this spell Regulus will be absolutely fucked.

â€œIf youâ€™re such a skilled duelist why donâ€™t you try getting past my shield little boy?â€

He feels the Aurorsâ€™s fingertips brush against his collar at the exact same moment that the pane of glass crashes into him, shattering over the manâ€™s head. Regulus flinches backwards, using his arms to shield his face as debris scatters everywhere. When he looks up again the man in front of him is bleeding from about a dozen places, shattered glass piling up like snow at his feet. The Auror stares back at him in a dazed kind of way, swaying slightly before he tries to take a step forward and ends up crumpling to the ground.

Regulus is breathing like heâ€™s just run a mile, hands shaking slightly as he stares at the heap of Auror in front of him. He doesnâ€™t think heâ€™s dead, knows that he should fix that. And yetâ€¦his wand remains at his side.

Thereâ€™s a booming scream from across the Atrium, loud enough that it rises above all the other noise. All the other screaming. It sounds like thunder, like it could shake the foundations of the city.

There, at the fountain, is a hunched over Alastor Moody, gripping his face as blood gushes into his hands and down his forearms, disappearing into the red of his uniform. And in front of him, is a beaming Evan Rosier.

â€œHoly shit,â€ Regulus mutters under his breath, suddenly moving again, trying to get to his friend.

Evan fires off another curse but Moody blocks it, even with one hand still clutching his face, quickly returning fire. Regulus tries to maneuver his way across the floor, through duelling pairs and over the various debris the fighting has caused. Moody and Evan come in and out of his line of sight, bobbing and weaving around one another. Regulus has no idea what spell Evan hit Moody with but he really is bleeding badly.

Merlin,

he thinks as he gets closer.

The spell hits him right in the chest.

Evan that is.

Hits Evan right in the chest. Which is funny because Regulus feels it. Feels it like another giant Auror has decided to drive their fist into him. For a moment he canâ€™t move. He just watches.

To make some stupid inappropriate joke.

But he doesnâ€™t.

Doesnâ€™t move an inch. Not even when Moody walks over to him, no longer covering the monstrous gash on his face that looks like itâ€™s taken half his nose. Not even when Moody spits on the ground beside his head, before turning away.

Thatâ€™s when Regulus starts running.

He lands on his knees beside Evanâ€™s body. His eyes are open. They stare across the room. They donâ€™t blink. Donâ€™t move.

â€œEvan?â€ his voice shakes as he slides his hands under his friendâ€™s torso and picks him up. Heâ€™s still warm. â€œEvan?â€

Heâ€™s dead.

Regulus knows that.

Really he does. He understands. He watched it happen. He can feel the unnatural stiffness already starting to take hold.

He knows that heâ€™s dead he justâ€¦he doesnâ€™t know what to do with that. He pulls his friend into his lap, holding him close. Because theyâ€™re supposed to be here together. To have each otherâ€™s backs. Because he canâ€™t justâ€”just leave him. Not alone.

This is your fault,

says the voice in his head.

You betrayed him. You did this.

You knew this was a trap. And you let him come anyway.

â€œIâ€™m sorry,â€ he whispers, rocking slightly. â€œIâ€™m so sorry.â€

He knows, deep down, that Evan Rosier was not a very good person.

But he also thinks itâ€™s possible, that he was the only one in Regulusâ€™s life who ever really loved him unconditionally.

And that loss feelsâ€¦profound.

â€œRegulus?â€

His head shoots up, he feels like heâ€™s in a daze, everything suddenly less real. This sensation is compounded by the fact that the person standing across from him is Frank Longbottom. The former Gryffindor Quidditch captain. Head boy. For a second Regulus feels like heâ€™s back in school, reality sort of slipping around him, all wobbly and undefined. And then he sees Longbottomâ€™s wand move.

Regulus lets go of Evan.

Because he doesnâ€™t know how to fight with a body in his arms.

Because heâ€™s always been good at letting people down when it comes to saving himself.

The spell is only an Expelliarmus, he feels it whiz past his ear as he rolls to his knees and then his feet, darting into the crowd. He doesnâ€™t know if Longbottom is following. Doesnâ€™t know why he doesnâ€™t turn around and fight. Maybe because heâ€™s always liked Frank Longbottom. He was a good Quidditch player. A better captain. Another person who matters to James.

He doesnâ€™t want to be here anymore, all will to fight draining out of him. He wants to go home. Wants to drown out the buzzing inside his chest. His head.

Fuck.

Someone weâ€™ll have to tell his mum.

Someone will have to tell Evanâ€™s mum that heâ€™s dead.

Thatâ€™s the last thought he has before heâ€™s hitâ€”part of the fountain blown off in a misdirected spell. It catches his temple, slamming him into the wall beside him. The world gives a great tremble.

And then all there is is black.

Â 

â€œGet up!â€

Regulus grumbles, turning over, trying to swat Kreacher away as he buries his head in his pillows, he already has one hell of a hangover and he hasnâ€™t even opened his eyes.

â€œJesus fucking Christ,â€ someone grabs hold of the back of his shirt and yanks him up to his feet, causing a searing pain to slice through his brain.

â€œAhh,â€ he cries, clutching his head, which is hot and wet and sticky. He stumbles against the person who dragged him up, his legs shaking. It feels like heâ€™s on the deck of a ship, the floor beneath him moving.

Thatâ€™s when the noise hits him. Itâ€™s so fucking loud. Too fucking loud to be his bedroom. And whoever heâ€™s leaning against is too fucking tall to be Kreacher. He opens his eyesâ€”a mistakeâ€”it burns, itâ€™s so bright, the lancing pain in his brain back in full force.

â€œMove,â€ the person holding him up snaps. â€œFucking move,â€ he shoves him forward, still gripping Regulus by the back of his shirt which is the only reason he doesnâ€™t instantly fall to the floor.

Regulus tries to think. Itâ€™s hard when heâ€™s this goddamn dizzy and nauseous and in pain. He needs to figure out where he is, whatâ€™s happening. He needs to figure it out now. He forces his eyes open again. It really goddamn hurts but he doesnâ€™t let them close. Thereâ€™s people. Chaos. The fountain.

The fountain.

The Ministry.

The coup.

The betrayal.

Evan.

Regulus gags, trying to stop, trying to grab hold of his knees and breathe but the person pushing him doesnâ€™t let him. Shoving him relentlessly forward despite his weak protests.

â€œYou canâ€™t stop. Itâ€™s already a miracle we havenâ€™t been spotted.â€

The voice is vaguely familiar. Regulus forces himself to look over his shoulder even though moving his eyes feels like having nails dragged across his brain. It takes him a second, because the man is wearing a mask, because his brain just got smashed against a fucking stone wall. But eventually. He gets there.

â€œLupin?â€ he asks, voice weak.

â€œJust shut up and keep walking okay?â€

Regulus doesnâ€™t have any idea whatâ€™s going on but heâ€™s honestly in no position to fight. So he lets himself be dragged across the atrium towards what looks like the reception area. Everything is coming to Regulus in bits and pieces. Like his brain is a radio that keeps losing signal. He sees the floor. Then a desk. His shoes. Lupinâ€™s arm.

And then all the sudden Lupin is shoving him into some kind of box. The minute Lupin lets go of him he collapses to the ground in the corner. He wonders if heâ€™s cracked his skull. It sure as hell feels like it.

â€œHey!â€ Lupin snaps his fingers in front of Regulusâ€™s face, causing him to blink up at him. That hurts too. Blinking. â€œStay awake okay? You have to stay awake.â€

Regulus isnâ€™t sure why. Not being awake sounds like an excellent idea right now.

â€œThis is the visitors entrance,â€ Lupin is explaining. â€œIâ€™m going to get it to take you up, itâ€™ll dump you onto Whitehall, then you need to Apparate the hell away from here.â€

Thereâ€™s no way Regulus is going to be able to Apparate in the state heâ€™s in. And the grimace on Lupinâ€™s face suggests he knows that too.

â€œFloo?â€ Regulus finally mutters. Because that would be so much easier, but Lupin shakes his head.

â€œMoodyâ€™s already had the Floo network closed. Theyâ€™ll be coming this way soon to shut this off as well. Keep everyone in. So this is your only way out and you need to go now.â€

There are about a dozen more things Regulus has to ask him, not least of which is â€œwhyâ€. Why are you doing this? But then, if he had to guess, Regulus would imagine itâ€™s probably the same reason he didnâ€™t tell anyone that Remus was a spy.

James.

â€œOkay,â€ Lupin exhales, straightening up. â€œIâ€™m sending you now.â€ He turns to the weird contraption on the wall, tapping in some numbers before shooting Regulus one last lingering look and slipping out of the box.

A second later it starts to move.

The silence of the booth is soothing after the noise of the atrium. Though it also makes it nearly impossible to ignore the relentless thumping of his injured head. He closes his eyes.

Stay awake okay?

Lupin whispers in his ear.

You have to say awake.

The box jolts as it comes to a stop, Regulusâ€™s eyes flying open again, met with the sight of a bustling city street. Itâ€™s grey out, the wind banging angrily against the walls around him. Regulus stumbles and slips as he pulls himself to his feet, he can smell the blood dripping down the side of his face almost as much as he can feel it.

â€œSteady on mate,â€ a man in a beige suit says as Regulus practically spills out the doors of the box. The man gives him a dirty look but doesnâ€™t stop.

Swaying, Regulus reaches for the nearest wall, feeling his way along it until he gets to an alley. Small and narrow, between two white buildings, he slips inside and proceeds to be sick. On his hands and knees. Beside the bins. Itâ€™s mostly stomach acid, he hasnâ€™t eaten much. When his body has finally finished he presses his back to the wall behind him, wiping his mouth on his sweaty hand and looking at his wand.

He has to Apparate. He has to get out of here. Even if the Aurors donâ€™t find himâ€”and they mightâ€”he is Regulus Arcturus Black and heâ€™s not about to die here with the rubbish. But heâ€™s also weak, and in pain, and he canâ€™t even walk let alone fucking Apparate.

He grits his teeth, trying to force his head to cooperate for one second. Just long enough to get him home. Tries to stop the ground from moving and the colours from blending and the overcast light from feeling like a sharp sliver being driven into his brain.

Inhale.

Exhale.

Inhale.

Exhale.

â€œOkay,â€ his voice cracks as he lifts his wand. â€œOkay. Okay,â€ he squeezes his eyes shut. And casts the spell.

Â 

The second he lands on the stoop of Grimmauld Place heâ€™s screaming. Blood curdling, bone deep, screams that heâ€™s never heard himself make. Heâ€™s splinched himself. The skin ripped from his arms and back in patches. Left somewhere in the space between Whitehall and here.

Itâ€™s fucking unbearable.

All he can do is lie there, bleeding and screaming and writhing in pain. And his head. His fucking head is splitting open. Heâ€™s never felt anything like this. Every single part of his body feels like itâ€™s being torn apart. Heâ€™s going to black out. Merlin he hopes he blacks out.

â€œMaster Regulus!â€

He tries to speak but he canâ€™t. He canâ€™t fucking stop screaming. And it only gets worse when Kreacher starts touching him. Hands on his open wounds.

â€œI is sorry, I is sorry, but you must get inside Sir. I is sorry.â€

He wants to tell Kreacher itâ€™s okay. Really he does. But the words only blink in and out of existence. A shadow in his mouth as he collapses back onto the floor in the front hallway. Into the blissful darkness of the house.

â€œI will be bringing Master Regulus to the hospital sir, I will be bringing him now.â€

Somehow, the fear manages to cut through the agony. â€œNo,â€ Regulus mutters, his voice barely recognizable. Scratched raw and shaking.

â€œSirâ€”â€œ

He looks at Kreacher even though it hurts. Even though is drives new holes into his brain. â€œThatâ€™s an order, you cannot take me to St Mungos.â€

Heâ€™ll be arrested.

Or something worse.

Kreacher looks down at him so sadly, large eyes filling with tears. â€œBut sir, you is needing saving.â€

Reality tilts.

Do you need to be saved Reg?

A boy in a tower. The night sky behind him.

â€œJames,â€

Yes.

â€œJames,â€

Please.

â€œJames,â€

Help me. Please help me.

â€œJames.â€

He doesnâ€™t know why thatâ€™s all he can say, when there are so many other things trapped inside of him. Desperate to be let out.

But he supposes there are worse last words to have.

PART III PETER

Peter Pettigrew is a very average person. He knows that. Has always known that. Mediocrity seems to be sown into the seams of his being. So he has never understood why James Potter, a boy who puts the sun to shame, ever bothered to befriend him at all.

The first time Peter met James was not on the Hogwarts express. It was at his Great Aunt Betsyâ€™s 100th birthday. She was somehow distantly related to Euphemia and, as a result, the Potters were there.

Theyâ€™d been eight at the time, him and James, but already the room seemed to orbit around James like he was the singular point in the universe. Children and adults both were enchanted by him. Peter had stayed away. Too timid. Too embarrassed. Heâ€™d had a slight lisp when he was younger and his mother cut his hair, so it always came out looking like a mixing bowl had been placed on his head. Even at eight he had an acute awareness that he was notâ€¦cool.

So instead of embarrassing himself he snuck upstairs, where he knew his Aunt kept her collection of horse figurines. He rather liked playing with those. Which was where James found him.

â€œWoah, neat.â€

Peter had jumped, startled by the boy with the messy hair and giant glasses. James had walked right up to him, holding one of the horses up and inspecting it, then placing it back down.

â€œHow do you play?â€ heâ€™d asked Peter, who had felt rather certain someone was pulling a prank on him. Why on earth would the coolest kid at the party leave everyone behind to come up here and hang out with him?

â€œâ€¦Hello?â€ James tilted his head quizzically.

Oh no. Peter was being weird.

â€œHi.â€

James smiled, a little confused, but still bright enough that Peter felt he had to look away.

â€œSoâ€¦how does it work? The game I mean,â€ James shook his horse for emphasis.

â€œOh, oh I donâ€™t know. Orâ€”I meanâ€”I just kindaâ€¦â€ he shrugged, before demonstrating moving his horse around the top of the dresser on his makeshift course.

â€œCool,â€ James said, even though it definitely wasnâ€™t, joining him with his own horse. â€œHey, you wanna race?â€ Peter had met his gaze again, surprised to still find it empty of mockery. He had a rather hard time fitting in, most kids seemed to think he was odd, or not worth their time. It was new to him, this easy camaraderie. This olive branch.

â€œYeah,â€ he smiled slowly. â€œYeah okay.â€

And just like that, Petter Pettigrew made a friend.

Peter was there. The first time James Potter fell in love. And it wasnâ€™t with Lily Evans, though he knows everyone thinks so. Everyone, maybe, except for Lily herself.

Peter had grown too complacent, that was the problem. Too comfortable with the idea that James Potter was his best mate. That he always would be. It wasnâ€™t like there hadnâ€™t been chances, between his Great Auntâ€™s birthday and the day they got on the Hogwarts Express for the first time. At any point James could have gone off and found himself a new friend, and he never had. Never made Peter feel less than, or unworthy, and eventually Peter had managed to forget, or at least push to the back of his mind, that he was those things. All of them.

And then Sirius Black had sauntered into their compartment.

It would have been easier, really, if it had been Lily. Because Peter was never going to be for James what Lily was. But Sirius, Sirius was the embodiment of everything Peter should have been. That James Potterâ€™s best mate should have been. And the moment those two were in the same space, even when they had barely spoken more than just their names, something changed. Two sparks come to life. It was impossible to look away. And Peter really had tried.

It used to be that Remus was Peterâ€™s ally. Sometimes, when James and Sirius would bounce off of each other too fast for anyone else to get a word in, Remus would look at Peter and Peter would look right back and it was like, the two of them understood one another. It was itâ€™s own special kind of bond. It made it feel less like he was on the outside of something and more like there were layers. Thatâ€™s different nowâ€¦with Remus and Sirius being whatever they are.

Peter had tried for a while, to fight for his place as Jamesâ€™s best mate. But it was a losing battle. And by the end of first year he felt exhausted by it. So he stopped trying. He doesnâ€™t think James ever noticed.

Â 

He runs a hand over his slicked back hair for the third time in the past fifteen minutes. The Portkey has brought him somewhere on the continent, he isnâ€™t sure where. Itâ€™s warm here, the sun beating down outside so fiercely that even standing in the shaded entryway heâ€™s still sweating profusely.

Or maybe thatâ€™s the nerves.

He always gets anxious before these meetings, itâ€™s only natural. But this time is worse. Because this time heâ€™s messed up. The very thought makes his stomach squirm. Heâ€™d been doing so well. For once in his life heâ€™d been excelling at something, not just barely scraping by. And nowâ€¦

He passes his weight between his feet, wringing his hands out in front of his stomach. The last time heâ€™d felt this terrified was probably the first time heâ€™d met with Voldemort. Itâ€™s a scary thing, switching sides. Brave, is what Voldemort had called it. It had felt quite good to hear that, from a man like him. Someone so smart and so talented. Someone who was, himself, willing to take on the government and the accepted order of society for what he believed in.

It isnâ€™t that Peter has much of a problem with Mudbloods really. That isnâ€™t why he did it. I mean, he likes Lily. And he likes Mary. But heâ€™s not willing to die for them. And he thinks thatâ€™s fair, because he doubts very much that theyâ€™d die for him.

â€œMr. Pettigrew?â€

Peter jumps as a man with an intimidatingly deep voice steps out of the shadows.

â€œErâ€”yeah?â€

â€œOur lord will receive you now.â€

He turns on his heel and Peter assumes heâ€™s probably meant to follow so he does, tripping a little as he goes, thankful the man is facing forward and doesnâ€™t see. Everything about this building is narrow, the hallway not wide enough for two people to walk side by side, the ceiling domed, with ornate copper chandeliers hanging down every few steps. And the heat. It really is bloody hot. Peter can feel his clothes growing damp.

They walk straight for a long time. There are doors on either side of them but no corners or twists and Peter thinks it must be a spell because he doesnâ€™t remember the building being this long from the outside.

Eventually the man in front of him slows to a stop, gesturing to the nondescript door beside him that looks like every other one theyâ€™ve passed.

â€œHeâ€™s waiting for you,â€ his voice fills up the tiny space and makes Peter want to cower away. Thatâ€™s all the instruction he gets before the man continues down the hall. Peter tries to squint through the shadows, to see the end, but he canâ€™t. Eventually, heâ€™s forced to face the door.

â€œCome in,â€ says a high voice after he hesitantly knocks, like heâ€™s hoping whoeverâ€™s inside wonâ€™t hear and heâ€™ll just be able to walk away.

The room smells heavily of something that makes Peterâ€™s head swimâ€”lavender? Sandalwood? The walls are plaster, cracked, old, faded green paint covering them. The floors dressed in luxurious carpets, a heavy oak desk at one end of the room and heavy oak bookshelves on the other, the same copper chandelier as the ones in the hallway hanging above their heads.

Voldemort is standing in front of a painting, his back to Peter, hands held behind him. For a moment neither of them speak. A long moment, as far as Peter is concerned. He fidgets at the door, trying to decide whether or not heâ€™s expected to say something. Constantly second guessing himself every time he goes to announce his presence until eventually the Dark Lord puts him out of his misery.

â€œI expect you know why youâ€™re here?â€

Peter swallows.

He does.

The Aurors were warned about the attack.

About the gas.

All of it. It was a massacre. Itâ€™d all been outlined for him in the letter that heâ€™d found in his flat, along with the Portkey that had brought him here. Peter isnâ€™t exactly sure how to answer the question though. Does Voldemort think thereâ€™s a chance he didnâ€™t read the letter? Is it a rhetorical question?

â€œThis is usually when you start babbling on about how thereâ€™s no way you could have known we were walking into a trap,â€ Voldemort once again speaks for him. â€œBegging for mercy, etcetera, etcetera.â€

Fuck.

â€œI didnâ€™t know,â€ because he hadnâ€™t.

â€œAnd how exactly is that possible?â€ the tone of his voice is calm, steady, his eyes still on the painting in front of him, like theyâ€™re just making small talkâ€”discussing what they plan on having for supper.

Peter fidgets. â€œWe had a meeting recently, the Order, Dumbledore and Moody announced to everyone that thereâ€™sâ€¦a spy.â€

â€œI see. And did anyone question you?â€

Peter almost snorts. Theyâ€™d have to remember I existed first, he nearly says, but doesnâ€™t. He doesnâ€™t want Voldemort to think he isnâ€™t important enough to be able to get him the information he needs.

â€œNo, and I pointed the finger at someone else before they could start.â€

Voldemort nods. â€œThen why didnâ€™t someone tell you about this?â€

â€œWell,â€ Peter swallows with some difficulty, his throat feeling tight. He pulls at his collar. â€œI think maybe Moody suspects that the spy is in the Order and not the Auror department,â€ heâ€™d been intending to keep that particular suspicion to himself butâ€¦well, he has to say something. â€œSo he kept the Order out of it. Kept it within his department.â€

Another long pause.

â€œHis suspicions will have been confirmed then. Heâ€™ll know whoever is passing me information is not an Auror. If youâ€™re telling the truth that is, and you really didnâ€™t know. That you havenâ€™t justâ€¦lost your nerve. Decided to switch sides again.â€

Peter feels as though his whole stomach has just jumped into his chest. â€œI would neverâ€”my lord I would never. I am committed to you I swear.â€

â€œIâ€™m sure you swear the same to Dumbledore,â€ he says casually. â€œBackstabbers really are such finicky little things.â€

â€œI will not betray you,â€ Peter can feel everything heâ€™s accomplished over the last few months slipping through his fingers. He had gained Voldemortâ€™s trust, his respect, completing every task given to him seamlessly. And nowâ€”now itâ€™s crumbling before his very eyes.

He licks his lips. â€œI swear on my life my lord, on the life of my mother and father, it is you I am faithful to and no one else. Andâ€”and I can still be useful. Even if Moody suspects an Order member there are dozens of other people it could be, heâ€™ll never think itâ€™s me.â€

â€œIt will make it more difficult for you to collect information though.â€

Peter grimaces. â€œI can do it. I promise this will never happen again.â€

Somehow Peter has managed to stumble into the middle of the room, arms held out, beseeching. Begging. He certainly isnâ€™t above begging. Heâ€™s honestly pretty good at it.

â€œThis painting,â€ Voldemort says when he speaks next, taking Peter completely by surprise, â€œis called the Flaying of Marsyas, have you seen it?â€

â€œErâ€¦â€ Peter feels lost. â€œNo?â€

Voldemort steps to the side, looking at Peter for the first time, dark eyes cutting right through him. â€œCome,â€ he gestures him forward, â€œlook.â€

Cautiously, Peter approaches. Itâ€™s a Muggle painting, that much is obvious right away because, well, no one is moving. Peter squints at it, not quite sure what heâ€™s looking at. Heâ€™s always rather preferred landscapes when it comes to paintingsâ€”simple, straight forward, pretty. This painting is none of those things.

â€œThe Flaying of Marsyas? So theyâ€™reâ€¦â€

â€œCutting his skin off,â€ Voldemort says. â€œYes. You see, Marsyas challenged the god Appollo to a music competition. He lost, of course, but then Apollo had him strung up and skinned alive for even daring to think he could best a god.â€

Something grows tight in Peterâ€™s chest, eyes bouncing from Voldemort to the gruesome painting. â€œMy lordâ€”â€œ

â€œIt's a lesson you see,â€ Voldemort interrupts him smoothly, â€œthat tragedy will inevitably befall anyone foolish enough to think they can best their betters.â€

Peterâ€™s heart is really beginning to flutter nowâ€”a bird unwillingly caged. â€œMy lord I promise, I promise I would never go back to them.â€

He smiles and then, in a movement so quick Peter doesnâ€™t even see it, he reaches out and grabs him by the face. Peter squeaks at the tightness of Voldemortâ€™s grip, the sharp puncturing of his nails. He leans in close and Peter begins to squirm but he gets nowhere.

The Dark Lord speaks. â€œI believe you Peter Pettigrew. But I want you to understand that if you betray me, if you dare to think you can out maneuver me, I will not hesitate to hang you from a tree and carve the skin from your bones.â€

He throws Peterâ€™s face out of his hand like he canâ€™t bare to touch it anymore, Peter stumbling back a few paces, rubbing petulantly at his injured cheek.

â€œI really do like the idea of flaying,â€ Voldemortâ€™s voice is light again, as though nothing has happened. â€œLike a snake shedding its skin,â€ a shiver runs through Peterâ€™s whole body when their eyes meet. When he sees the hunger in the man in front of him.

â€œYouâ€™re dismissed.â€

Chapter End Notes

Hi! Hey! Hello!

Am I freaking out about this chapter? Maybe. Do I just freak out about every chapter now? Apparently. Turns out. Oh well. Here we are.

Sorry this took so long again, but the chapters are just getting more complicated and heavy so it takes more time.

I hope this wasn't too much...I feel like Regulus chapters are always kinda a lot. But hey, next chapter is the Jegulus chapter so we can all look forward to that :)

Thank you all as always for sticking with me through this and being so kind even though it's the internet, I really appreciate all of you!

ALSO PSA: If you have made translations of Choices, can you get back in contact with me either via the comments or on tumblr (https://little-shit-soph.tumblr.com/) and give me a link and then I'll make a big post with links to all the translated versions so people can find them easier!!

Ok that's it thanks!

Chapter 51

Chapter Summary

â€œYou is not to be touching any of Master Regulusâ€™s things.â€

â€œRight, well, I need toâ€”ow!â€

â€œI said you are not to be touching!â€

â€œYeah, I heard youâ€”fuck you slap hardâ€”if you want me to help him then Iâ€™m going to need to touch things. I also need to know where he keeps his potions.â€

â€œNo one can go into Master Regulusâ€™s lab without his permission.â€

â€œI think maybe you can make an exception this time.â€

â€œNo.â€

â€œYouâ€™re very unpleasant, has anyone ever told you that?â€

The voices swim around in Regulusâ€™s head as he struggles through the dark. They donâ€™t mean anything to him. He hears them but he canâ€™t think. Canâ€™t understand. Noise, noise, noise. Thatâ€™s all it is. They come in and out of focus, sometimes louder and sometimes quieter. But when he pushes, edges closer to the thinning of the dark, where the black becomes grey, and then almost a faint red, he starts to feel the pain again, and instantly falls back into the hole behind him. Letting it consume him.

â€œWe have to take him to St Mungoâ€™s.â€

â€œNO! Master Regulus is being very clear that we cannot do that.â€

â€œHe needs a healer.â€

â€œNo!â€

â€œWell heâ€™s fucking bleeding out and I donâ€™t know what to do, Iâ€™m notâ€”I canâ€™tâ€”â€œ

Something in those words pokes at Regulusâ€™s flickering consciousness. Not the meaning, which is still lost on him, but theâ€¦sound. Breaking. Cracking. Splintering off. And he wants to fix it. Wants to pull it back together. Wants to hold all the pieces in his hands.

â€œOk, alright, new plan. Youâ€™re going to go get me whatever fucking healing potions he hasâ€”pain potions, blood replenishers, Skele-groâ€”whatever he has. And youâ€™re gonna get me towels and, I donâ€™t know, if thereâ€™s a book of healing spells in this goddamn house thatâ€™d be really useful too. And I wonâ€™t touch any of it except when I use it on Regulus okay? Deal?â€

â€œIs a bad deal.â€

â€œYeah well, we donâ€™t have a lot of options right now so itâ€™s bad deal or no deal.â€

â€œFine.â€

â€œFine.â€

It hurts. His whole body hurts. It started off soft but it keeps getting brighter and brighter and soon he thinks heâ€™s going to be on fire with it.

â€œGod Reg,â€ those words are quieter than the others. Soft. Followed by something gentle brushing against the back of his hand. And he understands them. He understands. But oh how it hurts.

He whimpers, unable to hold it in anymore, his body involuntarily contracting.

â€œReg? Regulus?â€

He tries to speak but it just comes out as a high pathetic whine. His eyes open and close, fighting with themselves. It hurts. It hurts. It hurts.

â€œPlease,â€ he canâ€™t remember what he did. â€œPlease, Iâ€™m sorry, please.â€ He tries to be good. So good and so quiet and so small. â€œPlease stop. Please stop.â€ To give them no reason to punish him.

Not that they need a reason.

â€œHey no, Iâ€”Iâ€™m going to make it stop, I promise. I promise Iâ€™ll make it stop okay?â€ the voice breaks again and Regulus squeezes his eyes shut, tears streaming down his face as he twitches and jerks and tries not to scream. Screaming always makes it worse. So does crying but he canâ€™t stop that at this point. Never could. He tried to tell Sirius but he didnâ€™t understand.

Sirius never cried.

Except that last time.

â€œAnd be what? Your mistress?â€ Honestly he would do it. Thatâ€™s the pathetic bit. He would do just about anything if it meant that he didnâ€™t have to live without this again. But he isnâ€™t going to say that out loud.

â€œNo,â€ James says firmly. â€œNo more lying, no more secrets. Not this time. I donâ€™t want to hide.â€

His brows draw together. â€œI donâ€™t know, I-I donâ€™t know, I justâ€¦â€ he shoves his hands into his hair, flustered. â€œI love you both so much. â€œNot everything,â€ James reaches out his hand, slow enough that Regulus could pull away if he wanted to. He doesnâ€™t. â€œNot yet,â€ he holds Regulusâ€™s face, thumb brushing his cheek. â€œCâ€™mon Reg,â€ he says, in a voice low enough that it makes Regulusâ€™s eyes flutter closed, â€œspoil me.â€

Regulus wants to argue, but thatâ€™s the truth isnâ€™t it? He had given up. Given up on them before they even started. Given up on himself before Sirius ever left him behind. â€œOkay,â€ he says finally, watching Jamesâ€™s eyes go wide.

â€œYeah?â€

â€œYes. Iâ€™ll come with you. Iâ€™ll come.â€

Itâ€™s not until that moment, when he hears the weight of the shaking breath that James lets go, when he sees the pain and relief twisting his face, that Regulus realizes how much heâ€™s hurt James. That he realizes how much James has meant it. All of it.

James sniffles, kissing the top of his head as he pulls away, linking their hands together. â€œCâ€™mon,â€ he says, offering Regulus a weak smile as he nods towards the fireplace. â€œlets go home, huh?â€

I am home,

he thinks stupidly.

It's always been you.

Regulus squeezes Jamesâ€™s hand. â€œI canâ€™t come yet,â€ he says, already wincing at the way it makes the light in Jamesâ€™s eyes flicker.

â€œRegâ€”â€œ

â€œI have to do something,â€ he tries to explain as the walls around them shake threateningly, the wards protecting them cracking. Some priceless antique shatters somewhere in the house. â€œItâ€™s important.â€

James interrogates his face, looking for something, Regulus doesnâ€™t know what. But he tries to give it to him, tries not to pull his mask on, tries not to hide anything. Not now. Not here.

Finally James nods. â€œBut then youâ€™ll come?â€

â€œI promise.â€

Thereâ€™s a pause, and then the ghost of a smile drifts across Jamesâ€™s face. â€œI believe you.â€

â€œI remember the address.â€

The one heâ€™d shakily written out in a Muggle post office all those years ago.

Seared in his brain.

â€œI love you Regulus.â€

Years disappear and suddenly theyâ€™re just two boys facing each other in an empty room.

A do over.

â€œI love you too.â€

James Potter is smiling when the flames pull him away.

After heâ€™s gone it feels like the oxygen has been sucked out of Regulusâ€™s life. Everything dark again.

He waves his wand, closing the Floo connection and leaning against the wall behind him for support. His body is sore, his head aching, and suddenly he feels exhausted. He thinks heâ€™s telling the truth.

He hopes he is.

Itâ€™s then that the house gives another tremendous shuddered, something else crashing to the ground.

â€œSir,â€ Kreacher appears, the shattered pieces of an ugly vase in his hands. â€œThey is be breaking the house! Breaking your motherâ€™s things!â€

Regulus isnâ€™t sure that thatâ€™s necessarily a bad thing.

â€œI know,â€ he says instead. â€œIâ€™ll let them in.â€

He nods, pushing himself off the wall with a groan. â€œTheyâ€™ll only keep trying until they get through anyway.â€

He closes his eyes briefly, muttering incantations under his breath and feeling the wards around the house pulse. Heâ€™s praying it isnâ€™t Lucius, even though he has a feeling it probably is. â€œRegulus!â€

â€œCerci?â€

â€œRegulus! Regulus are you okay? Regâ€”â€œ

â€œIâ€™m here, Iâ€™m in here.â€

He can hear her feet slamming into the floor as she runs towards his voice, sprinting into the room. â€œOh thank god,â€ she says as she launches herself into his arms, causing them both to stumble backwards.

Regulus winces, â€œCareful, Iâ€™mâ€”a bit fucked up.â€

â€œSorry,â€ she mutters into his shoulder, not letting him go.

Kreacher clears his throat. â€œI will beâ€”erâ€”putting this away sir,â€ he gestures to the broken vase in his hands, bowing out of the room with a knowing look that has Regulus rolling his eyes. Honestly, heâ€™s worse than Cerciâ€™s mum.

â€œI was so scared,â€ she murmurs, his had rubbing her back. Heâ€™s a bit awkward, comforting people having never been his forte. â€œI heardâ€”heard there was some kind of fight at the Ministry. â€œWell I can see that NOW.â€ But sheâ€™s still hugging him, like if she lets go he might disappear.

â€œOf course!â€

â€œWhat do you need me to do?â€

Chapter End Notes

Hello beautiful people!

For those of you who feel like Evan really got shafted in this chapter I promise he will not be forgotten and Regulus will be dealing with his death in the next chapter!

I hope this felt kind of satisfying to read, I wanted to give them the chance to talk about, like, everything. I don't know if I accomplished that but that was the dream!

As always, I know I am garbage at replying to comments but I do read them and they do mean a lot, I really appreciate all the love and support, we're getting really close to the end now which is honestly wild and making me feel a lil bit sad, but thanks for being here! Hope you're having a good day / night/ morning etc. ect.

Chapter 52

There's some cute shit here

Chapter Notes

tw Alcohol

tw Panic attack

tw ED (idk if this needs to be here because it's a side effect of the potions more than a conscious eating disorder but I just feel like it's being mentioned enough that I wanna throw this out there)

Canon continues to be a loose concept, like she's still around but sometimes we pretend we can't see her, y'know?

See the end of the chapter for more notes

PART I REGULUS

War is a strange thing. It bends the rules of normal life. Of normal morality. Warps everything to revolve around it. It had never occurred to Regulus that a body could be used as a weapon. He had somewhat assumed that, as a society, they were all agreed that certain things were sacred.

He was wrong.

The Ministry refuses to return the bodies of the dead Death Eaters to their families without a comprehensive list of names detailing everyone who was part of the attempted coup. No one, of course, agrees to supply such a list and so dozens of bodies go unclaimed. Unburied. Unmourned.

And Evan Rosier is one of them.

His mother waits a week before she decides to have a funeral anyway. Dozens of people dressing in black and attending the Rosier home where a large portrait of Evan is suspended in the middle of the living room, winking and smirking at everyone who walks by. Regulus finds it hard to breathe every time he sees it. Doing his best to avoid it all together.

Somehow he ends up on the stairs with Barty, passing a flask of firewhisky back and forth. They donâ€™t talk. There isnâ€™t anything to say. There have been speeches all day, from family members, friends. Neither Regulus nor Barty get up. Regulus has no desire to showcase his grief. Besides, he barely recognizes the Evan everyone else is talking aboutâ€”the perfect son, perfect student, perfect friendâ€”Regulus loved Evan. He really did. But â€œperfectâ€ is not the word he would use to describe him.

Mrs. Rosier had pleaded with Regulus to tell her about her sonâ€™s last moments. And so he had, hands shaking in his lap the whole time. He had told her about how well Evan had fought, how heâ€™d saved Regulus, how brave (not idiotic, or delusional, or selfish) he had been to take on Alastor Moody. How heâ€™d almost won. How heâ€™d died quickly and peacefullyâ€”though he isnâ€™t entirely sure that last one is true. Nothing about that moment had felt peaceful to Regulus.

He did not tell her that he held Evan in his arms. That he let him go. Left him behind.

The thing that hurts most. Well, besides all of it. Is that he doesnâ€™t think that Evan would have done it. Left him behind, that is. He never had before.

Heâ€™s passing the flask silently back to Barty when Cerci appears. Heâ€™d lost her sometime after they made it through the line of people offering condolences. Heâ€™s said â€œIâ€™m sorry for your lossâ€ so many times today heâ€™s not sure he knows what the words mean anymore.

â€œHowâ€™re you two holding up?â€ she asks, her eyes soft, running them over. He isnâ€™t sure what they look like. Probably pathetic. He feels pathetic.

Barty holds up his hand, palm down, and wiggles it. Cerci gives him a small smile.

â€œFair enough. Why donâ€™t we get out of here huh? Go get some food? My treat.â€

â€œThereâ€™s food here,â€ Barty says, though he doesnâ€™t even sound like heâ€™s making an argument, more just stating a fact.

â€œYeah, but I feel like you two could benefit from maybe not being here anymore.â€

Barty makes a noise that might be a laugh or a scoff, Regulus canâ€™t tell. Cerciâ€™s eyes finding him, asking a question.

â€œReg?â€

He holds her gaze for a moment before looking over at the doorway to the living room, just the edge of Evanâ€™s portrait visible.

â€œYeah,â€ he says finally, voice rough. â€œYeah lets go.â€

He isnâ€™t paying attention to where Cerci is taking them, doesnâ€™t think Barty is either, the pair of them asleep on their feet. Death is one of those thingsâ€”you have nothing to compare it toâ€”which makes it very difficult to hold. Evan is dead.

Heâ€™s dead.

Heâ€™s dead.

Heâ€™s dead.

Regulus knows that. Knew it the moment it happened. Saw the empty look in his friendâ€™s eyes. But he stillâ€¦canâ€™t quiteâ€¦grasp what it means.

Itâ€™s not until Cerci is shoving him into a leather booth after Barty that Regulus realizes theyâ€™ve ended up at the Leaky Cauldron. Itâ€™s empty mostly, people donâ€™t go out much these days, itâ€™s not safe.

Because of you, hisses the voice in his head.

He smothers it the best he can. He can only handle so much guilt at once.

â€œWhat can I get you folks?â€

Regulus blinks up at the overly chipper witch who has just arrived at their table. She smiles at them, pad of paper and QuickQuotes Quill floating beside her head.

â€œWhisky,â€ Barty says, voice flat. Heâ€™s leaning back against the booth, expression as blank as his tone, â€œlots of it.â€

The waitressâ€™s smile slips, replaced by confusionâ€”she looks like sheâ€™s trying to figure out whether or not to take him seriously.

â€œJust bring us the bottle,â€ Regulus says, satisfied when he sees the quill finally move.

â€œAlso a pitcher of water please,â€ Cerci cuts in. â€œAnd three burgers with chips.â€

When the waitress turns towards her, her face lights up. â€œOh my god, Cerci! I didnâ€™t even see you there, how are you?â€

Cerciâ€™s face goes red instantly. â€œIâ€™mâ€”Iâ€™m goodâ€”greatâ€”well,â€ she looks quickly at Barty and Regulus and then back at the waitress. â€œNot great, obviouslyâ€”just came from a funeral, so, bit sad actually, but also, alsoâ€¦great right now, well, here, cause chips andâ€¦you orâ€¦stuff,â€ all of that comes out more or less on the strength of a single breath, leaving Cerci looking rather deflated at the end of it, and panting ever so slightly.

â€œFuck,â€ he hisses, voice shaking. â€œI miss him so much.â€

â€œProbably. But thatâ€™s a good thing.â€

Regulus is feeling a little blurry so it takes a moment for that to really sink in, but when it does, something in his chest eases a little. â€œThank you,â€ he says finally, voice rough. â€œThatâ€”that helps.â€

Regulus does not remember Kreacher coming back. Or falling asleep for that matter. With some effort heâ€™s able to sit, mouth stale and dry, head pounding. He swings his legs over the side of the bed and then pauses, waiting for the spins to cease and his stomach to stop threatening to purge itself. And then he reaches for the potion.

Itâ€™s barely down his throat and he already starts to feel relief, a cool sensation wafting over him, like a damp cloth has been placed on his forehead. He chugs the water and stands, walking into the bathroom. He feels more human after a shower and brushing his teeth, fixing his hair in the mirror before his hand reaches outâ€”instinct, habitâ€”he freezes when he realizes what heâ€™s doing, suddenly caught staring at his own reflection.

after all of that,

Jamesâ€™s voice rings loud in his head.

All of the pain you caused so that you could survive, here you are KILLING YOUR FUCKING SELF.

He keeps staring at his reflection, hand beginning to shake. Surely, after seeing James again, after being given a purpose, a way to redeem himself, he can let it go. Let the ghosts go. Surely he can focus his attention entirely on his new plan. And do it sober.

Really?

Regulus winces at the voice.

Just gonna forget about me huh?

It feels like Evan is standing right behind him, head tilted, smirk hanging from his mouth.

Oh câ€™mon Reg, you canâ€™t really be surprised to see me, right? I mean, if it werenâ€™t for you Iâ€™d still be alive.

â€œI know,â€ he croaks, eyes suddenly squeezed shut. The thing is, it doesnâ€™t really sound like Evan. The voice maybe, but the words, the cruel liltâ€”Evan might have spoken to other people that way but never Regulus.

â€œGod, stop.â€

No.

You donâ€™t get to make demands. Not now. Not after what you did to me.

And thatâ€™s it. Thatâ€™s all he has in him, swinging the mirror open and reaching for one of the bottles.

Evan laughs again.

Damn Reg. I knew you were weak, but I didnâ€™t know you were quite this pathetic.

Regulus doesnâ€™t argue. Heâ€™s not sure he could ever sink low enough to surprise himself.

Â 

His thoughts are duller when he heads down the stairs a few minutes later. The voices silenced. Nothing but indistinct murmurs in the corners of his mind. He knows he wonâ€™t be able to keep this going, especially with James. But for now at leastâ€¦it helps.

Heâ€™ll stop when he has to.

Heâ€™s getting worse. The anxiety, the panicâ€”itâ€™s getting worse. The potions help, but they have their own side effects, Regulus knows that, he does. Knows that people get addicted to them. Maybe heâ€™s one of those people, he canâ€™t tell, it doesnâ€™t feel quite that simple. He just knows that he canâ€™t go to James like this. He needs to find a way to get himself under control.

â€œThe archives here cover a wide variety of areas,â€ the woman in front of them says before pulling out her wand and unlocking the door on their right. â€œYes thatâ€™s right,â€ Cerci says cheerfully, looking around.

â€œAbsolutely,â€ Cerci answers again, causing the woman to stare her down for a minute, like sheâ€™s trying to figure out whether or not sheâ€™s being mocked.

Â 

It would probably help if they had some idea what they were looking for. Mostly Regulus is just trying to see if there are places or objects that Salazar brings up a lot. He also writes a lot about the need of Wizards to guard themselves against Muggles. He does not think that they should be attempting to build political relationships with them, does not believe the Muggles can be trusted to honour any agreements they make. He writes very strong letters to the prominent leaders of the Wizarding world at the time. Not politicians as much as petty lords, each with their own tiny fiefdoms and array of vassals.

Which is fascinating.

Unhelpful.

But fascinating.

Regulus sighs, pushing the hair out of his face as he pulls out another folder of letters. Heâ€™s expecting more of the sameâ€”politics and potion theoryâ€”but then he reads the first line:

Ma moitiÃ©

Regulus stops. Rubs his eyes. Reads the line again.

Ma moitiÃ©

My other half. My better half. Thatâ€™s what that means, heâ€™s heard his father use it when referring to his mother once or twice. Itâ€™s meant for intimates. Friends, loversâ€”

Ma moitiÃ©,

I was on a walk the other day, in the forest around my home, and I couldnâ€™t help thinking about that time when we were young. Fifteen? Sixteen? And you declared that youâ€™d had enough of farm work and from now on you wanted to instead be an adventurer. The look on your fatherâ€™s face, I thought for certain he was going to end you. But then, you always got away with more foolishness than the rest of us (donâ€™t even try to deny it you know itâ€™s true). So instead he told you to go on, to try to be an adventurer, to survive on your own in the wilderness without all the comforts of the farm. You were the only one of us who didnâ€™t seem to know exactly how that was going to end.

I would have been happy to leave you to it, but, of course, you werenâ€™t having that. Wherever you went I was bound to follow. So we loaded our sacs with a few supplies, and a map we could barely read, and set off on what was inevitably going to be an absolute failure. That first night, out in the wilderness, it rained, do you remember? Started pouring and neither of us knew any spells to keep dry, so eventually we found a caveâ€”well, or at least a spot where the cliffs hung out just enough to offer us some shelter.

You started a fire, both of us stripping out of our wet clothes and laying them out to dry, down to nothing but our undergarments. We hadnâ€™t even kissed yet at that point and seeing you, standing there in all your youthful glory, was absolute agony. You were beautiful even then, before you had properly grown into yourself, properly become the hero everyone knows you as today. And then. You had the audacity to turn to me and beckon. BECKON. I swear my poor heart almost combusted at the feel of you against my back, your arm around my waist, mouth at the nape of my neck.

Do you remember what you said then? Do you remember? The fire dying, the sound of the rain in the trees surrounding us, me slowly drifting to sleep in your arms you said: â€œI want to always be this close to you.â€

Iâ€™m not sure Iâ€™ve ever recovered from that. Even all these years later.

I know there is a great deal of life that separates us now, that things are not nearly as simple as they were when we were fifteen. But I canâ€™t help but hope that you still long for the days when we fell asleep in one anotherâ€™s arms. Canâ€™t help but hope that after it all you still want to be that close to me. One day maybe, you will feel the urge to be an adventurer again. And find your way back to me.

Yours always,

S.

Â 

Regulus stares at that last line for a long time.

S.

Itâ€™s not possible. Itâ€™s not. Before he can stop himself he starts flipping through the other letters. â€œAny moment is a â€œgo teamâ€ moment if you try hard enough.â€

Â 

Â 

The second he gets home he rushes up to his bedroom and starts pouring over the letters. Greedily eating up every line. From what he can tell these were written at least a decade after Salazar left Hogwarts and they seem to go on for a decade more before they stop.

Because Godric finally came, whispers the childish voice in his head. Because Salazar finally let him in. Because after spending nearly their entire lives orbiting around one another it was finally time. Alone in the woods they spent their old age together. Hidden from the world.

Or at least thatâ€™s how Regulus is deciding the story goes.

Unwilling to accept anything else.

He feels a little giddy, his head filled with pages and pages of words. Words that arenâ€™t his own and yet sometimes feel so close to his heart that heâ€™s certain heâ€™s thought them himself. He wants desperately to tell James. He knows heâ€™ll laugh when he finds out, knows his head will grow at least another two sizes.

Heâ€™ll say something like â€œOf course I got it right. I canâ€™t believe you ever doubted me.â€

Before Regulus can stop himself heâ€™s getting off his bed and sitting down at his desk, pulling out a fresh piece of parchment and a quill. His quill draws elegantly across the page, the first words squeezing his heart.

Dear J,

PART II REMUS

Â

â€œI need some wings you mean?â€

â€œYou know what,â€ Sirius pulls out his own purple disc. â€œI think youâ€™re right.â€

â€œKids.â€

It still feels odd to say that. To have â€œkidâ€ be something they were not something they are. You spend so much of your youth trying to convince everyone that youâ€™re grown, but the minute the world turns around and says â€œyou, youâ€™re an adult, youâ€™re responsibleâ€ you canâ€™t help but feel that a terrible mistake has been made.

Sometimes heâ€™s even still trapped in that house.

He feels tugging on his sleeve and starts when he realizes that Charlotte is right next to him, her feet firmly on the ground for the first time since the wings went on.

â€œHey, whatâ€™s up?â€ he asks her, bending down slightly.

â€œI never see any anymore,â€ she goes on. â€œI miss them.â€

â€œIs he like us?â€

Remus doesnâ€™t know why that makes his breath hitch. Maybe because itâ€™s his biggest fear. He can hear Regulus Blackâ€™s dead voice in his head: Havenâ€™t bitten him yet then?

â€œNo,â€ Remus finally manages, voice a little tight. â€œBut heâ€”he knows.â€

She looks back at Sirius before nodding. â€œSo you can show me then?â€

Siriusâ€™s brows draw together, eyes bouncing between the pair of them, clearly trying to figure out if this is some sort of game. â€œButâ€¦itâ€™s not even close to the full moon?â€

â€œWhy would that matter?â€ Charlotte responds before Remus gets the chance.

â€œIâ€”â€œ Sirius lets out a shaky laugh, running a hand through his hair. â€œSorry, Iâ€™m lost here. What are we talking about?â€

â€œYeah?â€

Heâ€™s nervous. Partially because itâ€™s dangerous, and partially because Sirius is here. Is watching him. But he doesnâ€™t want all of Miaâ€™s hard work to be lost. He doesnâ€™t want Charlotte to see a cell at the Ministry every time she thinks about this part of herself.

â€œMoons,â€ Sirius says, falling into step with them as they head out of town and towards the school. â€œWhatâ€™s she talking about?â€

The whole time they walk Sirius shoots him nervous looks out of the corner of his eyes. For all that he loves springing them on other people, Sirius has never much liked surprises himself.

â€œOkay, this ought to be good,â€ Remus says as they come to a small clearing, far enough into the forest that no one passing by on the outside can see them.

Remus steps back, making sure thereâ€™s a good amount of space between him and the others. He notices Sirius moving closer to Charlotte and he tries not to take that personally. â€œShhh!â€ Charlotte silences him and Remus has to bite his lip to hold back a laugh.

Itâ€™s only Sirius.

He exhales again, searching for the howl, the one that runs underneath his thoughts. His pulse. Always there. Steady. He tries to remind himself that it isnâ€™t scary. That itâ€™s just a part of him, like every other part. And then he pulls it forward. Makes it loud. As loud as it wants to be.

For a moment everything disappears.

â€œHoly shit.â€

â€œCharlotte donâ€™tâ€”â€œ

Moony instantly lowers himself, dipping his head, trying to show that heâ€™s not a threat.

Pack, he thinks.

Pack.

and pack.

and pack.

And does not pet.

Beautiful.

thump.

thump.

Pack.

Pack.

Pack.

Â 

Â 

Remus is able to patch his clothes back together with magic. Heâ€™s still looking rough, but once he has his jumper and his coat back on itâ€™s not too bad. â€œPretty sure you have to communicate to murder someone together.â€
