â€œI love you too.â€

Chapter End Notes

Hello beautiful people!

Is this an accurate portrayal of how orphanages work? No. But I ask you to suspend your disbelief so that we can read less about paperwork and more about Wolfstar being dads for the day!

I hope that the softer moments in this chapter were a nice little break from all the drama and angst, and if not, don't worry, the next three-ish chapters are ALL drama and angst (can you believe there are only three chapters left, like goddamn)

Thank you all so much! Sorry this update took a while again! I hope you're having a lovely day! :)

Chapter 53

Chapter Summary

Don't go to Troy

Chapter Notes

tw: referenced sexual assault
tw: referenced substance abuse (recovering from substance abuse)
tw: child abuse (via magic)
tw: Major Character Death (I feel like everyone is aware of this one at this point but, yeah, hey babes, we're here)
tw: suicide

In case it is still unclear at this point - this is an interpretation of canon

I tried to make his death more about closure than about, y'know, being scary and traumatic, like it's still scary but that isn't the focus

PART I REGULUS

Regulus sighs as he watches the sun rise outside his window.

Another night gone in a blur of faces and voices and moments he would rather forget.

Itâ€™ll get better, he tells himself as he showers, as he does up the buttons of his shirt, as he wrestles his hair into something close to respectable. Itâ€™ll get better. Thatâ€™s what people say right? People like James Potter and Remus Lupin andâ€”well, he canâ€™t really see Sirius saying anything remotely like that but he must pretend when heâ€™s around them. Pretend to be the type of person who believes things get better. Regulus canâ€™t imagine it comes naturally to him. Itâ€™s not how they were raised.

His hands twitch, wanting to pull open the mirror, to shut-up the guilt vibrating inside his skin. He grips the sink in front of him and drops his head, letting out a shaky breath.

Heâ€™s trying.

But then, he still hasnâ€™t thrown them outâ€”the potions.

He could.

He could get rid of them all. Maybe lessen the temptation. But he just canâ€™t quite bring himself toâ€¦what if he needs them? Heâ€™s going to have to sleep at some point.

How does the saying go? No rest for the wicked?

Evan is right by his ear. Echoing in his head. Regulusâ€™s hands tighten around the sink. He tries to will the voice away, but even just doing that makes him feel guilty. He knows it isnâ€™t really Evan, he does. He hasnâ€™t completely lost it. But at the moment, itâ€™s the closest thing he has to him.

What dâ€™you reckon your boyfriend will say huh? When you canâ€™t sleep without getting fucked-up? Or better yet, when you start calling out his parentsâ€™ names? How exactly are you going to explain that?

Regulus is afraid that if he looks up heâ€™ll find Evan in the mirror. That if he sees his face, figment of his imagination or not, heâ€™ll crack. So he just keeps staring at the drain, nails scraping the porcelain.

â€œIâ€™ll tell him the truth,â€ he manages finally.

He wonâ€™t lie to James again. He wonâ€™t repeat old mistakes. Regulus tried to push James away, tried to make James stop loving him, it didnâ€™t work. Not for either of them. And he isnâ€™t interested in trying again.

â€œIâ€™ll tell him the truth,â€ he repeats, hoping that he means it.

Youâ€™re a fool if you think heâ€™ll be able to get over that.

Maybe, but Regulus reckons, of all the things he has to live with, being foolish is probably the easiest.

Itâ€™s another few minutes before heâ€™s able to let go of the sink and walk away. He should feel good. Triumphant. He didnâ€™t take the potions. Didnâ€™t open the cabinet. He isnâ€™t sure that he does exactly, but thereâ€™s somethingâ€”some little tickle just beneath his ribs. Something that if he waters and feeds it and gives it a bit of sun, might just blossom into good.

Â 

Kreacher is waiting for him in the kitchen, sliding a loaded plate towards him as he sits down at the table. Sometimes he thinks about how his mother used to snap at him for spending time in here. Acting common. He takes some satisfaction in knowing that this isnâ€™t her house anymore and he can spend his time wherever the fuck he pleases.

Regulus feels Kreacherâ€™s eyes on him as he shovels eggs into his mouth and when he looks up he sees the house elf with tears in his eyes.

â€œKreacher?â€ he asks, concerned.

Kreacher sniffles, before offering him a watery smile. â€œYou is eating sir, and I is not even having to throw things.â€

Regulus snorts. â€œItâ€™s really good Kreacher, thank you.â€

Another sniffle, Kreacher using the dishtowel in his hands to dry his eyes. â€œI will be making it all the time if you will be liking it.â€

Regulus feels his throat grow tight. He isnâ€™t sure if itâ€™s real, the care that Kreacher shows him, or if he canâ€™t help it. Part of his obligation to their family. Isnâ€™t sure he wants to know.

â€œThank you,â€ he manages eventually, before putting him and Kreacher both out of their misery and turning back to his breakfastâ€”saving them from anymore emotional outbursts.

Itâ€™s nice, being able to taste his food, even if heâ€™s still feeling a little unsteadyâ€”his stomach and head prone to aching, his skin hotter than is comfortable. He isnâ€™t worried. He knows these potions well. Knows what withdrawal looks like. Heâ€™s just hoping no one else does.

â€œFuck!â€ â€¨â€¨

Regulus drops his fork as a sharp burning pain shoots up his arm.

â€œMaster Regulus what is being the matter?â€

By the time Regulus is rolling his sleeve back, he already knows what it isâ€”what it has to be. And there, on his arm, is the snake wiggling inside its skull, glowing bright green.

â€œFuck,â€ he hisses again, a little more controlled this time.

â€œBut you is not being finished your breakfast yet!â€ Kreacher complains, sounding genuinely upset. Itâ€™s almost enough to make Regulus smile. Unfortunately, thereâ€™s already a sick feeling creeping up on him, threatening to make him vomit the food he has eaten. â€¨â€¨

â€œKeep it warm for me, yeah?â€ he manages, clearing his throat so he doesnâ€™t sound quite so scared. â€œIâ€™ll eat it when I get back.â€

He knew this was coming, of course. That after the dust had settled, and the wounds had been licked, they would have to come back together. To figure out their next move after the disaster that occurred at the Ministry. But god heâ€™s been dreading it.

â€œIs Mister Lucius going to be being there sir?â€ Kreacher asks as Regulus heads towards the front door, the mark on his arm begging to take him away, to Apparate to its master, unable to do so within the houseâ€™s wards.

â€œYeah,â€ Regulus says, happy that his voice comes out steady this time. â€¨â€œI expect so.â€

â€œGood,â€ Kreacher hands him his jacket as they get to the entryway. â€œPerhaps if he be seeing you he will be leaving the house alone. â€œYeah,â€ Regulus says noncommittally. â€œMaybe.â€

â€œI will be keeping your breakfast warm!â€ Kreacher announces, as though worried that Regulus might think heâ€™s forgotten.

Regulus opens the door, throwing the elf a weak smile over his shoulder, â€œThanks Kreacher.â€ Heâ€™s barely on the front stoop before the magic in his arm is pulling him away. He can resist it of course, but when he doesnâ€™t, the Dark Lord is able to call him wherever he pleases.

Â 

Itâ€™s not a surprise when he finds himself on the front lawn of Malfoy Manor, an angry peacock glaring at him as though heâ€™s just personally offended it. This should be fun.

â€œWell, well, well.â€

Heâ€™s barely crossed the threshold into the marble entryway when Luciusâ€™s voice finds him. Heâ€™s lurking in the shadows, clearly waiting for Regulus, leaning against the wall just under the stairs. Heâ€™s wearing an expensive suit, his hair long enough that heâ€™s started braiding it.

â€œI didnâ€™t think youâ€™d show,â€ he leers. â€œThe way youâ€™ve been hiding.â€

â€œGood morning to you too,â€ Regulus says flatly, not stopping on his way to the drawing room. He has no desire to engage in anything with Lucius.

â€œOh come now Regulus, whatâ€™s the rush?â€

Click.

Click.

Click.

Healed shoes on marble floors. Regulus thinks that noise will make him shiver for the rest of his life.

â€œThe Dark Lord has summoned us,â€ he replies diplomatically.

Lucius snorts. â€œWell look whoâ€™s an eager little beaver. But then, I guess you were always something of a teacherâ€™s pet werenâ€™t you? Desperate to please.â€

It takes a great deal of effort not to whip around and punch him.

The drawing room is just coming into view when Lucius grabs hold of Regulusâ€™s arm and yanks him to a stop. A sickening feeling rocks through Regulus as he pulls himself free.

â€œDonâ€™t. Fucking. Touch me.â€ He rounds on the older man, wand already in his hand.

Lucius laughs. â€œAre you going to curse me Regulus? Really?â€

Regulus doesnâ€™t move. Itâ€™s a bluff, he hates that itâ€™s a bluff, but he canâ€™t really fight Lucius. Heâ€™s respected too much. By everyone, but most importantly, by Voldemort. And Lucius knows it.

The older man steps forward, still smiling, allowing the tip of Regulusâ€™s wand to poke his sternum. â€œGo on,â€ he hisses, â€œdo it,â€ and when Regulus still doesnâ€™t move; â€œYou know, theyâ€™re looking for a traitor in there,â€ he nods towards the drawing room. â€œTrying to figure out who sold our secrets to the Aurors,â€ he leans slightly forward and it takes everything in Regulus not to flinch. Somehow he still feels trapped even though heâ€™s the one with his wand raised. â€œIâ€™ve already told the Dark Lord my moneyâ€™s on you. So go on sweetheart, prove me right.â€

Regulus grits his teeth, hands shaking. â€œWhat the hell do you want from me?â€

That only makes Luciusâ€™s smile grow. â€œWhat do I want? I would have thought that was obvious,â€ vicious, hungry. â€œI want you on your fucking knees.â€

Funnily enough, all he can think about is Bellatrix. Casting the Imperious on him. Making him crawl around like a dog.

The pathetic part. Is once upon a time he really did think they loved him.

â€œBlack.â€

He spins around to find Snape holding open the door to the drawing room, gaze cold, though surprisingly, not directed at Regulus.

â€œCome on,â€ Snape says after a brief pause, â€œyouâ€™re late.â€

â€œMe and Regulus were actually just having a chat,â€ Lucius says, his manners brittle. â€œSo if you donâ€™t mindâ€”â€œ

â€œI mind,â€ Snape interrupts. â€œBlack, lets go.â€ His tone is so blank that itâ€™s hard to fully appreciate what this is.

A rescue.

Regulus doesnâ€™t need to be told twice, slipping his wand back into its holster and heading towards the room without a backwards glance. He canâ€™t quite bring himself to thank Snape, but he pauses at the door, the pair of them locking eyes for just a moment. Some sort of understanding passing between them. He isnâ€™t doing this for Regulus, of course. Still couldnâ€™t give a shit about him, just like in school.

This is about Snapeâ€™s mum.

About what he could never do for her.

Doesnâ€™t mean Regulus isnâ€™t still grateful.

He nods his head in recognition. Snape, surprisingly, nodding back. And then the moment passes, and Regulus is walking into the room, the door slamming behind him. Lucius left in the hall.

It takes the wind out of Regulus when his eyes scan the table in front of him and find Barty sitting alone. His feet stuttering as he walks towards him. Itâ€™s funny how much space one person can take up without you even realizing it. But everything feels emptier without Evan. Smaller.

â€œA lot of people are missing today,â€ Regulus says under his breath as he counts heads, trying to work out whoâ€™s not there.

A deep feeling of unease grips Regulusâ€™s stomach. Partially, because he is a traitor, and partially, because he knows Lucius has been going around telling people so. â€œWe have much to discuss today.â€

Â 

The Ministry was a hollow victory for Dumbledore. At least, that is how Lucius sees it. And Bellatrix. Rodolphus. Theyâ€™re warn down. And Alastor Moody has no sympathy for them. But the Dark Lord does. Endless supplies of sympathy, if thatâ€™s what it takes to get them to switch sides.

â€œI would ask one more thing before we part today,â€ Voldemort says after nearly two hours. Regulusâ€™s head feels stuffy, his mouth and eyes dry. He canâ€™t wait to get the hell out of this place. â€œI have a task of great importance to completeâ€”â€œ

â€œI will happily take on any task you need my lord,â€ Lucius interrupts, causing Regulus to roll his eyes. â€œOf course.â€

PART II SIRIUS

Sirius wakes up alone.

Itâ€™s not so bad.

Heâ€™s used to it.

At least thatâ€™s what he tells himself.

Of just staying in bed until Remus comes home. Whenever that is. He pulls the covers up over his head, wrapping them around himself, pouting even though no oneâ€™s there to see it.

Sometimes he pictures their dorm room back at Hogwarts. He tries to remember every detailâ€”every scratch in the wall, every fingerprint on the window, every sock lost under the bed. He closes his eyes and imagines listening to Peter and James bicker about Quidditch, to Remus telling them off for getting distracted from their coursework. When he wakes up heâ€™s still alone.

No bickering. No touches. No noise.

Itâ€™s not so bad.

Heâ€™s used to it.

At least thatâ€™s what he tells himself.

Â

Â

PART III REGULUS

He doesnâ€™t know what to do with himself. He paces around the house, thinks about firecalling Cerci, but he knows that sheâ€™s at work. Fuck heâ€™s such an idiot.

He ends up in the kitchen, the part of the house that feels the safest, he makes tea because itâ€™s one of the only thing he knows how to do on his own. He finds his breakfast still waiting for him. He hadnâ€™t been thinking, too focused on maybe, finally, getting closer to the Horcruxâ€”he hadnâ€™t been thinking about what he was actually agreeing to.

He leaves his lukewarm tea behind and retreats to his bedroom.

He stares at the newspaper clippings on his wall like they will suddenly provide the answers they have failed to for the last few weeks. One end of the room to the other.

Hours pass.

â€œKreacher? Kreacher, are you alrightâ€”shit, Kreacher?â€ the elf is shaking and muttering to himself. Regulus lifts his wand only to realize itâ€™s not a wand but his quill. â€œKreacher what happened?â€

This is the moment that Regulus Black makes his choice.

To be the kind of person who stands on the shore and watches you drown.

â€œBodies?â€ Regulus repeats. In every direction he sees them, no patch of water clear. And then, at the base of the rockâ€”fingers. Grasping at the stones, slowly inching towards them, grey skin slouching off of knuckles and wrists.

â€œI would do it all again, you know. I would relive every miserable moment of my miserable life just for the chance to be yours,â€ his voice shakes, and he thinks about fighting back the tears but in the end he doesnâ€™t bother. No one is here. No one can see him. He can cry now.

â€œYou wereâ€¦the best part for me. Of being here. Ofâ€¦being. Justâ€”the best part. I never knew what it meant to be happy before I met you. Never knew what it meant to be full. He sits up, finding Boo standing in front of him, looking right at him. Still, he sees the glowing white blob Boo has become getting closer, feels the lovely tickling sensation of his presence as he sits next to him, right by his side. Flooding him with warmth. Spring.

Spring.

Spring.

Regulus opens his eyes, finally wiping away the tears, Boo shifting to set his head in his lap. Regulus laughs wetly. â€œT-thanks,â€ he manages, lightly passing his hand over Booâ€™s head, more miming petting than actually doing it.

Some of the Inferi have dragged themselves closer. Filling in the spots absent of Booâ€™s light. He canâ€™t help but wonder who they used to beâ€”if they have thoughts, if they can remember. If this is what will happen to him. Itâ€™s work to stop his breathing from getting out of control again.

He knows he could stay like this, shielded by Boo, maybe not forever, but certainly for a long time. But he isnâ€™t sure it would be worth it. The last thing he wants is for Voldemort to find him here. For him to hand Regulus over to Bellatrix to play with before he kills him. To Lucius.

â€œJe tâ€™aime, James,â€ he says eventually, hand sliding down, holding the stagâ€™s face. â€œJe tâ€™aime,â€ he gives Boo a wet smile. â€œSince I was eleven.â€

Itâ€™ll be easier, if James just thinks heâ€™s changed his mind.

If he doesnâ€™t know.

The truth would only make him do something stupid.

The bodies have started crawling towards him again, and because Regulus would really rather not see them he points at the orb floating above his head and whispers: â€œnox.â€

The darkness is good, though it does nothing about the sounds of flesh and bone dragging towards him. His breaths are getting shorter again, panicked, and he drops his head between his knees doing his best not to completely lose it.

Heâ€™s holding on. To every second, every moment, greedy for every heartbeat.

not yet,

â€œAvada-Kedavra.â€

Â 

Somewhere, in the West Country of England, James Potter canâ€™t breathe.

PART I TOM

Â 

Little boys never do know their limits. Always pushing. Running too far. Too close to the edge. Asking too much.

Mummy please.

Please.

Please.

And she gives in doesnâ€™t she? Makes him spoiled and weak until one day he calls and she doesnâ€™t answer.Â 

Mummy please.

Please.

Please.

The beauty of having a mother whoâ€™s dead, is you learn early on that no one is coming. Innocent or guilty. Fair or unfair. No one is ever coming.

Â 

So you better know how to swim. Â Â 

Â 

Empty grey eyes stare up at him. Wide and unseeing. The body floating on top of the water, starting to bloat. Tom draws it to him with his wand, watches as it bobs against the islandâ€™s edge. He crouches down, running his knuckle along the side of its face.

Regulus Black really is a handsome boy. Even half-rotted.Â 

Clever too.

You never can trust the clever ones.

Or the pretty ones for that matter.

Tom knows that better than anyone.

Standing up he walks towards the basin at the centre of the rocks, reassuring himself, once again, that the locket is still where it should be. He lingers on it for a moment. The snake thatâ€™s carved into the front distorted by the liquid on top of it, making it look as though itâ€™s squirming.

When heâ€™d first learned of his connection to Salazar Slytherin as a boy heâ€™d been rather delighted. Proud. But the more he learned of the Founder the more that feeling dulled. Salazar had no dreams of power. Merely defence. He wanted to build a wall around the magical world. But Tom, Tom wants to watch it grow.

Wizarding kind has become complacent. So many magical abilities remaining underdeveloped, so many possible avenues of study untouchedâ€”because theyâ€™re seen as immoral. It's provincial and small minded thinking. Tom has no patience for it. Even at school he found the idea that some magic is â€œdarkâ€ tedious. That there was a â€œrestrictedâ€ section of the library, laughable. These antiquated ideas have to be done away with. Especially if he is to achieve that which he wants above all else.

His eyes go back to the locket, thin fingers skimming the top of the potion before pulling away. Heâ€™s here because Regulus Black has been missing for three days. And Tom doesnâ€™t need Lucius whispering in his ears to know that Regulus Blackâ€™s loyalty is paper thin and that heâ€™s smart enough to do Tomâ€™s plans serious damage. Especially not after he found that book in Regulusâ€™s room. The one that had set Tom on this path in the first place.

So he decided it would be prudent to check on his locket. To make sure all was as it should be. And lo and beholdâ€¦

He considers the dead boy, pressing the bottom of his boot into his cheek. He wonders if he even managed to get across the lake? Did he find the boat? Or did he try to swim? Tom supposes in the end it doesnâ€™t matter. The caveâ€™s defences worked.

He could bring the body back. He knows Walburga and Orion will want it. Theyâ€™re very touchy about these sorts of thingsâ€”the old Wizarding familiesâ€”with their crypts and traditions. But after the stunt Dumbledore pulled with the bodies at the Ministry, Tom thinks heâ€™d rather use Regulus to send a message.

You keep mine. I keep yours.

Heâ€™d suspected Dumbledore of having a spy for a while now, even though Pettigrew swore he didnâ€™t. He hadnâ€™t trusted Black, but he hadnâ€™t quite believed that he had the courage for this type of betrayal either.

You never can trust the clever ones.

Or the pretty ones.

No, heâ€™ll be leaving Regulus Black here. Unburied.

Many believe that to be killed by the Inferi is to become one, but that is not the case. You have to be enchanted. Tom cocks his head to the side before pushing the body away from the shore with his foot. An eternity as the undead is too good for Regulus Black.

He can rot.

On the rocks outside the cave Tom pauses, closing his eyes and letting the wind blow through him. Exhaling. Heâ€™ll tell everyone that Regulus was a traitor. Heâ€™ll make it known that he killed him and that thereâ€™s no body left. That ought to scare anyone else thinking about doing the same. Maybe heâ€™ll throw in something about how loudly Black screamed.

Opening his eyes he looks out at the water stretching endlessly before him. Itâ€™s all coming together, heâ€™s out maneuvering all of Dumbledoreâ€™s roadblocks, and soon itâ€™ll be over. He just has to finish his acquisition of the Ministry. Just has to deal with the contents of the prophecy. Just has to push a little harder, inch himself over the finish line. And then heâ€™ll have it all.

Â 

Little boys never do know their limits.

PART II SIRIUS

Â

â€œWhatâ€™re youâ€”â€œ his voice has dropped, and when Sirius looks down at himself he sees that heâ€™s now in his pyjamas. Well, t-shirt and boxers, but he doesnâ€™t feel the cold anymore. Doesnâ€™t even feel the dampness of the snow.

â€œSurely you know. Youâ€™re there.â€

â€œReally? Thatâ€™s it? Thatâ€™s the reason? Now who has no imagination?â€

â€œAnd you sayâ€”you say youâ€™re not afraid of anything when youâ€™re with me.â€

He lets that sentence drift for a minute, unanchored, just floating in the air. Itâ€™s a while before he feels confident enough to speak again. â€œThis is one of the last times I remember,â€ Sirius says finally, waving his hand vaguely around, â€œthat you really felt like mine.â€

Sirius can see Regulus swallow. â€œYours,â€ his voice strained.

It isnâ€™t enough.

â€œLily?â€ he sounds desperate even to his own ears.

â€œPlease,â€ he manages finally. â€œI donâ€™t want you to go.â€

â€œI donâ€™t think you should be alone right now,â€ she pushes on, no longer looking at him. â€œI donâ€™t want you to be alone. I justâ€”it canâ€™t be me James. Not this time.â€

Sheâ€™s walking away.

And he doesnâ€™t know what to do.

Doesnâ€™t know how to stop it.

â€œWhen will you be back?â€ he finds himself asking as she reaches the doorway. Her hand is gripping the strap of her bag so tightly he swears sheâ€™s going to snap it. They sit in silence for so long that James starts to feel a new anxiety bubbling under his skin.

No.

No.

Heâ€™s lost them both.

After all of that.

Heâ€™s lost them both.Â

Â 

He goes back to bed. Pulls the blankets around himself and buries himself deep. Youâ€™d think sleeping would be hard, considering he canâ€™t possibly be tired, but it isnâ€™t. The room is dark and stale. He smells like sweat, his mouth dry. He canâ€™t remember the last time he ate or showered. Two days? Or has it been three? Eventually his eyes find the clock on the wall. 5:00 AM it tells him. Did Lily leave last night? The night before?

He pulls himself out of bed, dots prickling across his vision as he gets momentarily light headed, walking on unsteady legs down the hall to the bathroom and turning on the shower. He makes the water burn the way he always did after a bad Quidditch match. The pain of the scalding water on his skin feels good. He stands in it until the water starts to go cold, then pulls himself out, drying quickly and not bothering to look in the mirror. He doesnâ€™t want to see himself.

He dresses in a Quidditch jumper and baggy tracky bottoms, before heading downstairs. The light in the kitchen is still on. Lilyâ€™s water glass still sitting on the table. He stares at it for a while before picking it up and throwing itâ€”perhaps a bit aggressivelyâ€”into the sink.Â 

He needs to eat something, heâ€™s already feeling like heâ€™s going to pass out but impossibly he still isnâ€™t hungry. He makes some toast anyway. Butters it and forces it down his throat. Itâ€™s the only thing he can manage.Â 

After he finishes he just sits at the table for a while. Staring into space. He still feels like heâ€™s asleep in someways. His brain, his bodyâ€”tired and sluggish. Everything a little bit dull. He ends up returning to the bedroom, still with the curtains drawn and the lights out. Still dark even though it must be nearly mid-morning by now. Thatâ€™s adorable.

Â 

James feels uneasy standing outside Grimmauld Place. The scratching of grief in his chest growing more insistent, his brain dragging up images of the last time he was here. How fucking inadequate.

â€œWith him?â€ Frank repeats, looking briefly at Sirius and then back to James. â€œWhen? When he died?â€

No.

No.

He did that alone.

I left him alone.

James manages to shake his head. â€œI was with himâ€”Iâ€”we were together.â€

Thereâ€™s a beat of silence.

â€œTogether?â€

James canâ€™t read Frankâ€™s tone. Canâ€™t look at his face.

â€œYeah.â€

Thereâ€™s another pause.

â€œWhen?â€ Frank asks again, but thereâ€™s a different sound to his voice now. A different weight to the question. And James finally forces himself to look up, to hold the other boyâ€™s gaze.

â€œAt school,â€ Sirius answers for him, clearly thinking heâ€™s helping. Saving James again. But Frank doesnâ€™t look away and neither does James. â€œRight? James?â€

He doesnâ€™t want to answer.

Doesnâ€™t have it in him for another fight.

â€œThe day of the attack,â€ he finally manages, voice quiet.

To his credit, Frank doesnâ€™t flinch.

â€œWhat?â€ Sirius demands. â€œWhat the fuck are you talking about?â€

James swallows, his throat tight, turning to Sirius who is far less calm.

â€œIâ€™m sorry.â€

â€œYouâ€™re sorry?â€ And then, as though the information is only just sinking in. What James really means. What heâ€™s saying. Anger flashes clearly in Siriusâ€™s eyes. â€œWait, let me get this straightâ€”you were with him? With him with him? The day of the attack at the Ministry? â€

â€œYes.â€

Siriusâ€™s expression is thunderous. A storm on the horizon. James feels the weight of it in his chest.

â€œWhat about Lily?â€

James just stares helplessly back at him. Naked. Without excuses.

â€œItâ€™s been fucking weeks.â€

â€œI know.â€

â€œYou didnâ€™t say anything.â€

â€œI know.â€

Sirius shakes his head, a cold laugh falling from his mouth. â€œJesus fucking Christ, you know, you and Moony have really got this lying thing down patâ€”â€

â€œSiriusâ€”â€œ

â€œI never figured myself for naive. Thought my mum fucked me up a bit too much for that, but you lot? You lot are really proving me wrong.â€

â€œSiriusâ€”â€œ

But Sirius is on his feet, slamming his chair back so hard it falls over, storming out of the room. James braces himself for the sound of the door slamming again. For a moment neither James nor Frank seem able to move. To speak. Until finally Frank sighs.

â€œWellâ€¦I didnâ€™t see that coming.â€

James smiles shakily down at the table. â€œSurprise.â€

Frank huffs out a laugh. â€œSo, at school?â€

James does his best to work around the lump in his throat. â€œYeah.â€

â€œFor how long?â€

â€œBit more than a year.â€

Frank makes a noise of affirmation that James canâ€™t quite decipher. â€œThatâ€™s a long time in school,â€ he says eventually.

It had felt like it. Like all the rest of his seven years could fit into hours, but the time heâ€™d been with Regulus took up years. Decades. Lifetimes.

â€œYeah,â€ is all he says, the word barely a whisper.

Frank reaches out, hand wrapping around Jamesâ€™s wrist and squeezing. â€œI still donâ€™t think youâ€™re the villain James.â€

Something that was supposed to be a scoff but ends up being more choked comes out of Jamesâ€™s mouth. â€œYouâ€™re the only one.â€

â€œTheyâ€™re hurt. Itâ€™s not the same thing,â€ James doesnâ€™t bother replying. Something Frank lets him get away with for about thirty more seconds before he starts talking again. â€œI told you, I saw him that day. If it was heartbreaking for me I canâ€™t imagine what it was like for you.â€

Jamesâ€™s chest gives an unpleasant twist, and he exhales, slow, measured. Like heâ€™s just been hit by a Bludger and heâ€™s trying to stay on his broom.

â€œI could count his ribs,â€ he says, voice small. â€œBeing there was killing him. I mean reallyâ€”really killing him. Iâ€™ve never seen someoneâ€¦waste away like that.â€ His voice trembles and Frank tightens his grip. â€œI just wanted to get him out. I just wanted to keep him safe.â€

â€œJames,â€ there he goes, saying his name like that again. â€œHis death wasnâ€™t your fault, you know that right?â€ But James shakes his head.

â€œI asked him to leave. I asked him to leave and they killed him.â€

â€œListen to what you just said,â€ Frank pushes on fiercely. â€œHe was dead if he stayed anyway. At least leaving gave him a chance.â€

This doesnâ€™t feel like a chance.

This doesnâ€™t feel like anything.

James pulls away, wiping at his face even though there arenâ€™t any tears. â€œI should go check on Sirius,â€ he says eventually, forcing his voice to behave normally. â€œMake sure he isnâ€™t setting the house on fire or something.â€

Frank hesitates for a moment before nodding his head. â€œIâ€™ll clean up down here. Shout if you need backup, yeah?â€

James shoots him a shaky smile. â€œYeah. Okay.â€Â 

Â 

Â 

He isnâ€™t exactly sure what heâ€™s expecting to find. Certainly some sort of destruction. Some evidence of violence. What he isnâ€™t expecting, is for Sirius to be lying calmly on his back in his old bed, staring at the ceiling. Itâ€™s so unexpected James actually questions whether or not heâ€™s in the right room. None of the lights are on, the only brightness coming from the sliver allowed in by the door.

â€œIâ€™m so tired of secrets,â€ Sirius says finally, breaking the silence. â€œI thought we were done with that. I thought at least you and I were done with that.â€

James stands in the doorway for a second longer before walking forward and lying down on the bed next to him. The way they used to when they were kids. Theyâ€™re a bit bigger now mind you, but James still manages to fit, and Sirius doesnâ€™t instantly try to push him off so he takes that as a good sign.

â€œIâ€™m sorry,â€ James says finally.

Thereâ€™s a long moment before Sirius talks again. â€œSometimes I feel like I donâ€™t even recognize us anymore,â€ his voice is small, curling up and lying in the space between them.

James squeezes his eyes shut. â€œIâ€™m sorry.â€

He can feel Sirius shake his head but he doesnâ€™t say anything. At least not at first. â€œYou want to hear something really stupid?â€ he asks eventually.Â

He can only see Siriusâ€™s profile, highlighted by the light spilling in from the corridor. â€œI really thought we were going to be happy,â€ a joyless smile tugs at his lips.

James thinks he can hear the cracks forming in his chest.

â€œYeah,â€ he says softly. â€œYeah me too.â€

There isnâ€™t much to say after that.

Â 

Â 

James isnâ€™t sure how long they lie there before Frank comes up, stopping abruptly inside the door.

â€œAre you napping or are you dead?â€ he asks.

â€œNeither,â€ Sirius answers.

Frank wobbles his head from side to side. â€œFair enough. I take it Iâ€™m not going to need to separate you two then? Weâ€™ve worked through our issues?â€

James snorts, because the idea that anything that is happening right now can be worked through seems funny to him.

â€œI think weâ€™ll manage not to scratch each otherâ€™s eyes out, donâ€™t you Prongs?â€

â€œI should hope so, your eyes are your best feature.â€

Theyâ€™re attempting normalcy. Brevity. They donâ€™t quite manage it. Both of their voices too scratchy and too tired to make any of it believable.

â€œUh-huh,â€ Frank says from the doorway. â€œWell, Iâ€™ll leave you to it shall I?â€

â€œExcuse me?â€ Sirius calls out. â€œWhere do you think youâ€™re going?â€

Frank turns back to them and even in the dark James can see the confusion on his face. â€œErâ€”to find the guest room.â€ Technically theyâ€™re currently in the guest room but James doesnâ€™t bother pointing that out.

â€œGet in the bed Frank,â€ he says instead.

Frank laughs. â€œYeah, no, I donâ€™t think so.â€

Sirius looks at James. â€œHe thinks weâ€™re joking.â€

â€œHe must not know what jokes are then.â€

Frankâ€™s eyes move from one boy to the other, something between bemusement and shock on his face. â€œDonâ€™t be ridiculous. Thereâ€™s not even any room!â€

Rolling his eyes, Sirius sits up, sliding his wand out of his sleeve and casting an extensionÂ  charm on the bed that causes it to accordion out into the room. The pair of them then look at Frank expectantly but the older boy only shakes his head.

â€œIâ€™m notâ€”â€œ

â€œFrank,â€ Sirius cuts him off, sounding very serious, "weâ€™re sad.â€

Frank looks back at them, trying to hold out, but clearly defeated. Eventually he sighs. â€œThis really is ridiculous you know,â€ he mutters, noxing the light in the corridor and reluctantly climbing into bed with them.

When they were kids and they would lie like this, curtains drawn, talking, it was inevitable that Remus would eventually find his way next to Sirius, that Peter would come, sleepy-eyed and wrapped in a blanket, the four of them falling asleep on top of one another. A many limbed, many headed, monster.

This isnâ€™t like that exactly. The cruelty of the past, is nothing is ever as it was. But it helps. As James closes his eyes listening to the soft breathing of his two friends, pressing against him on either side, limbs sleep warm and reassuring, James feels his grief loosen. Still ever present. Just a bit less choking.

Â 

Â 

At some point in the night James wakes up. He lies there for a minute, blinking the sleep away, unclear if thereâ€™s a reason for his sudden consciousness or if itâ€™s just because Sirius has started snoring. He smiles a little at that. Heâ€™s missed the sound. Which is not something he ever thought he would say.

He stays still for a little longer before he feels something start to tugâ€”on his thoughts, his stomach, the heart in his chest. He slips quietly out of bed, a bit difficult since during the course of the night Sirius has seen fit to throw his arm over James, burying his face in his shoulder. By some miracle, however, James manages to escape. Avoiding the creaky floorboards heâ€™s had memorized since he was a kid, following the tug down the stairs and into the front hall. Following it all the way to his jacket pocket.

He lights one of the lamps in the sitting room with his wand, dropping onto the sofa, the letter held delicately in his hands. For a long time all he can do is stare at it, thumb tracing along the elegant J on the front. He knows this was written days ago. Weeks even. But itâ€™ll still be the last thing that Regulus ever says to him. And heâ€™s not sure heâ€™s ready to face that.

Eventually, fingers shaking, he slides his hand under the wax seal and pulls the pieces of parchment out of the envelope. They glow in the low light.

Â 

Dear J,

Â 

It startsâ€¦

Â 

Iâ€™ve been thinking about dinner. About which one of us would do the chopping and which one would do the stirring. Which one would set everything on fire. Iâ€™ve been thinking about laundry too. Who would put it off the longest (you) who would have a whole system in place for it (me) who would do the folding (you like mind numbing tasks donâ€™t you?). See what youâ€™ve done to me? Iâ€™ve been reduced to fantasizing about household chores.

You described to me once, the life you wanted us to have, that you pictured for us. I didnâ€™t believe in it then. But I believe in it now. I think about it all the time James. You were right when you said I gave up last time, but I promise I wonâ€™t do it again. Not now. Weâ€™ve wasted so much time. Iâ€™ve wasted so much time.

I know it must seem like Iâ€™m still wasting time, but once Iâ€™ve done what I need to, once Iâ€™ve done it youâ€™ll understand. I know it wonâ€™t make up for all the bad, but itâ€™s a start right? I wanna try this time, I really want to try. Sirius did it after all. It canâ€™t be impossible.Â 

I love you James. Pathetically and desperately and always. Even when we didnâ€™t speak. Even when I hated you I still loved you. Wherever you want me. However youâ€™ll have me. I just want to be near you thatâ€™s all. Iâ€™m so tired of you being so far away.

Sorry, itâ€™s getting late and Iâ€™m feeling overly sentimental. Mostly I just want you to know that Iâ€™ll see you soon. That Iâ€™ll make things right. I promise.

Â 

Yours, always.

R.Â

PART IV CERCI

Â 

It was Barty Crouch of all people, who told Cerci about Regulus.

He sent her an owl. Brief. To the point.

Â 

Greengrass,

Â 

Figured you should know.

Regulus is dead.

He tried to get out.

Thereâ€™s no body.

Â 

Cheers,

B. C

Â 

And of course she hadnâ€™t believed him. Not for a second. Apparating to Grimmauld Place immediately only to be met by a wall of impenetrable wards. It wasnâ€™t like it had been last timeâ€”after the attack on the Ministryâ€”these wards didnâ€™t feel like Regulus at all. Didnâ€™t feel like his magic.

Because.

Of course.

They werenâ€™t.

Even now, thinking about that moment, that realization, feels like breaking her ribs. Cerciâ€™s life is a much lonelier place without Regulus Black. Once sheâ€™d calmed down, sheâ€™d written Barty back. â€œTried to get out, no bodyâ€ was not nearly enough information for her. But he never responded.

She had fully intended to track him down and demand answers. Answers no one, so far, had been able, or willing, to give her. Not Regulusâ€™s father, who wept when she told him how much Regulus had wanted to visit, how much he had loved him. Or his mother, who recoiled at the mention of her sonâ€™s name. Embarrassed by his death. By his life. She was certain they had to know more than they were saying, but she was also certain, that she was far more likely to crack Barty Crouch than Walburga Black.

Sheâ€™d been coming up with a whole plan. Perhaps one involving a little kidnapping and intimidation. But then. Then James Potter had appeared. The last person she ever expected to find outside the Black family crypt. The last person she had ever expected of being Regulusâ€™sâ€¦wellâ€¦anything. And the shock of it, had jogged loose another memory of James Potter.

Or at least a story.

Of him beating the living daylights out of Lucius Malfoy in the Atrium of the Ministry of Magic.

And suddenly, there was someone else she wanted answers from.

Which is how Cerci Greengrass finds herself outside the gates of Malfoy Manor for the first time since she was nine years old and her parents dragged her along to some sort of Christmas ball. Cerci has a vague memory of eating some bad chicken and vomiting on the Floo ride home. Plus, sheâ€™d been forced to wear a terribly uncomfortable dressâ€”too many bowsâ€”even just thinking about it makes her nose wrinkle. All in all, not an enjoyable experience.

Still. Here she is.

â€œAnd you are?â€ a magical voice demands out of nowhere.

â€œCerci Greengrass.â€

Thereâ€™s a momentâ€™s pause and then. â€œThereâ€™s nothing in Mr. Malfoyâ€™s itinerary about a social call from a Cerci Greengrass.â€

No. There wouldnâ€™t be.

â€œTell him Iâ€™m here to talk about Regulus Black.â€

She had been there, for the week or so after the Ministry attack, when Lucius had relentlessly pushed against Regulusâ€™s wards. Every day. Without fail. Sometimes multiple times a day. She hadnâ€™t quite understood it then. Still doesnâ€™t quite understand it now. But she reckons that that kind of obsession doesnâ€™t just disappear. In fact, she suspects Lucius Malfoy is dying to talk about Regulus.

Thereâ€™s a longer pause this time before the voice returns. â€œAccess has been granted. Please follow the walkway to the main house. You will find Mr. Malfoy in the first floor sitting room, third door on the left.â€

The grand gates in front of her creak open, revealing an unnecessarily long driveway carved between two lawns which remain green even now at the end of December.

When she makes it to the main house her steps echo through the entryway. She isnâ€™t sure what she was expectingâ€”in her memories the mansion is filled with people and music and light. Of course, that had been a ball, but it all feels rather different when itâ€™s empty. The grey winter sun filtering in through the windows, the grand corridors and high ceilings making everything feel cold and hollow. Cerci shivers at the thought of having to live in a place like this.

â€œThird door on the left,â€ she murmurs to herself as she starts walking.

She isn't sure if sheâ€™s meant to knock. After a few seconds of standing outside the room she decides â€œpolite knockingâ€ is not quite the energy sheâ€™s going for and decides to just push on through.

Lucius Malfoy is sitting in a high-backed chair upholstered in green velvet, looking every inch the villain sheâ€™s sure he thinks he is. Heâ€™s reading something, long black pipe in his free hand. He doesnâ€™t look up when she comes in.

â€œClose the door,â€ he says, sounding bored.

Cerciâ€™s wand twitches as she lets the door slam behind her. It has the desired effect, Luciusâ€™s eyes snapping up at the noise, Cerci not bothering to hide her smug smile as she slips her wand back up her sleeve. No reason to put him on high alert just yet.

â€œMiss Greengrass,â€ he says, snapping his book closed and leaning back in his seat. â€œTo what do I owe the pleasure?â€

â€œI want to talk about Regulus.â€

She doesnâ€™t miss the flash in his eyes. â€œYes. So you mentioned. Though Iâ€™m not sure why you would wish to do so with me?â€

She arches her brow. â€œArenâ€™t you?â€

Cerci doesnâ€™t buy any of it. Not the forced casual tone, not the book, not the pipe, not the confused look on Luciusâ€™s face which is quickly disappearing. It all feels like an act to her. A piece of theatre.

She takes the chair across from him without being asked, eyes meeting his. She doesnâ€™t speakâ€”contrary to popular belief it is actually possible for her to be quiet. And silence is particularly good at getting people to start saying things they shouldnâ€™t, just to fill the void, all of us so desperately uncomfortable with the emptiness.

Regulus taught her that.

A few minutes pass before Luciusâ€™s eyes narrow. â€œWhat did he tell you then?â€

â€œWas there something to tell?â€ Cerci asks mildly, smiling politely at him. â€œI thought you had no idea why I would want to talk to you?â€

Now Luciusâ€™s face forms a full blown scowl. He isnâ€™t old, but when he makes this expression, you can see how he will be one day.

â€œIâ€™m not interested in playing games little girl.â€

But Cerciâ€™s smile does not diminish. â€œSure you are, or you wouldnâ€™t have opened the gate.â€

Lucius appears to have no response to this so he simply scowls harder.

â€œWhy were you trying to break through Regulusâ€™s wards?â€ her voice is calm, levelâ€”even pleasant. But if you were observant enough, something Lucius certainly is not, you would be able to see the knives in the corners of her mouth. In the centre of her irisâ€™s. The violence in the set of her shoulders.

Lucius lets out a breath of laughter. â€œIâ€™m not sure what youâ€™re expecting but itâ€™s nothing spectacular; I wanted to see him, thatâ€™s all. â€

â€œClearly he didnâ€™t want to see you.â€

â€œYes well,â€ Luciusâ€™s posh accent somehow manages to grow even more condescending as he flicks a bit of lint off his trousers. â€œRegulus was not a very good judge of what was good for him.â€

Cerci agrees. Though she doubts very much that Lucius and her are thinking of the same things.

â€œAnd you were good for him?â€ she asks, same calm tone.

â€œOf course,â€ as though suggesting anything else would be absurd. â€œIâ€™ve been his closest ally since his brother left him.â€

No, Cerci thinks, that isnâ€™t true. Regulus always kept his allies close, even in school. Even if he didnâ€™t particularly like them as people. Which means that whatever Regulus saw Lucius as, it wasnâ€™t that.

â€œYou two didnâ€™t seem particularly close,â€ she says finally.

A twisted smirk curls the corner of Luciusâ€™s mouth. â€œOh, I assure you. We were very close.â€

Something about the way he says it makes her skin itch. She isnâ€™t exactly sure what heâ€™s implying but she knows she doesnâ€™t like it.

â€œIâ€™ve got another question for you.â€

Lucius snorts. â€œGo on then.â€

She gives him a long look. â€œWhy did James Potter attack you?â€

Thereâ€™s the smallest flicker, a twitch of his lip, and when his words come out next heâ€™s practically snarling. â€œBecause heâ€™s unhinged I imagine. Iâ€™ve never experienced anything so uncivilized in my life.â€

Cerci lets that sit between them for a moment. â€œSo he just went off, unprovoked?â€

â€œAsk anyone who was there,â€ Lucius gestures with his pipe. â€œI did nothing to him.â€

â€œDid you do something to someone else.â€

She can feel it. The tensing in his posture. The way he draws himself up a little higher, holds his nose in the air a bit more. Wrapping his superiority around him like a shield.

â€œYouâ€™re going to have to be more specific, I have done a great many things to a great many people.â€

Cerci is still smiling, though it is beginning to feel a bit strained. â€œIâ€™m sure you have,â€ she inches her wand slowly towards her palm. â€œBut what did you do to Regulus Black?â€

Thereâ€™s a pause, Cerci can hear the clock on the fireplace mantle ticking, hear the sound of her own pulse pounding in her ears. Then, the older man sneers.

â€œNothing he didnâ€™t want.â€

Cerci never figured out how to put all the pieces of Regulus together, never quite managed to see the full picture all at once. Itâ€™s one of the many things that breaks her heartâ€”knowing now she never will. That so much of the boy who was her best friend, her family, will remain a mystery to her. But she does have a very clear memory of Regulus standing in the Slytherin common room, struggling to breathe, to put one foot in front of the other, a boy who couldnâ€™t be touched.

It would come and go, Regulusâ€™s aversion to other peopleâ€™s hands. It was in the moments when he was at his worst, the moments you wanted to touch him the most, that you had to keep away. She had worked that much out at least.

Looking at Lucius Malfoy now. She thinks she can perhaps work out a bit more.

Cerci doesnâ€™t know what her face is doing but it makes Lucius roll his eyes. â€œOh donâ€™t give me that look,â€ he says dismissively. â€œWhatever Regulus said, it was just him trying to get your attention. Your sympathy. He was always like that, a bit of a worm if you will. Iâ€™m not surprised it got him killed,â€ he laughs cruelly. â€œWhat a meaningless little life he ended up living.â€

Cerci is fairly certain Lucius doesnâ€™t see the wand slide fully into her hand. He certainly seems surprised, when a second later heâ€™s being thrown from his chair and into the wall behind him, body hitting with a satisfying â€œthudâ€.

â€œBitch,â€ he wheezes, the force of the spell knocking the air from his lungs. He reaches for his wand but Cerci is too quick.

â€œExpelliarmus,â€ the small piece of wood flicks across the room as she steps towards him.

â€œWhat the fuck do you think youâ€™re doing? DOBBY! Narcissa!â€

â€œI cast a silencing charm on the room the minute I stepped through the door,â€ Cerci says calmly, pressing the tip of her wand to the older manâ€™s neck. â€œYou must have missed it, while you were pretending to read your book.â€

Lucius bares his teeth, but he isnâ€™t able to wipe the fear from his eyes. â€œThis is a very bad idea little girl.â€

â€œI disagree.â€

â€œWhatâ€™re you going to do? Truly? Kill me?â€ he sounds like heâ€™s verging on hysterical. â€œYou expect me to believe youâ€™re capable of that?â€

She looks at him thoughtful. â€œNo,â€ she says after a brief pause. â€œI donâ€™t expect you to believe Iâ€™m capable of anything.â€ No one ever does. â€œCrucio.â€Â 

Lucius screams. She doesnâ€™t let it go on for too long. Just long enough. His skin shiny with sweat as he collapses back against the wall, shivering.

â€œCunt.â€

Cerci ignores him, lifting her wand again and watching Lucius desperately try to scramble backwards even though he has nowhere to go.

â€œWhat the fuck do you want from me?â€ his voice is almost painfully high.

I want you to take it back,

she thinks hopelessly.

I want you take it all back.

All the pain you caused him.

I want you to take his place.

â€œWhat happened to him, really? How did he die?â€ she asks.

Lucius shakes his head, the hair thatâ€™s slipped out of his plait whipping around his face. â€œI donâ€™t know, honest to Merlin.â€

Lie.

Cerci steps forward.

â€œLook, he went missing for a few daysâ€”â€œ

â€œYes I was there for that bit.â€

â€œNo one knew where he was, no one, not even the Dark Lord.â€

â€œAnd then?â€ she prompts.

Lucius swallowsâ€”itâ€™s a showy swallow, his Adamâ€™s apple on full display, bobbing up and down in his abnormally long, skinny neck. â€œAnd then one day the Dark Lord went somewhere on his own. And when he returned he said that Regulus was dead, that heâ€™d been trying to defect and that there was no body.â€

Cerci considers this for a moment. â€œNo one else ever saw him, Regulus? Just Voldemort?â€

Lucius cringes at the use of the name. â€œYes,â€ he answers.

It was the Horcrux.

It had to be.

Regulus found out where it was and went after it.

But why didnâ€™t he bring me? asks the small voice in the back of her mind.Â 

She notices Lucius attempting to inch towards his wand. She doesnâ€™t hesitate. â€œAfflicto,â€ wand pointed at his arm. Thereâ€™s an instant crack as the bone snaps and the older man begins to howl, clutching the broken limb to his chest. She watches him writhe around for a few more seconds before stepping forward again, wand back at his neck, knocking his chin so that heâ€™s forced to look at her.

â€œI want you to listen to me,â€ she says, gaze steady on his darting eyes. â€œI want you to hear this. To know it in your bones,â€ he whimpers, holding his arm closer. â€œYou could live for a hundred years. A thousand. But you will never matter the way that he mattered.â€

Finding no escape his eyes reluctantly meet herâ€™s. She makes sure her stare is relentless.

And then she pulls away.

Walking around the overturned chair, through the door, down the hall.

She makes it all the way to the front gate before the tears start.

Â 

Â 

Cerci writes Albus Dumbledore a letter.

She considers going to see him in person but she canâ€™t bring herself to. Too afraid maybe. Too tired more likely. Of all these men and their war.

So Cerci Greengrass writes Albus Dumbledore a letter.

She explains it all. The Horcrux, Tom Riddle, Salazar Slytherin, how she thinks Regulusâ€™s death is connected. She includes their notes. Their research. And at the end, right at the end of all that, she asks that if it turns out to be true, he tells people. Tells people it was Regulus who saw it first. Who tried first.

And then she sends it away.

She doesnâ€™t expect him to listen.

But for Regulusâ€™s sake she has to try.

Actually, she has a small list of things she has to try for Regulus.

Â 

Â 

â€œCerci!â€

She looks up as Moira walks through the Leaky Cauldron towards her. Cerciâ€™s sat at a table by herself currently taking out her anxiety on the napkins.

â€œHey,â€ Cerci smiles, wiping the dozens of shredded pieces of paper quickly onto the floor. Sheâ€™ll vanish them later.

â€œItâ€™s so good to see you,â€ Moira has about the loveliest smile Cerci has ever seen. Itâ€™s just soâ€¦warm. It makes her feel safe. â€œYou didnâ€™t bring your entourage today.â€

Chapter End Notes

Chapter 55

People make mistakes, but they also make choices.

Theyâ€™re looking at one another unabashedly now. No oneâ€™s eyes darting away, no oneâ€™s head turning to the side. Regulus rolls forward, closing the gap between them.

â€œYeah,â€ James says after a moment, reaching out to tuck a dark curl behind Regulusâ€™s ear. â€œYeah I know.â€

Â 

Â 

The next morning, after a brief whirlwind of scrambling and chaos, James pauses at the door on his way out, turning back to Regulus, crease lines from the sheets still clear on his face. Stupid.

â€œYou okay?â€ James asks, like he really wants to know. The question pulling Regulus out of his thoughts.Â 

â€œYeah James,â€ he says slowly, afraid of how much he means it. â€œYeah, Iâ€™m okay. I might even be happy, if you can believe it.â€

Jamesâ€™s smile is so bright it almost hurts to look at. But Regulus does. Tries to burn it into his memory, tries to make sure he will never forget.

â€œMerry Christmas Regulus.â€

â€œMerry Christmas James.â€

I love you, Regulus thinks helplessly, watching the door close.

I love you.

I love you.

I love you.

Â 

Justâ€”the best part.

PART II REMUS

Â 

The flat is empty when he gets home.

What if somethingâ€™s happened?

How would you even know?

Eventually he forces himself to move, body heavy as he starts to unpackâ€”which mainly consists of him dumping the contents of his tiny duffle bag into the dirty clothes hamper in the corner of their room.

Â 

Â

â€œWhatâ€™re you doing?â€

Remusâ€™s head snaps up, causing his broom to bob and him to drop down, pressing his chest to the handle and clinging on for dear life.

â€œYou hate flying,â€ Sirius says finally. Which seems a bit redundant to Remus, but given the current state of their relationship he manages to refrain from pointing that out.

â€œI wanted to talk to you,â€ he repeats instead.

Sirius watches him for another minute, that same confused look on his face, like heâ€™s trying to work something out, before eventually he flies forward.

â€œHere,â€ he says, reaching over and placing his hand on Remusâ€™s shoulder. â€œYouâ€™re making this harder than it has to be.â€

â€œWoah, woah,â€ Remus says as Sirius starts to try and push him upright again. â€œWhatâ€™re you doing?â€

â€œYouâ€™re not sitting right.â€

â€œIâ€™m sitting just fine.â€

Sirius huffs. â€œJust let meâ€”Iâ€™m trying to help. Could you just trust me, please?â€

Finally, Remus exhales. â€œOkay,â€ he says, relaxing enough that Sirius is able to gently push him upright again. Keeping one hand on his shoulder and placing the other on Remusâ€™s lower back, shifting him toward the tail end of his broom.

â€œThere you go,â€ Sirius says softly. Remus looks over at him, still terrified, though momentarily distracted by how close Sirius is. By the way his sweaty hair curls at his temples and ears.

â€œAnd then just,â€ Sirius lets go of his torso and Remus is surprised to find that he actually does feel more stable, â€œput your hands like this,â€ his tongue sticks out between his lips as he carefully adjusts Remusâ€™s hands, the contact making Remus shiver. â€œThere,â€ he pulls back slowly, â€œbetter?â€

Remus swallows, throat tight. He knows that itâ€™s the flying and the cold that have put the pink in Siriusâ€™s cheeks, but he canâ€™t help staring at it anyway. â€œYeah,â€ he manages finally, voice rough, â€œbetter.â€

Sirius nods and for a long moment they just float there, wind pushing against them, rocking them like ships. Remus does his best not to start hugging his broom handle again.

â€œSo,â€ Sirius finally clears his throat, looking off into the distance, â€œyou wanted to talk?â€

He had. He really had. Except now that heâ€™s here he has no idea what to say.

â€œI donâ€™t want to fight,â€ is what he decides on finally. Childish? Yes, perhaps. But succinct. Honest. Brutally, painfully honest.

He watches Sirius chew on the inside of his cheek, still staring into the distance. â€œIâ€™m not fighting,â€ he manages finally. â€œThatâ€™s what Iâ€™ve beenâ€”thatâ€™s what Iâ€™m trying not to do.â€

And of course, as soon as he says it, Remus can see all the ways itâ€™s true. Sirius has been walking away from him all day. Walking away when normally he would shout and yell and fume.

â€œItâ€™s still kinda fighting though,â€ Remus says eventually. â€œDifferent maybe butâ€¦youâ€™re punishing me. Arenâ€™t you?â€

Sirius sighs, scrubbing at his face. â€œI donâ€™t know what you want me to do Remus?â€ he says finally. â€œI donâ€™t know how to not be angry about this.â€

Which is fair.

More than, really.

Remus follows Siriusâ€™s gaze. The sky is almost cartoonish todayâ€”light blue, with big, fat, white clouds.

â€œRegulus loved flying,â€ Sirius says suddenly, making Remus start.

He opens and then closes his mouth. Itâ€™s not the kind of statement that really requires a response, so instead he watches Sirius, waits for him to say more.

â€œHe was going to go pro,â€ Sirius goes on eventually. â€œYou know there were already scouts looking at him? Back when he was at Hogwarts?â€

Remus hadnâ€™tâ€”though, in fairness, Remus knows very little when it comes to the workings of Quidditch. Still, it surprises him that Sirius knows this. â€œHe was going to have his pick. He was going to be a fucking star. And despite the unbelievable terror it strikes into his heart, Remus lifts one hand off his broom and reaches out, squeezing Siriusâ€™s arm.

â€œYou know, sometimes,â€ Sirius says weakly. â€œI wonder, if there hadnâ€™t been a war, would he have left that house with me? Would their hold on him have been weaker, if everything wasnâ€™t soâ€¦scary.â€

Remus doesnâ€™t know what to say to that, eventually offering up a pathetic; â€œMaybe.â€

Remus blinks, surprised. â€œHe did? He said he regretted joining Voldemort? When?â€

â€œWhen did he say he regretted it?â€

â€œOh,â€ Sirius looks suddenly embarrassed, which doesnâ€™t make sense to Remus. â€œHe didnâ€™t. Never mind. I donâ€™t know why I said that.â€

Which Remus doesnâ€™t buy, but he decides to leave it alone. At least for now.

â€œIâ€™m sorry,â€ he says instead, finally bringing Siriusâ€™s eyes back to him.

The other boy gives him a sad smile. â€œYeah. Arenâ€™t we all.â€

Itâ€™s like looking at James all over again. Like losing Regulus has severed whatever thin thread of childhood they were both still clinging to. Remusâ€™s hand slides from Siriusâ€™s arm to his face, holding it carefully, finger brushing over his cheek.

â€œI love you, you know,â€ he says, because itâ€™s all he has at this point. He canâ€™t go back and change whatâ€™s happened. Canâ€™t fix anything. All he has is love. Which the stories and the poets like to make a big fuss about.

All you need is love.

As they say.

Itâ€™s bollocks, of course.

A dying man might be loved but it wonâ€™t put the air back in his lungs.

And thatâ€™s what they are these days, isnâ€™t it?

Dying men.

Siriusâ€™s eyes open, the light catching them, making them glow, making Remusâ€™s breath hitch, snagging on his ribs. After a moment Sirius turns his head and kisses Remusâ€™s palm.

â€œI love you too.â€

PART III JAMES

Â 

James is outside Maryâ€™s house.

Itâ€™s probably a mistake.

Because this is probably a mistake.

But what else is there?

He paces back and forth, hands running through his hair as his fingers start to go numb from the cold. His thoughts are all jumbled up, nerves making them tangle themselves in knots. â€œWe can handle it,â€ James says. â€œWe can get past this, I know we can.â€

I want to help. Let me.

â€œYeah,â€ even though it kills him to say it. â€œLetsâ€¦find a Mind Healer.â€

Â

Sheâ€™s nice.

James doesnâ€™t think heâ€™s lying. Exactly. But heâ€™s maybeâ€¦not being completely open. Trying to find the answers to her questions that he thinks she wants. That heâ€™s supposed to have. Heâ€™s pretty good at reading people, at figuring out whatâ€™s expected of him, he always has been. â€œI donâ€™t understand why youâ€™re so pissed at me,â€ James snaps. Theyâ€™ve come home from their third session and Lily is stomping around the house, slamming cupboard doors.

Â

Well, I've been afraid of changin'

Â

And I'm getting older too

PART IV LILY

Â 

Lily never thought much about being pregnant.

She thought a little about getting pregnant.

About giving birth.

About being a mum.

But the actual being pregnant bit she never spared much thought for. It isnâ€™t quite as exciting a daydream she supposes. Itâ€™s only now that itâ€™s happening that she realizes what a mistake that was. That apparently there are lots of rules about being pregnant that everyone seems to know except her.

Itâ€™s because all those people have motherâ€™s, whispers the cruel voice in the back of her head.Â 

There are lists of things she canâ€™t eat or drink or do, and at least three potions sheâ€™s never heard of that sheâ€™s now drinking everyday. One of them is an anti-nausea potion and thank Merlin for that, because the term â€œmorning sicknessâ€ is entirely inaccurate and, as far as Lily is concerned, far too cutesy for a condition that involves being hit with the overwhelming need to vomit at random moments throughout the day.

She feels completely ill-equipped to deal with being pregnantâ€”this thing that is supposedly natural. Maybe that bodes poorly for her as a mother. Like if she had a proper maternal instinct she would know how to do all this already. Honestly, Lily has no idea. She never asked her mum what it was like being pregnant. She thought she would have more time.

At least she has Alice.

â€œThis is it?â€ Lily asks warily as they stop outside a shop in Diagon Alley with painted pink bricks and white shutters. An enchanted baby doll is sitting on the sign laughing and giggling.

â€œYup,â€ Alice says, frowning slightly. â€œBitâ€¦much, isnâ€™t it?â€

â€œA bit, yeah.â€

â€œDo you want to turn around and go back to mine and eat crisps and gossip?â€

Lily laughs. â€œYes, but I should probably get likeâ€¦a crib at least? I hear those are important.â€

â€œMm,â€ Alice agrees. â€œAlright then, lets give it a go shall we?â€ she smiles at Lily as she links their arms. â€œMaybe the inside wonâ€™t be soâ€¦â€ she gestures at the giggling baby and Lily snorts.

Unfortunately, the inside very much is still soâ€¦

â€œPink,â€ Alice says, a little dumbfounded.

â€œAnd blue,â€ Lily adds. Itâ€™s like thereâ€™s a wall dividing the store in two.

Lily can feel her anxiety mounting as she looks around the store. Whatever this isâ€”she hates it. But what does that mean? Shouldnâ€™t she be excited to buy things for her baby? Isnâ€™t that a whole thing? Why does she suddenly feel like she canâ€™t breathe?

â€œWhere did you get your stuff?â€ she asks Alice as they start cautiously making their way further into the store.

â€œI know it wasnâ€™t anything special,â€ certainly nothing like the Potterâ€™s cottage, â€œbut it wasâ€¦ours, you know? â€œCâ€™mon Lily,â€ Alice takes the lead, pulling Lily towards the door and back out onto the street.

Canâ€™t help wondering what she thinks of her.Â 

â€œThat woman was such a cunt.â€

â€œWhat?â€ Alice asks, grabbing hold of Lilyâ€™s arm as they keep walking down the street. â€œShe was!â€ and then, casual as anything, as though nothingâ€™s happenedâ€”which Lily supposes, in the grand scheme of things, it hasnâ€™tâ€”she goes on; â€œLets go to the Leaky, yeah? Lily laughs.

Itâ€™s been a long time since theyâ€™ve spoken, and Lily finds that sheâ€™s nervous as she walks up to the small restaurant in a suburb just outside of London. Hands fiddling with her sleeves.Â 

Petunia, of course, is early. So Lily gets to enjoy the distinctly uncomfortable sensation of feeling her sisterâ€™s critical gaze on her as she is lead to the table by the hostess.

â€œThanks,â€ she says to the woman as she sits clumsily in her chair, a menu placed in front of her.

She always feels big and loud and awkward around Petunia, who is none of those things. If the word â€œdaintyâ€ was a person it would be Lilyâ€™s sister.

â€œYou made it,â€ Petunia says flatly.

â€œOf course I made it,â€ Lily tries to smile but it doesnâ€™t feel quite right on her face, and Petunia certainly doesnâ€™t return it, if anything she looks suspicious. â€œWell,â€ Lily isnâ€™t sure why she sounds so out of breath or why her cheeks are so hot. â€œThis place is nice. â€œMe and the girls come here for lunch every other Tuesday.â€

The â€œgirlsâ€ is a group of women Petunia has been friends with since primary school. Lily has never much got on with them. To be honest, sheâ€™s not entirely convinced that Petunia gets on with them either but they certainlyâ€¦look the way that Petunia wants to. But then, itâ€™s not as though she knows much about her sister these days.

â€œGreat,â€ Lily manages, maintaining her false cheer. â€œThen you can tell me whatâ€™s good.â€

Petunia gives her a long look before dropping her eyes down to the menu. â€œTheir salads are lovely.â€

Lily does her best not to cringe.

â€œSoâ€¦â€ Lily starts awkwardly, once the waitress has left them.

Petunia arches her brow. â€œSo?â€

â€œHow are you? How are things?â€

Her brow does not lower. â€œReally? This is what you wanted to talk about?â€

Lily shifts uncomfortably in her seat, suddenly worried she didnâ€™t dress well enoughâ€”itâ€™s not that this place is fancy but itâ€™s certainly nice, and sheâ€™s only in a pair of stretchy black trousers and an oversized jumper.

â€œIsnâ€™t that what people ask each other?â€ she says hopefully.

Petuniaâ€™s eyes narrow. â€œPeople, maybe. But not you. You never ask how I am. Iâ€™ve barely heard from you since we finished dealing with mumâ€™s stuff.â€

Lily winces, knowing itâ€™s true. â€œWell, itâ€™s not like youâ€™ve called me either.â€

â€œYou donâ€™t have a phone,â€ Petunia points out flatly.

Right.

â€œWritten me then.â€

Petunia stares at her. â€œAnd how would I send this letter exactly? By raven? Badger? Or is there some other creature youâ€™re using these days?â€

The spell cast.

â€œBullshit,â€ she snaps. â€œRemus is catatonic, he can barely speak let alone legally consent to anything.â€

â€œMs. Macdonald.â€

â€œMs. Macdonaldâ€”Mary.â€

Hand on the doorknob.

â€œ29 Hendford Hill.â€

â€œThatâ€™s your brotherâ€™s address is it not? Damian?â€

She turns to face him, the rage transforming into something else. Something like acid. Something like fear. Dumbledore is standing now, illuminated by the tall windows behind him. He almost glows.

â€œYou will leave Harry Potter where he is,â€ all warmth gone from his voice. The curtain pulled back. The Wizard of Oz revealed. â€œYou will not speak to him, you will not write to him, you will have no contact with him at all.â€

She wonders how they all missed it. How they couldnâ€™t see. She doesnâ€™t know if it would have made a difference. Maybe theyâ€™d all still be gone even without Dumbledoreâ€™s help.

â€œAnd I promise,â€ the old man goes on, â€œto show your brother the same curtesy.â€

To let him live.Â 

For the first time in years, Mary Macdonald feels herself crack.Â

PART VII PETER

Â 

Peter has never given much thought to what kind of person he is.

Those larger questions, the ones that try to tear life open and understand it, never appeal to him. Those are Remusâ€™s specialty.

Peter simply is a person. That is enough for him.

When he feels desire he moves towards it.

When he feels fear he moves away.

He does not think life is meant to be more complicated than that. Weâ€™re animals after all. Things only mean more because we decide they do.

Death, is one of those things.

Peter has lost himself to grief. To the pain of it. The ache. But that was before he realized he had a choice.

Death hurts because humans decide to make it hurt.

They decide you should cry.

Tear your hair out.

Scream.

So you do. But death, like life, has no inherent meaning. It simply is. A fact. A state of being. Thereâ€™s no need for all the theatrics. No need to tear yourself up about it. If you simply ignore everything youâ€™re taught, death can be something quite mundane.

Well.

Other peopleâ€™s deaths, in any case.

Peter first learned this as he stood over Marlene McKinnonâ€™s body.

Initially, there was that swelling of feeling. That ache. That pain. But then heâ€™d made himself stop.

Stop.

Stop it.

It doesnâ€™t mean anything. Doesnâ€™t actually hurt. You just think it does. Youâ€™ve just been taught that it does. But that isnâ€™t actually how you feel.

In the end her death had seemed almost dull. Like there really ought to have been more to it. Heâ€™d stood over her, eyes staring up at him unseeing, and thought; â€œthat wasnâ€™t so bad.â€ He could do it again. If it was necessary. If he needed to. If it kept him alive. Because that did matter, that always mattered.

Peter mattered.

Thatâ€™s what the Dark Lord said.

It was one of the many reasons he was growing tired of his school friends. Especially Remus and Sirius. Listening to them suspect one another. Giving each other credit for his work. At first he had taken it as a compliment, that they didnâ€™t think he would ever turn on them, but he quickly realized that wasnâ€™t what it was. They had simply forgotten to consider him all together. He was a non-factor. Too lowly even to be suspected.

Voldemort, on the other hand, never forgot about Peter. He corresponded with him frequently, smiling whenever Peter came to see him. There had been no more fuck-ups since the travesty at the Ministry two years ago, and that had placed Peter firmly back in the Dark Lordâ€™s good graces. The Dark Lord had even revealed his identity to his more high-ranking followers. Forcing Lucius Malfoy and Rodolphus Lestrange to thank him for his great service. When there were meetings he sat at the head of the table.

It was impossible not to notice him.

Not to see him.

Not to consider him.

Still, it wasnâ€™t actually his intent to give James up to Voldemort. At least not at first. It meant a great deal to him that James had decided to change his mind. To make Peter the Secret Keeperâ€”as he should have been all along honestly. Sirius was far too brash for something like that. Too careless. Peter had always felt he was the obvious choice.

For a while he had become quite devoted to James again, visiting often, delivering whatever it was that he and Lily needed, playing with little baby Harry. Heâ€™d honestly started to reconsider things. Clearly James was coming around, seeing him the way he had when they were kids, before Hogwartsâ€”as someone worthy of his time.

He mattered.

Peter mattered.

But more and more he noticed that all James ever wanted to talk about was the others; Sirius, Remus, Mary, Alice, Frank. It was never questions about Peter. He had come up with dozens of excuses he could use to explain his frequent absences but he never needed them. No one asked where heâ€™d been or what he was up to. No one cared much how he spent his time.

There had been years when he had been James Potterâ€™s closest friend. His only friend, really. They had spent nearly every day together. How could James just forget that? Toss it all aside for Sirius? It wasnâ€™t that Peter didnâ€™t like Sirius. Or Remus. Of course he did. But he didnâ€™t like them more than he liked himself.Â 

James had seen something in him once. Something that had made him leave a room full of people to follow Peter upstairs. Somehow heâ€™d lost sight of that. But Peter was tired of being forgotten. And tired of being afraid. They all thought they knew better than him, but they were on the wrong side. The losing side. And while all of them sunk Peter floated.

Regulus Black left a hole in Voldemortâ€™s ranks. His family name would have made him the obvious choice to be Voldemortâ€™s protÃ©gÃ©. He wouldnâ€™t even have needed to work for it,Â  to prove his worthâ€”it all would have been handed to him. But he bumbled it. He hadnâ€™t figured out what Peter hadâ€”that you get to choose what matters. What means something. You get to choose what is right and what is wrong.

Peter thinks again of the memory of Marleneâ€™s dead body.

It had been right, in the end, that she die.

Right for him anyway.

And now he can take Regulusâ€™s place the same way Sirius has taken hisâ€”thereâ€™s a neat sort of symmetry in that.

So though it took him a few months to decide, he did eventually turn James over to Voldemort. And he expected the same nothing as heâ€™d felt with Marlene. Really this ought to be even easier, since he wouldnâ€™t be there.

And in a way, it was. There was no frettingâ€”well, not much frettingâ€”no tearing out of hair, no crying. Peter simply went about his day like anyone else. And yet. At exactly 8:32 pm on October 31st 1981, Peterâ€™s world dimmed.

He would argue with himself about this for years to come.

Because that was absurd.

The loss of one person could not possibly alter the universe so greatly.

But somehow all colours felt suddenly less vibrant. The food he ate less tasteful. Every piece of music, every summerâ€™s day, every touchâ€”duller.

He was certain he was making it up.

Certain.

But what he could not deny, what he eventually accepted the day his own hand wrapped around his neck, was that no matter how high he rose, how far out of the muck and dust of the war he was able to elevate himself, how close to the top Peter Pettigrew got.

He never did feel the sun again.Â 

Â 

Chapter End Notes

I don't really have the words to describe what writing this story has meant
There is so much of it that is so deeply personal for me and the fact that it has resonated with so many of you is more than I ever could have asked for when I started writing it

So thank you all for sticking around, for your patience and your kindness and for all collectively agreeing that James is so fucking dumb for thinking Remus had a crush on Mary in chapter 2, like bro please get it together

THERE IS STILL AN EPILOGUE it should be posted in the next few days and it'll end us on a bit of a happier note but, yeah, wow, okay, bye I guess????? Yeesh

Hope y'all are having a good day :)

Epilogue

Past the ocean-stream they went, past the white rock, past the portals of the sun and land of dreams, and soon they reached the field of asphodel, where spirits dwell, spectres of worn-out men. Here they came upon the spirit of Achilles, son of Peleus, and of Patroclus too.

Â 

Â 

This is the place where everything and nothing touch and all that we are is set free, spilling over our lines, bleeding out. Memories, thoughts, feelings, no longer contained by the borders of our bodies. Here is where life and death are old friends who meet for tea, and ask after one anotherâ€™s health. Here is where a boy with dark curls and stormy eyes stands in a garden somewhere in Scotland, tall grass tickling his kneecaps as he watches the clouds on the horizon.

His eyes close and he tilts his head up, basking in the light. The sun, usually distant and fadedâ€”a memory and nothing moreâ€”today, is bright and warm, placing gentle kisses on his cheeks, his hair, his shoulders.

â€œOkay I give up, what are you doing?â€

Regulusâ€™s eyes snap open as he spins around. James Potter is leaning against one of the trees behind him, arms crossed over his chest, a smile hanging from the corner of his mouth, the sun glinting off his glasses. The messy haired boy squints up at the sky.

â€œNo stars, so youâ€™re not talking to anyone. Sun tanning maybe? Youâ€™ll have to take off a few more layers for that,â€ he gives Regulus a wink.

â€œWhat?â€

â€œI saidâ€”â€œ

â€œNoâ€”shut upâ€”I heard you.â€
